HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Federated in Surprise Profit; Kmart Net Rises Modestly

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: CINCINNATI, May 18

 BODY:
Federated Department Stores Inc. reported an unexpected quarterly profit of nearly $12 million today, a vast improvement from a loss of more than $64 million a year earlier.
And the Kmart Corporation, the second-biggest American retailer, said its quarterly earnings rose only slightly because bad weather in March and April hurt sales of seasonal goods. 
 Allen I. Questrom, Federated's chairman and chief executive, said, "Although our strong performance in the quarter was due in part to one-time promotional events, results did exceed our expectations."
Following are details of the companies' results:
 
Federated
 The company, based in Cincinnati, said it earned $11.8 million, or 15 cents a share, in its fiscal first quarter, which ended May 2. In the first quarter of 1991, when Federated was in Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization, it lost $64.2 million.
First-quarter sales totaled $1.57 billion, little changed from $1.59 billion a year earlier.
Federated operates 220 department stores under the names of Abraham & Straus, Bloomingdale's, Bon Marche, Burdines, Goldsmith's, Jordan Marsh, Lazarus, Rich's and Stern's.
Mr. Questrom said he expected that for the rest of the year, Federated's results would be closer to the company's target, which assumes the economy will stay soft in the second quarter and recover in the second half.
On the New York Stock Exchange, Federated's shares closed unchanged today at $12.375 each.
 
Kmart
 Kmart said profits for the quarter that ended April 29 rose 8.3 percent, to $116 million, or 26 cents a share, from $107 million, or 27 cents a share, a year earlier. The slight drop in per-share earnings reflected an increase in the number of outstanding shares.
Sales rose 9 percent, to $8.3 billion, from $7.6 billion in the period last year.
Kmart said results were hurt by colder-than-normal spring weather in the Northeast and Midwest, which caused consumers to delay purchases of lawn and garden items, home improvement goods and spring apparel.
Kmart's chairman, Joseph E. Antonini, said in a statement that the weather affected both March and April sales of seasonal items.
"On a brighter note, sales in a number of big-ticket categories, most notably home electronics, continued to improve, strongly indicating that the economic environment continues to strengthen and that the weakness in some of the seasonal categories was weather-related," he said.
Kmart's general merchandise stores earned $251 million in the quarter, up from $242 million a year earlier, while the specialty retail division earned $29 million, against $22 million a year earlier.
The company, based in Troy, Mich., has 2,379 Kmart general merchandise stores in the United States, Puerto Rico and Canada. Its specialty store chains are the Pace Membership Warehouse, Builders Square, Pay Less Drug Stores, Waldenbooks, Sports Authority and Office Max.
 Kmart shares closed down 25 cents yesterday at $46.625 on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off in U.S. Trading; Gold Prices Mostly Lower

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled lower in quiet domestic trading yesterday, under pressure from events overnight in Europe.
Gold prices were mostly lower. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $338.90 a troy ounce, up 20 cents from Friday. The Republic National Bank said gold slipped 10 cents an ounce, to a late bid price of $338.40. 
 Analysts said the dollar's biggest moves occurred overnight in Asian trading. The currency sold on the heels of the surprise wage agreement reached between the powerful IG Metall metal workers' union and employers in Germany.
"That really strengthened the German mark against the dollar," said Andrew Busch, a trader with Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago.
The pay increase is expected to prevent the Bundesbank from easing German interest rates. The dollar fell below the psychologically important level of 1.6040 marks, generating a wave of additional selling. In New York, the dollar ended at 1.5950 German marks, down from 1.6105 late Friday.
An unconfirmed report that Switzerland is ready to begin talks on joining the European Community sent the Swiss franc sharply higher, also at the expense of the dollar. The Swiss Government is expected to make its decision public tomorrow. The dollar dropped to 1.4650 Swiss francs from 1.4855 in New York trading.
After heavy selling in foreign markets, the dollar held to a relatively narrow range when trading shifted to domestic markets, Mr. Busch said.
Interest-rate differentials continue to work against the the dollar. Today's meeting of the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee, which sets monetary policy, is widely expected to result in another downward notch in United States rates, a negative for the dollar.
Lower interest rates make dollar-denominated securities less valuable to investors. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 129.68 yen, down 0.92 yen from Friday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 128.78 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 128.75 yen, down from 129.80 yen on Friday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.8355, from $1.8185 late Friday. In New York, it cost $1.8365 to buy one pound, more expensive than Friday's $1.8220.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's rates, included: 5.3580 French francs, down from 5.4065; 1,201.00 Italian lire, down from 1,212.00, and 1.1987 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2025.

HEADLINE: Japan Trade Surplus Up

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 18

 BODY:
Japan's trade surplus widened last month, climbing to an unadjusted $7.16 billion from $6.31 billion in April 1991, the Finance Ministry said today.
The gap in two-way trade with the United States, Japan's most vocal trade critic, ballooned to an unadjusted $3.29 billion surplus in April from $2.26 billion a year earlier. 
 Over all, customs-cleared exports rose 13 percent, to $27.24 billion from $24.11 billion, while imports lagged slightly, with a 12.8 percent rise to $20.07 billion from $17.79 billion, the ministry said.
"The Japanese Government must tell other nations what it will do to reduce the surplus," said Kusuo Aoki, a senior economist at Yamaichi Research Institute. "Japan has to go to the summit bearing gifts."
He was referring to a meeting scheduled for July in Munich, Germany, of leaders of the seven leading industrialized nations: Japan, the United States, Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada.
Although April's surplus fell from March's record high of $10.99 billion, economists said the decline was only seasonal and represented no change in the upward trend.
Exports increased to $27.24 billion in April from $24.11 billion a year earlier. Imports rose to $20.07 billion from $17.79 billion.
The growth in imports resulted mostly from the lifting of a temporary tax imposed on oil imports from April 1991 to March 1992. The rise did not mean Japan's imports were surging, economists said.

HEADLINE: Patterns

BYLINE: By Woody Hochswender

 BODY:

The New Informality
Lilacs bloomed in Central Park. Roller bladers zoomed down the park drives in sleek aerodynamic outfits, arms tucked close to their bodies.
People packed the theater district for new Broadway shows, tieless and skirtless in acid-washed jeans, sneakers and sweatshirts -- the new informality. 
 The hot new hat, spotted over the weekend everywhere from St. Marks Place to the "Yo, MTV Raps" show, is a long knit cap, like a stocking, tied at the top, sold at 555 Soul on Ludlow Street.
If high-designer looks were nowhere to be seen, it is not from lack of designer activity.
Vivienne Westwood, the first designer in recent years to show high-platform shoes, is bringing her path-finding clothes to New York on Thursday. The show will take place at the Limelight (of course) at 10 P.M.
Junko Koshino, a Japanese designer who shows her clothes on Paris runways, plans to open a "designer gallery" in New York on Wednesday.
Ms. Koshino, who is known for far-out fashions, will use the shop, at 450 Park Avenue between 56th and 57th Streets, to showcase her clothing, accessories and home furnishings. There are dresses made of neoprene, the scuba-diving fabric, with conical busts; spiky black wigs, like the ones Patti LaBelle wears, and square Lucite handbags. The walls are aluminum grill; the floor is slate.
Stephen Sprouse, who returned to the fashion scene designing four camouflage-print outfits for last night's Don't Bungle the Jungle IIrain forest benefit, has plans to get back in business. But he doesn't know how or when.
 
Furriers Not Discouraged
 Like their counterparts in the ready-to-wear business, New York's furriers did not stage big fashion shows during last week's fall openings. The recession has taken its toll on all areas of fashion, particularly the luxury level. But fur manufacturers sounded anything but discouraged.
"Business has been coming back sensationally," said Stanley Schulman, the president of Alixandre Furs, which makes Valentino and Calvin Klein furs. "One reason is that store inventories have bottomed out, just as people with money are beginning to spend again. Those of us remaining in business are doing better."
Mr. Schulman said store orders were up for the first time in three years, despite the fact that many retailers have phased out their fur departments, including Lord & Taylor, I. Magnin in Chicago and Frederick & Nelson in Seattle.
Some furriers, including Mohl, which makes Arnold Scaasi's designs, and Wagner, which makes Oscar de la Renta's, have found greater acceptance in international markets, like Japan, Switzerland and Italy, where the spray-paint can is not an everyday threat.
Another encouraging sign: The use of fur trimmings, on cuffs and collars, was widespread in the recent European collections, although in many instances, the fur was faux.
 
Seeking Peace
 In the wake of the Los Angeles riots, Marithe and Francois Girbaud, the French designers of jeans and other casual wear popular with urban American youth, have introduced an educational program they call the "Peace Movement."
The course includes exercises in self-awareness and communication skills for sixth, seventh and eighth graders, "so they can learn to negotiate and mediate differences without resorting to violence," said a company statement.
The exercises will be presented this month to students and teachers in middle schools in the Greensboro, N.C., area, where the Girbaud manufacturing operations are based.

HEADLINE: Federal Panel Says Simple Steps Could Limit Bedsores

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 18

 BODY:
Bedsores, the painful and potentially dangerous pressure ulcers afflicting thousands of patients in nursing homes and hospitals, could be reduced significantly by relatively simple preventive measures, an expert panel said today.
The panel, convened by the Agency for Health Care Policy and Research to develop new Federal guidelines, said much suffering could be reduced among people confined to beds or wheelchairs if health workers were more aware of the problem and the easy ways available to monitor and prevent bedsores. 
 The leader of the panel, Dr. Nancy Bergstrom, a professor of nursing at the University of Nebraska Medical Center in Omaha, said she wanted to dispel the myth that bedsores were inevitable among those confined to a bed or chair.
 
Avoidable in Most Cases
 "The vast majority of pressure ulcers can be predicted and prevented, and those early ones that do occur need not worsen," Dr. Bergstrom said at a news briefing.
The guidelines called for doctors and nurses to check the skin of immobile and confined patients daily, keep incontinent patients dry, prevent skin dryness by using humidifiers and moisturizing lotion, moving immobile patients regularly, and supporting them with pillows, pieces of foam or special mattress covers designed to reduce pressure.
Bedsores result when skin is squeezed against bony parts of the body, like the heels or hips. Constant pressure squeezes tiny blood vessels that supply the skin with nutrients and oxygen, without which skin tissue dies and an ulcer forms. In severe cases, the tissue damage extends deep into the muscle and bone, sometimes causing serious infections and requiring surgery.
Dr. Bergstrom said it was difficult to determine the true incidence and economic effects of bedsores because the condition often went unreported, particularly with people who are cared for in their homes or at private health centers. One study estimated the annual economic cost at $1.3 billion to $6.4 billion for hospitalized patients alone, she said.
Dr. J. Jarrett Clinton, administrator of the agency, said though there were no exact figures, data from several sources indicated that up to one-third of nursing home patients had bedsores, as did about 10 percent of those in acute-care hospitals.
"If the health care community adopts the pressure ulcer guideline released today, these numbers will come down," Dr. Clinton said. "This is not to say that pressure ulcer prevention is inexpensive. But from all indications, prevention of these injuries is less costly than treatment."
The Agency for Health Care Policy and Research is a unit of the Public Health Service created by Congressional order to develop guidelines for doctors, nurses and other health workers to assure consistent, cost-effective treatment for Americans. The agency sponsors panels of independent experts who draw up recommendations. Before guidelines are completed, they are tested at hospitals and other health centers.
Dr. Bergstrom said the new guidelines covered prevention and treatment of the first and less-severe stage of bedsores. Later guidelines will focus on treating advanced forms of the condition, she said.
Stage-one bedsores are marked by a deep red or purplish coloration on the skin. If a finger is pressed against the area momentarily and then removed, normal skin color does not return and the area remains deep red, Dr. Bergstrom said. This type of bedsore may be difficult to identify in patients with dark skin, the panel said.
The risk of developing bedsores increases with a patient's level of immobility, nutritional deficiencies and in cases where the patient's skin is wet with urine, perspiration or wound drainage, the panel said. People at highest risk include hospitalized quadriplegics and paraplegics, elderly patients with hip fractures, orthopedic patients immobilized by other fractures, and people being treated in critical-care units.
The 13-member panel, which included nurses, doctors, researchers, therapists, educators and a consumer representative, recommended that bedsores be approached as a multidisciplinary problem to be dealt with comprehensively and early by a number of medical specialties before they become more severe.
To assure availability of the pressure ulcer guidelines, they will be distributed to doctors, nurses and other health workers through state and national professional organizations. In addition, a summary of the physicians' guidelines and a special patient's guide are available free by calling 1-800-358-9295 or by writing AHCPR Publications Clearinghouse, P.O. Box 8547, Silver Spring, Md., 20907.


GRAPHIC: Anyone who must stay in bed or in a chair can get pressure ulcers. They form where bone exerts the greatest force on skin and tissue, squeezing them against an outside surface. In bed, most appear on the lower back, shoulder blades, back of head and spine. (Source: Agency for Health Care Policy and Research)

HEADLINE: Environmentalists Accuse U.S. Of Trying to Weaken Global Treaty

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, May 18

 BODY:
As negotiations draw to a close here on an international treaty to slow the world's steady loss of plant, animal and microbial species, the United States is being accused by environmental groups of trying to weaken the agreement due to be signed at the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro next month.
Biologists have warned that unless international action is taken to curb the destruction of species, a mass extinction of epic proportions will result within a few decades. 
 American officials involved in the negotiations said it was possible that the completed version would be unacceptable to the Bush Administration. If so, they said, President Bush will not sign it when he attends the meeting in Brazil with other heads of government.
 
Bush Administration's Objections
 "The chances are only 50-50 that the treaty will have satisfactory language on the issues fundamental to the United States," said E. Curtis Bohlen, Assistant Secretary of State for the environment.
He said the Administration had a wide range of objections, including concerns about provisions that would adversely affect the growing biotechnology industry in the United States.
Representatives of the World Wide Fund for Nature, which is based in Switzerland, and the Washington-based Defenders of Wildlife said the United States delegation was trying to eliminate the requirement that each country adopt regulations to conserve its wildlife and to eliminate procedures to make one nation responsible for insuring that its private companies do not harm the wildlife of other nations.
The groups circulated a memorandum from the office of Vice President Dan Quayle that said the draft treaty was so "extensively flawed" that it was "highly unlikely" the negotiations here would resolve the Administration's concerns.
Delegates from European nations and Japan, as well as most developing countries, have indicated that their heads of government will sign the biodiversity treaty if agreement on its contents is reached here.
The United States agreed this month to sign a climate treaty aimed at limiting emissions of carbon dioxide and other heat-trapping gases that contribute to global warming.
The climate and biodiversity treaties, intended to be binding agreements that would require nations to take conserving actions, are regarded as the most important substantive matters at the Brazil gathering.
At the heart of the discussions here are the measures that nations would be required to take in conserving species, habitats and ecosystems.
The United Nations, whose environmental program is based in this East African capital, has said that without special efforts the world faces a "wave of extinctions unmatched in 60 million years."
"It has been suggested that up to 25 percent of the species now living will become extinct within a single human lifetime," said the executive director of the United Nations Environment Program, Mostafa K. Tolba of Egypt.
The biodiversity treaty draws special attention to the conservation of species in developing countries, where most of the world's biodiversity is found. In the last decade, more than 90 percent of the varieties of wild seeds that have been collected were found in the third world, United Nations ecologists say.
Seeking to help these impoverished countries preserve their ecosystems and wildlife, the treaty includes financial help. This would be done through the Global Environmental Facility, a new mechanism to channel funds for environmental protection from developed countries to poorer ones.
Mr. Bohlen, who is not attending the Nairobi negotiations but talks to the American delegation by phone, said from Washington that the United States had a number of objections to the draft treaty as now formulated.
He said the treaty would force the Federal Government to take the primary responsibility for the conservation of wildlife away from the states. The Government has the responsibility only for endangered and migratory species, Mr. Bohlen said. The Bush Administration objections to the transfer were not the only obstacle: the Senate would never ratify a treaty with such a provision, he said.
Seeking to limit the degradation by wealthy corporations of the oceans and ecosystems in developing countries, the treaty makes nations responsible for the environmental effects of their private companies' activities in other countries. Thus, if an American company wanted to log in an African forest, the United States would be responsible for insuring that an environmental impact assessment was completed.
The two senior members of the Congressional delegation to Rio, Senators Al Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, and John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, wrote to Mr. Bush that they strongly supported the principle that a country should be responsible for actions under its control, whether inside or outside the boundaries of the country.
But Mr. Bohlen said the Administration opposed the provision.
On biotechnology provisions of the treaty, Mr. Bohlen said the United States objected to efforts to regulate the industry. "We believe biotechnology should be addressed separately from biodiversity," he said. He said Washington disliked what it regarded to be a premise in the treaty that all genetically altered organisms were inherently unsafe.
A major issue under the rubric of biotechnology is the ownership of genetic material. Historically, seeds, germ plasm and specimens of individual species have been in the public domain. Anyone could exploit them without compensating the nation of origin.
Thus, the rosy periwinkle, a plant found only in the tropical rain forests of eastern Madagascar, has provided the basis for a drug used to combat childhood leukemia and Hodgkin's disease. Madagascar, a country of widespread hunger and unemployment, has received virtually no compensation for the plant, according to the United Nations.
 
Paying for Genetic Material
 The draft treaty seeks to insure compensation to underdeveloped countries for their genetic materials. Mr. Bohlen said the United States agreed with the principle that such nations should share in the economic benefits, but said the question was how that was to accomplished.
He said the United States was favored the principle of including compensation in the treaty but believed the mechanisms should be arranged by the countries concerned.
And one of the most contentious issues in the treaty between the rich countries of the north and the generally indigent nations of the south is the question of technology transfer. The developing countries are asking for transfers of biotechnology advances on a concessionary basis.
"The United States cannot agree on behalf of a private company to this, and we have a strong commitment to intellectual property rights," Mr. Bohlen said.

HEADLINE: AUTO RACING;
St. James Is Steering Her Own Course to Indy

BYLINE: By JOSEPH SIANO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS, May 18

 BODY:
Lyn St. James will not be taking many telephone calls at her apartment here this week. Each day, she will be sitting in a spare bedroom, wearing a fire-retardant suit and crash helmet, driving in the Indianapolis 500.
America's most famous auto race hasn't moved indoors. It will be run on Sunday, as scheduled, before about 325,000 spectators at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway. 
 St. James is simply using a simulated chassis of a race car -- her own innovation -- in a very precise game of pretend, trying to duplicate the mental and physical demands of the race as she prepares to become only the second woman to drive in the Indy 500.
Auto racing, like horse racing, is one of the very few sports in which women compete against men at the highest level. Ascending to this level has required St. James to overcome conditions more forbidding than any she might be simulating in her preparation for this weekend.
 
A Racer First
 Before last Saturday, when St. James drove a Lola-Chevy for four laps around the two-and-a-half-mile Speedway at an average speed of 220.150 miles an hour, only Janet Guthrie had qualified to enter a bastion so alien to women that she had to leave the garage area wearing her driver's suit and mingle with spectators when she needed a restroom.
That particular situation has changed, and so has the pioneering atmosphere that defined Guthrie when she competed in the race from 1977-79. St. James, 45 years old, of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., insists that she sees herself as racer first, with the groundbreaker role several laps behind.
"This is for me," she said. "This is a goal that I've had in meeting a career objective. It's a personally driven thing that I know could have ancillary benefits to it, but which I can't control."
In order for more women to ascend to the highest level of this sport, they will first have to master another sport, that of acquiring corporate sponsors.
St. James had to approach about 150 companies before she found two -- JC Penney and Agency Rent-a-Car -- willing to provide the minimum of $500,000 total to bankroll her effort here. Although St. James has been enterprising enough to turn her singularity in a male-dominated sport on its head by approaching companies that sell products to women, she has been turned down by, among others, major cosmetics companies.
But St. James demurs from blaming sexism for the paucity of female drivers here.
"If you knew how many licensed professional race drivers there are and how hard it is to get here," she said, "the odds are so much against you that in the big picture, the gender issue is such a small thing."
Guthrie, who retired from top-level racing in 1980, agrees, to an extent, that difficulty in getting sponsorship in a weak economy is an equal-opportunity impediment.
"But I must point out that the starting fields at major races remain full," Guthrie said last week, "and they are full of sponsored male drivers."
 
Sport of Individuals
 And some of them, she noted, promote laundry detergent and other products bought largely by women.
The difficulty in making inroads stems more from the fact that auto racing, unlike major professional team sports, does not have an organized, talent-based system of advancement from grass-roots to the elite level. It is a sport of individuals, who forge their way through the corporate structure in a search for ever-higher amounts of sponsorship money -- up into the millions of dollars necessary for a full season of Indianapolis-car racing. St. James describes with delight her first meeting with the three decision-makers from Penney. They were all women and it didn't hurt, she adds, that one drove a Porsche and another a Jaguar.
What has eased St. James's path to Indy is the fact that she is the most experienced female racer in this country, and very likely the world. Besides beating men in a highly competitive professional sports-car series in the 1980's, she has extensive experience racing at the 225-m.p.h. speeds the cars are expected to reach here on Sunday.
Dick Simon, who owns St. James's car and was a co-driver, on the same team as Guthrie, said St. James had the respect of her male competitors.
"At this time, she is a race driver," Simon said before she qualified, "and I think you can witness that when the drivers drive up alongside of her or enter the corner with her, they're not gun-shy at all. They pull right up alongside of her and they have all the respect in the world."
 
Decade of Preparation
 Getting that kind of respect from the men who drive these cars is hard. They have the demeanor of fighter pilots, which helps when your car is exceeding the take-off speed of a commercial jet. One twitch of the steering wheel by a rookie, as St. James is here, can get a veteran into a crash.
"Everything I've done in the last 10 or 12 years professionally has been in preparation for this," said St. James.
She was speaking of her on-track experience, which includes being on the winning team of drivers in the 1987 24-hour race at Daytona and being victorious in a sports-car series that is one of the key training grounds for promising young drivers.
St. James and Simon, who has been her mentor through her effort at Indy, believe that if she drives her best on Sunday, and the car has no mechanical problems, she can finish in the top 10 in the 33-car field. Based on last year's race, the smallest amount of money she can expect to win is about $125,000.
But more fundamental preparations occurred long before she learned her first racing lesson in the mid-1970's by losing control of a Pinto and driving it into a lake.
 
From the Secretarial Pool
 One of the people St. James can thank for her business education is the man who was the personnel director at a major steelmaker's offices in Cleveland, where St. James had one of her first jobs, as a secretary.
He took one look at a letter of resignation from St. James, who felt powerless against the company's rigid promotion system, and told her: "Secretaries don't write letters of resignation, they just quit."
She can also thank an all-girls school in her birthplace of Willoughby, Ohio, a school that filled her head with a revolutionary concept for the early 1960's: self-reliance (and led her to hang around with "car-crazy" boys in search of some male friends).
In a way, credit also should go to her frustration at being thought of simply as the wife of her business partner, frustration that led her to change her married name from Caruso one night after watching the actress Susan Saint James in the television series "McMillan and Wife."
These experiences all helped forge the businesswoman who would build her own auto-parts company, become a consumer adviser for Ford Motor Company and create a lucrative career teaching women how to walk into a car showroom or service department and speak the automotive language.
 
The 1960's and Muscle Cars
 The last six years of St. James's formal education took place at the Andrews School for Girls, on a 300-acre campus in Willoughby, a middle-class suburb of Cleveland a few miles from Lake Erie.
"Maybe because of going to an all-girls school and having no brothers, as a balancing effect, I had boys as my friends outside school," St. James said. "And this was in the 1960's, so they were all into muscle cars."
They were also into auto racing, and took her to the Indy 500, sparking her interest in racing.
Andrews, meanwhile, was teaching her something else -- as it has with all its students since it opened, one year before the first Indianapolis 500.
"Andrews was founded in 1910 as a school to make young women independent, which in 1910 wasn't such a popular idea," said Barbara Caseau, who has taught there for 33 years.
Caseau remembers St. James as one of her ninth-grade students. "It was sort of her excitement," said Caseau, "and the spirit that she had to go for what she wanted, even as a kid. Not in an aggressive way at all, but more like 'I know I can do this, and if I can't do it this way, I'll do it this way.' And that has certainly borne out in her life."
 
'Power of the Individual'
 Last June, St. James gave the commencement speech at Andrews, and the 23 graduates heard her describe how racing had provided gasoline-powered assertiveness training.
"It wasn't until I drove that first race car that I realized the power of the individual," St. James said.
It was only a Pinto, a vague ancestor to the 750-horsepower car she now races, but the feelings are likely to be the same when she sits on the starting grid Sunday and hears the command (which now might be changed) of "Gentlemen, start your engines."
"All of a sudden I felt powerful," she told the graduates. "I felt like I had never felt doing anything else."

HEADLINE: Fight Haiti's Thugs With Oil

 BODY:
Seven months of economic pressure from the Organization of American States have failed to budge the thugs who hijacked Haiti's infant democracy last fall. Negotiations are stalemated -- yet the crisis of repression boils ever hotter. Recent weeks have seen ever-more desperate refugees again fleeing in flimsy boats.
Sunday the O.A.S. rightly decided to tighten the economic screws. Ships that trade with Haiti will be turned back from ports in O.A.S.-member nations. Supporters of the outlaw regime will be denied visas. And European countries will be urged to suspend trade. 
 Sound steps all, but by themselves insufficient. The partial embargo so far has failed because it left the ruling gang time to find loopholes. The biggest loophole has been the European Community, and the key commodity has been oil.
The most plausible path to democracy is a complete cutoff of oil imports. The most likely way to achieve that is for the Bush Administration to lean on its European allies.
Last fall, when oil was scarce for a few weeks, the diplomatic process came alive. But after a few tankers unloaded, the military leaders dug in again. The latest compromise, negotiated in Washington early this year, lost any chance of parliamentary approval after hard-liners intimidated legislators in Port-au-Prince. Yet there's reason to believe some military leaders would accept compromise under credible pressure.
The renewed interest of other countries in Haiti's crisis may well be prompted by the increased refugee traffic. The Bush Administration's policies, in particular, seem to have been driven, shamefully, by fear of reaction to admitting thousands of poor Haitians to Florida. For months, those fears led Washington to understate the repression in Haiti -- and to assert the right to repatriate Haitians forcibly.
The Administration has won judicial support for that claim and acted on it. Even so, Haiti's poor continue to set sail, in ever-larger numbers. Increasingly, it seems evident that the only way to stem the tide is to achieve a fair political settlement in Haiti, one that encourages people to stay in their homeland. Only increased economic pressure is likely to bring such a settlement.
The United States can do much to make the embargo more effective by monitoring Haiti's ports and urging European allies to cooperate. If that isn't enough, a future O.A.S. meeting could be called on to impose a naval blockade. Such a blockade would be an act of war, but one that poses scant risk of wider conflict. Such a measure lacks firm precedent in international law, but the O.A.S. is entitled to defend democracy against violent and illegal challenges.
No hemispheric policy can guarantee that freedom and civilian rule are restored to Haiti. But the hemisphere's democracies do right to stand up for principle. They serve Haitians as well as themselves by trying to promote alternatives to the continuing tragedy of poor people in such despair they would rather set sail in matchstick boats than risk the political tides on land at home.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Mr. Bush's Political Environment

 BODY:
The "Environment President" now seems mainly interested in becoming the "Re-elected President." Twice in one week, on the issues of air pollution and forests, the Bush Administration has handed down rulings that sacrifice long-term environmental concerns to short-term commercial and political interests.
And perversely, in both instances, the Administration, even while enraging environmentalists, offers false promises to the interests whose favor it wishes to curry in this election year. 
 The most recent example is last week's decision by Vice President Quayle and the Council on Competitiveness to allow companies to increase pollution emissions without public hearings. Mr. Quayle argued that public reviews might delay changes in manufacturing processes to improve efficiency and competitiveness.
Nevertheless, the ruling is an empty promise. The Clean Air Act -- which Mr. Bush hails as his major environmental achievement -- explicitly requires "public comment." The ruling is therefore likely to invite lawsuits that could deny industry the flexibility Mr. Quayle seeks. The ruling also runs counter to some state regulations requiring public review, inviting bitter legal battle.
Finally, it embarrasses the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, William Reilly, whose plan to give industry some leeway within the spirit of the law was rejected.
It was not one of Mr. Reilly's better weeks. Just as he was losing on the pollution issue, a Cabinet-level committee chaired by Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan voted to override both Mr. Reilly and the Endangered Species Act and permit logging on 1,700 acres of Federal land in Oregon that is home to the threatened northern spotted owl. The 1,700 acres don't amount to much, either to the owl or the loggers. At the same time, however, Mr. Lujan also announced a broader "preservation plan" setting aside about 2.8 million acres for the spotted owl -- about half the acreage mandated by the Endangered Species Act and the courts. Mr. Lujan said his plan would save half the 32,000 jobs that would otherwise be lost.
Again, false promises, both to the owl and the loggers. Mr. Lujan's own biologists say the owl can't survive on less than five million acres. Nor will all that many jobs be "saved" by cutting the owl's habitat in half. There will be a short-run saving. But loggers are already fighting relentless market forces. Automation and industry's shift to the Southeast have cost more jobs than the owl.
And when Mr. Lujan's vulnerable acreage is gone, more logging jobs will also disappear. Neither do his calculations include the jobs that will be lost in other industries if heavy logging continues -- in tourism, for example, and salmon fishing, which depends on streams undamaged by over-cutting.
There are two bills in the House that would put more than six million acres off limits to logging. That's probably enough to save the owl, fishing and tourism. Both bills also seek to cushion the economic hardship in local communities.
Neither bill is perfect; yet both seek to demonstrate a just balance between economic needs and the environment. Whether the issue is clean air and jobs, or forests and jobs, the Bush Administration has so far produced an unwise balance.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Straight In the Eye

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Once and only once, I knew a national leader who told the truth to his people about the most important things in their lives -- themselves.
This man told them that they were superstitious and slovenly. He denounced their religion, customs, manners, furies and hatreds. He told them that sometimes they were so dense that they drove him mad. 
 Jawaharlal Nehru was not a great all-round leader. His foreign policy for India was a mess of platitudes and self-delusion.
About economics, Chakravarti Rajagopalachari, the first Indian Governor General of India, called Nehru a woolly-headed Socialist idiot. Looking back that strikes me as a little harsh but certainly in the ball park.
But how Nehru could lay about him when he felt his own people were leading themselves deeper into darkness through bigotry, casteism, violence or calcification of mind!
I wonder whether the United States will ever produce a Presidential candidate who will give us the gift of truth about ourselves.
What we have been getting from our candidates is mostly pure smarm. They allow us to blame everybody else and comfortingly lead our little minds away from our own contributions to bigotry, casteism, violence and calcification. We get the message that with a little economic higgledy-piggledy, never really explained, the country can solve its troubles without pain -- otherwise known as higher taxes, more schoolwork and no excuses.
No excuses means none from those who riot and loot, none from the preachers of bigotry and those who prettify them, none from dropouts, none from politicians. And none from voters who destroy any politician who is brave enough to tell us the bill will be high, with payments starting now.
Who will face the country straight? Who will look it in the eye?
President Bush? His campaign has become one long dreary attempt to rationalize or deny his failures.
Bill Clinton -- what's happened there anyway? Presented by Los Angeles with an opportunity for inspiring the country, he is fumbling it. He still has time to roll up the political safety net he lugs around and take more chances with candor, but not a lot of time. He is losing the country's attention.
Will Ross Perot have the courage to talk straight, or will we just get a lot more down-home one-liners? So far, he has presented the country with a blank tablet. That worked for a while because millions of Americans wrote their own hopes on it. And about Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton, he follows an old safe policy: never interrupt your opponents while they are making fools of themselves.
But he says soon he will show us his mind. If so, that will reveal whether he is capable of the hard intellectualism, the discipline, required for telling us the truths about ourselves and our problems.
If he thinks the country has to work harder, then how will he provide the jobs for those who want nothing but the chance to work?
Does he think the jobs can be created and the neglect of the cities rectified without more taxes? Then he has to show us the balance sheet any businessman would demand before investing money or trust in any investment salesman.
And although during campaigns candidates pretend foreign affairs are no great deal now, if he wins he will be neck deep in them the day after election.
So let's have a rundown on what he will do about starvation in Africa, aid to the former Soviet Union, the worldwide Communist Chinese missile trade and Saddam Hussein, happy, fat and born again.
President Perot -- it's a massive rebuke to the Messrs. Bush and Clinton that so many Americans like the idea and so few now dismiss it. And it is a compliment that he now should show he deserves. The only way is to say what he would demand of himself and the American public.
Many Americans, perhaps more as time goes on, will still want something he will find hard to deliver -- evidence that he could run a government and understand the delicate, essential balances that make it a democracy, not a horse.
But win, place or show, Ross Perot if he is brave enough can certainly do one thing. He can talk straight to the public and himself. That could help the country look itself in the eye, the essential price of starting to recover from Los Angeles.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: China's Rights Abuses Reflect a Bitter History

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"China Is Reported to Plan Release of Some Political Prisoners Soon" (news article, May 6) discussed photographs, provided by the Chinese Government, of Wang Juntao and Chen Ziming, two leading pro-democracy activists. The photos were given to John T. Kamm, an American businessman who serves as a conduit for information that Beijing releases to the West. Given the previous official disinformation provided on the status of these two men, the photos, which suggest that Mr. Wang and Mr. Chen are in good health, are highly suspect.
Wang Juntao and Chen Ziming, founders of the Beijing Economic and Social Sciences Research Institute, an unofficial think tank, were branded by Beijing as the two "masterminds" of the 1989 democracy movement. Arrested after the violence in Tiananmen Square on June 4, 1989, they were held for more than a year without charges, rushed to trial when world attention was focused on the Persian Gulf and quickly sentenced to 13 years' imprisonment. 
 After his conviction, Mr. Wang, who was seriously ill with hepatitis B, was kept in punitive solitary confinement in Beijing No. 2 Prison. He was held in a tiny, airless cell, with an overflowing toilet and a wooden mattress infested by vermin. Mr. Chen was locked up in similar conditions. Mr. Wang's numerous requests for medical care were denied by prison authorities.
Last August both Mr. Wang and Mr. Chen went on hunger strikes to protest their mistreatment. At the time the Justice Ministry firmly asserted that both men were eating well and gaining weight. To undercut a wave of international concern, Beijing went so far as to release television footage allegedly showing a healthy-looking Mr. Wang. Only after international pressure continued did the authorities finally move Mr. Wang to a prison hospital and acknowledge that he was suffering from hepatitis.
The timing of the release of these new photographs is hardly surprising. It is part of a pattern that has emerged as the Chinese Government has been forced to deal with growing human rights criticism. To defuse criticism as important dates on China's "human rights calendar" approach, the authorities issue incredible accounts of prisoners that cannot be verified.
One month earlier Mr. Kamm was quoted in your April 8 news article relaying the official account that China's most famous imprisoned dissident, Wei Jingsheng, was living well in his 13th year of solitary confinement -- watching television, reading several daily newspapers and debating with his guards. This contradicts all previous reports, including one in The Times, which have stated that Mr. Wei may be suffering from schizophrenia, has lost all his teeth and is in general poor health.
Beijing maintains a vast prison system that physically and mentally tortures large numbers of prisoners, including democracy activists. Wei Jingsheng's abuse in solitary confinement is bitter history. That two brilliant men like Wang Juntao and Chen Ziming are facing the same fate is tragic. They stand as symbols of China's gross abuse of human rights.
 
ROBERT L. BERNSTEIN
New York, May 12, 1992
 
The writer, chairman of Human Rights Watch, is co-chairman of the Committee to End the Chinese Gulag.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

COUNTRY: CHINA (98%); UNITED STATES (92%);

HEADLINE: For 100 Years, 'Forever Wild' and Forever in Dispute;
The Adirondack Park Remains the Focus of a Clash Between Preservation and Commerce

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BLUE MOUNTAIN LAKE, N.Y.

 BODY:
A hundred years ago, after vast timber cuts had denuded sections of the majestic Adirondack forest and turned rivers brown with silt, the Legislature stepped in. The Adirondack Park was created, with parts to be "forever wild," a preserve of mountains, lakes and woods.
This week the park, the largest in the country outside of Alaska, marks its centennial. But the clash between commerce and preservation has not ended: instead of lumberjacks, developers are pushing at the edges of the wilderness. 
 The fierceness of the struggle is rooted in the unusual nature of the Adirondack Park. It is home not just to dozens of spectacular peaks and 31,000 miles of rivers and streams, but to 130,000 people, living in hamlets scattered through the mountains, where several Adirondack counties are routinely at the top of the state's list for unemployment and poverty rates.
A panel appointed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, warning of a "last clear chance" to preserve the wilderness character of the region, has recommended a sweeping package of new zoning laws and conservation incentives to curb development on the private land within the park, where there has been a 43 percent increase in the number of homes in the last two decades. But for more than two years, the state Legislature has failed to act on any of the 245 recommendations.
 
Years of Talk, No Action
 And though many local officials contend that the gravest threat is not to the wilderness but to hard-pressed residents, various proposals to help the region's perennially battered economy have foundered as well.
The result is that for all the fervent debate in recent years, virtually nothing has been done in that time to help either the Adirondacks or the Adirondackers, environmentalists and the local officials agree.
The lack of action has serious consequences even beyond the 6-million-acre park, because a legislative blueprint for the Adirondacks was widely expected to serve as a national model of long-range planning to insure that both vast pockets of wilderness and the villages among them could thrive.
The fact that the Adirondack Park is a patchwork of public wilderness, timber tracts and private land makes its future a more nettlesome question in many ways than the issue of how to protect places like Yellowstone, Grand Canyon, Glacier and Olympic National Parks -- all of which, taken together, are smaller than Adirondack Park alone.
"A national park is, almost by definition, a place where few people actually live," said Peter A. A. Berle, the president of National Audubon Society, who also served as chairman of the Governor's Adirondacks commission.
"In the Adirondacks," he added, we're talking about a park that involves both people and wild space, both hamlets and open space. That's the difference. And that's also why any solutions there will apply much more broadly."
The Adirondacks are still a place of spectacular natural beauty, of high-peaks wilderness and clear mountain lakes. And while some of the vistas are not so lofty as those in parts of the western United States, the Adirondacks remain a remarkably accessible place, where the forests do more than beckon. There are hundreds of trails just off the main roads in the park, where a hiker needs all of three minutes before being completely immersed in the woods.
By some measures, the park is in better shape than it was a century ago. About 87 percent of the land is covered by forests, a much higher percentage than in 1892, when the logging caused floods as far away as Albany.
But other pressures that would have seemed remote back then are now looming over the park, and these were the basis of the report by the Governor's commission, which was formed in 1988 in the wake of widespread concern about sales of more than 100,000 acres of land to second-home developers.
The number of single-family homes in the Adirondacks climbed from 50,000 in the late 1960's to 70,000 in the late 1980's, according to figures provided by the Adirondack Park Agency, the state body that administers existing land-use regulations in the park.
The number of seasonal residents in the park is estimated at 250,000.
And those statistics do not include units in several condominium developments built around Lake George and Lake Placid and in the Gore Mountain ski area near North Creek.
 
Clear Lakes Now Less So
 Much of the construction is in lakefront areas, and in recent years several large lakes -- including Lake George and Saranac Lake -- have been plagued by algae blooms and other deterioration traced to septic systems and other human activity.
And despite what was widely seen as a landmark set of land-use regulations adopted in the early 1970's, which increased the number of acres needed per house in most parts of the park, some state officials charged with preserving the wilderness say those laws will be insufficient to guard against a new real-estate boom when the recession lifts.
Robert C. Glennon, the executive director of the Adirondack Park Agency, noted that even with all the regulations in place, up to 400,000 houses could legally be built in the region.
"The scheme of the present statute guarantees the ultimate destruction of the Adirondack Park, and anoints us to preside over it," said Mr. Glennon. "It's that simple."
But critics of stricter regulation dismiss such concerns as hyperbole. "We have always questioned the underlying premise of the commission report, that there's a development crisis," said Frederick H. Monroe, a town supervisor in Chester, which is within the park. "There isn't a crisis. We don't see the need for drastic changes."
An unwieldy collection of organizations, 18 by one recent count, have sprouted that all purport to speak for Adirondackers inside the park. There is an Adirondack Fairness Coalition, a Residents' Committee to Protect the Adirondacks, an Adirondack Solidarity Alliance.
 
A Certain Ambivalcence
 Much attention has been given to protesters at either extreme of the debate -- a radical environmentalist who said the solution was to move people out of the park altogether, an irate landowner who warned that new government regulators would come out of the park "in body bags." But many Adirondack residents seem more ambivalent about the future.
Hayden C. Tormey, who lives in the same brown-shingle house in the village of Onchiota where he was born 69 years ago, was an Adirondack guide who took tourists into the woods for 40 years before arthritis sidelined him.
He now hand-carves wooden loons and ducks to make a modest living, and, like many of the independent-minded people who live in the park, he says he does not exactly take kindly to the government. And some things in the Adirondack commission's report -- such as listing appropriate colors for the roofs of houses in the park -- irked him a great deal.
But, he added, when he decided to give up some family land on Lake Kushaqua several few years ago, he turned down offers from a developer and sold it to the state instead, at a lower price. "I wanted it to last," Mr. Tormey explained. " 'Forever wild,' like it says. In my mind anyway, that was the idea."
The official centennial celebration here will feature an address by Governor Cuomo, followed by a summer of activities ranging from workshops on how to make the classic Adirondack guide boat to a historical lecture on Adirondack diners.
 
Search for Common Ground
 There is also a traveling exhibition of photographs by Seneca Ray Stoddard, a bearded adventurer who in 1892 came to Albany, unpacked his easels and lanterns before curious lawmakers in the Capitol, and left many of them gaping at his glass-plate photographs of the Adirondack wilderness. That was the final push that led to creation of the park.
But this time around, there appears to be no Seneca Ray Stoddard on the horizon, and certainly no legislative consensus.
Last week the Democratic-led Assembly offered a package of regulations less stringent than those proposed by the Governor's panel, known as the Commission on the Adirondacks in the 21st Century. But leaders of the Republican-controlled State Senate, reflecting local concerns about the region's perennially battered economy, declared that plan "dead on arrival."
The Republicans said they would push instead for bills to abolish the Adirondack Park Agency, and to provide village governments with more money for housing, roads and infrastructure repairs. And Mr. Cuomo, who rejected some of the commission ideas as too radical and has vowed to forge a compromise, is expected to offer his own bills.
In any event, just about everybody involved with the issue, both in and out of the park, says that change is needed. "No interest group agrees that the status quo is a preferable position for the Adirondacks," said Thomas C. Jorling, the state's Environmental Conservation Commissioner. "The key to this generation making its mark on this legacy is finding the common ground."

History
Created by an act of the Legislature May 20, 1892. The word "Adirondack" is generally believed to be derived from an Iroquois expression meaning "those who eat bark."
 
Geography
Originally 2.8 million acres; with additions over the years, there are now nearly 6 million acres, of which 42 percent is state-owned forest preserve designated "forever wild" under the state Constitution. Largest park in the continental United States. Encompasses one-fifth of New York State and is roughly equivalent in size to Vermont. Twelve counties are either fully or partly within the park's boundary.
 
Topography
31,000 miles of rivers and streams; 2,759 lakes and ponds. Roughly 87 percent of the park is forest land, a higher percentage than in 1892. There are 42 peaks higher than 4,000 feet, most of them in the northeast part of the park, including Mount Marcy, the highest point in New York State at 5,344 feet.
 
Population
130,000 year-round residents in 105 communities; about 250,000 seasonal residents.

HEADLINE: Dropout Rate Down Sharply for New York Schools

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
New York City yesterday reported a significant decline in the number of students dropping out of high school, putting it ahead of other major cities that have also noted such declines.
Board of Education officials claimed credit for the change, saying years of hounding truants and pressing students to complete their required courses were finally paying off. But they acknowledged that a sluggish economy, with diminished job prospects, might be partly responsible for the improvement. 
 The city's new survey showed that slightly more than 17 percent of the 70,510 students who started the ninth grade in the 1987-88 school year had dropped out four years later -- two full percentage points better than the rate achieved by the previous ninth-grade class, or a 10 percent overall improvement. The proportion of those who graduated also improved, rising 1.2 percentage points to 38.9 percent.
It was the best showing in the six years since New York City began a more precise system of tracking entering high school freshmen throughout their school careers and it clearly buoyed Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez, who took over the system two and a half years ago.
In that time, Mr. Fernandez has overhauled the city's dropout program developed by his predecessors, pushing for stronger links between troubled high schools and neighborhood and counseling organizations that work with students deemed prone to drop out. Since he came into office, the four-year dropout rate has been reduced from 20.8 percent, to 17.2 percent.
As rosy as the citywide totals were, they belie the fact that some individual schools are still failing to hold onto their students. The seven-year dropout rate of the class scheduled for graduation in 1988 stood at 47.7 percent in George Washington High School in Manhattan, 43.8 percent at Monroe in the Bronx, 52.4 percent at Thomas Jefferson in Brooklyn, and 34.8 percent at Franklin Lane in Queens.
The dropout rate, one of the most closely watched indicators of school performance, has shown improvement in cities across the nation. Roughly two-thirds of the nation's cities have reported declines in their dropout rates, said Michael Casserly, executive director of the Council of Great City Schools, an organization of urban school superintendents.
Far Rockaway High School in Queens, one of many schools that saw a sharp decline in dropouts, has a machine that telephones parents in the evenings and informs them through a recorded message that their youngsters were absent that day. Two staff members pay regular visits to truants' homes.
The school has also broken up its student body of 1,700 into seven "houses" arranged by career subjects, finding that diminishing a large high schools' anonymity makes it easier to form relations with students who might otherwise grow disenchanted with school.
 
National Comparisons
 New York City students fared particularly well in national comparisons, which are done by simply recording the percentage of students who drop out in a given year. Only 6.80 percent of students dropped out of the school system in the 1990-91 school year, one of the lowest figures of any major city.
By contrast, annual dropout rates in Chicago were 13.2 percent; in Los Angeles, 16 percent; in Houston, 9.4 percent, and in Philaldelphia, 8.4 percent. Figures for Houston and Los Angeles were based on the 1989-90 school year.
The annual New York statistics demonstrate anew that students are choosing to stay in school five, six and even seven years to complete their high school education. In the class originally supposed to graduate in June 1991, 38.9 percent of the 70,510 students did so on time, but 27.8 percent enrolled for a fifth year.
 
Reading Problems
 Monitoring of an earlier group of ninth graders -- the one that was supposed to graduate in June 1988 -- shows that by 1991 57.3 percent did in fact graduate and 27.5 percent dropped out. The graduation figure included both those who graduated with regular diplomas and the small proportion who obtained equivalency diplomas. The seven-year graduation rate has remained fairly constant, though Mr. Fernandez predicted that future classes would start to reflect the impact of his innovations.
School officials did not interview any of the 12,111 dropouts from the ninth-grade class of 1987-88 to find out why they left school. But statistical studies show that as freshmen, 70 percent were over age for their grade and had probably been left back in elementary school or junior high school. Almost half had bounced around two or more schools.
Only 30 percent could read at the level considered appropriate for their grade. Less than 30 percent had passed the required ninth-grade Regents Competency Test in mathematics, a daunting hurdle that seemed to have discouraged most of the dropouts. Many students, the report's authors said, also failed to accumulate enough credits to make graduation likely and dropped out in defeat.
Analayzing the findings in ethnic terms, the study said Asian-American students followed for four years had the lowest dropout rate -- 9.7 percent. The dropout rates for non-Hispanic whites was 11.6 percent; for non-Hispanic blacks, 17.9 percent, and for Hispanic students, 22.5 percent. Boys were slightly more likely to drop out than girls, though the report did not speculate why.
Those not counted as dropouts, graduates or currently enrolled students are youngsters who chose to transfer either to private and parochial schools or to public school systems outside the city. The board does not keep track of such students once they have left, said Robin Willner, the Board of Education's research director. But officials assume that the pattern of graduating and dropping out mirrors the rest of the city's population. About 16 percent of the freshman class of 1987-88 were in that category.
 
Impact of Economy
 Some educators believe that a sluggish economy with fewer job openings may be prompting more students to stay in school. Others theorize that the economy cuts both ways and that children of out-of-work parents may be pressured to quit school and seek work. Still others, like Dr. Diane Ravitch, the assistant United States Secretary of Education for research, believe that school-age youngsters are learning that, recession or not, "there are not many good jobs for uneducated people."
In announcing the results of the survey, Mr. Fernandez took pains to cite some of the programs he has pioneered, particularly his overhaul of an expensive dropout program started by his predecessors that had been described as a costly failure in an evaluation by a professor at Teachers College at Columbia University.
The Chancellor also took the occasion to point out that the members of last year's graduating class were still the beneficiaries of the more generous budgets of ther 1980's, before the current round of budget cuts.
The Board of Education's dropout figures have long been the subject of controversy. Before 1986, the four-year figures were mathematical extrapolations based on the annual dropout rate, and some observers felt that they were subject to manipulation for public consumption. In 1986, the board began actually tracking all ninth graders and following these "cohorts" to their expected graduation date and three years beyond.

HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENT LAWS ARE EASED BY BUSH AS ELECTION NEARS

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19

 BODY:
As the recession hangs on and the election nears, the Bush Administration has followed a pattern of altering environmental laws and regulations to open more Federal land and the nation's natural resources to development, top Administration officials say.
The pattern emerged last summer, when the White House proposed eliminating restrictions on building and development on half the nation's wetlands. Since then the Administration has fostered a flurry of new proposals to make more of the nation's coal, timber, oil, water and land available to industry and agriculture. 
 Administration officials say the effort to open natural resources has been aided by President Bush's four-month-old regulatory moratorium in which existing environmental rules are under review and others are being rewritten to reduce their cost to business.
 
Philosophy and Politics
 Together, the two policies represent the strongest effort to reduce environmental restrictions since the early days of the Reagan Administration, White House officials and critics of the President say.
In public statements and private conversation, Bush Administration officials say the pattern reflects both the philosophical effect of the President's Council on Competitiveness, which is headed by Vice President Dan Quayle, and concern over carrying Western states in the election this fall.
The general thrust of both forces has been to shift the balance toward economic concerns instead of the conservationism favored by the main environmental groups.
"The President has always been in favor of protecting the environment in a way that is compatible with growth," David M. McIntosh, the executive director of the President's Council on Competitiveness, said Monday. "What you are seeing is a series of decisions that focused on the economic growth side of the balance. Perhaps what is going on is a shift in emphasis."
Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. said anti-environmental sentiment among some Western voters also played a role. In the Reagan years these sentiments fueled a movement called the "sagebrush rebellion," which put pressure on the Interior Department to open more Federal land for mining, grazing and logging.
Secretary Lujan has alerted the White House that members of the old rebellion have joined with private landowners, the timber industry, coal companies and others who rely on natural resources to form a new coalition that calls itself the "wise use" movement.
 
Conservative Constituency
 Mr. Lujan says the Administration should address the movement's agenda to improve its standing with its natural conservative constituency and should not worry so much about sentiment of environmentalists who, he believes, will not support Mr. Bush under any circumstances.
"I have never seen a positive reaction from environmental groups no matter what we do," the Secretary said. "I don't ever expect a positive reaction."
In an interview Saturday, Mr. Lujan, who served from 1969 to 1989 as a Congressman from New Mexico, said he was bringing "the plight of the Western constituency to the White House," and added: "People who live in the West look at the land in a different way than people east of the Mississippi River. Land is our heritage to use and not just lock up and put away, where only backpackers can go. I have been telling the White House staff that our constituency, the conservative Republican constituency, is not pleased at being ignored."
A number of officials agree with Mr. Lujan that the White House is driven by fears that the traditional Republican Party support in the eight Rocky Mountain states, which have a total of 40 electoral votes, is eroding. The White House is also following a plan devised by Senator Slade Gorton, a Republican from Washington state, to recapture Oregon and Washington, the only two Western states Mr. Bush lost in the 1988 election.
Thus, the President's strategy is meant to shore up support among the timber, mining, coal and agricultural groups that anchor the "wise use" movement. Leaders of the movement are pressing for a loosening of policies that they see as brakes on the economy. They also want to protect jobs and families by providing resources that some of the nation's largest industries need to operate.
Last week, in the clearest signs yet that Mr. Bush is taking account of industrial interests in weighing environmental protections, a Cabinet-level committee voted to exempt the Government from the Endangered Species Act and allow the cutting of 1,700 acres of forest in Oregon that provide habitat for the threatened northern spotted owl. Secretary Lujan also proposed legislation that, if approved, would rewrite the basis of the Endangered Species Act by introducing economic considerations, like the loss of jobs, when deciding if a rare species deserved Federal protection.
 
Air Pollution Curbs Relaxed
 The President also decided last week to allow companies to increase toxic air pollution above levels authorized on their operating permits without notifying the public. William K. Reilly, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, had argued for months that the Clean Air Act of 1990 required such increases to be subject to public review. In taking the action, Mr. Bush sided with his Vice President, who said that long public reviews would delay worthwhile changes in manufacturing and might cause companies to move their plants overseas.
Environmental leaders in Congress said they would fight the Administration's actions. Representative Henry A. Waxman, a California Democrat who is a co-author of the Clean Air Act, has filed a lawsuit contending that the President's decision to allow companies to increase emissions of pollution without notifying the public was "a knowingly illegal act."
Mr. Waxman, who is chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Health and the Environment, has scheduled a hearing on the issue, to be held Friday. "This is extremely troubling," he said in a statement Sunday about Mr. Bush's decision. "The notion that the President cannot change the law on his own, regardless of what big business wants, is basic to our democratic process."
Other actions the White House has taken to ease environmental restrictions and open resources to industry have been made quietly. They include new rules at the Interior Department and the Agriculture Department to eliminate the ability of the public to appeal and block timber harvests, mining, oil drilling, grazing and other uses of public land.
The Interior Department has also proposed a separate rule to make it easier for coal companies to strip mine Federal forest land in the East and grazing land in the West. And as the centerpiece of the President's energy policy, the White House wants to open the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska to oil exploration.
Privately, some influential Administration officials agree with their critics that the new policy directives are a sharp departure from Mr. Bush's first year in office, when he proclaimed himself the "environmental President" and appointed Mr. Reilly, a leading conservationist, to direct the environmental agency.
 
Rewriting the Rules
 Perhaps the most important change in environmental regulations that the Administration has proposed so far is rewriting rules to limit or eliminate the public's ability to intervene in corporate or government decisions.
In March, Mr. Lujan eliminated the public's decades-old ability to appeal decisions by the Interior Department and to block oil exploration licenses, grazing permits, mining leases and other industrial uses of public lands.
Mr. Lujan said in the interview that useful projects on public lands were being delayed indefinitely by opponents who did nothing more than mail in criticisms, automatically initiating long reviews of the agency's decisions. "It was the 29-cent appeal," he said. "A letter stopped everything. Now if they want to appeal, they go to court."
A month later, Agriculture Secretary Edward Madigan used the same rationale as the basis for proposing to eliminate an 85-year-old rule that gave the public the right to appeal decisions by the United States Forest Service and to block sales of timber on Federal land.
"What you see is an understanding by the President that in a recession there is an increased sensitivity to the job side of the equation," Michael R. Deland, the chairman of the President's Council on Environmental Quality, said today. "The President has an understanding and empathy for folks out of work. He doesn't want to see additional people put out of work by a rule that does not effectively protect public health and the environment."
