HEADLINE: AFTER THE RIOTS;
QUAYLE SAYS RIOTS SPRANG FROM LACK OF FAMILY VALUES

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, May 19

 BODY:
In a direct appeal to the Republican conservative base two weeks before the California Presidential primary, Vice President Dan Quayle said today that the Los Angeles riots were the result of a "poverty of values" in the inner cities and that the nation should show no sympathy to those who joined in the civil unrest.
Seeking to shore up President Bush's support in the most populous state, and to lay groundwork for his own political future, Mr. Quayle appeared before the Commonwealth Club of California to deliver the sort of tub-thumping message that conservatives, including some of the Vice President's supporters, contend is lacking from Mr. Bush's oratory.
 
Transition to Middle Class?
 "I believe the lawless social anarchy which we saw is directly related to the breakdown of family structure, personal responsibility and social order in too many areas of our society," Mr. Quayle said in his first trip to California since the rioting, which left 58 dead and caused hundreds of millions of dollars in property damage. 
 He suggested that poverty was an inevitable part of society but should be a transition to the middle class, and that many of the urban poor remained that way because they had lost their moral fiber in the social and political upheaval of the 1960's and 1970's.
"Yes, I can understand how people were shocked and outraged by the verdict in the Rodney King trial," he told the group of business executives and professionals during at a lunch at the Hilton Hotel after touring a housing project in one of the city's worst neighborhoods.
 
'Simply No Excuse'
 "But, my friends, there is simply no excuse for the mayhem that followed. To apologize or in any way excuse what happened is wrong. It is a betrayal of all those people equally outraged and equally disadvantaged who did not loot, who did not riot." [Excerpts from the Vice President's speech appear on page A20.]
Although Mr. Quayle did not break with Bush Administration policy on urban affairs, his speech, which was warmly received, included much stronger and more intensely ideological language than the President himself has used. In his May 7 visit to Los Angeles, Mr. Bush condemned "wanton lawlessness" but he also said: "We are embarrassed by interracial violence and prejudice. We are ashamed. We should take nothing but sorrow out of all of that and do our level best to see that it's eliminated from the American dream."
In part, Mr. Quayle's words today seemed to reflect his role as the representative of the Republican right in an otherwise largely non-ideological White House. After weeks of confused and sometimes contradictory responses from the White House to the rioting in Los Angeles, Mr. Quayle was clearly reaching for traditional Republican roots and conservative themes.
He took a noticeably harder line than that of Jack F. Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, who has been more conciliatory than others in the Administration and critical of policies of the last 12 years. Mr. Kemp accompanied Mr. Bush to Los Angeles earlier in the month.
 
Wants Sense of Family
 Mr. Quayle said the Republican policies of the 1980's had helped produce a strong black middle class, suggested that a stronger sense of family was the cure to urban blight, crime and drugs, and derided those who have called for greater Federal spending in the aftermath of the violence in California following the acquittal of four white police officers in the beating of Mr. King, a black motorist.
"Instead of denouncing wrongdoing, some have shown tolerance for rioters; some have enjoyed saying, 'I told you so,' and some have simply made excuses for what happened," he said. "All of this has been accompanied by pleas for more money."
Mr. Quayle often takes more conservative public positions than the President and sometimes tries out political themes that Mr. Bush later takes up.
While Mr. Bush is assured of renomination, his conservative challenger, Patrick J. Buchanan, is running hard in California. The Bush campaign is eager for a strong showing in the June 2 primary because California is vital to the President's re-election prospects.
Mr. Quayle called for "social sanctions" against women who bear children out of marriage "irresponsibly" and at one point even lashed out against a popular television program, "Murphy Brown," in which the title character, a single woman played by Candice Bergen, bears a child.
"It doesn't help matters when prime-time TV has Murphy Brown -- a character who supposedly epitomizes today's intelligent, highly paid, professional woman -- mocking the importance of fathers, by bearing a child alone, and calling it just another 'life style choice.' "
But despite Mr. Quayle's ardent plea, there was an element of confusion in the Vice President's remarks during a three-day visit to California this week as the White House tries to show that it recognizes the need for change without breaking entirely with the policies that have kept Republicans in the White House for the last 11 years.
After his speech today, Mr. Quayle flew to Palm Springs, in Southern California, for a fund-raising event at the Desert Horizons Country Club.
On Monday, Mr. Quayle told a group of schoolchildren in Salinas, near Monterey, that the "trickle-down" theory, which was espoused by President Ronald Reagan, was "ridiculous," and that the Bush Administration wants to help impoverished Americans rise up through society.
Quayle aides quickly tried to pull back that statement, saying Mr. Quayle had not intended to give a blanket criticism of Mr. Reagan's policies. Today, he offered a strong defense of those programs, and repeated the Administration's attack on the Democratic programs of the 1960's.
"It would be overly simplistic to blame this social breakdown on the programs of the Great Society alone," Mr. Quayle said. "It would be absolutely wrong to blame it on the growth and success most Americans enjoyed during the 1980's. Rather, we are in large measure reaping the consequences of decades of changes in social mores."
Reminding his audience that his birth in 1947 made him a "baby-boomer," Mr. Quayle said, "Let's look at one unfortunate legacy of the 'boomer' generation. When we were young it was fashionable to declare war against traditional values. Indulgence and self-gratification seemed to have no consequences. Many of our generation glamorized casual sex and drug use, evaded responsibility and trashed authority."
He added: "Today the 'boomers' are middle-aged and middle class. The responsibility of having families has helped many recover traditional values. And, of course, the great majority of those in the middle class survived the turbulent legacy of the 60's and 70's. But many of the poor, with less to fall back on, did not."
Declaring that "unless we change the basic rules of society in our inner cities, we cannot expect anything else to change," Mr. Quayle said that "government's first obligation is to maintain order."
He called for tough measures against drug dealers and gangs and for "dismantling a welfare system that encourages dependency and subsidizes broken families."
"Ultimately, marriage is a moral issue that requires cultural consensus and the use of social sanctions," he said. "Bearing babies irresponsibly is, simply, wrong. Failing to support children one has fathered is wrong. We must be unequivocal about this."
As for Mr. Quayle's allusion to "Murphy Brown," the show's creator and longtime producer, Diane English, issued this statement from her Hollywood office: "If the Vice President thinks it's disgraceful for an unmarried woman to bear a child, and if he believes that a woman cannot adequately raise a child without a father, then he'd better makes sure abortion remains safe and legal."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Heading Off Heroin's Return

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
WHAT turned thousands of ordinarily law-abiding citizens of Los Angeles into looters? While the seeds of the Los Angeles riots were surely nurtured in the deep muck of poverty and racial rage, economists who study illicit markets suggest there is a lot to be learned about explosive changes in crime from mundane analysis of deterrence and opportunity. And the most striking explanation for such discontinuities is what Mark A. R. Kleiman of Harvard's Kennedy School of Government calls "enforcement swamping" -- the disequilibrium created when forces of deterrence are overwhelmed.
Once stated, the idea seems obvious: lawbreaking can have positive feedback effects, making it "cheaper" for others to join the fray. But obvious ideas can be profound. Mr. Kleiman, the author of a new book on drug policy, "Against Excess" (Basic Books), contends that enforcement swamping explains why the use of crack cocaine reached epidemic proportions in the 1980's in spite of the billions spent to fight it. And failure to learn from that failure, he argues, could lead to a heroin epidemic in the 1990's. 
 Some people stop at the checkout counter because it is the right thing to do. Some pay, though, only because the "price" of stealing, measured in the perceived risk of getting caught and punished, is higher than the price of acquiring goods with cash. One would thus expect small changes in the cash price, or the number of store guards, or the length of prison terms would lead to small changes in theft.
But suppose an increase in the "demand" for crime or a decrease in the "supply" of law enforcement leads more people to attempt economic crime. And the extra volume of crime reduces the probability of any single thief's getting caught, further reducing the price of stealing. Then the rate of lawbreaking will continue to grow until there is nothing of value left to steal, or the law enforcers finally throw enough resources at the problem to reverse the feedback mechanism.
Mr. Kleiman says that positive feedback works more circuitously, but just as effectively, in markets for illicit drugs. He maintains that the Government's initial failure to rate cocaine as a serious health threat in the late 1970's allowed the drug to gain a foothold among affluent consumers. Demand grew thereafter by what the Harvard economist calls "word of nose" -- and in the process, reduced the overhead costs of distribution.
Then, in 1981, the price of cocaine collapsed as competitors rushed into what had been a cozy little local business. Enforcement was swamped, further reducing the cost of delivering the goods and creating incentives for technological innovation. At $40 a hit, Mr. Kleiman notes, only high rollers could afford to freebase -- smoke -- cocaine. But at $5 for a rock of powerfully addicting crack cocaine, the stuff went out the door like Armani jackets at a pre-Christmas sale.
The use of cocaine in its various forms peaked in the mid-1980's and has fallen since. In part, that is because enforcement has had a chance to catch up: arrest and imprisonment rates for cocaine are at their highs. But since the street price is as low as ever, falling consumption must largely be due to falling demand for a drug now widely perceived as a ticket to psychosis.
There is no direct evidence that a similar cycle has begun in the long-dormant heroin market. But Mr. Kleiman believes that the conditions are right for a breakout. The street price of heroin has been eroding for several years. And in real terms it is now no higher than it was in the mid-1960's, on the eve of the last great boom in consumption.
Mr. Kleiman acknowledges that AIDS has reduced the attraction of injected drugs. But he notes that at the current low price, it is practical to get high on heroin by smoking it or snorting it. And if the drug does take off, it will be very hard to stop. Foreign sources are diverse. And interdiction technology, focused on planeload-sized shipments of cocaine from Latin America, will be almost useless in stopping imports of heroin by mail and courier.
Most troubling, perhaps, definitive evidence of escalating use will come only after the horse has left the barn. Cocaine addicts burn out fast; huge numbers of recruits are needed each year to sustain an epidemic. Heroin addicts, by contrast, are generally lifers; the annual turnover at just 5 percent. Thus a doubling of recruitment, which would eventually lead to a doubling of addicts, would barely show up in the early years.
The prudent course, Mr. Kleiman argues, would be to reshuffle drug deterrence resources now. While heroin interdiction is impractical, one could raise the street price by blitzing domestic distribution. And it might be possible to contain demand with education on the risks of snorting and smoking.
Drug law enforcement, Mr. Kleiman warns, is like a souffle: "Once it has fallen, no manipulation will cause it to rise again."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
April housing starts fell 17 percent, as builders broke ground on new homes at a rate of just 1,115,000. The figure was largely seen as a slowing after unsustainably rapid increases. [D1.]
A complex energy bill is beginning to emerge after weeks of deadlock among several House committee chairmen. [D13.]
 
Companies
General Motors got more takers than it expected for its stock offering, enabling it to sell 55 million shares, or 5 million more than it had planned. The final price was $39 a share. [D1.] 
 A judge gave Macy more time to prepare a long-term business plan and a reorganization plan. [D3.]
An Olympia & York unit told holders of some bonds linked to 55 Water Street that it could not make debt payments. [D3.]
Abitibi-Price announced the sale of its paper distribution business in both the U.S. and Canada to Alco Standard. [D3.]
The merger of Northeast Utilities and Public Service of New Hampshire was approved. [D4.]
A former top aide to Charles Keating, Judith E. Wischer, pleaded guilty to fraud charges in Lincoln's collapse. [D4.]
A.J.C. Smith was promoted to chairman and chief executive of Marsh & McLennan. [D4.]
I.B.M. introduced its first tape library system to handle vast storehouses of corporate information automatically. [D5.]
The Long Island auto dealer accused of defrauding G.M. of $436 million has agreed to forfeit close to $400 million in assets. [B1.]
Newspaper deliverers are scheduled to vote tomorrow on new contracts with The New York Times and a distributor. [B6.]
 
International
The Administration said Japanese mini-vans were being sold in the U.S. at improperly low prices. [D1.]
A decision on the sale of LTV's missile division to Thomson-CSF will have important consequences. [D1.]
The former Soviet Union got direct-dial service to more than 2,000 cities in 15 republics. Only last year it could receive fewer calls than a medium-size Manhattan apartment building. [D1.]
The giant Babelsberg studio in Potsdam, where some of the world's memorable films were made, has been sold. [D1.]
Early completion of current global trade talks was called for by a group of nations, warning that failure would risk bringing "fragmentation, conflict and inefficiency." [D2.]
An intriguing Japanese financial whodunit has entered a new chapter. A lawsuit could clarify whether the police uncovered a huge counterfeit operation or instead made a huge blunder. [D5.]
 
Business Technology
Through its Sabre Group, Federated is selling to other retailers the computerized inventory-management and back-office record-keeping service it uses in its own stores. [D6.]
 
Markets
Stock prices rose, carrying the Dow to a new high, on portents of a possible rate cut. The Dow rose 21.96, to 3,397.99. [D8.]
Prices of Treasury securities rose sharply, and long-term interest rates fell to their lowest levels since early February. [D13.]
The dollar's selloff continued, spurred by the report on housing starts. [D16.] Soybean futures prices plunged. [D16.]
 
Today's Columns
What turned thousands of ordinarily law-abiding citizens of Los Angeles into looters? Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]
Forget about gold as a haven. That is what millions of investors did last year. Market Place. [D8.]
Chrysler's decision to phase out a car line will be a blow to one agency. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D17.]

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
A NEW VISION FOR THE WEST SIDE
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Mayor David N. Dinkins have agreed to create a joint agency to revive Manhattan's decrepit West Side waterfront, a potentially significant milestone in a project that has been stalled more than two decades. They envision a 40-acre ribbon of parkland straddled by a new highway from the Battery to 59th Street and three possible riverfront sites for commercial or residential development. A1.
 
A DECLINE IN DROPOUT RATES
New York City reported a significant decline in the number of students dropping out of high school. Board of Education officials said that years of hounding truants and pressing students to complete their courses were finally paying off. But they acknowledged that a sluggish economy, with diminished job prospects, might be partly responsible for the improvement. A1.
 
AN AIDS ACCORD, AND QUESTIONS 
 Rushing to heal political wounds in the Hispanic community, Mayor David N. Dinkins signed an agreement with the Mayor of San Juan that is intended to provide better access to AIDS care for Puerto Ricans who travel between New York City and their homeland. But advocates for people with AIDS immediately denounced the agreement, which does not provide for any financing or set any timetable for achieving its goals, as merely a publicity stunt. B3.
 
A RULING ON LANDMARKS
Peter S. Kalikow's plan to replace 4 of 14 historic tenements on the Upper East Side with an enormous apartment tower was blocked by a New York State appeals court. As significant as the impact is on Mr. Kalikow's project, the ruling could send an even broader signal: that landmark designations cannot be compromised for political reasons. B3.
 
Three teen-agers shot to death in the Bronx. B2.
 
Officer indicted in manslaughter case. B2.
 
REGION
 
FUZZY PICTURE ON CUTTING TAXES
Republicans swept to total dominance of the New Jersey Legislature because of voter anger over a 1990 tax increase. So the one thing that is clear is that the people of New Jersey want a tax cut, and anybody who stands in the way is committing political suicide. Right? Wrong. B6.
 
SHOWDOWN ON YONKERS' GARBAGE
With 200 tons of trash piled up along Yonkers streets, the Mayor has threatened sanitation with stiff fines in a test of wills between a new administration and the powerful Teamsters. B6.
 
AN ATTACK ON 'ONE-SHOTS'
Renewing the debate over one of New York State's most controversial fiscal practices, the State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, charged that the level of "one-shot" financing in the state budget adopted last month was much higher than the estimates provided by Governor Cuomo. B4.
 
'ALTERNATIVES TO PRISON'
A Long Island criminal-justice professor who taught a course on "alternatives to prison" has confessed to helping two inmates escape from prison in upstate New York last week, the state police said. The two, serving time for murder and armed robbery, remain at large. B6.
 
Newspaper drivers to vote on contract. B6.

HEADLINE: Drivers to Vote on Contract That Would Reduce Staffing

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL

 BODY:
Newspaper delivery drivers are scheduled to vote tomorrow on new contracts that would sharply reduce their numbers over several years and introduce other economies in exchange for job guarantees, retirement bonuses and other incentives.
The latest version of the contracts with The New York Times and a distributor would for the first time permit part-time workers as drivers, something long opposed by the union, which has insisted on full-time wages no matter how many hours are worked. 
 But the new contracts would set a lower percentage of part-time drivers than contracts that the union rejected earlier this month. The new contracts also contain provisions that could put off the hiring of part-time drivers for years.
The contracts, which could spell labor peace or war in the city's newspaper industry for years to come, would also make it easier for drivers to advance to positions that guarantee more hours and would maintain standard grievance procedures for drivers who have complaints about working conditions.
But the contract provisions most onerous to many drivers would remain. Company managers would get the right to designate delivery routes and even order freight other than newspapers to be carried on the trucks. Trucks would be larger and newspaper bundles heavier. Foremen would be taken out of the union and made management representatives. And overtime would not be granted as a routine part of the schedule, cutting many drivers' incomes to $40,000 from the current $80,000.
 
Members Briefed Tonight
 In preparation for tomorrow's vote, members of the 2,900-strong Newspaper and Mail Deliverers' Union of New York and Vicinity will be briefed at a membership meeting tonight in Manhattan on the settlement being proposed to end the bitter two-week labor dispute.
Earlier versions of the contracts were rejected on May 6 by 57 percent of the 1,600 union members voting.
None of the leadership of the parties involved in the negotiations -- the union's president, Douglas LaChance; officials of The Times, or the wholesaler, Arthur E. Imperatore of Imperial Delivery Service -- would publicly discuss the latest contracts or assess their prospects for passage. But some union members provided details about the major provisions.
And other union members said that while dissatisfaction with the contracts remained widespread, there was little alternative to approval.
 
Changes Called 'Minor'
 Anthony B. Laino, a shop steward for drivers at the Newspaper Distributors Company in East Farmingdale, L.I., one of two companies whose union contracts were voided when Mr. Imperatore purchased the company's assets, called the contract changes "minor" and "garbage," but said he would urge his members to vote for them anyway.
"I'm going to tell them, 'Listen, we have to take it because we have no support,' " he said Monday outside the distribution center. He said he was persuaded of this when Barry Feinstein, a teamsters' union leader and one of three intermediaries who helped arrange talks that led to the proposed settlement last weekend, warned publicly that rejection by the membership would be "the road to hell."
After a week of calm while talks proceeded, The Times yesterday reported two "isolated" incidents of vandalism, the attempted firebombing of a delivery truck early yesterday on Interstate 95 en route to Mr. Imperatore's other distribution center, Westfair Newspaper Distributors in New Rochelle, and the slashing of three conveyor belts at the paper's West 43d Street plant. Neither disrupted production or delivery, said a Times spokeswoman, Nancy Nielsen.
In addition to drivers at Mr. Imperatore's distribution centers, the proposed contracts would cover nearly 1,000 drivers who will initially deliver The Times out of the newspaper's $450 million plant in Edison, N.J., and drivers for two wholesale distribution centers whose assets are to be acquired by The Times.
On May 6 the drivers voted on five contracts. Two covered Westfair and Newspaper Distributors, which had been acquired by Imperial Delivery; two covered the prospective Times acquisitions, Metropolitan News Company and Newark Newsdealers Supply. Because all four companies had been sold as assets, their labor contracts lapsed with the sale and had to be renegotiated. The fifth contract was for the Edison plant, which, as a new workplace, required a new contract.
For tomorrow's vote, Mr. Imperatore's two contracts have been combined as one, so four are on the table.
The contracts run through the year 2000, with a provision to reopen negotiations on wages after three years. Salary increases in the new contracts are actually lower in the new contracts than in the contracts that were rejected. In exchange for increasing welfare and pension benefits for some drivers, the proposed contracts set the increase at $32 a week in the first year, $31 in the second and $31 in the third. The earlier contracts had called for raises of $34 in the first year, then $32 and $32.
In the current complex hierarchy of drivers, there are almost 1,000 employees called "permanent situation holders" who are guaranteed regular work at The Times and at the four wholesalers. The wholesalers receive papers from The Times's printing plants and deliver them to news dealers and home-delivery services.
In addition to those 1,000 employees, there are another 250 or so workers called Group 1 drivers, who are the first called to fill in when regular drivers retire or are absent.
Under staffing levels in the proposed settlement, the number of permanent drivers at Mr. Imperatore's distribution centers would be allowed to shrink through attrition to 126 from the current 210; at The Times's centers the numbers would shrink to about 230 from about 370.
The number of permanent Times drivers would be frozen at the current level of 370 until all The Times's Group 1 drivers advanced to permanent status. Then the number of permanent drivers could shrink to 270.
Over time, the total number of permanent drivers for The Times and the wholesalers would drop to under 700, saving The Times alone, according to one union member's calculations, at least $30 million a year.
Retirements would be hastened by one-time departure bonuses of $75,000 for permanent Times drivers and $35,000 for Group 1 Times drivers, and $35,000 for both groups of drivers at any of the four distribution centers.
All Group 1 drivers would get their welfare and pension benefits paid by management. To achieve this provision in the contracts, the union agreed to reduce its wage increase.
The contracts that were rejected on May 6 set the number of part-time drivers at 15 percent of the total regular shifts. Under the proposed settlement, that number would be reduced to 10 percent.
In the latest proposal, The Times and Mr. Imperatore dropped efforts to institute a more cumbersome multistep procedure for workers to file job grievances, instead maintaining standard newspaper industry procedures.

HEADLINE: Bosnian, in U.S. to Seek Aid, Assails Inaction

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19

 BODY:
In an impassioned plea for armed intervention to save the people of Bosnia and Herzegovina from starvation and slaughter, the country's Foreign Minister said here today that the world's inaction was a "disgrace for humanity."
The Foreign Minister, Haris Silajdzic, said the world was standing on the sidelines as it had done in the face of Nazi atrocities in the 1930's. 
 Speaking at a sparsely attended news conference -- he had been told, he said, that there wasn't much American interest in the war for Bosnia -- he described in vivid terms the plight of the newly independent republic, now under siege by Serbian forces.
Later today, a State Department official said that what was going on in Bosnia was "a very dirty war" but repeated the Administration position that the use of military force had been rejected "for very good reason." He said military intervention would be difficult because much of the fighting was going on among irregulars and foreign forces would get bogged down.
That left only economic and political measures to use against the Serbians, the department official said, warning that it could take "six months or a year" to resolve the conflict.
The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia, who instigated the attacks on Bosnia, was an uncompromising nationalist. "The only thing the man understands is power," he said.
Mr. Silajdzic said that Bosnian towns and cities were undergoing "ethnic cleansing" under Serbian guns and that whole neighborhoods of non-Serbs were being herded into what he called concentration camps.
All Yugoslav Army forces should be withdrawn, he said, and foreign troops should be brought in to take control of artillery and other weapons of war.
"My country has turned into a slaughterhouse," Mr. Silajdzic said. "Our people are suffering terribly. Millions are threatened with starvation, lack of medicine and clean water."
Mr. Silajdzic has been trying for several weeks to persuade a reluctant international community to send peacekeeping troops to halt the fighting in Bosnia.
After a visit to Washington by Mr. Silajdzic in April, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d gave several strongly worded warnings to Belgrade. But on this trip, the State Department said no meetings between Mr. Baker and Mr. Silajdzic had been planned.
More than 1,300 people have been killed in fighting since March when Bosnia and Herzegovina -- or at least its Croats and Muslims -- voted for independence from Yugoslavia. Large numbers of the ethnic Serbian minority opposed the move.
When the European Community and the United States recognized Bosnian independence, the Serb-dominated Yugoslav Army intervened.
The Foreign Minister told reporters today that the conflict was not an ethnic war. He said it was purely an attack by Serbia and Montenegro, the remaining republics of Yugoslavia, "with the Yugoslav Army instrumental in the aggression."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Fighting Rages in Bosnia
 BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 19 (AP) -- Fighting raged across Bosnia and Herzegovina today despite a truce, driving thousands more from their homes.
Russia's Foreign Minister, Andrei Kozyrev, met President Milosevic in Belgrade and said he had a plan for a peace settlement.
"After my visit to all the former Yugoslav republics, we may formulate a new initiative to resolve the Yugoslav crisis," he said.
But the Organization of the Islamic Conference called on its 46 member nations to recall their ambassadors from Belgrade.
And the International Red Cross said today that Frederic Maurice, 39 years old, who was to have headed the group's Sarajevo mission, died today of wounds he had suffered in an attack on Monday on a Red Cross convoy heading into Sarajevo.

HEADLINE: JAPANESE DECLINE TO CONDEMN ARMY

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 19

 BODY:
The Japanese Government, by far Thailand's largest source of foreign aid and a major influence in economic growth, said today that it would not press the country's leadership to stop the crackdown on anti-Government protesters.
The country's chief Cabinet secretary, Koichi Kato, said only, "We hope order is quickly restored." 
 Japan's mild comments, and its seeming embrace of the military Government, seemed to underscore the somewhat divergent approaches taken by Washington and Tokyo since since military leaders in Thailand, led by Suchinda Kraprayoon, took power in a coup last year.
At the time the United States cut off all assistance except for funds to fight drug trafficking. But Japan, which provides more than three-quarters of Thailand's foreign aid -- about $418 million last year -- restored its aid after only a brief pause and never strongly condemned the coup.
"We regard the Suchinda Government as a legitimate, constitutional government," a senior official of Japan's Foreign Ministry said today. "It is regrettable that blood has been shed, but there was an attack on the enforcement authorities that provoked it."
Government officials denied that business interests were playing any role in its gingerly treatment of Thailand's actions, which included the shooting of scores of protesters.
But Bangkok is ringed by Toyota automobile plants and a range of Japanese-owned electronics factories that make everything from computer chips to microwave ovens. Japanese cars account for over 90 percent of those on the road in Thailand. Prolonged political instability could have serious consequences for productivity on the factory floor.
 
Tolerant of Crackdowns
 In a statement late today, the Japanese Government said that it hoped "the situation will be settled promptly and peacefully" and that it would "monitor future developments, including the parliamentary deliberations on constitutional amendments" that would require that the Prime Minister be an elected official. But it avoided any condemnation of the shootings.
In many ways, Japan's tepid reaction seemed to echo its response in other cases when pro-democracy demonstrators and authoritarian governments have come into conflict. Japanese officials often argue that stable government and economic growth are preconditions for democracy.
With that logic, Japan was among the first countries to renew ties with China after the crackdown in Tiananmen Square in 1989. The previous year, Tokyo declined to cut off all aid to Myanmar after Government troops there killed hundreds of protesters. It continues to finance what it terms humanitarian projects, and Japanese trading companies are once again active in the country.
Several weeks ago, when President Alberto K. Fujimori of Peru suspended the constitution and dissolved parliament, Japan also declined to join the United States in condemning the actions or cutting off aid.

HEADLINE: Administration Must Decide On LTV Unit's Sale to French

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19

 BODY:
The Bush Administration must decide soon whether to permit a French concern to buy a leading American military supplier, a landmark decision that has important consequences for American national security, global competitiveness and thousands of jobs.
At issue is the $300 million sale of the LTV Corporation's missile division to France's Thomson-CSF, one of the world's largest military companies. 
 Supporters of the proposed deal say Thomson's deep pockets -- the French Government controls 58 percent of the company -- would give LTV a strong international marketing network and save jobs at the Dallas-based missile maker.
But many in Congress and the aerospace industry fear the sale will compromise American military technology and weaken the global competitiveness of American companies.
In House and Senate hearings last week, lawmakers voiced sharp skepticism that Congress could trust France and French companies, which have been among the most active arms merchants to countries like Libya, Iran and Iraq. In the Persian Gulf war, Allied forces confronted radar made by Thomson and other French equipment.
LTV's missile division makes missile and artillery systems for the Army, as well as Erint, a hit-to-kill missile that is an important part of the Strategic Defense Initiative plan for battlefield defenses against ballistic missiles.
A high-stakes battle is unfolding here as the team of losing bidders, the Martin Marietta Corporation and the Lockheed Corporation, appeals to lawmakers and to an interagency Administration committee. The sale cannot go forward until it has been reviewed by the panel, which will submit its recommendation to Mr. Bush, who makes the final ruling.
The Administration, normally a strong backer of free trade and open markets, has adopted a neutral position on the sale until a 90-day review period ends in late July. The decision rests with the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States, which is made up of officials from the Treasury, Defense, State, Commerce and Justice Departments, as well as the White House Office of Management and Budget, the Council of Economic Advisers and the United States trade representative.
A senior Administration official said today that the panel's 30-day preliminary review of the case, which expires on Wednesday, would be broadened to a more comprehensive 45-day examination.
Important members of the House of Representatives and more than half the Senate have challenged the Thomson purchase.
 
'A Dangerous Precedent'
 "This deal, if approved, would set a dangerous precedent by allowing foreign governments to compete with U.S. investors trying to buy ailing U.S. defense firms as that industry shrinks and consolidates," said Senator Robert C. Byrd, the West Virginia Democrat who heads the Appropriations Committee.
Mr. Byrd and Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, introduced legislation last week that would halt the sale.
Of the 700 filings submitted to the panel since it was formed by the Exon-Florio Act four years ago, the White House has rejected only one sale, a Chinese proposed takeover of Mamco Inc., a Seattle-based aerospace company.
Senior Administration officials, including Deputy Defense Secretary Donald J. Atwood, have said the sale may be approved if the Government and Thomson can agree on special security restrictions to protect classified military secrets from falling into hostile hands.
 
How Much Secret Work
 Thomson says only about 5 percent of LTV's business is highly classified, but Chester Paul Beach Jr., the Defense Department's acting general counsel, said at a Senate hearing earlier this month that about 75 percent of the missile contracts involve some components that require special security clearances.
Under the Pentagon's interpretation, Thomson-CSF would have to relinquish day-to-day control of the company, which Thomson executives have opposed.
At a hearing of the House Armed Services Committee last week, Representative Larry Hopkins, Republican of Kentucky, cited a classified Defense Department intelligence assessment that rated the Thomson deal as the highest national security risk of about 200 cases the Pentagon has reviewed in the last four years.
Industry officials say the case could also set an important precedent for future sales of American contractors abroad. "The reality is the industry is integrating across national borders, and American companies are among the last to recognize that they can't survive in the U.S. market alone," said Gordon Adams, director of the Defense Budget Project, an independent research organization here.
 
Bankruptcy Court Approval
 LTV signed a definitive agreement with Thomson-CSF and the Carlyle Group, a Washington-based investment company, on April 22. Under the terms of the deal, which was approved by Judge Burton R. Lifland of the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan, the French company would pay $300 million for the missile division, and Carlyle would pay $150 million for the aircraft unit. The Carlyle deal is not in dispute.
Foreign-policy issues are also being raised. Thomson and Carlyle officials say that if the sale is blocked for what are perceived to be protectionist reasons, relations with Paris and the European Community could be damaged.
Norman R. Augustine, Martin Marietta's chairman, said he did not oppose investments by privately owned foreign companies in American military contractors, but he did object to companies controlled by foreign governments.
 
Tough Foreign Competition
 "Is U.S. government going to signal to the world that even its major defense contractors are for sale to foreign governments at the highest bidder?" Mr. Augustine asked. "No company can successfully compete with a foreign government."
Carlyle's vice chairman, Frank C. Carlucci, a former Secretary of Defense, retorted, "Surely no one thinks that the French Government is sitting back plotting to take over the American defense industry."
LTV has been in bankruptcy since 1986. Most of the money raised from the auction of its once-prized aerospace and missile units would go to the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation as payments for three LTV steelworker pensions that require an additional $3.1 billion in financing.

HEADLINE: Tarnished Rainbow;
Under the Stars, a Bitter Strike

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO

 BODY:
Susan Grymes stood before 30 Rockefeller Center and faced a dilemma. Next to her, two dozen strikers called to her, sometimes plaintively, sometimes angrily, not to go in. Above her, 65 floors to be exact, the panoramic views, the ballroom in the clouds, the elegant 1930's decor, the spicy salmon tartare -- in short, the Rainbow Room -- called to her to come up.
She paused to glance at a union flier, then forged through the revolving doors, her husband and two friends in tow, grimacing under a barrage of chants, whistles and catcalls from the strikers. 
 "I feel badly for those people, I do," Ms. Grymes, a New Jersey resident, said. "But this is my fifth anniversary and I've been waiting so long to do this."
 
Signs of Strife
 A strike has come to the Rainbow Room, and suddenly the cool pastel of its Art Deco veneer has cracked, exposing labor strife inside.
Last Thursday, workers at the Rainbow Room walked off the job to protest stalled contract negotiations with the B.E. Rock Corporation, the Rainbow Room's owner. They say more than 200 of the restaurant's 325 workers are striking. Management, which has hired about 80 replacement workers, says about 150 people are on strike.
In December, the workers, who did not belong to a union at the time, elected Local 6 of the Hotel and Restaurant Employees International Union as their collective bargaining agent amid complaints that management was reducing health benefits, taking a percentage of tips and laying off workers. The union says that three workers have been fired for union organizing. The Rainbow Room denies the charges and is appealing the certification of the union to the National Labor Relations Board in Washington.
 
Disagreement on Discord
 The talks reached an impasse a week ago, after about 15 negotiating sessions, with the two sides separated by what the union says is about $250,000 in wages and benefits, but management says is closer to $700,000 per year.
Rainbow Room officials say that the pickets have had little effect on business and that the restaurant's grill, cafe, banquet rooms and main dining room have been serving about 1,000 customers a night, about average.
But a prolonged battle could delay the restaurant's slow climb out of the recession, management concedes. A bitter strike in 1989 at Tavern on the Green cut business by as much as 60 percent during the 10 weeks it took to resolve the dispute.
 
Cancellations Mount
 This week, the Ms. Foundation and the Exxon Corporation canceled banquets because of the pickets, and more cancellations are expected. The union has also vowed to disrupt business through the potentially lucrative Democratic National Convention, which begins on July 13, if the strike continues that long.
"Democratic officials have assured us they won't cross picket lines," said John Turchiano, a spokesman for the union. "I don't know if it will go that long, but the workers are prepared for it."
Frederic N. Richman, a lawyer for the restaurant, said that if the strike lasts through the convention, "Everyone loses. "
No contract negotiations have been scheduled, and the two sides do not even agree on what they are disagreeing about. Management says the strike is over economic issues. It says Rainbow Room waiters and bartenders earn an average of $50,000 a year, and would make more if they accepted management's offer. Meeting the union's demands would be "like asking Joe Baum to commit economic suicide," he said, referring to one of the owners of the restaurant.
 
Other Divisive Issues
 But the union says it is striking to protest the firing of the three union organizers and management's refusal to sign a contract. It says that few waiters earn over $50,000 and that Rainbow Room employees earn less in base pay than workers at comparable restaurants. The dispute is not just about wages and benefits, but also about safety conditions and scheduling, union leaders say.
In dozens of interviews, striking workers -- many hired just after the restaurant completed a $25 million restoration in 1987 -- said they elected Local 6 to be their bargaining agent because management had begun reducing health benefits and laying off workers.
Waiters, bartenders and hat checkers said management systematically takes a portion, and sometimes all, of their tips. And many complained that they were expected to work 18-hour days during busy seasons, a practice they said would be stopped under a union contract.
Mr. Richman, the lawyer, said the Rainbow Room is "prepared to rehire the strikers, but is not obligated to do so." But some workers said they fear permanently losing their jobs, though they said believed the risk was warranted.
"It was that impossible," said Mitchell Conrad, a waiter. "It was either change the place or leave it."
Peter Ward, the executive vice president for Local 6, said, "Management is counting on people to ignore the picket line. But I think they are in for a rude awakening."
But on a recent evening, the pickets deterred few diners.
Dr. Mervyn Peskin and his wife, Leah, arriving for her father's birthday party, were greeted at the East 49th Street entrance to Rockefeller Center, by two strikers dressed in tuxedos who offered fliers promising "VIP service" at Tavern on the Green.
"They were very reasonable," said Dr. Peskin, of Westchester. "I don't know enough about the issues to take a side, but you can see from their faces that they are hurt and angry."
Inside the lobby of 30 Rockefeller Plaza, Mrs. Peskin argued that the union's grievances "are probably legitimate," a pronouncement her husband questioned.
But with differences unresolved, they stepped toward the elevator to the revolving dance floor in the sky. "I'm upset about this," said Mrs. Peskin. "But it's my father's 70th birthday and this is his favorite place. It's so New York."

HEADLINE: Alabama Senate Bars Vote on School Aid Plan

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, May 19

 BODY:
A $410 million package of tax increases and education reforms that were being considered by the Alabama Legislature died late Monday night when the State Senate refused to bring the measures to a vote.
Advocates of the proposed legislation said that outright opposition to tax increases and the pressure of considering the tax package, budget measures and other bills on the last day of the regular legislative session had combined to derail the proposal. 
 Legislative approval of the package would have sent the tax increases to a statewide referendum in August, just before the 750,000 children who attend public schools in Alabama are scheduled to begin the 1992-93 school year.
Some of the state's 129 school districts have said that without new taxes and the revenue they would generate they will not be able to open schools on time this year. For the past two years the state's schools and other government agencies have operated on austerity budgets as tax revenue declined.
"Alabama's future is in question," said Philip E. Austin, chancellor of the University of Alabama system who is a member of a study group that recommended the package.
The legislation and proposed tax increase was fashioned and refashioned over the last seven months as the study group, appointed by Gov. Guy Hunt, and a handful of legislators sought ways to meet the rising cost of education and make up for revenue losses caused by the recession.
 
Rise in Property Taxes
 Besides increasing state taxes, the measure would have forced local officials to increase the amount of money they raise from property taxes for education. Alabama ranks 48th in the nation in local spending for education.
Peck Fox, a spokesman for Lieut. Gov. Jim Folsom Jr., said that a number of the 35 state senators simply opposed any tax increase, while others believed that the proposed legislation would not change education practices in the state enough to warrant a tax increase.
"It was a noble effort," said James Campbell, the House Speaker pro tem, who supported the measure. "But I'm afraid tax and education reform won't be addressed again until the next session of the Legislature, beginning next February."
In a news conference today Governor Hunt, a Republican, confirmed that he would not call a special session of the Legislature in an effort to revive the tax increase and education reform package this year.

HEADLINE: Congress Seeks $1 Billion for Helping Those Hurt in Military Spending Cuts

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19

 BODY:
In a largely symbolic effort to soften the blow of declining military spending, Congress is drawing up plans to set aside $1 billion in the Pentagon's budget next year to help communities, displaced military personnel and workers at weapon factories.
Supporters of the plans concede that $1 billion in a military budget of more than $275 billion will put only a dent in the problem. But proponents say the spending could be matched with state and local funds and used in proven programs adopted by private businesses. 
 The programs under review aim to promote high-tech companies that could absorb displaced workers, retrain former military personnel for new jobs in an industry that is prospering and cushion the economic dislocation in communities. If the programs prove successful in the first year, lawmakers said, financing could be increased.
The Congressional plan is the latest effort by lawmakers to counter growing political fears that cutting Pentagon spending too deeply could worsen job losses in the arms industry in a recessionary election year.
 
Hard-Hit Regions
 Although no one is certain what the economic effect will be from the $50 billion in military budget cuts that the Pentagon has proposed from 1992 through 1997, lawmakers are reacting to concerns that the savings will seriously harm some areas of the country. The aerospace industries in Southern California and Texas and big shipyards in Rhode Island and Connecticut could be especially hurt.
As a sign of this concern, Congress is considering whether to restore financing for one or two Seawolf submarines, assembled in Groton, Conn., that the Bush Administration wants to cancel.
Democrats in Congress have drawn up the most detailed plans for the conversion of industries from military to civilian uses. In a Presidential election year, these efforts have a secondary partisan goal: to pressure the Bush Administration to match their plans or face accusations of ignoring the plight of thousands of former military personnel and workers in the arms industry.
The Administration has not offered any sweeping proposals to cushion the effect of Pentagon budget cuts since the Soviet Union's collapse. And the Pentagon has resisted getting involved in the conversion.
 
Opposition at Pentagon
 "We fundamentally disagree with the concept of using Defense appropriations for domestic programs," Christopher Jehn, Assistant Secretary of Defense for Force Management and Personnel, wrote in a letter to Senator Claiborne Pell, a Rhode Island Democrat who heads the Labor subcommittee on education.
The Pentagon's main effort so far has been to designate $200 million from legislation Congress approved two years ago to help retrain and find jobs for employees of military contractors who have been laid off and for communities affected by base closings.
The Defense Department's tiny Office of Economic Adjustment gives grants of $200,000 to $300,000 to communities to help redesign their economies after a base or arms plant closes.
The House will consider the conversion plan in the first week of June, when it takes up the military budget bill for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. The Senate will consider its plan at the end of June, as part of its version of the military budget bill. Leading lawmakers say Congress will approve a version of the plans.
Under terms of the budget agreement that Congress and the Administration reached in 1990, the conversion programs under review must be military-related to use Pentagon money.
"Some of this is very innovative, but it's still dependent on the economy's recovery and overall Federal budget priorities," said Gordon Adams, director of the Defense Budget Project, an independent research organization.
Many of the proposals would expand existing programs run by the Departments of Labor and Commerce and other Federal agencies. In these cases, the Pentagon money would be transferred to the other agencies. Other programs involving partnerships with private industry would steer the Pentagon into areas the Government has historically left to free enterprise.
Under the conversion plans, the Pentagon would direct money to states, like New York and Connecticut, that have created diversification programs to help military contractors.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York plans to testify before the House Armed Services Committee on Wednesday about a two-year-old, $10 million program in New York State that has helped about 100 military contractors obtain skills in commercial design, retrain workers and introduce modern production methods.
"In my experience, the most successful adjustments are where local bankers, business people and officials take charge," said Robert M. Rauner, who retired last month as the director of the Pentagon's Office of Economic Adjustment.
Democrats on the House Armed Services Committee are drafting a detailed plan that would provide grants to private high-tech companies, expand existing Pentagon partnerships with such companies and pay the salaries of displaced military personnel who teach mathematics or science in public schools.
 
Grants to Convert Plants
 Senator David Pryor of Arkansas is leading a group of 22 Democratic senators who advocate grants for small high-technology military companies that convert to make products with military and commercial uses.
Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who is chairman of the Armed Services Committee, has proposed allowing military personnel a year's leave to attend college or vocational school to prepare for civilian life, then provide increased retirement pay to those who go into fields like teaching and law enforcement.
Representative Bill Goodling, Republican of Pennsylvania, introduced legislation last week to increase financing to help retrain laid-off arms employees and find jobs for them.
Thirteen Republican senators, led by Senator Warren B. Rudman of New Hampshire, formed a committee last month to examine job retraining and community assistance.

HEADLINE: Bangkok Upheaval Follows Year of Friction

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19

 BODY:
More than a year of political friction, constitutional debate and military maneuvering lay behind the confrontation that exploded on the streets of Bangkok over the last 10 days, pitting the Thai Army against thousands of unarmed civilians in Bangkok and other cities.
The crowds were demanding the resignation of an unelected Prime Minister, Suchinda Kraprayoon, a recently retired general. As supreme commander of the Thai armed forces, General Suchinda had plotted his way to power on a series of broken promises to restore a still-fragile democracy the army had abolished in February 1991. 
 In that month, a businessman-politician, Prime Minister Chatchai Choonhavan, was deposed in a bloodless military coup. Mr. Chatchai, whose Government was widely known to be corrupt, was nevertheless an elected leader and had been in office more than two years.
The post-coup period started out with promise. The generals named a respected former diplomat and civil servant, Anand Panyarachun, as interim Prime Minister and vowed that there would be a new election in a year. But first there would be a new constitution. Thailand has had 11 of them in half a century.
 
Effort to 'Raise Hopes'
 While an army-appointed commission was writing a constitution, Prime Minister Anand assembled a team of technocrats who took on the job of running the country with what critics acknowledged was a reasonably high level of efficiency.
The Prime Minister kept in touch with the constitution-writing process also, because there was apprehension among intellectuals and civilian politicans that the army was preparing a document that would institutionalize its political power.
Mr. Anand told the Far Eastern Economic Review in December 1991, after the document was completed, that he had intervened to reduce the powers the military intended to give to the appointed upper house of the Thai Parliament, called the Senate.
"What I wanted to do was raise hopes in people's minds that this was not a lost cause," he told the magazine.
 
Premier Forced to Resign
 But the final version of the constitution did not satisfy many Thais. Tensions began to rise by the end of last year, and the first democracy rallies began in November.
Throughout the year, competing generals and former generals had been positioning themselves for political careers. It seemed clear, many Thais said, that the military would insure that one of its number would emerge as head of government in elections set for March 22, 1992.
When the ballots were counted, no party emerged with a majority, forcing a coalition on a country already uncertain of the military's next moves. Generals had talked freely about controlling the "excesses" of politicians.
A pro-military civilian, Narong Wongwan, was named Prime Minister, but almost immeditely ran afoul of the United States. He had been denied an American visa in 1991 because there were questions about his family's involvement in the narcotics trade. He was forced to step down.
 
Dissident Ends Fast
 General Suchinda, still army commander and still protesting that he had no interest in politics, was soon "forced" by his military academy classmates -- each class becomes a lifelong fraternity in the Thai military -- to consider accepting the prime ministership.
He retired from the army and took the job, meaning that the restoration of Thai democracy was entrusted to an unelected head of government whose first allegiance remained to the army.
All that was needed to complete a combustible mixture was a leader who could serve as a focal point for the opposition. Chamlong Srimuang, a new member of Parliament and an extremely popular former governor of Bangkok, moved into the role. He began a fast in central Bangkok to back his demand for an elected prime minister, bringing out crowds of supporters.
Near death at the end of last week, Mr. Chamlong was persuaded to give up his fast, apparently by King Bhumibol Adulyadej, who has otherwise remained out of the present crisis.
But by then, the crowds had swelled into the hundreds of thousands and Thailand's largest democracy movement was rolling. Mr. Chamlong was arrested in the midst of the demonstrations, protesting that the violence around him was the work not of his followers but of provocateurs sent by the military.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE RIOTS;
Excerpts From Vice President's Speech on Cities and Poverty

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from remarks prepared for delivery by Vice President Dan Quayle before the Commonwealth Club of California, as transcribed by News Transcripts Inc. 
 I believe the lawless social anarchy which we saw is directly related to the breakdown of family structure, personal responsibility and social order in too many areas of our society. For the poor the situation is compounded by a welfare ethos that impedes individual efforts to move ahead in society, and hampers their ability to take advantage of the opportunities America offers.

 	 	 		. . .	 	There is no question that this country has had a terrible problem with race and racism. The evil of slavery has left a long legacy. But we have faced racism squarely, and we have made progress in the past quarter century. The landmark civil rights bills of the 1960's removed legal barriers to allow full participation by blacks in the economic, social and political life of the nation. By any measure the America of 1992 is more egalitarian, more integrated and offers more opportunities to black Americans and all other minority group members than the America of 1964. There is more to be done. But I think that all of us can be proud of our progress.

 	 	 		. . .	 	I was born in 1947, so I'm considered one of those "baby boomers" we keep reading about. But let's look at one unfortunate legacy of the boomer generation. When we were young, it was fashionable to declare war against traditional values. Indulgence and self-gratification seemed to have no consequences. Many of our generation glamorized casual sex and drug use, evaded responsibility and trashed authority.
Today the boomers are middle-aged and middle class. The responsibility of having families has helped many recover traditional values. And, of course, the great majority of those in the middle class survived the turbulent legacy of the 60's and 70's. But many of the poor, with less to fall back on, did not.
The intergenerational poverty that troubles us so much today is predominantly a poverty of values. Our inner cities are filled with children having children, with people who have not been able to take advantage of educational opportunities, with people who are dependent on drugs or the narcotic of welfare.

 	 	 		. . .	 	We are for law and order. If a single mother raising her children in the ghetto has to worry about drive-by shootings, drug deals or whether her children will join gangs and die violently, her difficult task becomes impossible. We're for law and order because we can't expect children to learn in dangerous schools. We're for law and order because if property isn't protected, who will build businesses?

 	 	 		. . .	 	Right now the failure of our families is hurting America deeply. When families fail, society fails. The anarchy and lack of structure in our inner cities are testament to how quickly civilization falls apart when the family foundation cracks.
Children need love and discipline. They need mothers and fathers. A welfare check is not a husband. The state is not a father. It is from parents that children learn how to behave in society; it is from parents above all that children come to understand values and themselves as men and women, mothers and fathers.
And for those concerned about children growing up in poverty, we should know this: Marriage is probably the best anti-poverty program of all. Among families headed by married couples today, there is a poverty rate of 5.7 percent. But 33.4 percent of families headed by a single mother are in poverty today.
Nature abhors a vacuum. When there are no mature, responsible men around to teach boys how to be good men, gangs serve in their place.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Answers to our problems won't be easy. We can start by dismantling a welfare system that encourages dependency and subsidizes broken families. We can attach conditions such as school attendance or work to welfare. We can limit the time a recipient gets benefits. We can stop penalizing marriage for welfare mothers. We can enforce child support payments.
Ultimately, however, marriage is a moral issue that requires cultural consensus, and the use of social sanctions. Bearing babies irresponsibly is, simply, wrong. Failing to support children one has fathered is wrong.
We must be unequivocal about this. It doesn't help matters when prime time TV has Murphy Brown -- a character who supposedly epitomizes today's intelligent, highly paid, professional woman -- mocking the importance of fathers by bearing a child alone and calling it just another "life style choice."
I know it is not fashionable to talk about moral values, but we need to do it. Even though our cultural leaders in Hollywood, network TV, the national newspapers routinely jeer at them, I think that most of us in this room know that some things are good, and other things are wrong.
Now it's time to make the discussion public. It's time to talk again about family, hard work, integrity and personal responsibility. We cannot be embarrassed out of our belief that two parents, married to each other, are better in most cases for children than one.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
Clinton's Platform Gets Tryouts Before Friends

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., May 19

 BODY:
In the past 48 hours, Gov. Bill Clinton has talked to students in Oregon, gay and lesbian Democrats in Los Angeles and shipbuilders in San Diego. Just today, he hopscotched across four time zones, replenishing the fast-emptying coffers of his Presidential campaign.
The Clinton organization hoped to raise $1.5 million this week, the most of any single week during the Presidential race and enough to offset the borrowing the campaign has made against its expected receipt of Federal matching funds. 
 But more important for his long-term political prospects, Mr. Clinton has begun using these forums to try to stitch together the disparate pieces of his platform into a message that will recapture the television spotlight that has drifted away from him in the last few weeks.
Although he tries to play down the threat of Ross Perot's swiftly emerging candidacy, Mr. Clinton evidently knows he needs a message tailored to a three-way race in which the undeclared candidate seems to be nailing down the outsider role that Clinton strategists have long regarded as the key to the voters' fancy.
"Now I find that having won the Democratic nomination -- almost -- people are saying, 'I don't want to vote for that guy Clinton; he's just another politician,' " Mr. Clinton said at a San Diego County Democratic Party dinner earlier this week. He said Americans are suffering from a "profound disillusionment with politics."
"Let's go out and tell the American people the Democrats can be for political reform," he said. "We'll change what we've done wrong too. But we're going to bring growth back to this country."
 
Attacking Bush, Not Perot
 In this political equivalent of out-of-town theatrical tryouts, Mr. Clinton gets his most enthusiastic response when he aims barbs, which have become more pointed in recent days, at President Bush. He has not yet begun attacking Mr. Perot, but his associates say he is gearing up for that battle as well.
"A lot of what Perot says we were saying a year ago," said Paul Begala, one of Mr. Clinton's chief strategists and speechwriters. "The whole criticism of the political process, the criticism of Washington and the gridlock of both parties. I'll be damned if we're going to let Ross Perot hijack our message."
As he tries to revamp his message, Mr. Clinton has so far not presented many new policy proposals. He still speaks of "three little words" -- invest, cooperate and educate.
For the shipyard workers, Mr. Clinton advocated using the money from cuts in the Pentagon to help the military industry and its workers adapt to the needs of a peacetime economy.
"It doesn't work to say, 'Keep taxes low on corporations and be wealthy and get out of the way,' " Mr. Clinton said. "You've got to get your hands dirty, pull up your sleeves and do what it takes to compete and win with these other countries in he world. It is one of the biggest questions the American people face in this election."
At the fund-raising meeting sponsored by gay and lesbian advocates at a Hollywood club, Mr. Clinton pledged to step up AIDS research, lift the ban on homosexuals in the military and invite a person who has H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, to address the Democratic National Convention in New York in July.
"Over a million Americans are now H.I.V. positive," he told the crowd. "And yet the Administration is still curiously silent until the famous fall; until, like Magic Johnson, they come forward, or like Arthur Ashe, someone takes advantage of their privacy. Then someone says something appropriately touching."
And at a rally in downtown Albuquerque today, Mr. Clinton summed up his reformulated message by calling attention to the youngsters in the crowd.
"These children here in front should grow up in a peaceful, exciting and prosperous world," he said. "If you want that kind of world, we have to invest, cooperate and educate. We've got to be responsible as well as create more opportunities. And we've got to recreate a sense of community."
Since the Los Angeles riots, Mr. Clinton has tried to claim the high ground on matters of race relations, but he has not come through with sweeping urban-policy proposals of the sort that might underscore Mr. Bush's seeming passivity in responding to the disturbances.
"This country is being killed by people who are trying to break us down and tear us up and make us be little when we have to be big," Mr. Clinton said at the Hollywood fund-raising event.
 
California Awaits
 The big California primary is, oddly, almost an afterthought. Mr. Clinton does not plan to return to the state until May 27, five days before the primary.
"There's so much in the mix here with the Senate races and the House races," said Dee Dee Myers, a campaign spokeswoman who was dispatched to Los Angeles last week. "There's been a lot of clutter in the environment. But Californians tend to focus late. This happens every four years."
Before a receptive audience of San Diego Democrats, he delivered some of the most stinging gibes of the campaign as he predicted that the Republicans would use welfare to divide voters.
"I've watched the Republicans divide our country in election after election with the politics of division and denial and destruction," he said. "And they are good at it. They're better at it than we are. Let's 'fess up. We're not near as good as destroying people as they are."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Bill Clinton greeting supporters on Monday night in Los Angeles after delivering a speech before a group of gay and lesbian Democrats. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Gold Loses Its Appeal As a Haven

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
FORGET about gold as a haven. That is what thousands of investors did last year, as buying of gold for a secure investment declined sharply in Europe and North America.
And don't worry about the Russians. Their gold selling spooked the market for several years. But as a menace, they are receding. The new bogymen are government central bankers, whose gold selling could stifle any rally. 
 These are some of the main conclusions from the latest survey of the gold market by Gold Fields Minerals Services Inc. of London, perhaps the best-regarded source in the world, according to analysts, on the goings on in gold. These are some of the other thoughts from the report:
*Gold investors might worry a little about the Iraqis. They have sold about 50 tons of gold recently, most of it this year. Their sales have not had a significant impact on the gold market yet. But who knows?
*And watch the Chinese. At current rates China should soon overtake the United States as the world's largest gold market. The slow opening of the economy is creating wealth that is snapping up gold.
The annual report comes as the price of gold, which closed yesterday at $337.80 an ounce, down $1.10, on the New York Commodity Exchange, is at its lowest level since 1986, continuing a strong four-year downward spiral. According to Gold Fields, the average price of gold dropped 6 percent in 1991 to $362.26 an ounce. The average price in 1987 was $446.07.
The report does not forecast what gold might do from here. But the balance of factors discussed in the report -- slowing production, stifling production costs that exceed the prices for many mines and a surprising rise in jewelry-making despite the worldwide economic slowdown -- seem to point for now to steady, low prices.
As for the more distant future, the presentation in New York, illustrated by slides, concluded with a photo providing clues on how to divine the unknown. The picture on the screen showed tarot cards, tea leaves, a crystal ball and a model's hand, presumably for studying the art of palm reading.
Philip Klapwijk, the Gold Fields analyst for Europe and the Americas, who presented the report's results to economists and analysts in New York, gave a slightly more concrete view in a subsequent interview. "Where do we go from here?" he said. "I think it is very difficult to call. We could spike down or we could spike up. But there is a good chance that we are seeing a bottom at the moment."
The drop in the investment buying of gold is a clear signal of the decline of gold as a haven in times of political and economic crisis. According to the data, European and North American investment in gold fell by 241 tons in 1991 after increasing by 173 tons in 1990.
The drop in investment is especially notable because it came despite the Persian Gulf war, a crisis that some investors supposed would raise the price of gold.
One note in the Gold Fields report suggests that disinvestment could be intensifying: investment in Asia, which had held up well in the past, has also declined. One reason is the many more alternative investments available as Asian financial markets liberalize. This trend had already depressed gold investment in the West.
The report also says that Asians might be changing their buying habits. In the past they have bought gold when the price was falling or low and sold when it rose. Now they could be acting more like Americans and other Westerners, buying when the price of gold is rising and selling when it falls. Mr. Klapwijk said this trend could make the gold market more volatile.
As for the gold sellers in the former Soviet Union, Gold Fields does not expect the recent sales rate to continue. One reason is that mine production there is faltering.
But, at the same time, central banks, have been selling gold more aggressively. If this pattern continues, these sales could further depress the price of gold. "This is the most contentious of all questions affecting the price of gold" in the next several years, Mr. Klapwijk said.
The major central bank sellers of gold last year were Brazil, Canada and Japan. In Canada, selling gold has been a regular policy to help ease the Government's fiscal problems. In Japan, the selling was more of a one-time affair. Sixty tons of gold were sold through the distribution of a gold coin to honor the new Emperor, Akihito.
Mr. Klapwijk is not worried about central bank selling, partly because he has not seen another big central bank follow Canada's lead of selling as a matter of policy. But with the threat of Russian sales receding, he said, the market, still very bearish, seems "to need a new menace, and that is the central banks."
