HEADLINE: AFTER THE RIOTS;
Tumult of Los Angeles Echoed in Long Beach

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONG BEACH, Calif., May 19

 BODY:
Once again, Cambodian refugees here have been made the victims of a sideshow, their adopted city largely ignored in its copycat wave of rioting last month, much as the fighting in their homeland was overshadowed in the 1970's by the Vietnam War.
Three hundred forty fires were set, 1 person died, 361 were injured and 1,200 people were arrested in the worst civil disorders in the history of Long Beach. But residents watching on television for news of their city found mostly the flames of Los Angeles, 20 miles north. 
 "I was watching all night but they didn't show Long Beach very much," said Satoshi Seta, who owns a row of small shops here in the nation's largest Cambodian-American community. "The only way for me to find out what happened was to come down and look."
He was one of the luckier ones. A grocery store he owns had been looted bare and a bullet had been fired through the window of his small medical center, but his jewelry store and barber shop had survived intact.
More than 17,000 Cambodians live in this city of 440,000, and much of the destruction affected their small businesses, including restaurants, grocery stores and other small shops in the neighborhoods along Anaheim Street.
When the Indochina war spilled over from Vietnam into Cambodia, the fighting in the smaller country was treated as a sideshow until 1975, when Phnom Penh fell to the Khmer Rouge and four years of mass killings followed.
On April 29, when four white police officers were acquitted in the beating of a black man, Rodney G. King, Los Angeles burst into flame and 58 people, including Matthew Haines of Long Beach, were killed. Grumblings of anger were felt in a number of other cities in the days that followed, but only Long Beach suffered its own serious outbreak of burning and looting.
Police today announced the arrests of seven Long Beach residents in connection with the death of Mr. Haines, 32 years old, who was pulled from his motorcycle and shot on the night of April 30.
 
Bandwagon of Vandalism
 City officials and residents now agree that the Long Beach riot, as destructive as it was, erupted mostly in imitation of the city's big neighbor and sometimes seemed as much a party as a protest. "I think they did it just to be doing it, just because Los Angeles was doing it," said Anthony Clarke, 14, as he leaned on his bicycle and surveyed the damage to the store where he used to buy candy.
Troy Fitzgerald, 21, said he had watched from his porch as scores of people gathered outside a row of shops across 10th Street chanting, "Break it open, break it open."
"They just went wild," he said, "taking everything they could and laughing in the street. When the police came, they just laughed and dropped everything. I think they saw what was going on in L.A. and figured they could get away with it."
Police Chief William C. Ellis noted that it took 24 hours for his city to erupt. "There was not the initial reaction to the verdict," he said. "I think people were being bombarded by visions of looters essentially walking out of stores untouched, and what we had here was a spillover."
Rotha Sieng, the owner of Khmer Market, fled the devastation of her country in 1979 as most of her fellow refugees did and settled here two years later. She said she had not realized that she had lost all her merchandise to looters until she arrived for work that Friday morning.
A refugee experienced in devastation, she seemed to have learned to ration her emotions. "When I saw that my door was broken and everything was gone," she said simply, "I said to myself, 'Oh, my.' "
Although the Cambodians suffered a heavy toll in the Long Beach damage, City Manager James C. Hankla said he did not believe they had been singled out by rioters, as Korean shop owners were in Los Angeles.
"I feel that it was more an issue of geography than an issue of ethnicity," he said, a view that was repeated by other residents and officials. The Cambodian shops are clustered in poor, ethnically mixed areas of the city where much of the looting took place.
Nevertheless, some Cambodian merchants said the rioting had fed their concerns over security. A violent rivalry between Hispanic and Cambodian gangs and extortion by a Cambodian underworld have already led some refugees to again seek safer cities.
"There is a lot of mixed feelings," said Julian Kim, a Cambodian refugee who owns a jewelry store. "Some people are thinking of moving somewhere else."
Behind the counter in her grocery store, Sokha Leng said, "It's hard to do business around here because too much stuff is going on -- gangs, drive-by shootings."
Mr. Hankla said that up to $20 million in damage occurred in Long Beach, far less than the hundreds of millions of dollars in damage suffered in Los Angeles. Swift and forceful police action helped contain the damage, he said, and officials have aggressively sought to recover stolen goods and pushed to collect private videotapes that could identify rioters.
Peter V. Ueberroth, who has been appointed by Los Angeles to oversee a long rebuilding effort, said today that Long Beach was being included in his plans for economic improvements.
But some residents, as they surveyed the blackened buildings in their neighborhoods, say they feel their city is still being treated as an afterthought.
"One thing I'm upset about is they're cleaning up Los Angeles but they're not cleaning up here," said Tamera Howard, who lives on 10th Street across from the ashes of a dry cleaner, pool hall, bakery and grocery store. "I realize Los Angeles is their priority now, but it was really horrible here, too."

GRAPHIC: Photo: For the 17,000 Cambodians living in Long Beach, Calif., reaction to the rioting in the city set off by violence in Los Angeles includes frustration and stoicism. Two young girls passed a burned-out building on 10th Street that is indicative of the damage many Cambodian businesses suffered. (Monica Almeida/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bush and Top Lawmakers Confer

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19

 BODY:
President Bush and Congressional leaders met today to try to reach a consensus on a new urban policy, but as Republican and Democratic lawmakers left the White House they voiced very different visions of what should be done in the aftermath of the civil unrest in Los Angeles.
The kernel of their dispute was predictably money. Democrats reissued their call that the 1990 budget agreement be reframed to permit transferring money from military programs to social ones. Republicans warned that giving money to inefficient city governments, most of which are controlled by Democrats, would deepen the recession and fail to improve the lives of the urban poor. 
 A consensus appears to be emerging to pass a modest package that includes tax benefits to businesses willing to invest in inner cities and a "weed and seed" program, promoted by President Bush after the riots, to bolster law enforcement and encourage community development. But Democratic efforts to create a $5 billion to $6 billion jobs program appear unlikely to receive much Republican support.
 
A 'No' to Raising Taxes
 The Republican leaders said after leaving the White House that they were in no mood for big spending programs.
"There's a unanimous feeling on our side that this is not a time to drive up the deficit and drive up interest rates," said Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Republican whip, "and it's not the time to raise taxes and cripple the recovery."
The Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, criticized big-city Democratic mayors who helped mobilize a march on Washington on Saturday to plead for more Federal aid. "We met with them privately and thought we had an understanding," he said, "but then they go out the next day and have a big march and all they do is bash Republicans, bash President Bush and ask for our help."

Mitchell, left, the Senate majority leader, and House Speaker Thomas S. Foley left the White House after the meeting. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: 17% Drop In Starts Of Housing

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19

 BODY:
In what was largely seen as a slowing in the wake of unsustainably rapid increases, builders broke ground on new homes at a rate of just 1,115,000 last month, 17 percent below the March pace, the Commerce Department reported today.
It was the biggest decline in eight years and embraced all regions of the country. In addition, permits issued for future construction fell 3.3 percent. 
 But while the drop in housing starts was considerably steeper than had been expected, most analysts said it was magnified by seasonal and other temporary factors. It thus did not represent, they said, the end of the recovery in housing that has helped generate four straight quarters of growth, albeit at a slow pace, in the economy at large.
 
A Note of Optimism
 "We're seeing it cool off," said Kevin Logan, economist for the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York. "The trend is still up," he added, noting that the April level is still 14 percent above that of April 1991.
Bond prices rallied, which helped to spur blue-chip stocks to a new peak, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 21.96 points, to 3,397.99. [Pages D8 and D13.]
Both climbed, in the apparent belief that today's policy meeting at the Federal Reserve resulted in a decision either to cut interest rates once again or to be prepared to do so at a moment's notice.
Some analysts thought today's poor housing figures nudged the Fed further along this path, while others said the Fed had probably already decided on such action in light of other recent data on the economy, including flat retail sales over the last two months and lagging growth in the money supply.
 
Presidential Reaction
 President Bush, addressing members of the National Retail Federation at the White House, was cautiously upbeat."Things are beginning to move," he said.
He did note that surveys show "the American people still feel the economy is getting worse." But he added: "I think it will turn around. And we are going to try and not oversell where the economy stands, but at least try to gun down some of this pessimism you get on the top of every news broadcast across this country."
On the other hand, the chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders, David F. Seiders, called today's report "troublesome," particularly since it followed a report three weeks ago that sales of new single-family homes slumped 14.8 percent in March while inventories of unsold homes rose after five straight monthly declines.
"The thing that worries me is how the numbers fit together," Mr. Seiders said. "Maybe there's more here than we thought was evolving." Association surveys also show a decline in home-buyer traffic this month.
 
Talk of 'Weakness'
 Lyle E. Gramley, chief economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association and a former senior official of the Fed, said he found "a weakness" in housing even though today's figures "greatly exaggerate" it.
He cited the second straight decline in permits, which he said were less heavily affected than were starts by quirks in weather and statistics and were a predictor of the economy at large, though not necessarily an indication of future housing starts. He said he expected gradual improvement in the housing market in the second half of the year.
What seemed to have happened earlier this year, various specialists said, was that a combination of unseasonably warm weather, declining mortgage rates and the prospect of a tax credit for first-time buyers emboldened builders to step up activity sharply, with some of that construction being "borrowed" from the early spring.
Since then, mortgage rates have risen, early-spring weather was soggy in much of the country and hopes for tax legislation have died.
 
A Volatile Category
 Analysts also noted that the statistics on apartment buildings and other multifamily residences have been so depressed that even moderate monthly changes produce wild gyrations. Starts of dwellings with five or more units soared 73.4 percent, to a 215,000 annual rate, in March before skidding back in a record drop last month, to 123,000, about the same pace as in February.
The 17 percent April drop in overall starts followed four straight sharp advances and was the biggest decline since a 26 percent plunge in March 1984.
By region, the Midwest had a decline of 30.4 percent, to a rate of 242,000; the West was off 16.7 percent, to 265,000; the South had a decrease of 10.7 percent, to 482,000, and the Northeast was down 8.7 percent, to 126,000.
For single-family homes, the decline of 10.6 percent, to a 963,000 pace, was the biggest since January 1991. Starts for dwellings with two to four units eased to a rate of 29,000, from 52,000 in March, the report showed.
 
A Look at the Future
 Permits were at a pace of 1,058,000 -- 873,000 for single-family homes, 45,000 for two to four units and 140,000 in larger units. The West posted an increase while the three other regions fell, with permits in the Northeast down to a rate of 109,000, from 124,000 in March.
Actual starts, before seasonal adjustment, totaled 109,700 in April, compared with 111,600 the month before. Permits on this basis rose to 105,300 from 97,900.
Shipments of mobile homes, figures for which are a month behind the other data, ran at a 197,000 annual rate in March, the same as in February.

HEADLINE: Yields Down Moderately On Bank Funds and C.D.'s

 BODY:
Yields on bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit fell moderately in the week ended today, The Bank Rate Monitor said in its most recent survey.
The decline for the last week was sharper outside the New York area, where the yields on both money market accounts and six-month certificates of deposit dropped four basis points. There are 100 basis points in a percentage point. In the New York area, the average commercial bank and savings banks rates were off one basis point. 
 Yet the 20 major banks nationwide are still offering higher interest rates on money market accounts -- 3.32 percent on average -- than New York commercial banks, where the average rate is 3.12 percent. The nationwide average is also higher on six-month certificates of deposit: 3.67 percent, compared with a 3.45 percent average in New York.
But New York savings banks were offering higher rates, with 3.74 percent on money market accounts and 3.94 percent on six-month C.D.'s. The average rate on three-month C.D.'s for savings banks was 3.72 percent, compared with 3.37 percent for commercial banks.
 
'Yields Remain Depressed'
 Robert Heady, publisher of The Bank Rate Monitor, said that despite the decline in the last week, bank interest rates had been relatively flat for the last 15 weeks.
Yet he said the "continual slippage in short-term yields" did point to another probable easing in interest rates by the Federal Reserve. "The simple fact," he added, "is that yields remain depressed because loan demand is extremely weak."
The largest reductions for the week all came at the Greater New York Savings Bank. It reduced its money market account interest rate 15 basis points, to 3.60 percent; its three-month C.D. 10 basis points, to 3.60 percent, and its six-month C.D. 15 basis points, to 3.75 percent.
Fleet Bank in New York increased its interest rate on its three-month and six-month certificates one basis point each, to 3.56 percent and 3.66 percent.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Up Sharply

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The weakest monthly set of housing data in eight years pushed prices of Treasury securities up sharply yesterday, and long-term interest rates fell to their lowest levels since early February.
The housing data showed that starts fell by 17 percent last month, and that permits to build new houses fell for the second straight month. The figures were far weaker than Wall Street economists had expected, and heightened expectations among credit market participants that the Federal Reserve Board would move soon to lower short-term interest rates. 
 However, the Fed, whose policy-making Open Market Committee was meeting in Washington when the Government reported the plunge in housing starts, did nothing to show its hand yesterday.
But analysts said the Fed could ill afford to ignore the report or its implications.
"The Fed will not ease on the basis of these housing statistics, which were partly due to abnormally cold weather in April and partly due to rising mortgage interest rates," said Lyle E. Gramley, chief economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association. "But if you are sitting over at the Fed, you have to be worried. This recovery may be in trouble again."
John R. Williams, a managing director for global markets economics at the Bankers Trust Company, said that the housing data, in conjunction with weak money supply growth and continued low inflation, "certainly gives the Fed the latitude to ease."
But Mr. Williams cautioned that another easing move would not be without some risks.
"In the final analysis, the last two easing moves have done nothing to get long-term rates down," he said. "If you really want to get an improved economy, you want to get long rates down. In that context, the market may be better served by a steady monetary policy."
 
Decline in Bond Yields
 Bond yields have moved slowly but steadily lower over the last few weeks, and declined yesterday to their lowest level since Feb. 7.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 29 1/2 year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 102 23/32 , up 5/8 point, to yield 7.76 percent, compared with 7.81 percent late Monday.
The improvement in bond prices was outstripped by the performance of Treasury issues with maturities of less than five years, securities that stand to benefit most, should the Fed cut short-term rates again.
Among outstanding note issues, the 5 7/8 percent three-year notes were offered at 100 29/32 late yesterday, up 11/32 , to yield 5.54 percent.
Prices of the new two-year and five-year Treasury notes to be sold today and tomorrow also rose sharply.
The two-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis late yesterday at a price to yield 5.03 percent, compared with 5.17 percent late Monday. And the five-year notes were offered in late when-issued trading at a price to yield 6.49 percent, compared with 6.62 percent late Monday.
Rates on outstanding Treasury bills moved lower.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 3.52 percent late yesterday, down seven basis points, or seven one-hundredths of a percentage point. And six-month bill rates fell by nine basis points, to a late offered rate of 3.60 percent.
The weak housing numbers and the rally they touched off in the Treasury securities market were a boon to New York City yesterday.
The city was able to sell $1.04 billion worth of general obligation bonds at interest rates that were roughly 10 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, below levels that were seen as likely by municipal bond participants on Monday.
Through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company, the city securities were priced at yields of 5.35 percent in 1994, 6.30 percent in 1997, 7 percent in 2002, 7.28 percent in 2015 and a maximum yield of 7.26 percent on bonds maturing in 2022.
Underwriters reported good demand for the new bonds. The securities are rated Baa-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
The rates on the securities sold yesterday are roughly 1.25 percentage points below city bond yields a year ago, when New York's financial crisis was at its nadir.
According to city officials, the drop in rates from last year will save New York more than $150 million in debt service costs.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, traders said the rise in Treasury prices helped pull up prices of most widely quoted municipal issues by 1/4 point to 3/8 point.
New-issue activity was also brisk in the corporate bond market.
Among the issuers was the Limited Inc., which offered $150 million worth of 10-year noncallable notes through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs.
The 7.80 percent notes were priced at $99.86, to yield 7.82 percent, 60 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The issue is rated A-1 by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's.
Merrill Lynch & Company acted as lead manager on a high-yield offering from Royal Caribbean Cruise Ltd.
The company offered $126 million worth of 10-year 11 3/8 percent senior subordinated notes at a price of $99.26, to yield 11.50 percent, 4.25 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities, which are noncallable for five years, are rated Ba-3 by Moody's and BB- by Standard & Poor's.

HEADLINE: Some Back Florio on Tax; Others Side With G.O.P.

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 19

 BODY:
Republicans swept to total dominance of the New Jersey Legislature last November by riding a crest of voter anger over Gov. Jim Florio's tax increase in 1990. So the one thing that is clear is that the people of New Jersey want a tax cut, and anybody who stands in the way is committing political suicide. Right?
Wrong. 
 Consider Helynn Masullo Burns of Closter, who is 70 years old and sports a little American flag on the back of the big black tricycle she was pedaling home with $87 worth of groceries in the basket on the back.
"I'm the last one to get into politics," she said, "but everybody seems to be so much against Florio. I don't know what or why, but when it comes to this 1 percent tax business, it makes no difference to me. Leave it at 7 percent. It's going to be raised somewhere else, isn't it?"
Or listen to 35-year-old Carl Doebel of Bloomfield, who was boarding an N.J. Transit train in Hoboken, coming home from his job as an assistant vice president for Bankers Trust in New York City. Mr. Doebel is a Republican but opposes repeal of the sales tax, saying: "I am in favor of what Florio is doing and I am against the G.O.P.'s behavior in the state capital."
 
'Mickey Mousing Around'
 "If I could," he said, "I would tell them to their faces that I demand more substance instead of this Mickey Mousing around in Trenton. We vote these people in and then have to watch this stuff going on. It's discouraging. It almost makes you think that all the intelligence in the state is going into the private sector, and the dregs of our society are moving into the public sector."
Such sentiments are not universal, but it is clear that while New Jersey taxpayers are frustrated and angry over their tax bills, they are by no means universal in the belief that a sales tax cut is advisable.
In fact, a Star-Ledger/Eagleton Poll released on Sunday shows that support for the Governor's approving the reduction in the sales tax, to 6 cents from 7, is only slightly greater than support for a veto. That is true despite the fact that it was primarily anger over a one-cent increase in the sales tax that fueled the voter rebellion that swept out the Democratic majority last November and replaced it with a Republican majority of two-thirds in both houses of the Legislature.
The Republicans' very first order of business was to roll back the increase, which will take $608 million out of the budget for the fiscal year that begins on July 1. Governor Florio vetoed the reduction on the ground that the Republicans have not said what programs, jobs or services they will cut to make up the difference.
Recent polls, bolstered by random interviews, show clearly that voters do want taxes lowered -- but not if it means giving up services.
Jim Mazzei of Park Ridge, a 31-year-old management consultant in New York City, says he is not happy with the sales tax, "but it's irresponsible to cut back without making corresponding cuts on the cost side."
Over all, about 6 in 10 New Jerseyans surveyed in the Star-Ledger/Eagleton Poll disapproved of a tax repeal if it results in a cutback in services.
However, about half the respondents thought it was possible to cut $600 million from the budget without reducing services.
On the question of the rightness or wrongess of the Governor's veto, about half -- 49 percent -- thought the Governor should approve the reduction, but only slightly fewer -- 43 percent -- thought he should veto it. The poll was taken before the Governor actually vetoed the sales-tax measure on Monday.
 
'Wrong on This One'
 Many in New Jersey appear to share the Governor's view that cuts should be identified before revenues are reduced. "I don't believe in government by veto," said Hank Greenfield, 46, an unemployed computer salesman from Hopatcong, "but I don't think Florio was wrong on this one. Where is the money coming from? Nobody seems to have any idea here."
Similarly, Jesse Moskowitz, a Jersey City lawyer who still puts in a full workweek at age 81, said: "If there is going to be a reduction in the sales tax, people should demand to know what programs will be sacrificed. Will the loss in revenue be linked with reductions in the homestead rebate program, school aid or other social programs?"
Referring to the poll data indicating that people want a tax cut but no reductions in services, Mr. Moskowitz said: "People are not thinking this through. They can't have it both ways."
 
Hoping for Tax Break
 There were some, however, who favored cutting taxes, even if it did mean reducing services.
Ron Cade, 41, who works for Paine Webber in Weehawken, was disappointed about the veto. "I was hoping for a bit of a tax break," he said. "I bought a car for $15,000; 1 percent would have saved me $150. But nobody's going to balance the budget and make everybody happy without cutting services."
But one sentiment that seems to seems to hang over the debate like a dark cloud is a failure of trust in government.
"I don't know who's telling the truth at this point," said 71-year-old Violet Arffman of Rockaway.

HEADLINE: U.S. Finds Japan Unfair In Pricing Its Mini-Vans

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19

 BODY:
Supporting Detroit's Big Three, the Bush Administration said today that Japanese mini-vans were being sold in the United States at improperly low prices, a decision that will further strain trade relations between the two countries and could produce higher sticker prices for the imported Japanese vehicles.
The Commerce Department ruling -- that Mazda mini-vans were being sold at 12.7 percent below their fair value and Toyota vans at 6.75 percent below fair value -- pleased General Motors, Ford and Chrysler, which sought an investigation last year. 
 Mazda said it was "mystified" and "astonished" by the decision, while Toyota officials called the decision "factual fantasy."
The International Trade Commission, a Federal agency, now has 45 days to rule whether the unfair pricing, known as dumping, has injured the American industry. If it rules that is has, penalty duties will be imposed on the Japanese mini-vans. It would be the first time such duties were placed on Japanese passenger vehicles.
Dumping occurs when a foreign company sells its goods in the United States below its domestic price or below its production cost plus a reasonable profit. In this case, the Commerce Department concluded that most mini-vans that the Toyota Motor Corporation and the Mazda Motor Corporation sold at home were sold at a loss, so the department instead sought to use their production cost plus reasonable profit as a measure of fair value.
The Big Three, led by the Chrysler Corporation, invented the mini-van and dominate the market. But they argued that Japan's van makers, who were late with a competitive product, were aggressively selling their mini-vans at illegally low prices to gain American market share.
The finding of dumping heightened tensions just a day after the heads of the leading American and Japanese auto makers met outside Chicago to try to resolve their differences. Some industry analysts said that in bringing this case in a segment of the car market that Detroit pioneered and dominates, the Big Three showed a new aggressiveness in seeking to protect their turf against Japanese encroachment.
Some representatives of the Japanese industry said today's decision, coming in an election year, was political and showed that the Administration had concluded that it could win votes by getting tough with Japan's auto makers. They cited the President's trip to Tokyo last December as another political move.
Representatives of the Japanese industry said it was ludicrous to bring the mini-van case because the Big Three had 88 percent of the market. Chrysler had 45 percent of the 1991 mini-van market, the General Motors Corporation had 26.2 percent, and the Ford Motor Company had 16.8 percent. Imports had 12 percent.
James Olson, vice president of external affairs for Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A., said the decision "may be politically correct, but it's factual fantasy." He added, "The Big Three's reaction to our modest success" in the mini-van market "is like a herd of elephants being stampeded by two mice."
According to the Commerce Department, about 95,000 Japanese mini-vans were sold in the United States in 1990 at a value of $1.2 billion. In 1991, Toyota sold 52,099 of its Previa mini-vans in the United States and Mazda sold 48,056 of its MPV mini-vans.
 
Higher Prices
 Mazda's mini-vans have a base price of from $17,710 to $21,360, so the imposition of 12.7 percent dumping duties could raise sticker prices by between $2,250 and $2,710. The base sticker price of Toyota's mini-vans is from $17,518 to $25,518, so a 6.75 percent duty could raise prices between $1,182 and $1,722. Japan's auto makers said this would provide an umbrella to allow American producers of mini-vans to raise their prices.
Big Three officials were heartened that today's final determination on dumping found far higher dumping margins than a preliminary decision last December, which found that Mazda's vans were selling at 7.19 percent below fair value and Toyota's at 0.95 percent below. The case involves sales of mini-vans between Oct. 1, 1990, and May 31, 1991, when the Big Three asked for an investigation.
Today's decision found that all other Japanese mini-vans were selling at 9.88 percent below fair value on average; the preliminary decision had said that they were selling at an average of 4.23 percent below fair value. The Big Three's dumping complaint mentioned only Toyota and Mazda, which are the dominant mini-van importers.
 
Rise in Market Share
 Thomas Hanna, president of the Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association in Detroit, said the Big Three had brought the case because they were convinced the Japanese were dumping as their market share increased from 3 percent to about 12 percent in three years.
"This product was invented in the U.S.," Mr. Hanna said. "When the American companies saw the rapidity with which the Japanese were penetrating the market, it was alarming. The question is, do you stand back until the segment is decimated by the Japanese or do you ask for an investigation? I think it was a wise thing to do."
One unfair mini-van pricing practice that the Commerce Department found was that component suppliers sometimes sold parts for mini-vans planned for sale in Japan for far less than what they charged for similar parts for Japanese mini-vans destined for the United States.
Toyota had argued that these pricing differentials resulted from the economics of the fact that it sells far fewer of mini-vans in Japan than in the United States. But the Commerce Department's decision said these arguments were "unconvincing."
Mazda issued a statement that denounced today's decision and added that there was "no possibility" that Mazda's sales "have caused any material injury" to the Big Three. It added that Chrysler's mini-van sales were so strong that the American company recently added a third shift at its mini-van plant in St. Louis.
"The department's finding is based on the absurd conclusion that Mazda is selling the MPV at a loss in Japan and in the United States, which we know is not the case," Mazda said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Rival mini-vans: A 1992 Plymouth Grand Voyager, top, and a 1991 Toyota Previa. The Administration has agreed with the Big Three American auto makers, which invented the mini-van and dominate the market, that two Japanese companies sold vans in the United States at illegally low prices to gain market share, a practice known as dumping.

HEADLINE: A Closing High: Dow Rises 21.96, to 3,397.99

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Stock prices rose on Wall Street yesterday, carrying the Dow Jones industrial average to a new closing high, as investors read a disappointing economic report as portending a possible cut in interest rates.
The Dow rose 21.96 points to close at 3,397.99, eclipsing the previous mark of 3,397.58 set on May 11. It was the Dow's 20th record this year. 
 Advancing issues outnumbered declining ones, 1,010 to 698, on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume on the Big Board came to 189.4 million shares, up from 151.4 million on Monday. The exchange's composite index rose 1.73, to 229.32.
 
Broader Gauges Up
 The broader market was also higher. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 3.56, to 416.37, while the American Stock Exchange's composite index finished 0.85 higher at392.37, and the Nasdaq composite index of over-the-counter trading gained 1.52, to 578.05.
Stock prices rose broadly despite a Commerce Department report showing that housing starts plunged 17 percent last month, the largest drop in eight years. Economists had forecast only a 6.1 percent decline.
But gloomy economic reports sometimes prod the Federal Reserve into lowering interest rates to help the economy, and stocks rose on that expectation, analysts said. Lower interest rates could help stock prices.
Bonds rallied on the weak housing data and the central bank speculation as the Fed's Open Market Committee met to discuss the economy.
"The market has held up quite well considering the disappointing housing starts," said Michael Metz, an analyst with Oppenheimer & Company. "There is hope the Fed will push short-term rates down."
 
'Investors Are Troubled'
 Hugh Johnson, the chief investment officer with the First Albany Corporation, said many investors were sitting on the sidelines, waiting to see what the Fed would do.
"Investors are troubled," Mr. Johnson said. "They believe the market is overvalued. They're worried that the stock market has come too far too fast."
The market has been edging toward the 3,400 level since last week but has been unable to break through the mark except briefly. Analysts have said investors are uncertain about the strength of the economic recovery and whether it will support stocks at their current prices.
 
Blue Chips Fare Well
 Blue chips fared well yesterday. I.B.M. was up 1 3/4, to 92 1/2; Merck was up 3 3/8, to 149; Coca-Cola was up 7/8, to 45 1/8, and Walt Disney was up 1 1/4, to 40 7/8.
Disney, the entertainment conglomerate based in Burbank, Calif., was the Big Board's most active issue yesterday, with a volume of 5.3 million shares. A 4-for-1 stock split took effect on Monday.
In other Big Board activity, the Limited was up 1/8, tot 20 7/8 and Kohl's Corporation, a department-store concern based in Wisconsin, was unchanged at 14 after an initial stock offering.
 
Boston Scientific Unchanged
 The Boston Scientific Corporation, a manufacturer of medical devices, was unchanged at 17 1/8, after a stock offering at a below-expected price.
The American depository receipts of British Airways gained 3 5/8, to 55 3/4, after the company announced solid earnings for the first quarter.. Storage Technology fell 7/8, to 35; Conseco Inc. was off 2 1/2, to 28 3/8, and Polaroid was 7/8 higher at 26, after a good report from an analyst.

HEADLINE: Industrial Lands Renew Call for Trade Accord

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, May 19

 BODY:
A group of major industrialized nations called anew today for early completion of the current global trade liberalization talks, warning that failure would risk bringing "fragmentation, conflict and inefficiency" to international commercial relations.
Yet nothing occurred at the annual ministerial meeting of the 24-nation Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development to suggest that the main obstacle to success -- a deadlock between the United States and the European Community over agricultural subsidies -- was close to being overcome. 
 The community's chief negotiator, Frans Andriessen, rejected the suggestion that only the Western European producers should make concessions. Mr. Andriessen will meet with the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, in Washington next week in one more attempt to break the deadlock.
 
Dispute Over Agriculture
 "There is no way the community will be able to accept a deal if it is not comprehensive in terms of agriculture, services, market access, etc.," he told reporters here, asserting that the United States was being inflexible on these related issues.
The head of the American delegation, Commerce Secretary Barbara H. Franklin, in turn said she was surprised to find Mr. Andriessen blaming Washington for the absence of agreement. "Everyone knows and accepts that the major impediment is the community's stance on agricultural subsidies," she said.
In a statement after their two-day meeting here, ministers from the 24 O.E.C.D. countries said world economic growth would be promoted by completion of the current round of trade talks, known as the Uruguay Round for the site of its first meeting, in Punta del Este, Uruguay, in 1986. "An early conclusion is urgently needed," the statement said. "For that purpose, the process of negotiations now stalled needs to be reinvigorated."
The organization consists of the European countries outside the former Communist bloc, plus the United States, Canada, Japan, Australia and New Zealand. Much of the closed-door meeting was given over to analysis by the members of how the major industrial nations could contribute to maintaining the current cautious economic recovery. Germany was urged to lower interest rates, Japan to stimulate domestic demand and the United States to keep fighting its fiscal deficit.
But, with this debate overshadowed by preparations for the scheduled summit meeting of the Group of Seven industrial powers in Germany in July, the French Finance Minister, Michel Sapin, was the only finance minister of the seven to attend this week's meeting here.
 
Concern About Unemployment
 The gathering nonetheless spotlighted the perils implicit in the chronically high unemployment levels of O.E.C.D. members, up by 5 million, to 30 million, over the last two years and running at twice the level of 20 years ago.
Norway's Finance Minister, Sigbjorn Johnsen, the chairman of the meeting, noted that unemployment levels had remained high even during the expansion years of the 1980's. "Young people who fear a future without adequate education and jobs represent a grave danger to political stability," he said.
While emphasizing the need for improved education and training systems, the ministers called on the organization to prepare a report for next year's meeting on remedies to "the disappointing progress" in cutting unemployment, which now averages 7.5 percent in the 24 countries.
The ministers were more upbeat about prospects for economic growth, with the organization's secretariat projecting that growth among the members would rise from 1.0 percent last year to 1.8 percent this year and 3.0 percent next year. For the United States, it forecast growth of 2.1 percent this year and 3.6 percent in 1993.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Continues to Retreat And Gold Prices Are Mixed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar's selloff continued yesterday on world currency markets, spurred by a report showing a steep decline in United States housing starts in April.
Gold prices were mixed. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $337.80 an ounce, off $1.10 from Monday. The Republic National Bank said gold fell 90 cents an ounce, to a late bid price of $337.50. 
 The dollar was weakened by selling overnight in foreign markets, and the trend was exacerbated by a United States Government report showing housing starts plunged 17 percent in April, the largest drop in eight years, with each region of the country suffering declines.
Analysts had expected construction to slow in April after four sharp monthly advances, but the extent of the drop was unexpected. Another worrisome factor that appeared in the Commerce Department report showed a 3.3 percent decline in building permit applications, often considered a barometer of future activity.
"This gave the market a little room to move on the downside," said Randolph Donney, research director at Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J.
But shortly after the report was released, the domestic market appeared to stabilize. "It's getting to the point where all this bad news has to be converted into an actual monetary policy change," Mr. Donney said.
The Federal Reserve's policy-making arm, the Open Market Committee, met yesterday in Washington but did not take any immediate action to lower interest rates in an effort to spur the economic recovery.
"The general consensus is that the Fed may go as far as cutting" rates in coming days, said Michael Malpede, an analyst with Refco Inc. in Chicago.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 130.30 yen, down 2.30 yen from Monday's close. Later, in London, it fell to 129.05 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 129.10 yen, up from 128.75 yen on Monday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.8400, from $1.8355 late Monday. In New York it cost $1.8385 to buy one pound, more expensive than Monday's $1.8365.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates included: 1.5905 German marks, down from 1.5955; 1.4600 Swiss francs, down from 1.4650; 5.3475 French francs, down from 5.3580; 1,197.00 Italian lire, down from 1,201.00, and 1.1944 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1987.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $338.65 a troy ounce, from $338.85 bid late Monday. In Zurich, it rose to a closing bid of $339.50 from $338.80. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.24 an ounce to close at $339.89.
Silver prices were steady to lower. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.079 a troy ounce, down from $4.087 on Monday. In London it was unchanged at a late bid price of $4.09.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
2 Big Agencies Waiting for Chrysler's Other Shoe to Fall

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
THERE is an adage in the agency business that shops should approach their work as if every advertisement they create for clients might be their last. Now, two giant agencies handling two giant automotive accounts are confronting exactly that unpleasant possibility, because one of those accounts has been a target for extinction.
Last week, Robert J. Eaton, the designated successor to Lee A. Iacocca as chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, confirmed speculation that the No. 3 auto maker would phase out one of its four car lines to reduce sales and marketing costs and, it is hoped, improve the awareness of Chrysler's remaining brands.
Any such decision, said Mr. Eaton, who is Chrysler's vice chairman, would affect either Plymouth or Eagle, which sell fewer units than the company's Dodge and Chrysler nameplates.
Not since 1960 has an automotive agency faced a similar problem. Then, too, it was Chrysler that discontinued one of its car lines, DeSoto, in a decision that cost BBDO , which had handled DeSoto since 1944, a multimillion-dollar acount.
The demise of Plymouth, which Chrysler introduced in 1928 as an alternative to lower-priced automobiles like Chevrolet and Ford --"Look at all three," early campaigns urged -- would be a blow to Bozell Inc. in Southfield, Mich. Plymouth ad spending last year totaled $36.1 million, according to Advertising Age.
And if the Eagle brand, which had an estimated $29 million in ad spending last year, goes, it would be a blow to Campbell-Mithun-Esty , which also handles that account out of Southfield, a Detroit suburb. Chrysler introduced Eagle in 1987 after acquiring American Motors, which had developed the line as an automobile companion to its Jeep sports-utility vehicles.
As a result of Chrysler's plans, each agency finds itself in a highly unusual position. Not only is each required to continue selling cars to consumers in an unruly economic climate, agency executives must somehow also sell the client, no less, on the necessity of continuing the car line itself.
"The only thing the agencies can do is to make a last-ditch effort to sell the strategy for those products and how they fit into the marketplace," said Allen A. McCusker, a principal of the Canaan Parish Group, an advertising and marketing consulting company in New Canaan, Conn.
"Go in and make a defense," he advised, "that says, 'If you spend more money and say so-and-so, we could make a business out of this.' "
Two executives who advertise automobiles not directly competitive with Plymouth or Eagle also offered suggestions.
"Either agency should not worry about itself, but about Chrysler," said Marvin Sloves, chairman and chief executive of Scali, McCabe, Sloves in New York, which handles Mercedes-Benz of North America's national account. "It's an opportunity to show you care about the client," Mr. Sloves added. "The very act of doing that, being honest and fair, might help you get more business from Chrysler."
Indeed, advertising history bolsters Mr. Sloves's argument, because BBDO did not fare too badly when Chrysler closed DeSoto. To compensate the agency for that loss, Chrysler awarded BBDO another of its accounts, Dodge, which had been at the Grant agency. And BBDO has kept Dodge to this day.
But Martin Puris, president and chief executive at Ammirati & Puris in New York, which handles BMW of North America, was less sanguine about the agencies' ability to influence Chrysler.
"An agency in this sort of situation is trapped," he said. "They can make the case for their particular brands, but in the end, the decision will be made for such a wide variety of reasons. I would say my prayers."
For whichever agency whose car line is selected to go the way of the Packard and Studebaker, the loss is likely to be cushioned by additional work that it already performs for Chrysler.
Besides Plymouth, Bozell handles advertising under the Chrysler name, for Chrysler cars, the Town and Country mini-van and corporate image ads. Chrysler ad spending totaled $119.7 million last year, according to Advertising Age.
And in addition to Eagle, Campbell-Mithun-Esty handles Jeep. According to Advertising Age, Chrysler spent $58.2 million last year on Jeep ads.

HEADLINE: AUTO RACING;
Doubts Are Disappearing As Guerrero Shows the Way

BYLINE: By JOSEPH SIANO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS, May 19

 BODY:
Roberto Guerrero is amazed, and slightly upset, at how much healthier he has looked to everyone else since May 9.
That was the day he won the pole position for the Indianapolis 500 on Sunday by clocking a speed of 232.482 miles an hour. 
 "Right now, everyone tells me, 'Well, you're finally back,' " he said last weekend, "which makes me a little mad because I've been fine for years."
What he is finally back from -- at least in the outside world's perception -- is an accident at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway on Sept. 10, 1987, that left him in a coma for several days.
 
A Four-Year Decline
 Guerrero, who was born in Colombia and is now an American citizen, finished second in a 200-mile Indy-car race in Phoenix in his return to racing in April 1988, but doubts about him persisted, probably because his career went into a four-year slide.
This month, he and his teammate, Jim Crawford of Scotland, have had the sport of Indy-car racing chasing them for a change.
"I couldn't say this place owes me something," said the 33-year-old Guerrero. "I mean, this place has been very good to me."
In his first four races here, starting in 1984, he was second, third, fourth and second, in that order, with the runner-up spot in 1987 coming after a stalled engine on a pit stop robbed him of an almost certain victory.
"It hurt me one time," he said of the Speedway, "but over all, it's come back again. It's given me probably the biggest thrill of my career, sitting on the pole here."
It also gave him a $110,000 bonus and $35,000 van for the pole spot.
Guerrero's recovery from his coma, which was caused by a tire that hit his head when his car struck the wall during a tire-testing run, was aided in large part by the devotion and persistence of his wife, Katie.
"The doctors said Katie stayed by my side every day and she talked to me," Guerrero said. "She brought our boys over. And the doctors said that, obviously, it's impossible to know how I would have recuperated if she wasn't around."
"I taped Marco a lot," Katie said, referring to their only son at the time, "and I played that. I sang children's songs every night. I just kept the chatter up.
"We have such an incredible bond. I almost felt like I was concentrating twice as much for the two of us."
Guerrero recovered fully, and before he resumed Indy-car racing in 1988, with the full support of his wife, he used video games, among other things, to sharpen his neurological system and recover the eye-hand coordination necessary in this sport of split-second decisions.
 
An Unhappy Venture
 After his successful runner-up showing in his return, his team, Vince Granatelli Racing, had trouble the rest of the year. He was eager to listen when Alfa-Romeo approached him with plans for an Indy-car engine.
He bought out his contract with Granatelli, but soon regretted it. "It's still mind-boggling to me how they could have been that bad," Guerrero said with a laugh.
Those responsible for the Indy project refused to admit that the engine was no good, so they compensated, Guerrero said, by blaming everybody, including the team owner and the driver, and everything else, including the chassis.
Guerrero's turn as a scapegoat came at the end of 1990, when Danny Sullivan replaced him.
"Then they found out it wasn't the team, it wasn't the chassis, it wasn't the driver," Guerrero said.
Guerrero, who had a year left on his contract, reached an agreement with Alfa that allowed him to drive for the team at Indy last year. After getting into an accident with another driver after only 23 laps, he was an unemployed racer.
 
Joins Bernstein Team
 Kenny Bernstein, a Dallas-based drag racer who owns the King Motorsports Indy-car team, had always been impressed by Guerrero. Bernstein let Guerrero drive one of his cars in four races after Indy, and Crawford and Guerrero began intensive testing for this year's race last September.
The two of them have been kicking the speed records here higher this month. On May 4, Crawford ran the fastest practice lap in Speedway history at 233.433 miles per hour.
Five days later, Guerrero's four-lap average of 232.482 m.p.h. obliterated Emerson Fittipaldi's two-year-old record of 225.301.

LENGTH: 360 words

HEADLINE: Licenses, and Liberty

 BODY:
The legislation is called "motor voter" for short, and by approving it today the Senate can enlarge democracy. Exhorting citizens to vote is mere piety without doing what this bill would do, make it easier to register to vote.
Barely half the eligible voters participated in the 1988 Presidential election and, given wide expressions of disgust with politics, there's no reason to think turnout will improve this year. Indeed, it can't improve much so long as only 60 percent of eligible voters are registered. 
 The "motor voter" measure holds tremendous promise for increasing registration -- to an estimated 90 percent. It would require states to allow citizens to register to vote when they apply for or renew a driver's license.
The bill is sponsored by Senator Wendell Ford, Democrat of Kentucky, and Senator Mark Hatfield, Republican of Oregon. It would also require states to permit registration by mail, instead of forcing citizens to appear in person at some municipal office, the discouraging requirement still exacted in 25 states. States would also be required to distribute registration forms and give assistance at public agencies like unemployment and welfare offices.
These common sense steps deserve the support of all who care about expanding democracy. Indeed, a similar bill passed the House in 1990 with strong bipartisan support. Yet Senate Republicans, evidently out of fear that unregistered voters are more likely to vote Democratic, have succeeded in blocking "motor voter" from even getting to the floor -- that is, until today.
By joining the present honorable band of Republicans who support the measure, Republicans like Alfonse D'Amato of New York and Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania can show the kind of bipartisanship "motor voter" needs if it's to have a realistic chance of avoiding a veto.
Opponents of "motor voter" say they're worried about cost and vote fraud. But these concerns are exaggerated. What's hard to exaggerate is the shame Americans confront in a system that leaves only six of every ten eligible voters registered. The Senate today can vote to efface that shame and enfranchise the other four.

HEADLINE: Brutal Betrayal in Thailand

 BODY:
Apologists for last year's military coup in Thailand argued that it was benign, even constructive. The democratic government it ousted was clearly corrupt. The technocrats it appointed to office were intelligent, honest and competent. And the coup's mastermind, Gen. Suchinda Kraprayoon, solemnly promised that he would never take political power into his own hands.
But constructive coups are as rare in real life as unicorns. Today, General Suchinda runs Thailand as its unelected Prime Minister. He has brought back corruption and suffocates democratic government. Worst of all, he has ordered his troops to fire their M-16's at pro-democracy demonstrators. Scores have been shot in Bangkok. Protests have spread to other cities and the death toll climbs. 
 It's up to Thai leaders, especially King Bhumibol Adulyadej, to resolve this crisis by re-establishing democratic rule. The United States can also play a useful role. Already, it has suspended most forms of cooperation with this bloodstained regime. Now it needs to denounce General Suchinda in the strongest terms.
Words matter in Thailand, especially when Washington is their source. Bangkok will go to considerable lengths to avoid jeopardizing its military and economic links to the U.S. Several weeks ago, for example, the Bush Administration eliminated a proposed prime minister from further consideration when it denounced him as a suspected drug figure and therefore ineligible to travel to the United States.
Surely Americans regard shooting peaceful demonstrators to be as repulsive as drug dealing. Declaring General Suchinda persona non grata could spur his departure or a face-saving compromise.
Chamlong Srimuang, the leader of the current protests, is a former general. But in two terms as Governor of Bangkok, he earned respect for decency, competence and devotion to democratic ideals. Those ideals are now supported by many in the urban middle and working classes.
Until recently, Thailand seemed poised for further economic gains. Now it risks being dragged down into turmoil. By putting personal ambition ahead of Thailand's best interests, General Suchinda has betrayed the rhetoric of his own coup. And he has betrayed his country.

HEADLINE: Dialogue: A Voodoo Amendment?;
Discipline Is Overdue

BYLINE: By Paul Simon; Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois, is a member of the Senate Budget Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The balanced budget constitutional amendment I have introduced now has 14 Republican and 16 Democratic co-sponsors. It is more workable than the version Ronald Reagan championed and more flexible than Thomas Jefferson's suggestion that the Constitution ban deficits.
The amendment would make fiscal responsibility the general rule instead of the rare exception. This is needed because the political will to reduce the deficit is absent in the White House and in Congress. Critics wish for the day when our leaders will come to grips with the deficit crisis without a constitutional crutch. But danger is upon us. 
 Expect new fiscal discipline under this amendment, but don't expect an ironclad guarantee. The Constitution is no place for airtight procedural details that can withstand budgetary tricks a future Administration or Congress might dream up.
The amendment requires the President to submit a balanced budget to Congress. Congress and the President must then enact and abide by annual budgets in which receipts match outlays, unless 60 percent of the House and Senate vote to set the requirement aside, for whatever reason, in any year.
If two-thirds of the House and Senate approve the amendment, it must be ratified by three-fourths of the states. It would take effect two years after ratification by the last state, perhaps five years from now, although the legislation allows seven years for ratification. Congress and the President would have several years before the starting date to begin controlling the deficit, and would have a powerful incentive to do so.
The amendment has special importance today because few if any alternatives are left. The deficit and interest payments are veering further out of control, imperiling the economy, our trading picture and our domestic obligations.
In 1986, the last time the Senate voted on a balanced budget amendment, the Federal debt was $2 trillion; by the end of 1992, it will top $4 trillion.
The rising interest payments, which the amendment would cap, are sobering. In the next fiscal year, for the first time we will spend more on gross interest -- $315 billion -- than on any budget item, including defense or Social Security. We get no education, health care, crime prevention, infrastructure and environmental protection from that money. Unless the interest figure is capped, the next 10 years will see even worse figures.
The $315 billion in interest will be America's largest income redistribution payout ever. The money will come primarily from people of limited means and go to those wealthy enough to invest in Treasury bills, more and more of whom live in countries like Saudi Arabia and Japan.
Higher interest costs and inflation that stem from the budget deficit discourage industrial investment, hurt exports, help imports and widen the trade deficit. For every dollar the budget deficit is reduced, the trade deficit will be cut 32 to 47 cents.
We rely heavily on the Social Security Trust Funds to buy Federal bonds. Starting in the year 2010, the number of retirees will rise dramatically. As payouts increase, there will be three options. We can dramatically reduce Social Security benefits, which would be extremely unpopular; dramatically raise taxes, also unpopular, or print more money, devaluing our currency. The third solution is politically the easiest, and most dangerous. Yet that's where we're headed if we don't act now.
Unless Congress discards business-as-usual, the deficit will shape our destiny. Virtually every major area of policy is being squeezed or ignored because of runaway interest payments. This should trouble liberals and conservatives, for no one's interests are served when such sums are wasted.
In an ideal world, a balanced budget amendment would not be necessary. In the real world, it is.

GRAPHIC: Drawing.

HEADLINE: Dialogue: A Voodoo Amendment?;
No Will. No Way!

BYLINE: By Rudolph G. Penner; Rudolph G. Penner directs economic studies at KPMG Peat Marwick, an accounting firm.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
If there is little political will to realize a goal, putting it into the Constitution will not help. Thus, a constitutional amendment requiring a balanced budget will work as well as the Prohibition amendment.
The futility of using constitutions to balance budgets is clear from the experience of state governments. While 49 have constitutional provisions or legislation requiring a balanced budget, many routinely resort to outrageous accounting gimmicks to "balance" budgets, and many have created "off-budget" agencies. State provisions, which generally apply only to operating budgets, often permit borrowing for capital budgets. 
 My experience watching the operation of Gramm-Rudman while director of the Congressional Budget Office in the mid-80's convinced me of the undesirability of legislating numerical goals for the deficit. Gramm-Rudman originally promised to balance the budget by fiscal 1991. The deficit that year set an all-time record. The goal was missed by $269 billion. A revised version of Gramm-Rudman postponed the goal of a balanced budget to 1993. That goal may be missed by more than $300 billion.
Some say that Gramm-Rudman, while failing miserably to achieve its explicit goals, nonetheless lowered the deficit below what it would have been otherwise. Maybe so, but the cost was too high.
Gramm-Rudman produced forecasts that promised to achieve deficit goals when there was little hope of coming close to them. It spawned accounting gimmicks that seemed to make the deficit lower than it really was. Some gimmicks cost the taxpayers money. For example, people who borrowed from the Government when interest rates were high were allowed to repay the loans early without a pre-payment penalty. This made the deficit appear lower, but the Government lost significant interest income.
More important, Gramm-Rudman encouraged Congress to behave cynically, helping to spawn the public's hostility toward Congress. The pressures Gramm-Rudman created pale beside those a constitutional amendment would create; as legislators scrambled to evade it, they would harm their own reputations and demean the Constitution.
Why am I so sure Congress would evade the amendment? First, it is impossible to write an amendment that is not easily evaded. If Congress tired of imaginative accounting, it could issue regulations mandating that business and lower-level governments provide goods and services that might otherwise be financed through the budget. Second, it is evident, after watching Congress struggle with huge deficits for 10 years, that the will to balance the budget does not exist. If raising taxes largely solved the deficit problem, the required increase would be many times the increase resulting from the 1990 budget agreement. If cuts in spending mainly solved the problem, the goal could not be reached without dramatic cuts in Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid, which together will constitute more than one-half of non-interest spending by the year 2000. The politically powerful elderly have easily thwarted cuts much smaller than those required.
A combination of tax increases and spending cuts would spread the sacrifice, but the decisions are so painful politicians have avoided debating them seriously. A cynic would say the renewal of interest in an amendment is a ploy to postpone debate further.
Some proponents of the amendment believe it would work; that assumption may be worse than an assumption that it would be impotent. The Government would raise taxes and cut spending during recessions, and programs would be turned on and off with every wiggle in tax revenues.
Some proposals for an amendment allow a 60 percent majority to approve deficit spending. It may be very difficult to break an impasse if a super-majority cannot be found to approve a deficit and a simple majority cannot be found to take the steps necessary for a balanced budget. In short, whether the amendment worked or did not work, it would be a disaster.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Adam Smith Would Bless a Balanced Budget

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Unbalanced" (editorial, May 10) predicts terrible consequences if a constitutional amendment mandating a balanced budget were to be adopted. This prediction reminds one of a drug addict's forebodings about the harmful consequences that would supposedly follow in the wake of giving up the drug habit.
To place this matter in perspective, deficit spending as a deliberate Government policy was initiated by the Administration of Franklin D. Roosevelt to counteract the depression of the 1930's. At the time, the Government's finances were in excellent shape. This reality enabled the Government to borrow money at extremely low interest rates and to extend a helping hand to the private sector. 
 The realities confronting us today are quite different. The real operating budget deficit of the Government will exceed $500 billion in 1992. The Federal debt will reach $4 trillion before the end of this year. If the Government were a private entity, it would have been declared insolvent a long time ago. The only thing that stands between the Government and bankruptcy is the Federal Reserve's ability to create new money by fiat. However, this power is subject to limitations.
Most of the Government's debt is in private hands. If investors got the impression the Federal Reserve was creating excessive amounts of fiat money, they would likely lose faith in Government obligations. Bond prices would collapse and interest rates would soar. Under these conditions, the Government would have great difficulty raising new funds to pay for deficits and money would become increasingly worthless.
In effect, if the Government does not take rational actions to balance the budget, market forces will impose their own solution, which would be far more damaging to the economy than the proposed amendment.
I propose the following measures to balance the Federal budget over the next five years: (1) Cut defense spending in half, saving $150 billion annually; (2) raise the gasoline tax by 20 cents a year until it reaches $1 per gallon, which would increase Government revenues by $100 billion; (3) levy a temporary surcharge on estate taxes to pay for the savings and loan bailout, which would raise an estimated $50 billion annually, and (4) save $100 billion annually through reduced entitlement programs and the reduction of waste and inefficiency in Government.
We have a clear choice. A continuation of massive deficit spending will bankrupt the Government, jeopardize all private wealth, risk financial crises and runaway inflation, undermine the economy, endanger democracy, enrich foreigners at the expense of the American people and compromise the independence of the United States.
In contrast, balancing the Federal budget would put the country in a favorable position to solve its problems. This approach would reverse all the harmful consequences that have resulted from chronically huge budget deficits. It would lay the foundation for wealth creation by the private sector, in turn bringing greater prosperity to all Americans.
The proposed policy would constitute a return to classical economic thinking and orthodox financial policies, as valid today as they were two centuries ago when Adam Smith presented them in "The Wealth of Nations."
 
ERNEST J. OPPENHEIMER
New York, May 13, 1992
 
The writer is the author of "Balancing the Federal Budget" (New York, 1991).

HEADLINE: 'I've Never Felt Like A Stranger at Home'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Although I too am a Japanese-American, I found David Mura's "Bashed in the U.S.A." (Op-Ed, April 29) disturbing because his attitude about his heritage and looks is, and should be, far from universal among Japanese-Americans.
I am half nisei and half sansei (second- and third-generation Japanese-American). My Japanese mother was born an American citizen and was raised on a small farm in Utah. My father was born in Japan and came to the United States at age 9. In 1951, at 40, my father was naturalized as an American citizen. This was his lifelong dream despite having lost everything during World War II when he was treated as an enemy alien. 
 My parents proudly raised my brother, sister and me as Americans. As far as I am concerned, I look, act, feel and am perceived as 100 percent American. And I never considered drilling a friend, as Mr. Mura did of his "white friend," about his or her image of me as a Japanese. I've never felt like a "stranger at home."
Mr. Mura's article exhibits an insecurity and inferiority complex I have seen in other Japanese-Americans. Japanese-Americans must stop reinforcing this complex; they must stop wondering what other people think of them. They must also stop highlighting the negative behavior of other Americans; they must stop listening to the "Japan bashers."
I do agree with Mr. Mura that there is a need to educate Americans about the Japanese, their culture and business practices. More important, Americans need to understand ethnic groups of all kinds. Let us not be defensive; that only encourages division. Let us bring back the "united" in the United States, or we will surely lose our effectiveness in the growing global economy.
 
DORI SHIMODA
Ridgefield, Conn., May 3, 1992

HEADLINE: Mexico Disaster Had Roots in Policy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The sewer explosions that killed more than 200 people, destroyed 1,422 homes, 450 businesses, 600 vehicles and turned Guadalajara, Mexico's second largest city, into a disaster area are just the tip of the iceberg.
Official unaccountability, negligence and macroeconomic mismanagement in Mexico are both chronic and rampant. As happened during the Chicago flood and the Los Angeles riots, governments seem to have no trouble in finding scapegoats at the municipal or even state levels. Mexico's attorney general has blamed local officials and the state-owned oil company, Pemex, for the explosions (news article, April 27). His investigation established that the loss of life could have been avoided if public officials had acted to evacuate residents from the area of highest risk. 
 Sadly this is true, but President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's Government is reluctant to address the disaster's underlying causes and to face its own responsibilities for the ailing oil sector. Pemex has had its budget slashed since 1987. Acceptance of International Monetary Fund and World Bank guidelines has meant that all of its net pretax profit of $36 billion during the last five years was sent to the Treasury, leaving the company financially depleted.
Thus, while Pemex now provides more than 30 percent of Government revenue, its oil and gas distribution system is shrinking. Since 1990 more than 125,000 workers who handle the nuts and bolts of the oil industry have been fired. Official sources report the transportation fleet went from an estimated capacity of 214,500 cubic meters to just 185,700 from 1990 to 1991, and the tanker truck fleet collapsed to its lowest level since 1981.
The national gas and oil pipeline distribution system is crumbling because there is no money for maintenance, much less for the required expansion. According to the United States Embassy in Mexico and the General Accounting Office, the accumulated lack of investment in Pemex over the last decade has created a major bottleneck that now impedes Mexican industrial development.
Perhaps it is more than just an irony, but while the Salinas administration weakens Pemex's infrastructure, the Bush Presidency exerts pressure for its privatization, while proposing huge tax breaks for our own oil and gas industry.
In the burning and devastated areas of Guadalajara, we daily experience the human and material impact of these senseless policies.
 
JOHN SAXE-FERNANDEZ
Ciudad Universitaria, Mexico
PUB-DATE: May 7, 1992
 
The writer is a professor of political science at the National University of Mexico.

HEADLINE: New York State Colleges Need a Fiscal Pledge for the Future;
What's at Stake

 BODY:
To the Editor:
We cannot pretend to offer quality higher education through our state's public and private institutions without paying for it, one way or another, as your April 22 editorial "Higher Education -- or Lower?" indicates. State financing for higher education -- public and private -- is sadly out of sync with expectations for quality.
Even in these dire economic times, action is possible right now. We can begin immediately by formulating (at long last) a coherent, rational public policy for higher education. What's at stake is not simply the future of our colleges and universities. Hanging in the balance is the educated work force that the modern industrial economy requires -- and, more important, the future of our children.
 
DENNIS O'BRIEN
Albany, May 1, 1992
 
The writer, president of the University of Rochester, is chairman of the Commission on Independent Colleges and Universities.

HEADLINE: Theater in Review

BYLINE: By D.J.R. BRUCKNER

 BODY:

Testimony
Henry Street Settlement's
Louis Abrons Arts Center
466 Grand Street
Lower Manhattan
 
By Safiya Henderson-Holmes; directed by Raina von Waldenburg; set, Nathan Jones; lighting, Marty Liquori. New Federal Theater, Woodie King Jr., producer, Shoestring Productions, Lynn K. Pannell, artistic director and producer.
WITH: Marty Liquori, Julie Bray-Morris, Mantee M. Murphy and Sonita Surratt.
There seems to be no bottom to the personal suffering caused by the racial animosity that Safiya Henderson-Holmes explores in her second play, "Testimony." 
 It is possible that the recent riots in Los Angeles give this play greater resonance. But one would guess this it would leave most people stunned and shocked even if the surface tranquillity of this troubled society had never been ripped apart. This young playwright is a poet who knows how to make words bite and gnaw.
The testimony of the title comes entirely from one young black woman, Jacintha (Sonita Surratt), being held in a New York City prison on a murder charge. A white psychiatrist (Julie Bray-Morris) is interviewing Jacintha. The session is audiotaped by a black technician (Mantee M. Murphy) while a white technician (Marty Liquori) makes a videotape that can be seen on two monitors, even though the interrogation frequently lunges beyond the gaze of the red eye.
Ms. Surratt meets a formidable acting challenge. Jacintha has several personalities, each with her own exquisitely devious program for concealing truth as a tale of appalling abuse and hopeless longing unfolds. The abuse comes from her mother, her employer, her neighbors -- the whole world, it seems -- and all of it is based on color. Ms. Surratt positively pulls the audience through this terrible labyrinth with her.
Ms. Henderson-Holmes still has things to learn about playwriting, mostly about economy. Her faults are those of generous youth: she tries to include everything imaginable about all her characters, and at times her story wanders beyond the attention of even the most alert audience. The director, Raina von Waldenburg, has a hard job trying to hold it all together. But Ms. Henderson-Holmes can surely write, passionately; her characters speak with absolute conviction, and often nobly, even when they mean to evade or deceive.
