HEADLINE: Dial Direct To Moscow And Beyond

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The former Soviet Union, which only last year could receive fewer telephone calls from beyond its borders than a medium-size Manhattan apartment building, got direct-dial service yesterday to more than 2,000 cities in 15 republics. For the first time, calls from the United States do not need the help of an American operator and are not shuffled through the inefficient and sternly monitored lines in Moscow.
But the former Soviet Union still has relatively few lines, antiquated equipment, some of which predates the 1917 Revolution, and is hemmed in by restrictions by the West on how much and what kind of advanced equipment it can buy. For these reasons, the new republics will still only have the telephone abilities of a large Manhattan apartment building.
 
Many Calls Don't Get Through
 There are now 421 international long-distance circuits, quadruple the number only nine months ago, when the former Soviet Union had 91 circuits, enough for only 91 simultaneous conversations. In A.T.& T.'s Network Operating Center in Bedminster, N.J., which monitors the world's telephone traffic, the first three letters of Moscow on a map of the world are permanently lighted in red, indicating that a large number of calls cannot get through. 
 "Telecommunications is vitally important to the Soviet economy," said Donald H. Morrison, A.T.& T.'s regional managing director with responsibility for the former Soviet Union. "It is an accelerator and the lack of it is a brake." Mr. Morrison spoke in a telephone interview yesterday from Amsterdam, on his way to Moscow to negotiate new telecommunications agreements.
Domestic long-distance and local service is not much better.
There are perhaps 200 million or more traditional and cellular telephones dispersed throughout the United States, with a population of 250 million. By contrast, there are 40 million poorly operating telephones in the new republics, with a population of 290 million. Most of the phones are in Moscow, St. Petersburg and a few other cities.
In Moscow, only 40 percent of local and long-distance phone calls are completed, compared with more than 99 percent in the United States. In other big cities of the ex-Soviet Union, and especially the smaller towns, the completion rate falls even lower.
Depending on demand, which is expected to total millions of attempted calls a day, Americans will still find it difficult to get through and will get a recording advising them to call back later because all circuits are busy.
While phone calls to the former Soviet republics are still expensive, they will no longer carry the operator charges of $3 for station-to-station calls or $6 for person-to-person calls.
 
Range of Rates
 Rates will range from economy periods, or 2 A.M. to 7 A.M. in the various time zones of the United States, to discount periods, or 7 A.M. to 1 P.M., to standard periods, or 1 P.M. to 2 A.M. The charges are based on when networks are busiest in the United States, typically daylight hours for businesses and evening hours for consumers. The economy period will cover daylight hours in Moscow and most big cities, which are 7 hours ahead of New York and 10 hours ahead of San Francisco.
A 10-minute economy call will thus cost $15.65 and a standard call $20.34. The old rates were the same, but calls were more expensive because of the operator surcharges.
As recently as 1987, A.T.& T., the only big international carrier in the region, had only 16 long-distance circuits, enough for 16 conversations. Nine months ago, it had 91, 24 of which were granted on an Eastern bloc communications satellite.
The bulk of the additional circuits, 180, are in the Armenian republic, with the remainder on Intersputnik, an Eastern bloc satellite, and in land lines in Moscow, St. Petersburg and Ukraine. Leased lines from eight other countries, including France and Australia, also help to complete the network.
 
More Lines Are Planned
 A.T.& T. has plans to add several hundred circuits by the end of the year and would like to add as many as 1,600 circuits as soon as the authorities in Russia and the other republics permit. A great deal of the problem, however, is in paying for the equipment with scarce hard currency.
In Armenia, however, the authorities pay for A.T.& T. equipment and services through charging A.T.& T. for completing incoming calls over the Armenian local network. And to help modernize telecommunications, Russia, as well as the other republics, is seeking foreign partners and financing that does not require hard currency.
In March, an international organization appeared headed toward a relaxation of export controls to the former Soviet Union, but only weeks before a June 1 meeting in Paris of the group, the relaxation is in doubt. Agreement within the group, the Coordinating Committee on Multilateral Export Controls, or Cocom, appears to be foundering because of a disagreement among countries over the exact kind of telecommunications equipment that can be sold in the ex-Soviet Union.
 
High-Capacity Lines
 For example, Western countries may sell Russia fiber-optic lines able of carrying 45 million bits of information a second, or at least 2,800 conversations, but can sell China more advanced fiber-optic lines capable of carrying 140 million bits, or nearly 9,000 conversations. By contrast, United States companies can use equipment with two-billion-bit capacity or more.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 25, 1992, Monday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Wednesday about direct-dial telephone service to former Soviet republics omitted one carrier that provides it. In addition to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, with 421 long-distance circuits, the Sprint Corporation has supplied 23 international direct-dial circuits since January in conjunction with the IDB Communications Group.

HEADLINE: U.S. Caps Amount Of Interest Offered By Weakest Banks

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20

 BODY:
The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation placed new limits today on the rates that the nation's weaker banks and savings and loans can offer customers. The move, a step toward reregulating interest rates, will make it easier for strong banks to grow and harder for some weak banks to survive.
The new rules, which stem from a banking law passed by Congress in 1991, separate the nation's 14,370 banks and savings and loans into three classes, based on their ability to absorb losses. Only the financially healthiest institutions will be allowed to pay whatever interest rates they choose, which will mean less competition for deposits and far fewer -- if any -- opportunities for savers to find exceptionally high rates paid by some banks and savings and loans. 
 The effect of the rules, which will take effect June 16, will bar the weakest banks and savings and loans from bidding up interest rates to attract deposits. That was a common practice in the 1980's, when tiny savings and loans grew by paying premiums for deposits that allowed them to make bigger and riskier loans. The tactic engendered a "hot money" market in which individual deposits and those collected by brokers chased the highest rates in the country.
The practice helped cause the savings crisis to snowball. As loan losses mounted, some savings and loans kept bidding up interest rates to attract deposits in order to stay afloat. As they delayed their demise, losses continued driving up the cost of the savings bailout.
Banking officials said today's decision was significant because the new classifications for the nation's banks might be used by regulators to determine which financial institutions would pay higher premiums for Federal deposit insurance, along the lines of a recent proposal by the F.D.I.C. The categories may also determine the banks that might someday be allowed to expand into the securities or insurance businesses.
"We feel this decision is very significant," said Christopher Reick, a spokesman for the American Bankers Association. "It will have future implications on all kinds of other issues."
C. C. Hope, a member of the F.D.I.C. board, protested the new rules, saying it would be improper for the agency to take the weighty step of getting back into the business of regulating interest rates. Interest rate ceilings on savings accounts were largely removed in the early 1980's and totally phased out in 1986.
F.D.I.C. officials estimated today that 8,900, or more than 72 percent, of the nation's 12,300 commercial banks would be classified as well capitalized; 3,000, or 24 percent, as adequately capitalized, and 400, or 3 percent, as undercapitalized.
 
Banks Not Named
 Of the nation's 2,070 savings and loans, 1,150 of them, or just 56 percent, would be categorized as well capitalized; 580, or 28 percent, as adequately capitalized and 330, or 16 percent, as undercapitalized. Individual institutions were not named. The F.D.I.C. said a higher percentage of banks in the American heartland would be classified as well capitalized because they traditionally have been very careful about their capital bases.
Under the rules, the weakest, or undercapitalized, institutions will be barred from using brokers as well as offering high rates, while a middle tier of institutions that meet minimum capital standards set by regulators will be able to use brokers or offer higher-than-average interest rates only if they receive a waiver from the F.D.I.C.
According to the F.D.I.C., 800 of the nation's 12,300 commercial banks and 260 of the 2,070 savings and loans now accept brokered deposits. Under current rules, undercapitalized institutions can receive a waiver to accept brokered or high-interest-rate deposits, but once the new rules go into effect they will be unable to do so. F.D.I.C. officials estimate that 90 undercapitalized banks and 65 savings and loans that now use brokered deposits will have to stop accepting them.
F.D.I.C. officials acknowledge that the new rules may drive some weak savings and loans under and force the Federal Government to step in and run them. But these officials say Congress wanted the F.D.I.C. to make sure that banks and savings and loans abandoned the unhealthy practice of living off costly brokered money.
 
Experts Defend Move
 Banking experts said it was not unwise or unhealthy to allow well-capitalized banks to use brokered or high-interest deposits. The new rules will give well-capitalized banks greater flexibility to expand than other banks.
The rules define well-capitalized banks as those with capital exceeding 10 percent of their risk-adjusted assets and whose core capital, or money paid in for common stock, exceeds 5 percent of their total assets. In addition, well-capitalized banks cannot have been classified as troubled by Federal regulators.
In determining a bank's capital adequacy, regulators weigh the riskiness of a bank's loans or other assets. Thus, when a bank holds safe assets, like Government securities, it might be required to hold less capital reserves as compared with capital required for riskier real estate loans.
The definition of a well-capitalized bank is considerably more stringent than that of the 1988 agreement signed in Basel, Switzerland, setting capital adequacy standards for the world's banks. Under that agreement a well-capitalized bank must have capital equal to at least 8 percent of its risk-adjusted assets.
The rules also state that an undercapitalized bank or savings and loan is one that fails to meet the minimum capital requirement of its principal Federal regulator. Generally, then, an institution will be classified as undercapitalized if its capital is less than 8 percent of its risk-adjusted assets.
Under the new rules, an adequately capitalized institution would have capital that represents 8 to 10 percent of its risk-adjusted assets.
 
Complaints by Banks
 Many American banks have complained in light of the nation's long recession and loan losses from the depressed real estate market that the capital rules were making it difficult for them to grow.
Commenting on today's announcement, an official at a large New York City bank who spoke on the condition of anonymity said, "The worrisome thing to us is the effect that continuously more stringent capital definitions can have on the efficient operation of the United States financial system and its international competitiveness."
Under the new rules, well-capitalized institutions may pay whatever interest rates they choose.
But an adequately capitalized bank or savings and loan may not, without a waiver, accept or renew deposits that exceed by more than half a percentage point the effective yield paid on deposits of comparable size and maturity in its market area. Thus, if the local rate on savings accounts averages 4 percent, the bank or savings and loan may pay up to 4.5 percent.
For deposits from outside its market area, an adequately capitalized institution may not, without a waiver, pay interest of more than half a percentage point above the national rate. That rate is to be determined by adding one percentage point to "the current yield of similar-maturity U.S. Treasury obligations."
For example, if a six-month Treasury bill pays 4 percent interest, the national rate on a six-month certificate of deposit would be 5 percent and the adequately capitalized institution could pay at most 5.5 percent. For accounts of more than double the $100,000 federally insured limit, the national rate would be one and a half percentage points above the yield of a comparable Treasury security.
According to the rules, if the interest rate paid on comparable Treasury securities exceeds 10 percent, the national rate will be 1.5 percentage points above that. For deposits exceeding $200,000, the national rate would be 2 percentage points above the Treasury rate.
Undercapitalized institutions are even more restricted. They may accept deposits only when their yield does not exceed by more than half a percentage point the prevailing yield of insured deposits of comparable maturity in the institution's local area.

HEADLINE: AID PLAN DRAFTED FOR ATOMIC SAFETY IN EASTERN EUROPE

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VIENNA, May 20

 BODY:
President Bush and the leaders of the other six major industrial democracies are expected to endorse a multibillion-dollar plan for improving the safety of nuclear reactors in the former Soviet Union and Eastern Europe at their economic summit meeting in Munich in early July.
The plan, which is being prepared with advice from officials at the International Atomic Energy Agency here, would provide for refitting of some reactors with more modern safety features, the closing down of those considered too unsafe to be worth saving and the provision of alternative sources of electricity, including supplies from Western Europe, according to diplomats and agency officials here.
 
Billions to Prevent Catastrophe
 Estimates of the cost of such a program, which is designed to prevent another nuclear catastrophe like the one in Chernobyl, vary from $10 billion to $20 billion. The idea is to find this money over several years from a number of sources, including direct government grants, guaranteed government loans and loans from such development institutions as the World Bank, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the European Community's European Investment Bank. 
 Germany's Environment Minister, Klaus Topfer, said last month that the cost of such an assistance program would be around $9 billion. The United States has told the International Atomic Energy Agency that it might cost between $11 billion and $20 billion.
"At present it looks 90 percent certain the Munich summit will back the program and we hope this agency will provide its secretariat in partnership with the Brussels Commission of the European Community," said Morris Rosen, Assistant Deputy Director General of the International Atomic Energy Agency and head of its Nuclear Safety Division.
 
Concern Over Safety
 The so-called Group of Seven countries -- which, besides the United States, includes Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan -- first expressed concern about the safety of nuclear reactors in East Europe and the Soviet Union at their 1989 Paris meeting, three years after the Cher nobyl disaster. Last year, at their London meeting, they urged Western countries to help raise safety standards in the former Communist world.
After the appeal at the London meeting, the so-called Group of 24, a body set up by all Western industrialized countries to coordinate aid to the former Communist world, created a special working group to examine the nuclear safety problem in cooperation with the Brussels Commission of the European Community.
But while this led to several Western governments offering help to Eastern countries to make their reactors safer, officials at the atomic energy agency said the aid is uncoordinated, duplicative and far less effective than the program they expect to be approved at the Munich meeting.
 
Companies Need Orders
 Just how specific a commitment the Group of Seven countries will give to make the East's nuclear power industry safer still remains uncertain.
[In Washington, a Congressional expert on nuclear energy voiced support for such a plan. Representative Norman D. Dicks, Democrat of Washington and a member of the House Appropriations Committee, said he believed the Bush Administration should do more "to work with the Soviets regarding their unsafe reactors."
["This is more serious than dismantling nuclear weapons," Representative Dicks said. "We can get a lot of support for this in the Congress."]
Officials of the atomic energy agency said such a program for the former Communist world's nuclear power industry would also be attractive for American and European nuclear companies, which are starved for new orders because of environmental opposition to nuclear power and the fact that the low price of oil and gas currently makes nuclear-generated electricity relatively expensive.
France, which has invested more heavily in nuclear power than other industrialized countries, is especially anxious for contracts to upgrade East Europe's reactors. But Germany's nuclear industry has been hit as well by that country's ecological movement.
Speaking in Budapest last month, the head of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, Jacques Attali, said the international community should "mobilize itself in order not only to finance the closing of the most dangerous nuclear power plants, but also to bring together the human and technological resources needed to rehabilitate that portion of the stock of nuclear power plants which can be brought up to a satisfactory safety level." He said the bank would be ready to take part in lending operations up to some $4 billion for this purpose.
Germany and France are leading the drive for such a campaign, warning that another nuclear disaster like one at Chernobyl would deal a devastating blow to public confidence in nuclear power around the world and further cripple the West's nuclear industry.
"We must protect Western nuclear investment by making sure there is no catastrophic accident in the East," Mr. Topfer, the German Environment Minister, told the Japan Atomic Industrial Forum in Yokohama in April.
 
Safety Standards Urged
 Germany is also pushing for a new international convention that would set obligatory reactor safety standards replacing existing national norms. Experts said the German plan would effectively close most, if not all, existing Soviet-designed power reactors.
But the experts said that shutting down the former Communist world's Soviet-designed power reactors temporarily to make them safer or closing these plants altogether will be difficult to organize because these countries are heavily dependent on nuclear-generated electricity. Hungary gets 50 percent of its power from nuclear reactors while Bulgaria gets 35.7 percent, Czechoslovakia 28.4 percent and the territories of the former Soviet Union 12.2 percent.
Reactors that cannot be made substantially safer are likely to be replaced with other fossil fuel power plants, which are far cheaper to build. But Czechoslovakia has already said it wants to replace its Soviet reactors with safer Western ones if it can find the money because it does not wish to increase pollution by burning more of its own brown coal.
The officials of the Group of Seven countries who prepare the annual economic summit meetings have created a special subcommittee to draft a declaration on nuclear safety in the East. It met in Cologne earlier this week.
 
16 Chernobyl Reactors
 The territories of the former Soviet Union have 16 large graphite reactors of the kind that exploded at Chernobyl. The atomic energy agency considers the safety of these reactors "a matter of great international concern."
Reactors of the type used at Chernobyl currently provide 47.8 percent of the nuclear-generated electricity in the countries of the former Soviet Union.
The continuing deficiences of these reactors were highlighted a few weeks ago when a reactor of this type near the major Russian city of St. Petersburg sprang a leak that resulted in a small quantity of radioactive material escaping into the atmosphere.
Soviet-designed reactors of all types make up 11 percent of the world's operating reactors and 32 percent of those currently under construction, according to a new study by the atomic energy agency. Of the pressurized water reactors, which are known as W.W.E.R.'s and are the only type to have been exported by the Soviet Union, there are a total of 41 in operation and 31 more under construction.
All of the W.W.E.R. reactors, the agency said, "lack important safety features which are basic to similar pressurized water reactors in the West." Their weaknesses include lack of a containment system to prevent accidental radioactive emissions from leaking into the atmosphere as well as deficient controls and insufficient fire protection.
 
10 Still in Operation
 The least safe reactors, in the atomic energy agency's view, are the first generation pressurized water reactors known as W.W.E.R.-230's. Ten of these early reactors are still in operation. Four of them are in Russia, two near the Finnish border, four more are in Bulgaria and two are in Czechoslovakia.
The former East Germany had four of these reactors, but after reunification the Bonn Government ordered them permanently closed for safety reasons, replacing the lost power without difficulty from plants in the western half of Germany. Armenia also closed its reactors of this type when it became independent, citing safety considerations and saying they had also been built in a region where earthquakes occur.
Last year the agency recommended that Bulgaria permanently close its four W.W.E.R.-230's. But the Sofia Government refused, saying it could not accept the electricity shortages this would create. But it has agreed to shut down two of them temporarily while new safety features are installed.
In its new report, the atomic agency reckons that the 10 functioning W.W.E.R.-230's together have about 50 serious safety faults, which would cost some $200 million to $400 million per reactor to rectify. They also have 50 other less serious safety defects, which would cost an additional $50 million per reactor to resolve.
A later generation of the same reactor, called the W.W.E.R.-213, is considered safer but still needs more modern instruments and other improvements, the agency said. Finland, which has two, has already made these changes, introducing German technology. But Russia, Hungary and Czechoslovakia, with a total of 14 among them, have not yet done so.
Two reactors of this type are also under construction in Cuba.
A 1,000-megawatt version of the W.W.E.R. is considered by the agency to incorporate relatively good safety features, which would probably contain any radioactive leak. But this reactor's operating controls are said to be old-fashioned. Bulgaria is the only country outside the former Soviet Union to have a reactor of this type.

HEADLINE: Macy Says It Will Close 8 Stores, Including 4 in the New York Area

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
R. H. Macy & Company said yesterday that it would close eight department stores, including four in the New York region, by Aug. 1 as part of its effort to restore the financial health of its bankrupt business.
Macy's departures will leave many neighborhoods bereft of department stores that served as the centerpieces of once-thriving urban hubs like the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, downtown Newark and Main Street in Columbia, S.C. 
 In addition to those stores, the company is shutting Macy's stores in New Rochelle, N.Y.,; Plainfield, N.J.,; Cockeysville, Md., near Baltimore, and Avondale, Ga., near Atlanta. It will also close one of the department stores in its Bullock's chain, in La Habra, Calif. About 1,850 employees will be affected by the closings, but Macy said it would work to find jobs elsewhere in the company for as many of them as possible.
 
Reaction by Civic Officials
 Although Macy, which also operates the I. Magnin department store chain, had warned that it would close a handful of its less profitable stores, some officials in the affected cities and communities said yesterday that they were surprised and saddened by the announcement.
The decision also means that in less than a week the New York region has essentially lost 15 department stores.Alexander's Inc. closed its 11 stores last Friday.
Economic analysts said the blight among the area's traditional merchants was reaching a crisis and damaging New York's cachet as the capital of the global retail industry.
 
'Detrimental Impact'
 "Grand stores are still part of the world image for New York," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. "The turmoil going on in the retail industry has an especially detrimental impact here because it tarnishes that image."
The concerns were similar in other cities.
"Macy's was the last large department store downtown," said John Bowers, manager of government affairs for the Greater Columbia Chamber of Commerce. "It's just going to add to the perception here and everywhere, really, that Main Street is unhealthy."
Some of the stores being closed are among a handful of large retailers that remained in inner-city neighborhoods long after their most affluent shoppers fled to the suburbs. And since several of the stores serve largely black and Hispanic neighborhoods, some retail analysts, who refused to be named, said the closings could be construed as having racial overtones.
In response, a Macy official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said, "Macy continues to operate stores in major urban areas and is the only retail company to operate stores in all five boroughs of New York." He added that a high proportion of Macy's 65,000 employees nationally are from minority groups. The closings will leave the company with 112 stores across the country.
Macy also plans to build or lease new stores in the downtown areas of Pittsburgh, Denver and Providence, R.I.
The Newark Macy's opened in 1928 as Bamberger's, the flagship of what became a large New Jersey chain. The chain was bought by the Macy company, which kept operating it as Bamberger's before eventually changing the stores' names to Macy's.
 
Reasons Given by Macy
 In its statement on the stores being closed, Macy cited declining sales, poor growth potential in the markets they served and the need for costly renovations and improvements as among the reasons for giving up on them.
Macy has other stores that have not done well during the recession but believes that those stores have stronger potential for recovery when the economy rebounds, people familiar with the company's strategy said.
Judge Burton R. Lifland of the Federal Bankruptcy Court, who is presiding over Macy's bankruptcy case, and Macy's creditors would have to agree formally to the store closings but were not expected to object.
"We thought there had to be some store closings, and these stores were logical ones to close," said Robert M. Miller, partner at Berlack, Israels & Liberman, the law firm representing Macy's bondholders.
 
Customers' Memories
 Others were more nostalgic, dredging up childhood memories of wandering the stores' wide aisles on Saturday afternoons and playing on the rickety wooden escalators that became a hallmark of some of Macy's older stores.
Customers like Naomi Fisch remembered how she had eagerly awaited the annual back-to-school shopping spree at the Macy's on Flatbush Avenue, which opened in 1948.
Ms. Fisch, an account manager at a large marketing-support company in New Jersey, recalled using a gift certificate she had received upon her graduation from eighth grade to purchase a brown suede handbag.
"It was twice as much as I had ever spent on a bag before, but I had that gift certificate and I just loved that bag," she said. "I carried it for years. I wonder what ever happened to it."
 
Effect of Kings Plaza Opening
 But then Macy opened a big, modern new store in Kings Plaza, only five miles from the Flatbush store but light years away in terms of atmosphere, convenience and space. And when Ms. Fisch moved to Hillsboro, N.J., 10 years ago, she found an even newer, nicer Macy's store to shop at.
"Macy's signed its own death warrant on Flatbush Avenue when it opened Kings Plaza," Ms. Fisch said. "Why would you go to a small, rinky-dink department store when you could go to a mall, which had Macy's plus lots of other stores -- and it had parking."
Ms. Fisch's memories tell the story behind almost all the store closings Macy announced yesterday. As people left the city and moved to the suburbs, retailers set up shop there, too. As Macy's suburban stores contributed more and more to the retailer's bottom line, more and more of the money Macy spent for renovations and modernizations was spent on those stores.
 
2.6% of Company Sales
 In 1991, the eight stores Macy is closing had revenues of about $175 million, or just 2.6 percent of the company's total sales of $6.7 billion. "These were small stores, and they have gotten less and less profitable as the suburbs grew," said Walter F. Loeb, a retail consultant who once worked at the Macy's on Flatbush Avenue. "Today, Macy is used to running $60 million stores at the least."
He said Macy might still close a few other stores, although the company has said there will be no further store closings. It has already announced the closing of five I. Magnin stores and 57 other specialty outlets.
In some of the cities where the company will close a store, Macy's was the last major department store in the downtown area. Macy's has been the only major department store in New Rochelle since Bloomingdale's left 15 years ago, and community leaders worried about the impact the store's closing would have on a 28-store mall at the intersection of Le Count Place and Main Street.
"It's a definite blow to the economy here," said Robert J. Streger, president of the New Rochelle Chamber of Commerce.
But he said local business people were not surprised. Rumors that the store might close had circulated since Macy filed for bankruptcy protection on Jan. 27 and announced it would close some stores. Macy's newer, larger store in White Plains had siphoned off business from the New Rochelle store for some time.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money Market Fund Yields Show Mixed Trend in Week

 BODY:
Yields offered by money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed in the latest reporting week, with tax-exempt yields falling while taxable yields were unchanged.
The tax-exempt yields fell for the second straight week. Walter K. Frank, the chief economist at Donoghue's, said that it was possible that rates could rise just a little in the weeks ahead. This is because the recent fall was in anticipation by many analysts of a cut in official interest rates by the Federal Reserve. But Mr. Frank said that he did not expect the Fed to cut rates in the near term. 
 The seven-day compounded average yield for tax-exempt funds fell by 4 basis points, to 3.08 percent in the latest reporting week. The simple yield also dropped 4 basis points, to 3.03 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
 
Higher Long-Term Yields
 In the same period, the 30-day compounded average yield rose 6 basis points, to 3.14 percent, and the 30-day simple yield increased by 5 basis points, to 3.09 percent.
Donoghue's said the average number of days left to maturity of securities held in tax-exempt portfolios dropped by a day, to 52 days.
In its weekly survey of tax-exempt funds with assets greater than $100 million, Donoghue's said that the Fidelity Spartan Municipal Money Fund offered the best return, at 3.97 percent. The fund's distributor is the Fidelity Distributors Corporation of Boston.
Donoghue's reported that the assets of taxable money market funds rose by $1.1 billion in the week that ended Tuesday, to $492.8 billion. Institutional assets grew by $1.7 billion, to $165.9 billion, while retail assets fell by $600 million, to $326.9 billion.
 
7-Day Taxables Unchanged
 The average seven-day taxable compounded yield was unchanged at 3.57 percent, and the simple yield was also unchanged, at 3.51 percent. For the 30-day compounded average, the yield was 3.61 percent, down 2 basis points, with the simple yield down 3 basis points, to 3.54 percent.
The Olde Premium Plus Money Market Series repeated again as the best performer, with a return of 4.41 percent, down 4 basis points from its best yield last week. The fund is distributed by the Olde Discount Corporation of Detroit.
By comparison, the average bank money market account, a prime competitor of the money funds, is yielding 3.44 percent.

HEADLINE: Man Pleads Guilty In Smuggling Case

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 20

 BODY:
A former South African military officer pleaded guilty today in Federal District Court here to a single charge stemming from a smuggling operation that brought rhinoceros horns and the heads and skins of other endangered species into the United States.
The plea by Marius Meiring, 44 years old, once the second-highest ranking South African Defense Force officer in Namibia, ends a case that started with a sting operation conducted in part by United States wildlife and firearms agents in 1988. 
 Conservationists have said that the case is important because it sheds light on a thriving underground economy that threatens the black rhinoceros with extinction.
Powdered rhinoceros horn is prized as a medicine and an aphrodisiac in East Asia and other markets, including some in the United States, where it reportedly has sold for as much as $2,500 per kilogram. In the Connecticut case involving Mr. Meiring and nine others, including the officer's wife, a single horn was purchased by Federal agents for $30,000.
Conservation officials hope that Mr. Meiring's expected cooperation with law-enforcement agencies will lead to further inquiries into what they believe is complicity in poaching and smuggling among South African Defense Force officers and government officials in southern Africa.
The smuggling began with South African soldiers procuring rhinoceros horns, as well as automatic rifles, during recent wars in Namibia and Angola, according to court documents. South African military vehicles were used to ship horns from Angola to Namibia, prosecutors say.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Greeted as a Friend In the Dominican Republic

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Re public, May 20

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins took his Caribbean campaign to the Dominican Republic today, where he received a rousing welcome from the leaders and people of this nation, which has the fastest-growing immigrant population in New York City.
For today, at least, it appeared that Mr. Dinkins had left his highly publicized problems with Hispanic leaders and citizens behind in Puerto Rico, where for two days he was accused of political opportunism. 
 In sharp contrast to Puerto Rican leaders' stiff criticism that Mayor Dinkins is insensitive to their needs, Dominican leaders here and in New York said in interviews that they fully support Mr. Dinkins because he has helped their expanding community in New York.
Last night, the Mayor of Santo Domingo, Rafael Corporan de los Santos, announced his endorsement of Mr. Dinkins for re-election for next year. "Because Mayor Dinkins is so concerned with the fate of Dominicans in New York, it obligates me to endorse him."
 
Serious Remaining Problems
 Specifically, the Dominican leaders said Mr. Dinkins had announced new health-care programs last month in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan, which has the largest concentration of Dominicans in the United States. The Mayor has also appointed Dominicans to high positions in his administration and has invited community leaders to take part in city planning sessions, the leaders said.
But equally important, the leaders said, is that Mr. Dinkins, who is black, serves as an important role model for Dominicans, who are of African, European and Indian descent.
"We feel very different about the Mayor than most other Hispanic groups," said Dr. Rafael Lantigua, director of the National Council of Dominican Americans, a nonprofit advocacy group for Dominican New Yorkers. "We like him because Mr. Dinkins has been a friend of the Dominican community, and it makes us proud to have an African-American as Mayor."
But Dr. Lantigua, who is a professor of medicine at the College of Physicians and Surgeons at Columbia University, said Dominicans were still plagued by serious problems like health care, housing, education and unemployment, and that he hoped Mr. Dinkins would learn of those issues during his visit here.
While Mr. Dinkins will spend a little more than 24 hours in this nation of six million people, the Mayor plans to meet with President Joaquin Balaguer, attend a reception in his honor at the American Embassy, visit a children's hospital and receive an honorary degree from the Universidad Autonoma de Santo Domingo.
It is estimated that 350,000 to 500,000 people of Dominican ancestry live in New York City, mainly in upper Manhattan. About 20,000 Dominicans immigrate legally to New York each year.
 
'He Cared Enough to Stop By'
 Mr. Dinkins said at a meeting with reporters, "If I can better understand the needs of and the challenges faced by the Dominican people during my short stay here, upon my return to New York I can work to build a government which better serves those of your fathers and mothers, sons and daughters, who have graced my city with their talents."
Beatrice Cruz, a foster mother who was returning to the Dominican Republic from visiting her three sisters in New York, clapped her hands when she saw Mayor Dinkins enter the airline terminal.
"It's wonderful that he cared enough to stop by and see us," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayor David N. Dinkins tying on a surgical mask before he entered the AIDS ward at the San Juan Medical Center yesterday in Puerto Rico. After the hospital visit, the Mayor traveled to the Dominican Republic. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Director Admits C.I.A. Fell Short In Predicting the Soviet Collapse

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20

 BODY:
Responding to criticism that the Central Intelligence Agency failed to forecast the collapse of the Soviet system, its director, Robert M. Gates, today conceded shortcomings in the agency's analysis, but defended its overall performance over the years.
In a speech to the Foreign Policy Association in New York, Mr. Gates, the Director of Central Intelligence, said that although the agency wrote many assessments describing a growing crisis in the Soviet Union, it was not until 1989 that agency analysts began "to think that the entire edifice might well collapse." 
 Mr. Gates also acknowledged that the agency's statistical analysis portrayed a stronger and larger economy than the one that existed in reality. "From a personal standpoint," he added, "I would contend also that our quantitative analysis always considerably understated the real burden economically of the Soviet military."
During his confirmation hearings last fall, Mr. Gates was widely criticized for having promoted a view of an expansionist, invulnerable Soviet Union in more than a dozen speeches and articles between 1986 and 1988, when he was a senior C.I.A. official. The agency was also faulted for exaggerating the economic and military strength of the Soviet Union.
Adm. Stansfield Turner, who was Director of Central Intelligence from 1977 to 1981, complained in an article last year in the journal Foreign Affairs about "revisionist rumblings that the C.I.A. did in fact see the Soviet collapse emerging after all."
"On this one," Admiral Turner added, "the corporate view missed by a mile."
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, who wrote in 1979 that the Soviet Union would break up in the 1980's, has called for the dissolution of the agency. The Senate and House intelligence committees have introduced bills calling for sweeping reorganization of the entire intelligence apparatus of the Government.
But Mr. Gates, citing hundreds of assessments, briefings and monographs produced over the last three decades, maintained that the C.I.A. had accurately described the weaknesses of the Soviet Union, including the economic distortion from its extraordinary investment in the military.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo;
Anxious Days for Bush's Campaign As G.O.P. Heads Into a 3-Way Race

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20

 BODY:
Few Republicans would trade their troubles for the Democrats', but these are anxious days in the President's party.
Most of the Republican scripts for this election have not been working. The economy is recovering, but only sluggishly, and the President's job approval rating is moving even less. 
 The Democrats have produced a bruised and little-known likely nominee, which Republicans generally count on, but President Bush is also faced with a powerful and healthy third force in Ross Perot. Mr. Bush found it necessary last weekend to predict that he would carry his adopted state of Texas, an almost poignant display of bravado toward Mr. Perot, the Dallas billionaire.
The Republican Party is headed into the uncharted wilds of a three-way race with polls showing almost 60 percent of Americans supporting someone other than the incumbent President of the United States. The national mood is bleak, even bleaker in the aftermath of the riots in Los Angeles, some polls suggest.
 
As the Numbers Turn
 In short, Republicans have known for some time that this campaign would not be "morning in America," Ronald Reagan's triumphant march toward re-election. But it is turning out to be darker and harder than many of them had imagined.
"The most salient fact and dangerous fact is that the economy has turned and the perception of the economy is turning, and the President's numbers didn't turn," said one Republican strategist. "They kept going down. That's scary. Denial, which is the natural first reaction to this thing, is giving way to serious concern -- at both the campaign and the White House."
Another Republican strategist, who like others spoke only on condition that he not be identified, expressed another growing worry in the party: All their years of experience, all their targeting and all their blueprints are based on a two-way race.
That is their premise for directing resources to key states and putting together an Electoral College majority. It is the basis for such tried-and-true strategies as driving up the negatives of a Democratic nominee without worrying that the defecting voters will turn to a relatively unsullied third candidate, a common occurrence in three-way statewide races.
 
Conventional Wisdom Is Out
 "It's a terrible, terrible kind of campaign to run," the Republican strategist said. "Almost every state becomes somewhat competitive. And all the conventional wisdom about how you target and how you run a Presidential race is useless."
Still, much of the immediate concern in Republican circles is over Mr. Bush himself and his stall in the polls. The New York Times/CBS News Poll showed him with a 40 percent job approval rating in February, ominous but perhaps understandable amid an ugly primary challenge from Patrick J. Buchanan and a painful economic downtown.
But three months later, in early May, Mr. Bush was still at 39 percent; by way of contrast, President Jimmy Carter had an approval rating of 43 percent in May 1980, when he was seeking re-election, and President Ronald Reagan was at 52 percent at a comparable time in 1984, according to the Gallup Poll.
Moreover, some polls in the last few weeks have shown Mr. Bush losing ground after the rioting in Los Angeles.
The President himself, in an interview with The Dallas Morning News last weekend, seemed to cling to the belief that a rising economy would lift all boats, including his. "I've been through all this stuff before," he said. "My confidence is predicated on the fact, I must say, that I think the economy is recovering.'
But some analysts argue that Mr. Bush is buffeted by forces bigger than the business cycle -- a sense of national drift, of a struggling middle class, of a government that does not work as it should.
Kevin Phillips, the conservative theoretician who is one of the principal advocates of this view, asserts: "Americans are not looking at this as one economic cycle. They're looking at this as the unraveling of the American Dream."
In a poll conducted May 4-6 and made public this week, the Wirthlin Group found that 14 percent said the country was moving in the right direction, while 83 percent said it was on the wrong track. That was the highest level of pessimism recorded in 12 years, said the group's political project director, Michael Dabadie.
The group tied these findings, in part, to the riots in Los Angeles, but it was also part of a bleak pattern throughout 1992, Mr. Dabadie said.
This is hard terrain for any incumbent President to campaign on, and Mr. Bush reflected those difficulties as he traveled last weekend, delivering commencement addresses at Southern Methodist University and the University of Notre Dame.
At S.M.U. he gave a defiantly upbeat speech, railing against the "declinists" and asserting, "I'm a little tired of the pessmism in this country." It was reminiscent of the way Mr. Reagan used to poke at the "gloom and doom Democrats," but "gloom and doom" was not a majority view in Mr. Reagan's glory years.
At Notre Dame, Mr. Bush sat and listened as the valedictorian, a young woman, assailed the state of the nation, from its race relations to its environmental policies. When his turn came to speak the President never acknowledged her, talking instead of family values and the limits of what government can do.
There is considerable grumbling among Republicans about the President's message and campaign themes these days. Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, a conservative who is the House Republican whip, argues that the President needs to combine dramatic action with powerful words, to fulfill "the pedagogical burden" of the Presidency as Mr. Reagan did, or as Mr. Bush himself did in the events leading to the Persian Gulf war.
 
Playing to the Middle
 Mr. Gingrich contended that the President keeps trying to play to the middle, between the "elite" culture and the "popular" culture that he so "brilliantly" mined in his 1988 campaign.
Other Republicans worry that Mr. Bush is simply frustrated and ill at ease in a campaign focused unremittingly on domestic problems. "Here's a good and decent man who believes he has flat nailed it, long term, in terms of preserving the peace, and his political fortunes have declined at the same time," said one Bush strategist.
Still other Republicans fear that what the Democrats argue may be right: that the opposition to Mr. Bush is not just discontent or economic unease, but increasingly personal. Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic polltaker, asserted: "Bush is the one known quantity here. People really don't want Bush back."
In the middle of all this, the Bush camp is trying to adjust to Mr. Perot, although some Republicans worry that they are still not taking him seriously enough. "They have their truisms -- Perot falls by the wayside, they get their mano-a-mano with Clinton, the election is decided on personal qualities and they win," said one consultant.
But Charles Black, a senior adviser to the Bush campaign, said of Mr. Perot: "There's nothing we can do to affect what he's doing. And until he gets in and defines himself, it's not clear who he hurts and who he helps."
Frederic V. Malek, the campaign manager, says that for the time being Mr. Perot is "clearly helping us more than hurting us, because he's keeping Clinton from making any move."
If Mr. Perot enters and does not fade, many Republicans say, the strategic implications are profound. "States that would have been slam dunks, like Texas, become competitive," Mr. Malek said. "But states like Massachusetts also become competitive."
In other words, all the assumptions about what is a safe Democratic state and a safe Republican state will have to be re-examined.
All this feeds into the general uncertainty of a re-election campaign that, in the afterglow of the Persian Gulf war, seemed nearly a done deal for Mr. Bush.
Thomas Mann, director of governmental studies at the Brookings Institution, predicts that Mr. Bush will still win this November, but adds, "The whole script that was prepared seems quaintly out of date."

HEADLINE: U.S. Reluctance to Reduce CO<2> Is Sharply Criticized in Germany

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, May 20

 BODY:
Chancellor Helmut Kohl and other German leaders called on the United States today to strengthen its environmental policies before the world environmental summit meeting in Rio de Janeiro next month.
Speaking to a special session of the German Parliament, Chancellor Kohl said Germany was willing to make substantial new contributions to the Global Environmental Facility, a fund established by the World Bank to support environmental programs in the developing world. 
 "I link this readiness with the expectation that other countries are also ready to assume their share of responsibility," the Chancellor said. "I am thinking especially of the United States and Japan."
According to German officials, the United States is blocking a World Bank proposal to triple the size of the $1.5 billion environmental fund after 1993.
 
Critical of 'Skepticism'
 Chancellor Kohl was one of the first world leaders to commit himself to attend the Rio conference, which officially opens June 3. Germany has some of the world's most advanced environmental laws, and public opinion here is highly sensitive to environmental issues.
The Chancellor told Parliament that when he introduced environmental questions at the 1988 economic summit meeting in Toronto, leaders of other industrial powers reacted with "great skepticism and even rejection."
"The industrialized nations must face their special responsibility," Mr. Kohl said. "Our 20 percent of the world population produces about 80 percent of worldwide carbon dioxide emissions. So it is clear who has the chief responsibility and who must bear the chief burden for reducing carbon dioxide emissions."
Scientists say these emissions, which come from automobiles and factories, contribute to depletion of the Earth's ozone level, which in turn could produce disastrous changes in the world's climate.
Environment Minister Klaus Topfer, who also addressed Parliament today, criticized the United States and Japan for refusing to increase energy taxes, as the European Community has suggested. The Europeans, he said, could not take such a step alone.
Gerhart Baum of the centrist Free Democratic party, which is a member of the governing coalition, criticized the United States for refusing to commit itself to reducing carbon dioxide emissions to the 1990 level by the end of this decade.

HEADLINE: Build an Empire! New York City Bonds in Yen

 BODY:
Going farther afield in its quest for financing, the Dinkins administration is planning to sell yen-denominated bonds to investors in Japan.
With an eye to lowering its borrowing costs, New York City has authorized the Nikko Securities Company to make preparations with Japanese authorities to sell up to $120 million of taxable yen-denominated bonds at some point this fall. 
 By selling securities in Japan, the city would be able to save because market interest rates are lower there than in the United States.
In a May 19 letter to Kichiro Takao, who is Nikko's president, Barry Sullivan, Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, and Darcy Bradbury, the city's Deputy Comptroller for Finance, said any such financing in Japan would coincide with an offering of tax-exempt New York City securities in the United States.
 
Experience in TokyoXx
 The city is not authorized to issue securities denominated in foreign currencies, but it is seeking to acquire such authorization from Albany. Through Nikko, in March the city did sell dollar-denominated bonds in Tokyo.
If legislative approval is not granted, Mr. Sullivan and Ms. Bradbury said in the letter that the debt would be issued through a "special purpose not-for-profit corporation organized solely for the benefit of the city."
City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman said in a telephone interview that the effort was the latest in a series by the city to attract new investors. New York is by far the nation's biggest issuer of tax-exempt securities.
"The more demand there is, the less interest we will have to pay," Ms. Holzman said.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Carter, With Clinton at His Side, Praises the Candidate's Qualities

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, May 20

 BODY:
Former President Jimmy Carter met with Gov. Bill Clinton in Atlanta today and made a case for sending another Southern Governor to the White House, saying that Mr. Clinton has the "knowledge and integrity" to be President.
But for all of Mr. Carter's kind words about the probable Democratic nominee and Mr. Clinton's effusive praise of Mr. Carter, the two men spent most of the news conference answering questions about Ross Perot, the Texas billionaire who is likely to wage an independent bid for the Presidency. 
 "I really look on Ross Perot right now as kind of, anybody-but-the-above," Mr. Carter said, adding these views of Mr. Perot:
"Eventually he's going to have to let the American people know what he stands for. He can't hide all the way through the season when people are actually going to be addressing him as a potential leader of our nation. He's been evasive so far, deliberately so. He brags on the fact that he doesn't get specific about what he's going to do about anything.
"He either doesn't have ideas clearly in mind now or he is ashamed and doesn't want to share his ideas with the public because they might be unpopular. I think that can go on only so long."
 
Carter Faults Republicans
 In a formal news conference held on the grounds of the Carter Center here, Mr. Carter also used the opportunity to take up an increasingly familiar Democratic Party view. The Republicans, he said, are the people responsible for "the deterioration of our inner cities and the sliding of our country into divisiveness between rich and poor, between black and white, between different regions of the country."
The words, which reflected those Mr. Clinton has used to attack the Bush Administration, were also similar to those employed by Gov. Ann W. Richards of Texas at a fund-raising dinner in Austin on Tuesday.
Mr. Carter endorsed Mr. Clinton last month, and an aide to the Arkansas Governor said the meeting today was designed to juxtapose Mr. Clinton, whom many voters have said they do not trust, with Mr. Carter, who has won high marks for honesty and public service.
Mr. Clinton has grown visibly agitated in recent days at having to fend off repeated questions about Mr. Perot's probable candidacy at a time when he is trying to raise his own stature as a general election candidate.
In response to reporters' questions in Austin on Tuesday, Mr. Clinton said he expected Mr. Perot's current popularity to go through a "life cycle."
"I can remember when I burst up in the popularity polls," Mr. Clinton said. "Those things happen. But in the end, people get a deep, full knowledge of whoever is there at the end of the Presidential race."
Mr. Clinton said today that Mr. Perot was enjoying an "initial honeymoon" that most national candidates experience when they are first presented to voters.
"That is an unbroken pattern as far as I know," he said. "The only thing I care about in those polls is whether I believe in the places I'm going and the people I'm talking to, whether I'm making progress. And I believe I am."
Mr. Carter said that Mr. Perot is at the pinnacle of his popularity with voters.
 
Discord Over Tax Cut
 "But he is going to have to show some substance other than being a non-politician who happens to have made a lot of money," said Mr. Carter, who said he had never met Mr. Perot.
Although he agreed with Mr. Clinton on the subject of Mr. Perot, Mr. Carter repeated his criticism of a central part of Mr. Clinton's economic recovery plan -- his call for a middle-income tax cut.
"I've never been in favor of advocating tax cuts when we have a deficit that's now approaching a half a trillion dollars a year," Mr. Carter said. He said that the White House and Congress should instead be willing to make "bold and politically courageous joint decisions negotiated very carefully about what would be best."
Americans, he said, would be willing to accept a "reasonable sacrifice" to address the Federal budget deficit. His words echoed a theme often sounded by Paul E. Tsongas, the former Massachusetts Senator who dropped out of the Presidential contest in March.

HEADLINE: Senate Passes Bill to Force States to Make Voter Registration Easie

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20

 BODY:
With Democrats seeking higher turnouts at the polls, the Senate voted 61 to 38 today to make voter registration easier by allowing people to register by mail and as they renew their driver's licenses.
Changes in voter registration and limits on campaign spending have been the subjects of some of the most heated and partisan debate in the Senate this year, as Republicans and Democrats jockey to exploit or duck the electorate's cynicism and anger. 
 Several Democrats noted that the rise of Ross Perot as a likely independent Presidential candidate is a reflection of voter disgust with both parties, an emotion they hope to redirect squarely at the Republicans as protectors of business-as-usual politics.
 
Veto Is Predicted
 Senate Republicans have vowed that President Bush will veto the voter-registration bill, although the White House says he has not made a decision.
"We would likely veto it in its current form," a White House spokeswoman, Judy Smith, said today. She said that the bill would be costly for the states, that it could lead to fraud and that "the Voting Rights Act of 1965 already provides sufficient tools to challenge registration procedures that are discriminatory."
The House, which overwhelmingly passed a similar voter-registration bill two years ago, is expected to take up the matter again in a few weeks.
Democrats in the Senate lack the votes to override a veto, but they promise to make a political issue out of what they are portraying as a Republican effort to block electoral reform and to keep minorities and the disabled from voting.
Only 6 Republicans joined 55 Democrats in voting for the measure. Senator Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina was the sole Democrat against it.
Today's vote came a week after the Senate failed to override Mr. Bush's veto of another measure that Democrats promoted as electoral reform, a bill that would have limited Congressional campaign spending.
 
Explaining Low Turnout
 Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, who led the Republican effort to defeat the registration bill, characterized it as "a solution in search of a problem" because, he said, low voter turnouts demonstrated that the electorate was basically happy with its leaders. And, he added, allowing people to register when they renew their driver's licenses is no guarantee of higher turnouts, since turnout has declined in 7 of the 10 states that have had such a procedure since 1972.
Republicans, who twice in the last year used the threat of a filibuster to block the measure from coming to the floor, say the bill will encourage vote fraud. Democrats, on the other hand, say Republicans fear that increasing the number of registered voters would add millions of Democrats to the rolls.
There is little evidence, however, that an increase in registration will lead to a considerable increase in voter turnout.
The measure, known in Congress as the "motor-voter" bill, would replace the patchwork of registration procedures that exists from state to state. It would require states to allow eligible citizens to register to vote at the same time they obtain or renew their driver's, fishing or hunting licenses. States would also have to offer voter registration by mail and at the offices of state agencies like welfare and unemployment offices. It would also prohibit removal of a registered voter's name from voter rolls for failure to vote.
Twenty-seven states, including New York and New Jersey, and the District of Columbia have some of the registration rules required in the bill. Of those states, five -- Montana, New Mexico, Oregon, Texas and West Virginia -- have adopted motor-voter procedures in recent months. The Connecticut legislature approved a motor-voter measure two weeks ago, and Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. is expected to sign it.
The bill, which if approved would become effective on Jan. 1, 1994, would not apply to states that do not require voter registration or that permit registration on Election Day.
The Congressional Budget Office has estimated that the new registration procedures will cost the states a total of $20 million to $25 million a year, largely to computerize lists, with the cost decreasing after five years. Republicans say the expense will be much higher.
 
Motivating Voters
 Democrats said that the inconvenience of registration deters many citizens from voting and that their failure to participate in elections makes them feel only more alienated and apathetic. Republicans said that voter turnouts were high only in times of crisis and that turnout in general had little or nothing to do with registration rules.
Senator Wendell H. Ford, Democrat of Kentucky, said, "The bill will knock down the confusing and restrictive practices which continue to frustrate the right to participate in our democracy." He suggested that opponents of the measure were trying "to achieve through archaic and confusing registration procedures that which they cannot achieve through outlawed practices such as poll taxes and literacy tests."
While some Republicans have argued that the bill's provisions intrude on states' rights to regulate their elections, Senator McConnell said the bill's "most disturbing aspect" was "its potential to foster election fraud and thus debase the entire political process in this country." He warned that states would try to save money on the new procedures by doing away with registration completely, making it impossible to verify voter eligibility.
An aide to Senator Hollings, the only Democrat to vote against the bill, said Mr. Hollings was concerned that the requirement for mail registration would increase the risk of vote fraud.
But supporters of the bill said it contained sufficient safeguards against fraud, including making both false registration and procurement of fraudulent ballots a criminal offense.
Senator Mark Hatfield, an Oregon Republican who is a sponsor of the bill, said the motor-voter measure enacted in his state six months ago had already resulted in the registration of 72,000 new voters with no reports of fraud.
A coalition of 60 voter and civil rights groups lobbied hard for the Senate measure with letter-writing and telephone campaigns.
"Persistance has paid off," Susan S. Lederman, president of the League of Women Voters, said today. "Americans need national voter registration reform to break down the barriers that discourage and discriminate."
Richard A. Cloward, executive director of the 100% Vote project of Human Serve, a New York-based voter registration group, predicted that the legislation would raise voter registration to 95 percent, from 60 percent. "The Civil Rights Act of 1965 stopped Government from preventing people from registering to vote," he said, "and this legislation goes the final step by imposing on Government an affirmative obligation to register the eligible electorate."

HEADLINE: Trade Gap Widened In March

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20

 BODY:
The nation's foreign-trade deficit widened sharply to $5.8 billion in March as imports surged and exports eased off their record levels, the Commerce Department reported today.
The March figure compared with a $3.3 billion deficit in February, the best performance in nearly nine years. 
 Since trade figures are among the last Government reports published each month -- many economic statistics have already been issued for April -- the latest data cast little light on the current state of the economy. But the trade figures did point up the danger that a sag in exports could undermine an already sluggish recovery and the likelihood of intensified trade friction with Japan.
 
 
Bigger Gap With Japan
 The American deficit with Japan rose by a third, to $4 billion, for the month, and pushed this year's deficit pace ahead of last year's by 4 percent. On Tuesday, the Bush Administration determined that Japanese mini-vans were being sold in the United States at unfairly low prices, beginning a process that could lead to higher duties.
Exports slipped in March by $679 million, or 1.8 percent, to $37 billion. The record level of exports in February was heavily aided by deliveries of aircraft, which this time showed only a modest gain that was not enough to offset a $434 million decline in capital goods, the biggest for any of the major categories.
Aircraft are expected to be a drag in April, with the Boeing Company having delivered only 27 planes abroad, according to analysts at the Mitsubishi Bank. Boeing, the nation's biggest exporter, delivered 24 planes in January, 34 in February and 37 in March.
Exports have provided a vital support to the economy during the recession, and the Bush Administration is relying on further strength in sales abroad to help sustain a recovery. But with the Japanese and various European economies slowing down, continued overseas demand for American goods is in doubt.
 
 
'Continued Deterioration' Is Seen
 "Until their domestic economies begin growing again, we can expect continued deterioration in our overall trade deficit," Barry Rogstad, president of the American Business Conference, a group of fast-growing corporations, said today.
But he noted that American manufacturing productivity had improved over the last few years. He said the gains "may enable us to ride out the current sluggish world economy with minimal declines in exports."
Imports rose in March by a hefty $1.84 billion, or 4.5 percent, to their highest level since November 1990. The biggest factor was a $500 million increase for capital goods, most of it reflected in a 6.1 percent jump for motor vehicles and parts.
Higher imports generally suggest robust consumer spending, which was evident during much of the first quarter but appears to have subsided this spring.
At $5.8 billion, the March deficit in merchandise -- services are reported separately -- was about the same as January's. Analysts did not expect the deficit to continue at February's low level of $3.3 billion, but the consensus was that half of that month's gains, instead of none of them, would survive.
As usual, a large chunk of the deficit reflected imports of crude oil and other petroleum products. The nation's bill for crude rose 10.7 percent, to $2.46 billion. Volume increased 3.3 percent and the average price edged up 4 cents a barrel, to $14.46.
Geographically, Japan accounted for 69 percent of the American deficit. Imports of Japanese cars rose to $1.82 billion, from $1.66 billion, while exports of American cars to Japan edged down to $48 million. This meant Japan sold 38 times as much of these goods as it bought from the United States.
The deficit with China fell by a third, to $800 million, while the deficit with Taiwan grew modestly, to $700 million. The deficit with Canada, the largest United States trade partner, eased to $500 million, from $650 million.
The American surplus with Western Europe narrowed to $2.3 billion, from $2.6 billion. The gap grew with Germany and the Netherlands, but it fell with Britain.
"The widening of the deficit with Japan suggests, obviously, that our deficit with that country remains a thorny issue," said Elliott Platt, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "The widening of the German deficit and the overall narrowing of the Western European surplus should not be viewed as problematic. The deficit with Germany remains low by recent historic standards, while the surplus with Western Europe remains relatively high by recent standards."

HEADLINE: Capitalism for Emigres, in 12 Steps;
Scientists From the Former Soviet Union Study an Unusual Subject: How to Get a Job

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG

 BODY:
One by one, the emigre scientists -- specialists in ichthyology, pisciculture, biomineralization and more -- rose to present themselves.
"I am Bril," the first man began. "I come here two months ago from Minsk." 
 Then the next: "My major is fracture mechanics. I have 20 publications in international journals."
And a graying engineer: "I was a supervisor," he said. "I have 30 certificates. Now, sadly, I am rather old."
It was a touching exercise, but awkward, like a bad "Saturday Night Live" skit snapped to life in a conference room on East 33d Street. Dozens of scientists and engineers, many of them stars in the former Soviet Union, had come together for a post-doctoral lesson in "the American mentality." Their goal, more bluntly: jobs.
 
Concepts Like Eye Contact
 It had been but a few months since most of them had arrived from Russia and Belarus, but the eager students had already found their way to this "crash course in capitalism" offered by an American-born astrophysicist and career counselor, Dr. Stephen Rosen.
Their capitalist re-education, which will take 12 sessions at no charge, began early this month at the Workmen's Circle, a former bastion of Jewish socialism, itself re-educated into a fraternal organization. With the ready humility of immigrants, these dozens of Ph.D.'s from St. Petersburg University, Moscow State and the Steklov Mathematical Institute arrived prepared to study concepts like eye contact, thank-you notes and the buddy system.
"I know about eye contact -- you have to maintain it -- but I have bad knowledge in many areas," Dr. Vladimir Faynberg of Kiev said, his glasses slightly askew. "For instance, must you really wear only a blue suit to a job interview or is brown acceptable?"
Dr. Faynberg may well be a physicist specializing in the nondestructive testing of semiconductors, but that and 50 cents, he has learned, will get him a cup of coffee in America. Neither he nor the others have any desire to take a typical first job for immigrants, like driving a taxicab. Why watch a meter tick when you could be tinkering with a carbon buckyball?
So, referred by refugee-resettlement agencies, former capitalism students and Russian-language newspapers, the emigres have found their way to this workshop, which will initiate them into such alien activities as networking, interfacing and looking for a job. It's a hazing they're willing to endure, considering that many are already suffering what they hope will be a temporary indignity of depending on public assistance.
Dr. Rosen estimated that more than 4,000 scientists have migrated here from the former Soviet Union in the last two years in what he calls a brain gain. His nonprofit program, Scientific Career Transitions, which is supported by grants and donations, grew from a marriage of his vocation in career counseling and his avocation, helping Jewish emigres.
 
Exploitation and Capitalism
 Standing before a hand-lettered sign that said, "Either Network or No Work," Dr. Rosen, whose grandparents came from what is now Belarus, gave them their mission: "The job that you have to do is to persuade or convince an American employer that you can bring in more money than they pay you. In the Soviet Union, this was called exploitation. In the U.S., this is called capitalism."
As would any self-actualization teacher worth his ego, Dr. Rosen introduced a success story, Dr. Aleksandr Salman, a once-nervous geophysicist from Moscow, who, after participating in the workshop, landed a position in soil mechanics at Polytechnic University in Brooklyn.
An elegant bearded man, Dr. Salman offered a testimonial. "I came over a year and a half ago," he said. "I figured out it's rather impossible to find a job here in my field, earthquake prediction. But I didn't give up.
"We must learn small things, for example, keep smiling," he said, his face impassive. "How to feel yourself comfortable when not comfortable. You must start making telephone calls. You must be in the right place at the right time."
Dr. Salman, after placing himself in the right place at the right time, discovered -- right in Brooklyn -- a project that could benefit from his knowledge of seismology. He is studying the vibrations shaking the historic town houses above the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway.
 
Resumes and Vodka at Lunch
 "Many people are proud of themselves because of their former achievements," Dr. Salman told his colleagues. "You must forget about that. You must accept anything you are offered."
Spouting aphorisms and jokes, Dr. Rosen, in "Topic A: Orientation," offered his dos and don'ts of looking for work in America.
Don't send out resumes randomly, rely on classified advertisements, wait for the phone to ring, arrive late or depressed for job interviews, smoke, photocopy cover letters or wear wrinkled brown suits.
"Class, is it O.K. to drink vodka during an interview lunch?" Dr. Rosen asked. There was a pause.
"Maybe a little?" one chemist ventured.
 
Einstein Never Wore a Tie
 Do be succinct, ask your interviewer questions -- "Don't let it become a K.G.B. interview" -- search the Scientific Citation index for those who have cited your research, call people in your field and engage them in shoptalk. And get a haircut.
Dr. Rosen nodded at another workshop graduate, Dr. Gregory Pelts, who has secured a research position in the high-energy physics department at the Rockefeller University. "Notice that Gregory does not wear a tie and jacket and has long hair. He fought with me. He said Einstein never wore a tie. Well, you're not Einsteins, not in the United States."
Dr. Pelts, however unkempt, was an exemplary networker. "I just called up Rockefeller University, and said, 'Good day, may I speak with someone working in string theory?' " he explained.
Russian-style bluntness can, however, prove clunky. Dr. Faynberg offered an example. He had gone for a chat, not exactly a job interview, but an opportunity nonetheless, at a laboratory in New Jersey. The topic was semistate conductors, and Dr. Faynberg's interviewer ventured an opinion, to which Dr. Faynberg responded, "You are wrong."
"His jaw dropped, and he looked at his watch and said, 'I'm in a hurry,' " Dr. Faynberg recounted. "It was a very unhappy occurrence."
