HEADLINE: NEWARK JOURNAL;
No Miracle on Market St. for Final Retail Holdout

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
AT the end yesterday, a floorwalker could roll a bowling ball down almost any aisle at Macy's in Newark and not hit anyone.
Sunday newspaper inserts announced specials or extended store hours at Herald Square and many branches, but not in Newark. 
 And the Cellar, Macy's famous Manhattan basement of exotic food and state-of-the-art pots and pans, was reduced to a small section of china, glassware and small appliances on the second floor here. The real basement in Newark was closed to shoppers, as were 12 of the 16 floors in the block-square building on Market Street.
By lunchtime, customers had already begun to hear about the end of a store whose slogan, "We're a part of your life," mocked the announcement yesterday. With the closing, Newark has lost the last and perhaps most potent symbol of a once-glorious mercantile history and suffered another blow in its attempt to restore an economy that fled with its middle class two decades ago.
While most shoppers expressed dismay, there was also a good deal of indignation that the only sizable chain stores left in downtown Newark would be two five-and-dime stalwarts, McCrory's and Woolworth's.
"Where am I going to do my shopping now?," said Octavia Hutchins, who had just bought a pair of shoes. "This is the last of the quality stores."
Ms. Hutchins, who lives in East Orange and teaches first grade in the Newark public schools, said she shopped at Macy's because it was convenient. And while its noontime trade rarely registered brisk on the shopping meter, it was the busiest part of the selling day, which revolved around the schedules of office and courthouse staffs on their breaks.
Mary Mahoney of Union Township, who works in state offices a few blocks away, said she shopped often, for cosmetics, clothes and housewares. "It saves us going to the mall at night," she said.
Macy's managers refused to discuss the closing, and many on its sales staff followed instructions not to talk about it. Reporters were politely asked to leave. But Ms. Mahoney and other customers reported that some of the 340 employees were clearly distraught, after having been told at 9 yesterday morning that the store, the largest of seven Macy's outlets to be shut, would close by Aug. 1.
Mayor Sharpe James expressed shock at the announcement but said through a spokeswoman, Pamela E. Goldstein, that he would not comment until after a meeting tomorrow morning that had been requested by a Macy's official earlier in the week.
In a statement issued in New York, Macy's said the Newark building, which is owned by the company, would stay occupied, housing a computer operation and corporate offices employing several hundred people.
In its heyday, the Macy's store, which began life in 1892 as L. Bamberger & Company, was a jewel of Newark's carriage trade. Its founder, Louis Bamberger, arrived from Baltimore, acquired a bankrupt dry goods shop called Hill & Cragg and turned it into a vast emporium of service and style. It made him rich, and he returned the favor, endowing the Newark Museum and the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton University.
By 1929, with both of his partners dead, he sold to R. H. Macy & Co., which kept the Bamberger name until 1986. Many customers still call the store by its old nickname, Bams, and the name L. Bamberger & Co. remains on bronze plaques outside the building.
 
'A Kind of Filene's Basement'
 For years, Bamberger's shared Broad and Market streets with stores like Kresge, Hahne's, Hearn's, Ohrbach's, Jay's, Burt's, S. Klein on the Square and Sears Roebuck & Company. All of them are gone.
And with Newark's economy souring, Macy's began to use its store here to move merchandise that failed to sell elsewhere. "It became a kind of Filene's basement, I guess," said Richard G. Schoon, president of the Chamber of Commerce, adding that in his impression the store was probably just breaking even.
Ultimately what happened to its predecessors happened to Macy's, just as it happened elsewhere: malls. But the character of Newark's neighborhoods and its central business district were contributing factors. Few people live downtown, so getting to Macy's meant driving or taking buses. There is little free parking, and if shoppers have to rely on buses, there are buses that go to the malls, which have more variety than the small, inexpensive shops that are all that remain on Market Street.

HEADLINE: Trenton Allows More Spending By Road Fund

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 20

 BODY:
Gov. Jim Florio today signed a bill that he said would provide $1.46 billion for work on roads and bridges and create 43,000 construction jobs in the next year.
The bill increases the statutory cap on spending from the Transportation Trust Fund to $565 million annually. 
 If the cap had not been lifted, Transportation Commissioner Thomas M. Downs said the state could have been forced to leave $263 million in Federal aid in Washington. Now the state will be able to spend a record amount in the next fiscal year on capital projects proposed by the Department of Transportation and New Jersey Transit.
"We're creating jobs and boosting the economy of the state at a time when we need it most," said Governor Florio, who included the proposal in his State of the State address.
The Legislature must approve the projects to be built with the money. The list includes two major rail projects in the Meadowlands, repairs to Interstate 80 and Route 17 in Bergen County and Route 21 in Newark, and the installation of electronic toll collection equipment along the Garden State Parkway, the New Jersey Turnpike and the Atlantic City Expressway.
Two years ago the cap on the transportation fund was temporarily raised to $565 million from $365 million. That change was scheduled to expire June 30.
The state trust fund, created in 1984, is supported by a part of the state tax on gasoline, trucking fees and toll-road contributions from the Garden State Parkway, the New Jersey Turnpike and the Atlantic City Expressway.
The trust fund's authority may also sell bonds.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A Glimpse Into Perot's Portfolio

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
Ross Perot got rich in computers, and his current stock market investments show a decided tilt toward technology companies. But he has also made money lending to R. H. Macy & Company, getting out at a profit before the retailer went bankrupt. He also made millions speculating on the Japanese stock market.
Those are some of the items detailed in Mr. Perot's financial disclosure form filed with the Federal Election Commission covering his investment activity last year. 
The report shows that Mr. Perot, who is considering running for President, joined millions of other investors in sharply scaling back his short-term investments as interest rates plunged. While for many that meant taking money out of bank savings accounts, Mr. Perot sold millions of dollars in commercial paper issued by American and foreign companies for their short-term borrowing needs.
 
Selling Common Stocks
 Mr. Perot also sold substantial quantities of common stocks in 1991. He eliminated sizable positions in Marion Merrill Dow Inc., a drug company, reporting a capital gain of more than $100,000. He also sold shares of the NCR Corporation, a computer company acquired by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, producing a gain of between $50,000 and $100,000.
Mr. Perot became a billionaire by starting a computer services company, Electronic Data Systems, with a $1,000 investment. He took the company public and eventually sold it to the General Motors Corporation for cash and stock valued at $2.55 billion. With such a history, he has shown a willingness to invest in other young technology companies, both directly and through investments in venture capital partnerships.
And he has also speculated widely. He reported large profits last year on the sale of real estate, airplanes, municipal bonds, currency futures and computer technology, as well as from common and preferred stocks.
One of his largest profits in 1991 came from an investment in the Amtech Corporation, a Dallas company that developed computer-related products to aid in collecting highway tolls and identifying railroad cars.
Mr. Perot bought Amtech stock in 1987, two years before the company went public, a company spokeswoman said. The report shows that Mr. Perot sold his stock last year, making a profit of more than $1 million. He also turned a profit of at least $50,000 selling shares in Xilinx Inc., a San Jose, Calif., semiconductor company.
Mr. Perot also sold shares and stock options in Centocor Inc., a Malvern, Pa., biotechnology concern, realizing capital gains of at least $100,000 on the shares and at least $5,000 on the options. The sales appear to have been well-timed; Centocor has run into problems this year, encountering obstacles in bringing a new drug to market. But Mr. Perot still owned more than $1 million in Centocor convertible bonds at the end of 1991, on which he suffered substantial losses if he has not sold them.
He also turned a profit of at least $50,000 last year trading in stock options of Salomon Inc., the brokerage firm shaken by the Treasury bond scandal. He also reported capital gains of more than $100,000 from trading in options on Treasury bond futures.
Mr. Perot's filing was the most extensive anyone at the Federal Elections Commission could remember, but the forms used by the Government call for limited details for many of investments, asking only for broad ranges of values. In addition, because capital gains are reported but capital losses are not, and because original costs are not shown, it is not clear whether many of Mr. Perot's investments have been profitable.
In some cases, because the law says that filers need only provide the types of financial instruments being used, it is impossible to know on which side of an investment question Mr. Perot placed his bet.
For example, Mr. Perot reported that at the end of 1991 he owned futures contracts for crude oil worth more than $250,000, and that he owned more than $1 million worth of options on the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index.
Similarly, he had millions of dollars worth of positions in various currency contracts, whose value would be determined by whether the dollar rose or fell against the Swiss franc, the Japanese yen and the Canadian dollar. But there was no indication whether he had bet for or against the American currency.
James Squires, a spokesman for Mr. Perot, declined to say on which side Mr. Perot had invested. "There will be no comment from us on that document," he said. "It is a matter of principle." He said Mr. Perot had complied with all required disclosures and would go no further.
It is also unclear from the disclosure whether Mr. Perot was betting for or against Japanese stocks. However, he reported profits of more than $1 million each from investments in two index options contracts on the Nikkei 225-stock average in 1991, a year in which the Japanese stock index declined. That would seem to indicate he bet against the Japanese market.
At the end of the year, he held investments in two other Nikkei index contracts, each worth more than $1 million. If those contracts were also betting on lower Japanese prices, he would have made substantial profits this year, because Japanese stock prices have fallen rapidly.
Mr. Perot said his real estate holdings, including land parcels in Texas, Virginia and Georgia, were worth millions. And he reported making a capital gain of more than $100,000 when he sold a home in Eagle County, Colo.
Mr. Perot's investment in Macy was a large but relatively conservative one. The notes he bought were issued by a Macy subsidiary and secured by the company's credit card receivables, which are owed by customers.
Those notes were redeemed when Macy sold its credit card operation to the General Electric Company last year, giving Mr. Perot a capital gain of less than $15,000. Before he sold out, his interest income in 1991 from the notes was more than $100,000.
Mr. Perot also showed profits from Americus Trust securities, a conservative way to invest in certain stocks. He reported profits from selling "prime" units in the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company and in Johnson & Johnson. Effectively, such investments allow an investor to own shares at a relatively low cost by giving up some possible capital gains.
In some cases, it is too early to tell if Mr. Perot has invested wisely, but he has placed substantial bets, including a stake of more than $1 million in Zonagen, a private company engaged in biotechnology research.

HEADLINE: Dow Off By 4.15, To 3,393.84

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Stock prices fell slightly yesterday after the Dow Jones industrial average twice came close to passing 3,400. The modest setback from Tuesday's record highs came as interest rates turned upward in the credit markets.
The Dow, which had climbed nearly 22 points on Tuesday, gave back 4.15 yesterday to end at 3,393.84. 
 Losers held a narrow edge on gainers for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange. Big Board volume came to an estimated 198.8 million shares, up from 189.4 million on Tuesday.
 
Waiting Out the Fed
 Analysts said traders took a cautious approach as they waited for signs of whether the Federal Reserve was ready to ease its credit policy any further, given recent signs of slow, erratic growth in the economy.
Yields on long-term government bonds had fallen Tuesday to their lowest levels in about three months at 7.76 percent. In yesterday's trading they reversed course. Treasury bond prices fell about $5 for each $1,000 in face value, raising their yields to around 7.8 percent.
Wall Street seemed to take in stride General Motors' offering of more than $2.1 billion in new stock -- the largest sale of shares ever by an American company.
G.M. was easily the most active Big Board stock, with nearly 17 million shares traded. It ended by slipping 25 cents, to $39, matching the offering price for the 55 million new shares.
 
Salomon Buoyed by Settlement
 Salomon Inc. jumped $2.875, to $33.50. In its case involving last year's scandal in the Treasury securities market, Salomon reached a settlement with the Government that would permit the firm to remain a primary dealer in that business. Moreover, investigators and regulators said no criminal charges would be levied against Salomon or its Salomon Brothers subsidiary.
Humana fell $2.25, to $23, in active trading, as the company estimated lower quarterly profits.
British Airways gained $1.25, closing at $57. The company said it had no present plans to offer new stock, contrary to some recent speculation.
 
AMR Down on Earnings Outlook
 American Airlines' parent, AMR, dropped 87.5 cents, to $65.50. Analysts said it appeared that the company's second-quarter results would be disappointing in the aftermath of airline fare changes this spring. AMR's chairman, Robert Crandall, said at the annual meeting that the company was considering dropping out of unprofitable airline markets and studying "nontraditional options" to try improving its financial health.
QVC Network, traded over the counter, climbed $2.125, to $20.625. The television-shopping merchandiser reported earnings of 28 cents a share for the fiscal first quarter ended April 30, against 5 cents a share in the corresponding period a year earlier.
 
Blue-Chip Losers
 Losers among the recently strong blue chips included Walt Disney, down $1.50 at $39.375; Coca-Cola, down 62.5 cents at $44.50, and Ford Motor, down 25 cents, to $44.25.
McDonald's gained $1.375 to close at $46.125, a record high. The company said it knew of no fresh developments to explain the activity.
The Nasdaq composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 2.24, to 580.29. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 0.22 at 392.15.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Drop on the Fed's Inaction

BYLINE: BY KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved lower yesterday after the Federal Reserve Board indicated that it had not eased monetary policy again.
Expectations of a Fed easing were high after a report Tuesday that showed renewed weakness in the housing industry during April. 
 But for the second straight day the Fed sent a clear signal that policy remained unchanged by refraining to conduct open market operations.
Yields on short-term notes and bills were particularly sensitive to the lack of action by the Fed, and bids at a 1 P.M. auction of new two-year Treasury notes were at much higher rate levels than early in the session.
At the auction, the $14.5 billion worth of securities were sold at an average yield of 5.13 percent, well below the 5.43 percent average at the last two-year note sale on April 22. Still, early in yesterday's session the notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 5.02 percent.
 
'Healthy for Market'
 "This backup in rates is healthy for the market," one Government-bond trader said. "We have run a long way, and this takes some of the froth out."
In addition to the Fed's decision not to ease policy, traders said that heavy issuance of corporate bonds both here and overseas tended to dampen demand for Treasury securities yesterday.
Among the issuers in the corporate bond market was the province of Ontario, which sold $2 billion worth of 10-year notes. The global offering is the first undertaken by a borrower other than the World Bank.
Earlier, Toyota Motor floated $1 billion worth of five-year securities in the Eurodollar market.
However, the session was dominated by the Fed. A number of analysts said they were surprised the central bank chose not to ease policy.
"Given the weakness in the housing-start numbers and the fact that money supply figures are at the bottom of their growth targets, it seemed to me they had no reason to wait," said Raymond W. Stone, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., firm.
 
Early Access to Data
 But Mr. Stone said Fed governors might have chosen not to ease policy because they had early access to money supply data.
"They may be waiting because they know that money growth is accelerating," he said. "If that isn't the case, I don't know what they are waiting for."
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 29 1/2-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 1026/32 , down 1/2 point, to yield 7.80 percent, compared with 7.76 percent late Tuesday.
Among Treasury note issues outstanding, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 101 3/4 in late trading, down 13/32 , to yield 7.25 percent. And the 6 7/8 percent five-year notes were offered at 10112/32 , down 13/32 , to yield 6.54 percent.
The Treasury is scheduled to auction $10.25 billion worth of new five-year notes today.
 
Short-Term Rates
 Rates on short-term Treasury bills rose after the Fed chose not to ease monetary policy.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 3.57 percent late yesterday, up six basis points, or six one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by eight basis points, to a late offered rate of 3.68 percent. And one-year bill rates rose by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 3.88 percent.
Among the new debt issues priced in the investment-grade corporate bond market was a two-part $243 million offering by Commonwealth Edison.
The smaller part of the offering consists of $103 million worth of 6 1/8 percent three-year notes.
The notes were priced at $99.70 to yield 6.236 percent, 57 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 5 7/8 percent three-year notes at the time of pricing.
The remaining $140 million were offered as 12-year, 8 percent notes.
These securities were priced at 99.70 to yield 8.10 percent, 85 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
Salomon Brothers acted as lead manager for the offering. Both parts of the issue are rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service and A- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
 
Tax-Exempt Offering
 In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, a group led by the Bank of America won at competitive bid a $155.5 million issue of general obligation bonds issued by San Francisco.
The bonds were reoffered to investors with yields from 3.25 percent in 1993 to 6.30 percent in 2012.
The securities are rated AA by both Moody's and Standard & Poor's.
Traders in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds said that prices of most widely quoted issues slipped by 1/8 point to 1/4 point.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
New Hewlett Computers Aim for Mainframe Market

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif., May 20

 BODY:
The Hewlett-Packard Company introduced its most powerful midrange computers today. They are intended to supplant more costly room-size mainframes that many corporate offices are seeking to replace with smaller machines.
The company said its nine new machines, which are about the size of refrigerators and range in price from $365,000 to $925,000, had as much speed and power as multimillion-dollar mainframes. 
 "These computers are about 60 to 70 percent more powerful than our current high-end machines, so it's a great leap forward," said Lewis Platt, executive vice president in charge of Hewlett-Packard computer systems. "We're calling them alternatives to mainframes because we can match that workload."
Forty-six percent of mainframe owners said last year that they planned to switch to smaller, but powerful computers that could handle multiple tasks and lots of data, according to Dataquest, Inc., a San Jose market research firm.
"The watchword in the industry these days is downsizing," said Tom Willmott, an analyst with the Boston-based Aberdeen Group research company. "Executives are not about to just throw out their mainframes," he said. "But they have been under enormous pressure to reduce expenses and retain productivity."
 
Cost Comparison
 Hewlett-Packard said that buying and operating a standard mainframe cost about $15 million over three years, compared with about $2.7 million for its new computers. Mr. Willmott agreed with the assessment that high-end computers that match mainframes were much more economical.
He noted, however, that the high-end computer market was not easy to crack. For example, he said, the VAX 9000 system made by the Digital Equipment Company had not done well in the market and was recently withdrawn. He said the Digital machine did not accomplish mainframe-level power as promised.
Mr. Willmott said that Hewlett-Packard had made a heavy commitment as early as 1985 to its precision-architecture RISC, or reduced-instruction-set computing, chips. "So now, it's paying off," he said. "They don't have to funnel money into competing systems."

HEADLINE: British Airways Plans A Slight Peak Fare Rise

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Despite strong bookings, British Airways said yesterday that it planned to raise fares only slightly for the peak summer travel season on the main North Atlantic routes.
The good news for travelers was delivered by Sir Colin Marshall, British Air's chief executive, at a briefing for analysts and the press at the Pierre Hotel. The airline is by far the largest carrier across the North Atlantic. 
 Normally, when bookings are strong, carriers try to push up fares, and in addition the heavy losses caused by the Persian Gulf war last year have created pressure to try to recoup when times are good.
But some analysts said that the economic recovery in many nations had been fragile and a fare increase could dampen a travel rebound that has begun on most international routes.
British Air's fare increases are expected to be about 1 to 2 percent, Sir Colin said.
 
'A Good Idea'
 "Holding the line on a fare increase is a good idea," said Rose Ann Tortora, an airline analyst for County NatWest. "The economies of the world are just getting their strength back and they could be set back again."
British Airways said that its April traffic increased 10.3 percent from April 1990. The comparison was not made to April 1991, it said, because the gulf war severely skewed that month's results.
Holding down fare increases will mean that peak-season travel between the United States and Europe will be cheaper than it has been in some time.
In 1989, for example, the lowest fare between London and New York available on weekends was $692 round trip. It rose to $738 in 1990, and increased again in 1991 to $758. This summer it is expected to be about $689.
Sir Colin said that bookings in economy class, where most early bookings are made, were so strong that those who waited until the last minute might not find space.
Virgin Atlantic recently announced a low fare of $398 round trip from New York to London but it must be bought on the day of travel. The offer is good until June 15.
Sir Colin said British Air would consider the Virgin Atlantic low fare but said the airline already had attractive low fares and might decide not to match.
Lori Levin, a spokeswoman for Virgin, said the carrier's bookings had been strong.
Another reason that British Airways may want to keep fares low is that it plans a major increase in capacity on the North Atlantic of 11.5 percent over two years ago. The carrier will, for example, beef up its flights from one daily to two a day to London from Chicago, Boston, Washington and Miami.
Sir Colin said that all the major carriers such as American, United and Virgin were putting more seats on the North Atlantic route.
 
A Strong Recovery
 Domestic traffic has been disappointing for the United States carriers, which hope that a good summer on recently acquired international routes will help offset the domestic weakness.
British Airways has shown a strong recovery from the heavy losses that most carriers suffered last year. In the company's fiscal fourth quarter, ended March 31, the airline showed a profit of $37 million, compared with a loss of $254 million in the same period a year earlier. Revenue totaled $2 billion, up 29.3 percent.
British Airways has also held its own in the increasing competition in the North Atlantic, having seen its market share go up by 1 percent at Heathrow even though 17 new carriers have begun service to Heathrow in recent years.

HEADLINE: Philip Morris to Buy Control Of Czech Cigarette Maker

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRAGUE, May 20

 BODY:
In one of the largest American investments in the former Soviet bloc, Philip Morris has agreed to pay $413 million for control of the Czechoslovak cigarette manufacturer Tabak, beating a rival offer from R. J. Reynolds in a fiercely contested bidding war.
The investment is the second largest made here by a foreign company; Volkswagen agreed last year to put $6.4 billion into the Skoda automobile factory. 
 It is a sign of growing American interest in Czechoslovakia. Mart Bakal, a senior United States adviser to the Privatization Ministry, said American companies had committed $1.4 billion to Czechoslovak investments, most of it in recent months.
Among these investments, he said, were $89 million by Coca-Cola in the Praszke soft drink company, $118 million by Kmart in the Prior and Maj Department Store, $250 million by Dow Chemical in the Chemicke Zavody Sokolov company and $27 million by Teepak, a maker of food packaging, in the Cutisin sausage casing company.
Although contractual details of the Tabak sale are still being hammered out, officials of Philip Morris and the Privatization Ministry said there was no doubt that it would go through.
"It's a done deal," said Louis Camilleri, Philip Morris vice president for Eastern Europe. Tabak controls nearly two-thirds of the Czechoslovak cigarette market.
Privatization Ministry officials said Philip Morris would pay $226.2 million for 65 percent of the company. This will be divided into an initial payment of $104.2 million for the first 30 percent, followed by the balance of $122 million within a year.
After that, Philip Morris will invest $187 million in modernization of Tabak and bring its equity stake over 80 percent. The balance will be held by the public.
The deal comes after a long period of American hesitation during which German companies raced ahead and plowed some $2.5 billion into Czechoslovakia. It appears to reflect a growing conviction that the country offers strong long-term prospects despite current difficulties.
 
Aggressive Privatization
 National output plunged 19.5 percent last year and inflation soared above 55 percent, but the country has now brought inflation under control and is pushing forward with the most aggressive privatization plans in Eastern Europe. With low labor costs, a skilled work force and a central position in Europe, the country is being viewed as an increasingly attractive export base by United States and other Western companies.
Mr. Camilleri said Tabak would be used to provide cigarettes for what Philip Morris anticipates will be "a phenomenal growth of exports to Russia, which is short of cigarettes, and also to Central Asia."
Mr. Bakal, who has seen the American company's business plan, said it spoke of exporting at least a billion cigarettes a year to the countries of the former Soviet Union. Unlike in Western Europe and the United States, the former Soviet bloc has stable or growing cigarette consumption.
Philip Morris appears to have paid a high price for the company. The investment bankers advising the Czechoslovak Government said Tabak had profits of about $2 million in 1990 on sales of about $170 million. Philip Morris has thus paid a large premium in an attempt to control the Czechoslovak tobacco market and a build a strong long-term base in Eastern Europe.
R. J. Reynolds, which bid $291 million for Tabak, and the French tobacco company Seita have protested to the Czechoslovak Government over the sale, which they contend was unfair, asserting that Philip Morris had been provided with privileged information on Tabak. A senior official of the Privatization Ministry said these complaints were unfounded and had been rejected.

HEADLINE: 'Nigerian Scam' Lures Companies

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
In the annals of white-collar crime, the trick known as the Nigerian letter scam already stands out as a testimony to criminal energy, not artistry. Sleuths at Scotland Yard, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Interpol and private investigators describe it variously as crude, amateurish and preposterous. But they also agree it is one of the most wide-ranging and bizarre fraud schemes of recent years.
Thousands of American companies, including many in the New York area, have in the last 18 months received bogus letters that like many a street fraud preying on the greedy promise big payoffs in return for playing along and putting up some advance money, according to the International Criminal Police Organization. That agency, known as Interpol, is the coordinating network for police internationally.
 
Loss Estimates Are Sketchy
 
 "You almost never see a net spread this wide in white-collar fraud," said Dan Karson, a managing director of Kroll Associates, a large financial-investigation company in New York. Estimates of the number of victims and their losses are sketchy -- up to more than $200 million worldwide, according to Scotland Yard.
The Financial Crimes Enforcement Network, a Treasury Department unit that investigates white-collar crime, has just issued a warning under the heading "Nigerian Scam" to the banks, lawyers and private investigators who receive its quarterly bulletins.
Here is one common version of the scheme: A letter arrives from a writer who says he is a director of the state-owned Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation. It looks official and reads convincingly, though its offer is unusual.
The writer says he wants to transfer $20 million to your bank account. The money, he writes, was budgeted but never spent, and your help is needed to spirit the questionable funds out of Nigeria. The letter hints strongly that such official shenanigans are a routine part of government and business life in Nigeria.
Your company gets to keep 30 percent of the total -- a cool $6 million -- for playing along. The Nigerians pick up the rest, after expenses. Just to get the process started, you are asked to send a few sheets of your company's letterhead (signed but otherwise blank), your bank account number and other information.
The letter, the director and the offered money, of course, are all fake -- an attempt to dip into the target company's bank account or collect advance fees for the phony transfer of funds. Thousands of similar letters have been sent to companies from Sweden to Australia in the last few years.
"It's a real shotgun approach," agreed Edgar Adamson, an assistant chief of financial fraud for Interpol in Washington. "They just send out all sorts of letters and see who replies."
 
Prosecutions Are Few
 Prosecutions are few and convictions fewer. In Britain, there have been four successful convictions, with the most recent offender sentenced in February to two years in prison for fraud. And last November, the United States Attorney's Office in Manhattan charged two men, Prince Churchill Ovu and Wilson Alex Holland, with defrauding an unnamed New York businessman of $444,000 -- a bogus advance fee to release $18.6 million that, the victim was told, had been illicitly obtained from contractors for the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation.
Many victims are too embarrassed to come forward. When the victims do go to the police, the culprits are hard to find because the letters have fake names.
"The victim is left facing bogus people with bogus documents," said Detective Inspector Paul Brown of Scotland Yard's fraud squad. "Identifying the people behind one of these letters is a big problem."
The Nigerian letter scheme appears to have picked Britain as its first target, starting nearly three years ago. By now, Scotland Yard has more than a thousand letters from British companies, dozens of victims, and a sense that the worst is over. "The anecdotal evidence is that the letters are fewer here and the problem is moving across the Atlantic and to Scandinavia," Detective Inspector Brown said.
 
Bogus Identities
 The letters differ somewhat in the amounts on offer and the bogus identities of their phantom authors, like Rowland Olebara of the state oil company and Chief G. P. Uche of the aviation ministry.
Most of the letters, though not all, are sent from Nigeria. Investigators assume that the Western corporate names are plucked randomly from business directories. The letters are so numerous and sent to so many countries that "there was an assumption for a long time that there was a school for this," said David Brooker Sr., president of the National Fraud Investigation Center Inc., a private investigator in Ambler, Pa. "But it's probably just the streets of Lagos."
The Nigerian Government is understandably distressed by the letter scheme and has tried to curb the fraud. To be sure, Nigeria has been tagged with a reputation for sharp dealing because its citizens have been involved in publicized white-collar schemes in the United States during the 1980's, including credit card, student loan and insurance frauds.
But in a nation of more than 100 million people, the letter-writers represent "a small number of small-time crooks -- and nothing more," said Richard Uku, a counselor in the Nigerian Embassy in Washington. A handful of criminals, he stressed, should not deter the Western investors Nigeria is trying to attract to further its free-market reforms.
To warn foreigners, Nigeria's central bank placed an advertisement last fall about the schemes in major Western newspapers, including The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal and The Washington Post.
 
Some Went to Lagos
 Law enforcement authorities in Britain and the United States say that some victims have met with people in Government buildings in Lagos who said they were Nigerian officials. But the Western investigators add that there is no evidence Nigerian Government officials are involved.
"The Nigerian Government is not a party to this sort of thing," Mr. Uku said. He advises American companies that have received suspicious letters from Nigeria to contact the country's embassy in Washington or the consulate general in New York City.
Besides, Mr. Uku added, victims of the Nigerian letters are partly to blame for their plight. "The people who would bite on this are greedy," he said.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "How the Letter Scheme Works"
 
1) The Mysterious Letter
The letter arrives at a company from Chief Uche, who claims to be chief accountant of a Nigerian Government ministry. It offers to give the company 30 percent of $25 million, or $7.5 million, for helping the Chief transfer the $25 million out of Nigeria. The funds, the letter explains, represent a "deliberate" overpayment by the ministry budgeted to be paid to a foreign contractor. In short, the funds to be transferred are shady. This is meant to give the company the illusion of being in on a lucrative back-channel deal that would be jeopardized if the company checked with authorities
 
2) The Catch
To get the deal started, the letter asks the company to send blank sheets of its letterhead, blank company invoices, the name of the company's bank, its account number, and telex and fax numbers.
 
3) Playing Out the Scheme
If the target firm replies, the Nigerians can use the information and the blank stationary to try to dip into the company's bank account. Or, having found a gullible company, the Nigerians can try to get money directly under the pretense of "advance fees" needed to execute the deal. They may ask the company to purchase air fare for face-to-face meetings, or say the company must pay an "economic recovery tax" supposedly required under Nigerian law before funds can be transferred outside the country.
 
4) The Chief Vanishes
 The documents sent to the company are phony and so are the names of the Nigerian officials. The $25 million transfer never appears. But the company's money is genuinely gone, and the culprits are hard to find.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Slightly Higher And Gold Prices Are Mixed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled marginally higher yesterday in technically driven trading.
Gold prices were slightly higher to lower. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $338 an ounce, up 20 cents from Tuesday. The Republic National Bank later gave a price of $337.50, unchanged from Tuesday. 
The dollar reversed its downward spiral of the last few sessions but still held to a narrow trading range, dealers said. There was little news to move the market.
 
Shrugs Off Trade Report
 Traders did not react to a worse-than-expected report on the United States trade deficit, which climbed to $5.82 billion in March. Americans' appetite for foreign goods pushed imports to an 18-month high, while weakness in overseas markets cut into export sales, the Government said yesterday.
Many were counting on continued improvements in trade to support the economic recovery, but the negative report could be a sign of more bad news.
Currency dealers turned their attention to the Federal Reserve, monitoring the central bank's actions to see if it would intervene in the money markets to push interest rates lower.
When the Fed did not act by midday, traders quickly bought dollars.
"There was one spurt of buying all day," said Kevin Lawrie of the Bank of Boston.
Attention is now centering on tomorrow, when traders think the Fed will take action to trim the discount rate. "There's a lot of talk and rumor and innuendo" about a rate cut, Mr. Lawrie said.
Such a move would be bearish for the dollar, however, since lower interest rates make dollar-denominated securities less valuable to investors.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 129.22 yen, up 0.22 yen from Tuesday. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 129.65 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 129.50 yen, up from 129.10.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.8300, from $1.8400 late on Tuesday. In New York, it cost $1.8310 to buy a pound, less expensive than Tuesday's $1.8385.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.6010 German marks, up from 1.5905; 1.4700 Swiss francs, up from 1.4600; 5.3865 French francs, up from 5.3475; 1,205.00 Italian lire, up from 1,197.00, and 1.1945 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1944.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Making Documentaries for Roosevelt

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:

F. D. R.'s Moviemaker
Memoirs and Scripts
By Pare Lorentz
243 pages. Illustrated. University of Nevada Press. $29.95.
Pare Lorentz, the great American documentary film maker, didn't live to see the publication of his invaluable "F. D. R.'s Moviemaker," but fortunately he completed the manuscript before his death on March 4 at the age of 86. The book is a personal monument to his trailblazing and a reminder of the glory years of that overlooked art form, the social documentary. 
 And it is more. In light of the current harassment of creative artists and performers by political watchdogs, including those who would dismantle public television, the Lorentz memoir serves to recall that the Federal Government was a fountainhead of financial support and encouragement for the arts during the New Deal era.
The Federal Writers' Project employed such struggling authors as Conrad Aiken, Nelson Algren, Saul Bellow, John Cheever, Ralph Ellison and Richard Wright. The more controversial Federal Theater Project, which produced a range of plays, from an all-black version of "Macbeth" to Sinclair Lewis's "It Can't Happen Here," gave work to such talents as John Houseman, John Huston, E. G. Marshall, Arthur Miller and Orson Welles. Under attack from the House Committee on Un-American Activities, the Federal Theater Project was abolished by Congress in 1939.
The title of Lorentz's book is no idle boast. In 1938, President Franklin D. Roosevelt appointed him chief of a newly established small agency, the United States Film Service. With a storyteller's eye, Lorentz describes the scene at a White House dinner in 1939 when the President introduced him to two Episcopalian bishops. They were dressed in velvet knee breeches and were smoking long cigars that reminded the young film maker of Hollywood movie producers. To the annoyance of the bishops and other dignitaries, Roosevelt singled out Lorentz and said: "He's my shooter. He photographs America to show what it's like to our people."
That description was based on a reputation Lorentz shared with John Grierson and Robert Flaherty, two other legends in the documentary field. They used film as an instrument for social change, to expose violations of human dignity and the precious environment, and for educational instruction and occasional propaganda.
In his memoir, Lorentz describes his beginnings in the 1920's as a contributor of brief items to The New Yorker and as a film critic for Judge, Vanity Fair, Town and Country and McCall's. Coming from a poor family in West Virginia, he was familiar with the plight of the homeless and unemployed. He decided to turn his hand from film reviewing to film making.
In 1936, with a budget of $6,000, he wrote and directed "The Plow That Broke the Plains," about the plight of people living in the Dust Bowl and the fragility of the earth's mantle. The documentary, which had a score by Virgil Thomson, was sponsored by the Resettlement Administration. After the Resettlement Administration was adjudged unconstitutional by the Supreme Court, it was moved into the Agriculture Department by Executive order and renamed the Farm Security Administration.
In 1938, Lorentz wrote and directed a second classic, "The River," again with music by Thomson, for the Farm Security Administration. It was a history of the Mississippi River Basin and the effect of the Tennessee Valley Authority on controlling erosion and flooding. This time Lorentz came in with a master print for $49,500. "The River" opened at the Criterion Theater in New York, received universal praise and won the award for best documentary that year at the Venice Film Festival.
Lorentz gave the documentary a new direction in 1939 with "The Fight for Life," an adaptation of Dr. Paul de Kruif's book, for the United States Film Service. By vividly depicting infant mortality in the Chicago slums, the film illustrated the inadequacies of prenatal hygiene. It was released theatrically by Columbia Pictures.
In "The Fight for Life," for which he also wrote the screenplay, Lorentz used Broadway actors, including Myron McCormick, Will Geer and Dudley Digges, to portray doctors. More than two-thirds of the 68-minute film was shot on the scene in real tenements and the Chicago Lying-In Hospital, a fact that the author cites in response to the purists who objected to the use of actors in a documentary.
Students of the documentary will appreciate the background notes and actual scripts of these Lorentz films that appear in the book. His narrative writing is in the spirit of "The Grapes of Wrath" by John Steinbeck and "The People, Yes," by Carl Sandburg. Some of the spirited Depression language in "The Plow That Broke the Plains" and "The River" would be frowned upon today in a Government-sponsored film or over the commercial airwaves.
"F. D. R.'s Moviemaker" blends autobiography and film history. It's a tribute to a bold documentarian and to an idealistic time in the arts.

HEADLINE: PARENT & CHILD

BYLINE: By Lawrence Kutner

 BODY:
WHEN a parent borrows money from a child, it can be an uncomfortable situation for both generations. We've come to expect the opposite, with the younger generation asking the older for financial help to make a down payment, pay tuition or handle a crisis. But there are times when parents must approach their children for assistance. It is an act that can affect their relationship long into the future.
Dr. Bernard Guerney Jr., a professor of human development and counseling psychology at Pennsylvania State University in State College, Pa., said: "There's an old saying: 'When a father helps a son, both smile. When a son helps a father, both cry,' In our culture, for a parent to borrow from a child is often considered shameful and embarrassing." 
 Much of that discomfort derives from the contradictory expectations that parents and children have about their relationships as children enter adulthood. Parents usually hope their children will be more successful than they were, but it is a social leap that has become more difficult for the current generation of young adults. Parents also expect to maintain their independence so they won't be a burden.
Children want to be able to think of their parents as people to whom they can always turn for help. At the same time, they want to be prosperous enough to care for their parents if the need arises.
"There's an inherent conflict there," said Dr. Alan Entin, a family psychologist in Richmond and the past president of the division of family psychology of the American Psychological Association.
Dr. Entin has borrowed money from his children, who are now in their 20's. They had received inheritances from a distant relative and had kept that money in a savings account. He felt obligated to pay for their collegeexpenses, but needed a loan to do so. By borrowing from his children, he could pay at a lower interest rate than he could if he borrowed from a bank. At the same time, he could give his children a higher return than their bank was giving them.
"While it's a straightforward business deal, I had feelings of awkwardness and humility," Dr. Entin added. "I wish I'd had the money in the bank just to write a check."
In most families, however, a request for a loan is prompted by a personal crisis such as a medical emergency or a business problem. Few children would hesitate to help in such a situation if able to do so. But in their rush to help, psychologists said, children may inadvertently do things that lead to trouble. "If you don't talk about your feelings about the money, and such things as what if the parents can't pay it back, then you're setting yourself up for later problems," said Dr. Norman Epstein, a professor of family and community development at the University of Maryland in College Park.
Yet the many symbolic meanings of money in our culture make it especially difficult for families in this situation to discuss their true feelings about the need for a loan or a gift. Parents often feel embarrassed, as if it is a sign of failure instead of circumstance.
"A parent who borrows money from a child will have an awful lot of self-esteem on the line," said Dr. Sandra J. Eller, a clinical assistant professor of psychiatry at the University of Rochester Medical School.
Children may feel uncomfortable asking for details, as if doing so would be an intrusion. By not asking questions, however, they are falling back into their old roles as children, which may leave them resentful.
Dr. Epstein described a 30-year-old man he counseled who had been sending his parents money. Both generations were uneasy discussing money. The parents had asked for help only indirectly. The son had felt it was too awkward to ask whether he'd be repaid. Although he expected that he would be, he never discussed the issue directly with his parents.
"Eventually, he felt so uncomfortable and angry that he avoided his parents," Dr. Epstein said. "He would have felt more comfortable if he'd just given it to them without expectation of being repaid.
"But this way he felt cheated by his parents, even though it wasn't a large sum."
 
THERE'S MORE THAN MONEY INVOLVED IN A LOAN
IF you have decided to ask for money from your children -- or if your parents ask you for a loan -- psychologists have some suggestions to help avoid problems:
Remember that the money is only one part of the transaction.
Discuss the underlying emotions, as well. "The goal at all times should be to preserve or enhance the good feelings in the relationship," said Dr. Sandra J. Eller, a clinical assistant professor of psychiatry at the University of Rochester Medical School. "It's a chance for you to know one another even better."
Recognize that borrowing from a child often puts more pressure on parents than if they had borrowed from a bank. "It tinges all their future interactions," said Dr. Alan Entin, a family psychologist in Richmond. "It's hard for the parents to spend any money on themselves before paying back their children."
Put things in writing.
It is a good idea to do this, even if you don't want it to be a legally binding contract. "It limits the chance of hard feelings," Dr. Eller said. "It can also prevent problems with siblings if the parents die and the child expects to be paid back out of the estate."
Writing an agreement has other benefits, as well. "That businesslike approach helps the parents still feel like adults and in control," said Dr. Norman Epstein, a professor of family and community development at the University of Maryland in College Park. "If the child just slips the money to the parents and doesn't talk about it, it strips the parents of their adulthood."
Recognize that sometimes the best answer is "no."
As with children, there are times when a parent's request for money is simply a sign of a problem, like alcoholism or compulsive gambling, that needs a different approach. Providing the parent with additional money will often make those problems worse. "It puts the children in a difficult bind because they're now in the position of being the parents," Dr. Eller said.
If that is the case, call a family meeting to explore ways to deal with the real issues and to get the outside help that's needed.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Punish the Serbs

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In the face of Serbia's bloody invasion of its neighbors, President Bush has ducked under his desk in a way that recalls Benjamin Harrison's 1888 doctrine: "We Americans have no commission from God to police the world."
Excuses for inaction range from "it's Europe's problem" to "our vital interests are not involved" to "those historic hatreds run so deep, there's nothing anybody can do." 
 The unspoken excuse is that in an election year, no American politician wants to commit American forces to what may be a quagmire. Yet the lack of any threat of harsh consequences encourages the aggression.
What would the other candidates do to stop the killing if they were President right now? I phoned that question to Ross Perot's spokesman and was faxed this prompt, if Carteresque, response: "I would be actively working with the United Nations in an effort to restore peace to the area." Can't get in trouble with a platitude.
Bill Clinton, after criticizing Bush "indifference," responded: "The United States and the international community must adopt immediately the kinds of tough sanctions that will make the Milosevic regime pay a heavy price for continuing its aggression, such as freezing assets, an oil embargo, and suspension or expulsion from appropriate international organizations."
That's at least a policy that offers change. Opinion makers as far apart as Anthony Lewis and Jeane Kirkpatrick agree that if collective security is to have meaning, the President of the United States must do more during mass slaughter than send Margaret Tutwiler out to wring her hands and play Benjamin Harrison.
Last year we saw how televised pictures of atrocities turned around a callous, let-it-happen policy in Iraq. After the public outcry, Mr. Bush put a protective air cap over much of Iraqi Kurdistan; as a result, this week, for the first time in a thousand years, Kurds are voting in a free, democratic election.
A Bosnia-Herzegovinan official -- this year's Haile Selassie -- says that if the world intervened to escort relief to starving, persecuted Kurds, why not Bosnians? "We are real people, too."
Did America set a precedent by protecting the Kurds? Or was that a special case, where our interests were at stake, where we had a moral responsibility because we had called for the anti-Saddam uprising, and where the American public supported our intervention?
Answer: both. The extent of our participation will depend on previous commitment, vital national interest and sphere of influence. But wherever in the world brutality is inflicted on millions of people, America's place is in the vanguard of marshaling civilization's response.
The Serbs have earned a reputation for ferocity. They are now represented by -- and not oppressed by -- their own dictator, Slobodan Milosevic. They are seizing territory they believe was stolen from them. If this causes death and desolation, they say, so be it -- Serbs have suffered in the past, too.
Sorry, but the law of the jungle has been repealed. No longer should any people get away with barbarism in the name of vengeance.
How do we stop the killing? The international community -- that's Germany, France, Britain, Russia and the U.S., under U.N. or regional auspices -- must put an intolerable cost on continued aggression.
This does not mean Operation Balkan Storm; the Serbs, unlike the Iraqis, would fight forever. Nor would this mean namby-pamby sanctions like suspending airline landing rights.
It means, as Mr. Clinton suggests, embargoing Serbia's oil and freezing its assets. Beyond that, we should impinge on its long-sought sovereignty by seizing Serbian airspace, much as we have done in Kurdistan.
This would not immediately stop Serbian aggression, but it would be a painful and humiliating penalty. Peacemakers would have cards to play.
Harrisonism need not paralyze us. "Chronic wrongdoing," wrote Theodore Roosevelt, "or an impotence which results in a general loosening of the ties of civilized society, may . . . ultimately require intervention by some civilized nation."
Update that to "alliance of nations" and apply the responsibility to intervene to the Balkans today.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Mockery of Justice

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
On one side in the lawsuit is the United States Government, represented by the Justice Department. On the other is a group of Haitian refugees held at the U.S. base in Guantanamo, Cuba, represented by some Yale law students, their professor and other volunteers.
One might think that the Government would be content with those odds -- with its great advantages in power, money and legal resources. Not so. 
 The Justice Department has brought heavy pressure on the volunteer lawyers, evidently trying to intimidate them out of the case. It has made extreme, hysterical arguments with no visible basis in fact. In its conduct in this case -- this amazing case -- the Department has grossly abused its position. Why? What is going on?
The plaintiffs, who fled the brutal Haitian military regime in small boats and were picked up by the U.S. Navy, are in a special category. All of them have been screened by the Immigration and Naturalization Service and found to have a "credible fear" of political persecution in Haiti. By our own official finding, then, they are likely candidates for political asylum in the United States, not just people looking for a better economic life.
The only issue in the lawsuit is whether the refugees can talk to a lawyer before a final determination of their asylum claim. The Yale law students want to go to Guantanamo, at their own expense, to question and advise them. The Government strenuously objects.
Just three months ago the Justice Department told the Supreme Court that, "under current practice," Haitian refugees who pass the first screening would be "brought to the United States . . . for a full adjudicatory determination" of their asylum claim. That meant a hearing with a lawyer.
But the practice changed. And when the Yale law students sued for the right to meet the refugees, the Justice Department responded with a sledgehammer.
The department asked the Federal courts to impose sanctions on the plaintiffs' lawyers -- Prof. Harold Hongju Koh of Yale and Michael Ratner of the Center for Constitutional Rights -- for bringing a "frivolous" lawsuit. It demanded that the plaintiffs put up a bond of $10 million, the largest bond ever sought in the New York Federal courts.
The case was heard by Judge Sterling Johnson Jr. of the Eastern District of New York, who was appointed by President Bush last year. He fixed a bond of $5,000. And he decided the case in favor of the refugees, ordering the Government to let the Yale students interview them and, meanwhile, not to send any back to Haiti.
Before an appeal could be heard, the Justice Department rushed to the Supreme Court and asked for an emergency stay of Judge Johnson's order. It claimed that the order had "fueled a nearly 20-fold increase in the number of Haitian migrants attempting to enter the United States illegally."
What was the basis for that extraordinary claim? All the Justice Department offered was an unsupported statement by a State Department official that in her "considered judgment" Judge Johnson's order had "contributed in significant part to the increased outflow of Haitians."
The Supreme Court voted 5 to 4 to issue a stay. The case is now before the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
A lawsuit that the trial judge decided in the plaintiffs' favor could hardly be "frivolous" but the Justice Department demand for sanctions on the lawyers is still there.
In its Supreme Court papers Justice relied on the 1950 case of Ellen Knauff, a war bride who was kept out of the United States as a security risk without being told why. The Supreme Court narrowly upheld that procedure. But the case aroused such outrage that the Attorney General changed his mind and let her in.
The Haitian refugees are asking for much less than Ellen Knauff: just the chance to see a lawyer. But it is worth recalling Justice Robert Jackson's dissent in the Knauff case:
"Security is like liberty in that many are the crimes committed in its name. The menace to the security of this country . . . is as nothing compared to the menace to free institutions inherent in procedures of this pattern."

HEADLINE: America's Urban Apartheid

BYLINE: By David Rusk; David Rusk, the former mayor of Albuquerque, N.M., is guest scholar at the Woodrow Wilson Center.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Stirred by the smoldering ashes of South-Central Los Angeles, a new generation of politicians is poised to make the same mistakes about cities, race and poverty that were made after the Watts riots 27 years ago. They do not realize that urban poverty can be overcome only by bringing down the walls between cities and suburbs.
Liberals appeal for large-scale Federal aid for inner-city social welfare and economic development -- the Big Buck strategy. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Jack Kemp, renews his call for inner-city enterprise zones, public housing "perestroika" and "empowerment" -- the Big Bootstrap strategy. 
 At heart, both the Big Buckers and Big Bootstrappers embrace the same views: Quarantine poor blacks and Hispanics in inner-city ghettoes and help them build from within. Both camps believe that separate can be made equal -- or at least equal enough to be tolerable.
But the 1990 census testifies to different truths. First, separate is invariably unequal. Second, the real city now is the total metropolitan area -- city and suburbs. According to the census, of the 200 largest metropolitan areas, about two-thirds follow the characteristic patterns of modern American urban apartheid.
Most poor blacks and Hispanics are penned up in inner cities. They are surrounded by suburbs that are at least 90 percent white. The number of jobs in the cities is declining, while suburban jobs grow. City incomes have dropped to 88 percent of suburban incomes. Public education has fragmented into multiple school systems, separating children by race and class.
But about 60 of the metropolitan areas have significantly lower levels of racial and economic segregation. A dozen of these are "cities without suburbs" like Albuquerque, N.M., Colorado Springs and Huntsville, Ala., which have aggressively annexed emerging suburbs. In such cities, typically 74 percent of the metropolitan population lives and pays taxes in the city (as against 33 percent for all other central cities). Incomes of city residents are 113 percent those of suburbanites. Public services and facilities are more adequate. City planning and zoning encourage affordable housing throughout the area. School districts are well integrated.
About 50 other metropolitan areas have developed almost without central cities. Places like Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood-Pompano Beach, Fla. and Vallejo-Fairfield-Napa, Cal. are really "suburbs without cities." Their dominant, unifying institutions are strong county governments and large, sometimes county-wide school systems. Low-income minorities have not been highly ghettoized, and middle class families have no place and no reason to flee. If the poor and middle class are not always neighbors, they are still taxpayers and citizens in common.
Why has this happened? In part, these metropolitan areas are newer, smaller and have had steady economic growth. But they are helped by unified city or county governments and public schools that link city and suburb.
How can older cities reverse their balkanization into racial and economic enclaves? It's unlikely to happen through local ballot boxes. It will be a rare white county commissioner or black city mayor with the vision and courage to challenge white fears or black community empowerment.
But the political power for reform exists -- in state capitals. Governors and state legislatures can consolidate fractionalized local governments and merge school districts. They can enact metropolitan area tax-sharing arrangements, affordable-housing quotas and state funding of local schools.
Utopian fantasies? Hardly. Somewhere in this country all of these strategies have been put into practice -- and they work. What's lacking is the political will to act. The "urban problem" is not some insurmountable economic given. It's the product of racism and classism. Los Angeles warns us again: It's long past time to start building that political will.

HEADLINE: Recognizing Macedonia Can Only Fuel Conflict

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "The Name Game in Macedonia" (editorial, May 15), similar to "The Two Macedonias" (editorial, April 5), you insist on the recognition of the "defenseless nation of two million Slavs, Albanians and Turks" with the name of Macedonia. This name was usurped by Stalin and Tito in 1945 for expansionary reasons in the Greek region of Macedonia, Aristotle's birthplace, and in the Aegean Sea. If it is not for future expansion, why don't the Skopjan leaders use a name related to their Slavic heritage, of which they should be proud?
After recognition of this tiny republic, Slav, Albanian, Greek, Bulgarian or Turkish minorities may try to join their neighboring mother countries and engage in bloody fighting similar to that of Bosnia. Such editorials may fuel further conflicts and the "Balkanization" of the area, which may be worse than the Lebanon strife, with the possible involvement of neighboring countries. 
 An effective policy may be to support an associated membership of the former Yugoslav republics in the European Community, steaming out ethnic conflicts, giving hope for economic and socio-political improvement and increasing U.S. trade and investment.
 
NICHOLAS V. GIANARIS
New York, May 15, 1992
 
The writer, professor of economics at Fordham University, is author of a forthcoming book on the Balkans.

HEADLINE: To Solve Urban Crisis, New Version of W.P.A.

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The Los Angeles Law: Use It" (editorial, May 14) seems to hold that the solution to our urban crisis is putting more money into old programs that haven't succeeded.
Contrary to your suggestion that welfare recipients or the unemployed are not educationally or emotionally ready for stable jobs, the inner-city poor are ready and willing to work. Their only handicap is a welfare system that robs them of a sense of community and motivation. 
 Those people who once worked for the Works Progress Administration and the Civilian Conservation Corps can look back with pride on their tangible contributions to society. That sense of pride, of belonging, of learning a skill leading to gainful employment has been lost under our welfare system. Training and education are useful, but if no jobs are available they are of little help.
A bipartisan consensus is building for our proposal to bring back a modern version of the W.P.A. and C.C.C. Jobs would range from building parks to helping at hospitals or delivering meals to the elderly. As an added benefit, existing surplus military facilities and equipment as well as skilled military personnel being forced to take early retirement could be used in the program.
Increased financing for existing welfare and job-training programs alone is not the answer. What is needed is a new approach that looks at what has worked in the past. If we are to solve our urban crisis, we need to work our way out of it -- literally.
 
(Senator) DAVID L. BOREN
(Senator) PAUL SIMON
Washington, May 15, 1992

HEADLINE: Congressional Panel Votes to Keep at Least One Seawolf Submarine

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20

 BODY:
A House-Senate conference committee voted today to save one of two Seawolf submarines President Bush had hoped to cut from the budget and to set aside an additional $550 million toward building either a second Seawolf or a smaller submarine.
The decision was a victory for the New England Congressional delegations, which struggled for more than a year to keep the submarine program alive and guarantee the continued operations of the General Dynamics Electric Boat shipyard in Groton, Conn. The shipyard provides more than 10,000 jobs. 
 The action on Seawolf was part of an overall-budget adjustment bill, known as a rescission, which would slash $7.1 billion from programs for which Congress had already appropriated money. The Congressional negotiators also agreed today to cut $500 million out of this year's budget appropriation for the B-2 stealth bomber and $200 million more from the Strategic Defense Initiative program.
"We came out a winner," said Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut. He said that Mr. Bush's proposal to cut more than $3 billion from this year's Seawolf budget had been "a death notice" for the shipyard. Under the conference committee's compromise, $1.15 billion would be carved from the program.
The House and Senate are expected to vote in favor of the committee decision within the next few days.
Mr. Dodd, like many liberal Democrats around the country, finds himself in the position of defending a military program that the Pentagon no longer supports. But salvaging the Seawolf, at least for a couple of years, is expected to help them make the case that they are fighting for local jobs.
Mr. Bush himself went to Congress last month to lobby against the Seawolf, after the Pentagon argued that dwindling dollars could be spent more wisely on other programs. The Seawolf is a stealth submarine that was designed to track a Soviet submarine fleet that is now in disarray.
The conference committee decision came as a compromise between the Senate, which wanted to salvage both Seawolf submarines, and the House, which wanted to save only one. House conferees remained steadfast against building two, in large part because the large California delegation would not have tolerated a deeper cut in the B-2 program, and there would not have been enough money to build two Seawolf submarines without further B-2 cutbacks.
 
Views on 'Star Wars'
 Meanwhile, Mr. Bush had promised to veto any bill that cut deeply into the Strategic Defense Initiative program, popularly known as "Star Wars."
The director of the "Star Wars" program, Henry F. Cooper, told the Senate Armed Services Committee today that Congress's order to rush a limited, ground-based anti-missile system into the field posed "a high risk" of delays and cost overruns.
Mr. Cooper said the risk in fielding the system by 1997 was "acceptable," but Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia and Senator Carl Levin of Michigan, both Democrats, criticized putting into effect any such high-risk program.
Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona and the leading opponent of the Seawolf in Congress, was sharply critical of the decision, calling it "a hare-brained scheme." He said he would urge Mr. Bush to veto the rescission bill and ask him to introduce an alternative bill to cut both Seawolf submarines again.
"You can never justify defense spending to create jobs because," said Mr. McCain.
Before the Soviet Union collapsed, the Administration had planned to build 29 Seawolf submarines. That number was reduced to three, then one.
One Seawolf is now being constructed. Under the conference committee compromise, a second $1.9 billion Seawolf would be built. Afterward, the Defense Department would have the option to apply an additional $550 million to a third Seawolf or to construct a Los Angeles-class nuclear submarine, a vessel the Seawolf was designed to replace.
Mr. Dodd said building the submarines would serve as "a bridge" until the region can convert its economy from military spending.
Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Connecticut's other Democratic Senator, said the conference committee decision would preserve "our nation's capacity to produce submarines into the next century." He argued that by building the Seawolf submarines, the Groton plant would remain primed to build the next class of nuclear submarines, the Centurions, scheduled for the production line in 1998.
Mr. McCain said the Centurions could be built in another shipyard. "I'm not sure we will even need the Centurion," he said.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 23, 1992, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about Congressional action on the Seawolf submarine program quoted Senator John McCain incompletely. The Senator said, "You can never justify defense spending to create jobs because it's the most inefficient way to spend money."
