HEADLINE: The Road To Rio -- Setting an Agenda for the Earth;
Homesteaders Gnaw at Brazil Rain Forest

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MARACA, Brazil

 BODY:
Bright green manioc plants sprouting among charred tree trunks and a constant hammering and sawing on house frames are signs that a new colony of homesteaders has arrived in this remote corner of the Amazon, an area covered only a year ago by tropical rain forest.
"I worked all my life as a sharecropper," explained Antonio Rodrigues dos Santos, a 38-year-old migrant from Brazil's impoverished northeast. "Now I have my own land," he added with satisfaction. With bulldozers standing by to resume road work when the dry season begins in June, the number of houses in this new town is expected to jump this year from 5 to 120. 
 Also in June, almost 2,000 miles south of here, 100 world leaders will meet in Rio de Janeiro for the so-called Earth Summit. To polish its environmental image, Brazil volunteered to serve as host of the meeting, officially titled the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development.
Now, Brazil is expected to point to statistics charting a steady fall in Amazon deforestation rates. But as the desolation here attests, the problem endures, fueled by commercial logging interests, a regional yearning for economic development and a land hunger among refugees from Brazil's poverty bowl, its overpopulated northeast.
After weathering heavy criticism over Amazon destruction in the late 1980's, Brazilians will issue statistics next month that indicate a 63 percent drop in annual deforestation rates in Brazil's Amazon since 1985. Encouraged by the new numbers, Brazil's Government recently reversed its position and decided to back adoption of a "Statement of Principles on Forests" at the Earth Summit.
Based on analysis of photographs taken by Landsat 5 satellites over the Amazon, researchers at Brazil's National Institute for Space Research calculate that the annual deforestation rate dropped from a high of 11,580 square miles in 1985 to 4,299 square miles in an annual period ending in August 1991.
"If last year's rate remains unchanged, it would take us 330 years to finish off the Amazon," said Luiz Gylvan Meira Filho, who directs the program at the institute near Sao Paulo. Seen as a pioneer in deforestation documentation, the institute is training research teams for the seven other nations of the Amazon basin -- Suriname, Guyana, Venezuela, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru and Bolivia.
Brazilian and United States scientists attribute the decline in forest burning rates to a series of factors: the suspension of tax incentives for ranching and logging projects in the Amazon, a sharp decline in the Brazilian economy, a public information campaign coupled with fines levied against violators of forest laws, and rainfall during traditional burning seasons.
"I have no reason to doubt the numbers," Philip M. Fearnside, a United States ecologist in Manaus and a frequent critic of Brazilian Government policies, said. "The main reason for the drop in burning is the economy."
 
10% of Amazon Forest Lost
 Dr. Fearnside calculates that about 10 percent of the forest cover of Brazil's Amazon has been removed. Measuring 1.9 million square miles, Brazil's portion of the Amazon -- 60 percent of the total -- stretches over a land mass equal to the United States east of the Mississippi.
But, with an Amazon forest area twice the size of Delaware going up in smoke last year, scientists warn that dangers to the forest are still strong, especially at the edges.
Out of this huge area, the southeast corner of Amapa state offers a microcosm of the region's pressures and of the players: a new road bringing homesteaders from Brazil's overpopulated and destitute northeast, a large wood pulp company seeking to expand operations, and local unionists joining with United States and European environmentalists to preserve a forest area larger than Rhode Island for 2,000 families who live off the land.
A frontier territory that became a state in 1988, Amapa had the third fastest population growth rate -- 4.5 percent -- of Brazil's 27 states and territories in the 1980's. The two states with higher rates -- Rondonia and Roraima -- are also in the Amazon.
"We are finally living the way God intended," Mariane dos Santos Castro, a 37-year-old settler and mother of six, said in their two-room palm-thatched shack built near the new road, BR-156. "Before we didn't earn enough to pay for a children's pair of shoes."
 
Homesteaders Stake Claims
 Her husband, Otacilio Pereira da Silva, said that after moving to Amapa from Brazil's drought stricken state of Ceara, he had struggled for years working the land of others. Last year, when road graders started smoothing a new 100-mile road from Macapa, the state capital, to the state border at Jari River, he staked a claim to 250 acres.
Today, in fields marked by gray skeletons of jungle trees, he grows corn and manioc. To earn some cash, he hopes to work in this dry season for a timber company that has applied for permission to cut logs in the nearby Cajari Extractive Reserve.
The federally financed road, a line of graded dirt through thick forest, enjoys powerful political backing in the state. One Amapa senator, Henrique Almeida, is part owner of the construction company, C.R. Almeida. Another Amapa senator, Jose Sarney, who is a former President of Brazil, won election to Congress 18 months ago by promising residents along the Jari River that he would end their isolation.
 
3 Hours From the Movies
 Euclides Reckziegel, head of forestry management at the Jari tree farm, 75 miles west of here, said, "We will be only three hours from restaurants, movie theaters, car dealerships and Macapa's new free trade zone."
Remo Scalabrin, operations manager at Jari, agreed. "Even though the road goes through our land, we aren't against it," he said. "You can't be against the march of history."
Dissenting voices are rare and not very popular in this frontier land. Development advocates complain that 35 percent of Amapa state is off bounds to economic exploitation -- protected by Indian reservations, extractive reserves, national and state parks.
Pedro Ramos, a state representative to the National Council of Rubber Tappers, opposes paving the road. A few days before the environmental hearing, two men visited the union leader at his house and beat him severely with wooden clubs.
The attack drew public protests from United States, Canadian and German environmental groups who are helping the union assert control over the reserve, which begins 20 miles west of here on the new road.
 
Minority Opposes Road
 "I'm against the road," said Elson Martins da Silveira, a Macapa newspaper editor, voicing a minority opinion. "The history of roads in the Amazon is that the Government builds them without a development plan and it becomes a path for disordered growth."
Calixto Pinto de Souza, president of the Cajari Reserve Association, added: "We can't let in people who will disrupt the forest. They can't be trusted. They will have 10 children, and then will want more land."
Mr. de Souza said he has received death threats, not only for insisting that strict controls be placed on road traffic through the reserve, but also for opposing an application by the Jari project to deforest 20 miles of native forest to plant eucalyptus.
Founded by a United States investor in 1967, the Jari project claims title to 6,500 square miles of contiguous forest in Para and Amapa -- an area larger than Connecticut and Rhode Island. Now Brazilian-owned, the company finds that Government opinion in Brasilia has shifted against large projects in the Amazon.
The new president of Brazil's environmental protection agency has said she will not issue a logging permit.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Sales Tax Cut 1 Cent As G.O.P. Overrides Florio Veto

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 21

 BODY:
The Republican majority in the New Jersey Legislature overrode Gov. Jim Florio's veto today and made good on their promise to cut the penny from the state sales tax that the Democrats put there two years ago.
The Republicans said they were acting to protect the taxpayers and spur the economy in reducing the sales tax to 6 cents a dollar from 7 and producing the largest tax cut in New Jersey history, $608 million in next year's budget. 
The Democrats charged that it was irresponsible to reduce the tax without specifying what would be cut to make up the revenue and they argued that property-tax payers, mass transit riders and the elderly would inevitably be hurt.
 
First Overriding in a Decade
 The overriding of the Governor's veto, the first in a decade, passed comfortably, 59 to 9 in the Assembly, five more votes than needed, and 29 to 2 in the Senate, two more than needed in that house. One Democrat joined with the Republican majority in the Assembly and two in the Senate to override the veto. The last such action was in 1982 when Gov. Thomas H. Kean's veto of a bill to allow a moment of silence in the schools was overridden, but later struck down by the courts.
Governor Florio pronounced himself "happy to see taxes go down," but added, "People all over the state have been saying, slow down and make sure this is a good deal."
"Now," he said, "the Legislature begins the job of cutting $1 billion. I join with the people of the state in awaiting the results of that effort."
The Assembly Speaker, Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, said that his party's proposed cuts would be on the Governor's desk for his consideration by early June.
Republican leaders have hinted that a chief target is the one of the Governor's favorite programs, homestead rebates for homeowners and renters, budgeted at $685 million for next year. The Republicans are expected to cut at least half of that.
Other items that may face cuts include aid to cities and towns, aid to mass transit and the jobs of state employees, especially middle managers.
Some critics of the rollback, particularly the elderly, observe that the 1-cent reduction would amount to less than $77 per capita. That amount, they maintain, is not enough to make up for what are likely to be substantial reductions in homestead rebates that now range up to $500.
Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco of Scotch Plains said the tax reduction and the overriding of the Governor's veto had redeemed the first part of the Republican Party's pledge to reduce taxes and spending. In November the party swept to veto-proof majorities in both houses on the strength of resentment over the record tax increase rushed through the Legislature in 1990 by Governor Florio and the Democrats.
"Next," Mr. DiFrancesco said, "we are preparing to fulfill our second commitment to the people of New Jersey by delivering a budget that will reduce the size of state government."
The Republicans have vowed not only to cut from the budget the $608 million in lost revenues that will result from the sales-tax reduction, but also to cut another $400 million, for a total of $1 billion. That would reduce Mr. Florio's proposed budget for the fiscal year that starts on July 1 from $15.7 billion to $14.7 billion.
 
'Political Gamesmanship'
 To make those cuts, the Florio administration made clear, the Republicans are on their own. Secretary of State Daniel Dalton, himself the former Democratic Senate majority leader, called the rollback "a farce" and "political gamesmanship."
The outcome was a foregone conclusion since Wednesday, when the last Republican holdout in the Senate, Henry P. McNamara of Franklin Lakes, announced that he would vote to override. Mr. McNamara had abstained from voting for the original repeal when it was passed by an overwhelming majority six weeks ago because of concerns that he did not know what programs would be cut to make up the difference.
In explaining his decision to override, he said: "I now realize that Governor Florio is committed to keeping things the way they are, the way they have been. He believes beyond a shadow of a doubt that 'good' government means government which keeps spending more and more of working people's money."
"The people who work hard and pay the taxes have had enough. They want a change," he said.
 
Joined by One Democrat
 There had never been any doubt that the Republicans would achieve the overriding in the Assembly, where they hold 58 seats to the Democrats' 22, four more than needed to override. They did, joined by one Democrat, Robert G. Smith of Piscataway. Mr. Smith is running for the Democratic nomination for the House of Representatives in the Sixth Congressional District against Frank Pallone Jr., an incumbent with a record of opposing taxes.
Twelve other Democrat voted to support the Governor's veto, and the nine others abstained.
In the Senate, two Democrats, Raymond J. Zane of Woodbury and John H. Adler of Haddonfield, joined with the Republicans in voting to override the veto.
With the outcome ordained, so was the debate, but with the presence of television cameras from New Jersey Network on the floor and the vote itself being considered historic, few legislators passed up the opportunity to speak. The Assembly debate that began shortly after 10 in the morning thus stretched three and a half hours into the afternoon.
Democrats dwelt on the refusal of Republicans to talk about what programs, services and jobs they planned to cut and who would be hurt, and the Republicans dwelt on the need for fiscal restraint and a curb on unbridled spending.
Assembly Speaker Haytaian, of Hackettstown, repeatedly warned Democrats to stick to the issue at hand, which he maintained was the tax cut itself, while Democrats repeatedly raised the question, "Who gets hurt?"
Though the debate in the Assembly was partisan, it was amiable.
At one point, when he was cautioned several times by Mr. Haytaian not to stray from the tax cut itself, Assemblyman Louis A. Romano of West New York said, "I would remind the Speaker that I was the only member of the Assembly who stayed to the end during his speech to the Jewish war veterans."
Mr. Haytaian replied, "That's why I haven't ruled you out of order already."
 
Brief Partisan Burst
 Things were a bit less amiable in the Senate. Senator Randy Corman of Sayreville, for example, in one brief burst of partisanship, called the Governor's conditional veto "a diabolically clever example of cynical political hardball," "a fraud and a farce," "irresponsible," "malevolent" and "a devious document."
For their part, Democrats like the assistant Senate minority leader, Richard A. Cody of West Orange, accused the Republicans of "operating under the cover of darkness" and being "afraid to tell the truth" about what they planned to cut from the budget.
Similarly, John A. Lynch of New Brunswick, the former Democratic Senate President and now the minority leader, accused the Republicnas of embarking on "a mystery saga with a surprise ending."

HEADLINE: U.S., IN NEW POLICY, WILL NOT PICK UP ALL HAITI REFUGEES

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
With refugee centers at Guantanamo Bay Naval Base filled to capacity, the Administration announced today that the Coast Guard would no longer pick up all the Haitians fleeing their country in rickety boats for the United States.
The Coast Guard said that people in boats bobbing in Caribbean waters would be asked first to return to Haiti. But it acknowledged the possibility that more Haitians might sail to Florida, risking drowning and posing new problems for United States officials who worry that a tide of refugees will overwhelm the state's social services.
 
Embargo Is Questioned
 The new policy, described as part of a re-examination of the Administration's procedures for Haitian refugees, reflects a growing feeling among officials that the embargo against Haiti is doing little more than ruining the country's economy and motivating masses of poor people to emigrate. Officials say they fear that in picking up the refugees just off the Haitian coast, the United States is encouraging more and more Haitians to flee. 
 "Our hope is that people won't put to sea and risk their lives," said Richard Boucher, a State Department spokesman.
Under the new Coast Guard procedures, if a ship commander decides that a boatload of refugees is in no "imminent danger" -- that the vessel is strong enough and contains enough food and water for the voyage to Florida -- he will not pick them up.
Rather, officers will encourage the Haitians to sail back to Haiti, although an Administration official said "the incentives and disincentives have not been totally worked out." However, the Coast Guard said it did not have the authority to force a boat in international waters to return to Haiti.
 
Base Closed to New Refugees
 The Coast Guard announcement came shortly after Pentagon officials decided they could not accept any more refugees at the tent camps at the naval base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, because of the strain on its water, electrical and sewage systems. The Coast Guard will now process any new refugees on seven cutters patrolling off the Haitian coast. Three additional patrol boats are on their way to provide extra space for those who are newly rescued.
The Coast Guard said the patrol boats could reach the waters off Haiti by tonight.
Guantanamo Bay Naval Base, where the Coast Guard has housed nearly 250 new refugees a day in recent weeks, reached its maximum capacity after three Coast Guard cutters unloaded 400 Haitians picked up on Wednesday. The 10,404 rescued in May is a one-month record since President Jean-Bertrand Aristide of Haiti was overthrown in an army coup in September.
More than 12,000 refugees are currently crammed into the base, including 1,100 who have been denied asylum and are awaiting their return to Haiti. More than 100 are processed and forcibly returned every day.
The Coast Guard estimates that it has picked up 34,090 Haitians from 461 vessels since Oct. 29. It says it has no estimates of the number who may have drowned in attempting the crossing to Florida.
Some 10,000 who have fled Haiti since the coup, or about a third of the total, have received asylum or otherwise been approved for entry into the United States, and 13,918 have been repatriated, including 259 today.
It is the sizable number accepted by the United States that is encouraging Haitians to board their boats in hopes of being rescued and taken to Guantanamo. A State Department official said the Coast Guard was announcing its new policy with some fanfare so "Haitians will know" and be discouraged from sailing.
"If we determine that they're not in imminent distress, and they are in international waters," said Petty Officer Joe Dye, a Coast Guard spokesman in Miami, "we're strongly encouraging them to turn around and go back to Haiti. We're not picking up every vessel we come across."
He said that if the Coast Guard found a leaking boat, "we will take immediate action to save their lives."
 
Repeated Flights Noted
 Officials noted that the new policy was mostly intended to deter Haitians who sail out just beyond the 12-mile limit of their country's waters and wait there hoping they will be picked up by the Coast Guard and taken to Guantanamo for immigration processing. When they are not picked up, the officials said, they usually return to Haiti on their own.
Petty Officer Dye noted that many Haitian refugees had been picked up "two or three times," taken to Guantanamo, and returned to Haiti. "They say it's better in Guantanamo Bay then it is in Haiti," he added.
He said the Coast Guard knew of no Haitian refugee vessel to have reached the United States since October 1990, although a few had landed in the Bahamas. He said two boats had capsized in Cuban waters, resulting in an unknown number pf drownings.
State Department officials said the Administration was considering a variety of ways to modify its repatriation policy, but they were vague on their options. One official said there was little likelihood that the Administration would stop accepting political refugees since that would contradict international law.
"The options are about what do you do with people in transit and what do you do with people screened out and waiting to go back," a State Department official said.
 
Four Killed in Capital
 Seeking to explain the new surge in Haitian emigration, officials noted that weather and sea current patterns in recent weeks had been favorable for crossings.
The political tensions that have buffeted Haiti since the coup have not subsided, and there appears no end to the confrontation between the army and the impoverished masses who still support Father Aristide.
In Haiti today, soldiers poured into the streets of Port-au-Prince to disperse protesters who had set up barricades of old tires. Four people were killed in separate incidents, Reuters reported.
Anti-Government forces are trying to get a general strike under way. Many schools closed today and traffic around the capital was light, but a crackdown by security forces appears to be intimidating many from taking part in the strike.
The flight of Haitians has been accompanied by an effort by American civil liberties and refugee groups to permit as many as possible to remain in this country. State Department officials are critical of the Immigration and Naturalization Service for granting political asylum to such a high percentage of Haitian refugees, insisting that the vast majority are leaving their country for economic and not political reasons.
The Pentagon is also unhappy because the overcrowding at Guantanamo has burdened the base, which is built on land leased from Cuba, and provided a propaganda opening for the Castro Government.

HEADLINE: SMOKING DECLINES AT A FASTER PACE

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ATLANTA, May 21

 BODY:
Smoking in the United States has reached its lowest level in 37 years because of health concerns, the increasing cost of cigarettes and public smoking restrictions, Federal health officials said today.
The Centers for Disease Control reported that 25.5 percent of adult Americans smoked in 1990, the latest year for which figures are available. That is the lowest since the agency began monitoring smoking in 1955. 
 "This tells us that Americans are responding perhaps in even greater numbers to the public health education campaign that's occurring," said Dr. Gary Giovino, the chief smoking epidemiologist at the centers.
 
Decline Becomes Steeper
 The percentage of Americans who smoke has been decreasing at a rate of 1.1 percentage points a year since 1987, more than double the rate of decrease from 1965 to 1985. If the rate continues, the country will meet its national health objective of reducing the rate to 15 percent of Americans by the year 2000, the agency said.
"An awareness of the health consequences, the increased cost of cigarettes and the declining social acceptance all contributed to this," Dr. Giovino said.
The Atlanta-based agency surveyed 40,666 people in 1990. The prevalence of smoking was highest among American Indians, high school dropouts and people ages 25 to 44. The lowest levels were people over age 75 (6.5 percent) and college graduates (13.5 percent).
 
Decline Among Women
 The sharpest declines occurred along lines of race and sex.
From 1965 through 1985, 39 percent to 45 percent of women ages 20-24 who had a high school education or less smoked. In 1990, the percentage dropped to 33.4.
In 1965, 43 percent of blacks smoked; it was down to 26.2 percent in 1990.
Economics and social acceptability also played crucial roles in the decline, Dr. Giovino said.
The average cost of cigarettes jumped from 23 cents a pack in 1955, when 42 percent of Americans smoked, to $1.74 last year. The average smoker puffs 19.1 cigarettes a day, just less than a pack a day.
Social acceptability can be measured in part by clean-air policies, Dr. Giovino said.
Forty-four states and the District of Columbia have instituted some form of smoking restrictions in public places, and 85 percent of employers had workplace smoking policies last year, compared with 54 percent in 1987.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Study Cites Death Toll
 LONDON, May 21 (AP) -- Cigarettes will kill one in five people in industrialized countries, according to a worldwide analysis based on American studies of smoking.
The study is being published in Saturday's issue of The Lancet, a British medical journal.
"It had been thought about a quarter of smokers died from smoking-related deaths," said Prof. Richard Peto, the leading investigator at the Imperial Cancer Research Center at Oxford University. "Now we know at least a third of smokers, and maybe closer to a half of smokers, die from it."
Tobacco has been linked with increased risks of cancers of the lung, mouth, pharynx, larynx, esophagus, kidney, and bladder. Smokers are also at increased risk of heart disease, emphysema and other chronic lung ailments.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Politics of Morality;
Speech by Quayle on Family Values Raises Questions About Thrust of Bush Campaign

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
Vice President Dan Quayle and his staff were clearly delighted by the stir he caused with his gibe at Murphy Brown, but the underlying question is whether the ensuing debate on family values was good for the 1992 Republican Presidential ticket or just for Mr. Quayle.
The Vice President's speech, delivered during a three-day political swing that was carefully planned to generate as much publicity as possible, clearly had aims beyond its stated purpose of sparking a national debate on marriage, child-rearing, poverty and other social issues. 
 Republican strategists said it was intended as political shock therapy for a White House political team that many Republicans, including some close to Mr. Quayle, believe to be asleep at the wheel. According to their accounts, Mr. Quayle wanted to demonstrate that it is possible to seize control of an important issue, rather than to continue to drift while Ross Perot gains in the polls.
The White House is increasingly concerned about Mr. Perot's outsider candidacy, but it is also uncertain about how Mr. Bush, a lifelong politician and Washington insider, can counter it.
Mr. Quayle was also trying to demonstrate that it is possible to short circuit Mr. Perot and his followers by stealing their anti-establishment thunder with blasts at fat targets like the press and what the Vice President is calling the "cultural elite" of the entertainment industry.
The upside of all this for Mr. Quayle is easy to see. By casting himself as the energy source of a struggling campaign, Mr. Quayle furthers his ongoing repair work on his political image and his efforts to lay the groundwork for a Presidential campaign in 1996.
But what is good for Mr. Quayle, as he tightens his bond with the political and cultural right, may not be good for his boss, who will not be back in the White House if he loses mainstream Democrats and independents to Mr. Perot or to Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the likely Democratic nominee.
Mr. Quayle's clear ideological focus and aggressive attack on the family-values front only highlighted the President's diffuse message and the hesitancy and confusion that have been evident in its response to a series of political challenges this year. Yesterday, Mr. Bush and his press secretary were in the embarrassing position of not being sure how to deal with the political offensive of the President's own running mate.
"It may be another sign of the President's weakness that they can't figure out how to respond to Dan Quayle, much less to the riots in L.A. and the economy," said Harrison Hickman, a Democratic poll taker.
 
Clinging to the Center
 More broadly, while any incumbent President must hold the center to win re-election, that seems an even greater imperative for Mr. Bush as he tries to keep recession-weary voters from turning to the Democratic Party and to stop Democrats who voted for Ronald Reagan from defecting to Mr. Perot.
That could become harder if Mr. Quayle helps to drive the Bush campaign too far to the right. But Kevin Phillips, the Republican commentator, said Mr. Quayle's actions in California suggested another possibility: that the Bush campaign is expecting a three-way race in which the winner could have less than 50 percent of the vote, and is thus trying to appeal to a narrower audience.
"I think the Murphy Brown flap is good for Quayle," he said. "I think it's possibly to the detriment of Bush in the medium term, and I think the long-term prospects for Republicans are negative because they're into a calculated narrowing mode."
Mr. Quayle and his aides said they laid out their plans for the California trip with the specific intent of getting as much attention as possible from the Vice President's speech on family values. Mr. Quayle is said to have inserted the reference to Murphy Brown, the television comedy character who bore a child out of wedlock.
"Maybe the best thing to do is to take it at face value, which is, he wants people to talk about family values and this is a way of doing it," said Richard Fenno, a professor of political science at the University of Rochester who wrote a book about Mr. Quayle's Senate career.
 
Focusing on Hollywood
 But Administration officials acknowledged that for reasons of political tactics, Mr. Quayle is also trying to make the case that he stood with "ordinary Americans" against an established power that does not care about the same things they do.
"It's clear there is a very large number of voters who say the country is on the wrong track," said one Republican strategist. "That is going to turn against the incumbent pretty quickly unless you can show you're for change. What Quayle did in California fits into that pattern by focusing the 'what's wrong' feeling on Hollywood."
The Vice President pressed that attack today as he told reporters that he "wouldn't change one word of the speech" he delivered on Tuesday. "I'm sure that the media elite and Hollywood didn't like the speech that I gave," he said. "But the American people support what I'm talking about, and I'm talking about values."
Some Republicans, like Gary Bauer, head of the Family Planning Council, an anti-abortion group, said Mr. Bush should follow his Vice President's lead.
"The West Wing could do themselves a big favor by running with the larger theme of the breakdown of the family for the next week or so," Mr. Bauer said. "I think it's one of those things that will make their lives miserable by producing all sorts of turmoil, but I have no doubt it would resonate to the American people."
But he and others said it was not clear whether the White House was prepared to do that.
"Bush should give a speech like this," said Steven Merksamer, who ran the Bush-Quayle campaign in California in 1988 and traveled with Mr. Quayle this week. "Whether he can do that or not, given where he is coming from ideologically, is another question."
Mr. Quayle himself was diplomatically circumspect on this question. "It was a speech that needed to be given," he said.

HEADLINE: In Challenge to Bush, Senate Adds $1.4 Billion to Urban Aid Bill

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
The Senate today passed an urban aid measure that dared President Bush not to spend $1.45 billion more than he said was needed in the aftermath of the violence in Los Angeles.
Mr. Bush supports a bill, passed by the House last week, that would have provided $822 million in loans and grants for disaster relief and small business loans for cities, since reserves for both were low even before the Los Angeles riot and the Chicago flood. 
 But by a vote of 61 to 36, the Senate today adopted a proposal by Senators Edward M. Kennedy and Orrin G. Hatch that took the House bill and expanded it. The Senate bill added $700 million for summer youth jobs, $250 million for a summer Head Start program, $250 million for summer school for disadvantaged students and $250 million for the Justice Department's "weed and seed" program of tougher law enforcement and community development.
The Administration's response was cagey, stopping well short of threatening a veto. While Mr. Bush has insisted that he would oppose a bigger urban aid package than the one he favors, the White House Office of Management and Budget suggested it might trade acceptance of more spending on the existing programs in the Kennedy-Hatch measure for Congressional compliance with some of its proposals.
Big-city Democratic mayors, meanwhile, were meeting with Congressional leaders for a second time since the riots. Mayor Raymond L. Flynn of Boston, chairman of the United States Conference of Mayors, called the Senate bill "a small down payment.
Mr. Kennedy, a Massachusetts Democrat, and Mr. Hatch, a Utah Republican, had sought to take advantage of the sudden concern for urban problems.
The biggest percentage increase for one program was for the Justice Department program; its spending would increase more than 20 times, to $250 million from $12 million. The biggest absolute increase would be for summer jobs, adding $700 million to $683 million.
The two Senators argued that these four measures should be added as emergency spending because if the money was not put out immediately, it could not be spent this summer. But they and others have argued that the $1.45 billion is only a first step.
But as passed by the Senate, the bill would not actually require Mr. Bush to spend the $1.45 billion unless he made a formal declaration of a budget emergency, which is required under the 1990 budget act before the deficit can be increased. Mr. Bush had already agreed to an emergency declaration for the $822 million in loans and grants in the House version of the bill.
The statement of Administration policy from the budget office called it unhelpful "to advance funding increases for non-disaster programs without also addressing the crucial issues of reform."
That suggested a willingness to consider the spending measures if Congress were also to move on Administration proposals.
No tax measure can be attached to a spending bill. But if the dealing gets complicated and serious, the enterprise zone legislation could be added to a bill extending emergency unemployment benefits and making permanent changes in the unemployment law that the House Ways and Means Committee approved today.
Whether or not the dealing goes that far, the measure passed today by the Senate stands a good chance of quick acceptance by the House.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
Clinton Sees Bush Engaging In Empty Talk on Families

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CLEVELAND, May 21

 BODY:
Adding his voice to the theme of family values that has occupied President Bush and Vice President Quayle this week, Gov. Bill Clinton said the White House had engaged in "cynical election-year politics" designed to avoid taking a leadership role in resolving the problems of families.
Mr. Clinton called a speech the Vice President gave on Tuesday a symptom of the Bush Administration's inability to take actions on the problems that affect cities and those living in poverty. 
 In his speech, Mr. Quayle said the nation was experiencing a "poverty of values" and assailed television character Murphy Brown's single motherhood.
Mr. Clinton said Mr. Quayle's speech ignored "the relationship of our family problems to our economic decline, holds out Murphy Brown as a bigger problem than TV's crass commercialism and glorification of selfishness and violence, and denies the Administration's responsibility to face the full range of America's staggering family problems."
The Governor's speech today was a distillation of weeks of speeches and comments he has made since the Los Angeles riots about the declines of cities and families. In it, he detailed his positions on social issues like family-leave legislation, abortion, welfare changes and child support.
 
Quayle's Remarks Help Clinton
 Mr. Clinton, whose place in the political spotlight has dimmed in recent weeks, benefited today from the reflected glare of publicity over Mr. Quayle's remarks. Acknowledging that the subject of family values "has acquired more currency," the Governor attempted to define the term as a matter of "governmental philosophy" rather than political opportunity.
"It isn't enough for America's leaders to blame past social programs on current TV programs," he said. "It isn't enough for America to change channels. We need to change course."
Mr. Clinton also used the opportunity to describe his own family values, recalling his impoverished upbringing as the son of a woman who has been widowed three times. For a portion of his childhood, Mr. Clinton was raised by his grandparents. His father died in a car accident before he was born.
 
Shares Family Attitudes
 He also spoke extensively of the involvement of his wife, Hillary, with child-welfare issues and of his own experiences raising his daughter Chelsea, who is 12 years old.
Mr. Clinton's advisers have been concerned that voters seem to know little about him beyond the questions that have been raised about his character. They have sought in recent weeks to re-introduce him to voters as a caring public servant who will bring an outsider's perspective to national problems that the Bush Administration has ignored.
"Family values can't simply be Washington code for Beltway Republicans who really mean you're on your own, or Beltway Democrats who want to spend more of your tax money on programs that don't embody your values," Mr. Clinton said.
He said that the nation's social problems could only be resolved by working to find "a third way, beyond the traditional politics of both parties."
"Family values alone won't feed a hungry child, and material security cannot provide a moral compass," Mr. Clinton said. "We must have both."
President Bush, in a commencement speech delivered at the University of Notre Dame on Sunday, said the American family was "an institution under siege" and that its problems must be addressed "at the personal, individual level for governmental programs to be effective."
Mr. Quayle, in his toughly worded San Francisco speech two days later, decried a "welfare ethos" in the nation's poorer communities, and he said the country was "reaping the whirlwind of decades of changes in social mores."
Mr. Clinton said today that he agreed with the White House that there is a "values crisis" in America, but he said the Bush Administration has taken no action to address it.
Noting that President Theodore Roosevelt once called the Presidency a "bully pulpit," he said Mr. Bush had abdicated his responsibility to use his words to "move a nation."
"But talk must be backed up with action or we risk diminishing the bully pulpit to a pulpit of bull," Mr. Clinton said.
 
Reiterates Social Policies
 Consolidating several of his previously stated policy positions in today's remarks to a business crowd at the Cleveland City Club, he called for an earned-income tax credit for the working poor whose incomes fall above the Federal poverty line.
He also reiterated his call for welfare changes, saying that job training, day-care vouchers and medical coverage should be provided for welfare recipients to allow them to return to the work force.
"People want the dignity of work," Mr. Clinton said. "We should give everyone a chance to have that dignity."
After two years on welfare, recipients should perform public service work if they cannot find jobs, Mr. Clinton said.
The Governor also called for tougher enforcement of child-support payments, including releasing to credit-rating agencies the names of fathers who do not make court-ordered payments, and instituting a national collection system administered by the Internal Revenue Service.
Mr. Clinton also said he would sign a Federal law allowing for parental leave and provide money in the budget to pay for the Head Start preschool program.
Mr. Clinton received the longest applause when he said he would support abortion rights as a matter of "preserving personal and family privacy." He described abortion as a matter of choice and linked it to Mr. Bush's support of Federally supported tuition vouchers that would allow parents to choose what school their children can attend, whether public or private.
"The President says he wants private school choice even if it means taking public money away from public schools that are already underfunded," he said. "He's willing to make it a crime for a woman to exercise her right to make the most private choice of all. I don't understand that."
Mr. Clinton was not able to remain on the subject of family values entirely today. During a question-and-answer period that followed the speech, he was asked to participate in 15 seconds of silence in memory of Roger Keith Coleman, the Virginia man who was executed on Wednesday.
"I think you and others should properly pray for his soul," he said after a few seconds' silence. "I do not know what the facts are in the case. But I do not believe we should abolish the death penalty."

HEADLINE: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK;
'Hooray for Senor Dinkins!' And the Mayor Says, Well, Not Much

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 21

 BODY:
Before leaving the Caribbean for New York today, Mayor David N. Dinkins took some time away from the pomp and circumstance dominating his short visit here to concentrate on the problems plaguing a nation with strong ties to his city.
After receiving an honorary degree from the Universidad Autonoma de Santo Domingo for his work on the behalf of Dominicans, Mr. Dinkins made an impromptu visit to Villa Juana, one of the poorest sections of Santo Domingo, where he was cheered by residents who ran out of their shacks to greet him. 
 Thirty percent of the adults in this country are unemployed and those who do have jobs earn an average of $30 a month. Health care, housing, education seem woefully inadequate.
"Hurray for Mr. Dinkins! Hurray for Mr. Dinkins!" people yelled as the Mayor pressed through the crowd shaking hands and kissing babies.
"I see many of the faces here that I see on 158th Street and Broadway," Mr. Dinkins said, referring to the large Dominican population in Washington Heights.
Mr. Dinkins announced a "sister city" exchange program this morning in which New York City would train Dominican health care professionals at city hospitals and donate used medical equipment to hospitals and clinics in Santo Domingo.
Such equipment could include beds, respirators, X-ray machines and diagnostic equipment. City officials said that while the equipment, much of it sitting in warehouses, is no longer appropriate for hospitals in New York, it would be useful here.
Later the Mayor visited a children's hospital, where he passed out stuffed animals before heading to the airport to fly back to New York. He arrived at about 8:30, ending a three-day trip began in Puerto Rico on Monday.
 
No Habla Espanol
 It has become quite clear in the last three days that Mayor David N. Dinkins and his Hispanic associates do not speak the same language. Mr. Dinkins has struggled to speak Spanish throughout his trip, often mispronouncing the names of dignitaries and his own staff members.
At a news conference with Gov. Rafael Hernandez-Colon of Puerto Rico, Mr. Dinkins grossly mispronounced the name of the founder of the Puerto Rican Commonwealth government, Luis Munoz Marin, , and the Mayor repeatedly dropped part of the Governor's name, referring to him as Governor Colon. Following Spanish custom, the Governor uses both his parents' surnames.
Later Mr. Dinkins needed help pronouncing adoquines to refer to the cobblestones he presented to the Governor to repave a historic road in Old San Juan. The Mayor was also overheard saying "MUC-hass GRAC-hass" for "MOO-chas GRAH-see-ass," or "thank you."
As one local journalist suggested, "El Gringo needs to wear a sign that reads 'No habla espanol.' "
Mr. Dinkins also offered a dry comment on his language "skills" during his speech accepting his honorary degree from the Universidad Autonoma: "I'm listening carefully to my translator to make sure he does not make any mistakes."
A spokeswoman for the Mayor, Anabel Franceschini, said she and the Mayor were working to improve his pronunciation and have made a wager that by the time he returns to the Caribbean, he will sound like a native.
 
Concern for Gypsy Cabs
 Many citizens of the Dominican Republic depend heavily on support from relatives in the United States. New York City has between 150,000 and 500,000 residents of Dominican ancestry who send about $500 million a year back to their homeland.
That explains why local reporters told Mayor Dinkins of growing concern that gypsy-cab drivers in New York are increasingly the targets of discrimination and violence. Many of the 20,000 Dominicans who emigrate to New York each year drive cabs.
Responding to their concern, Mr. Dinkins said that his administration does not tolerate bias of any kind and that New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission would soon announce a program to more effectively regulate the taxi industry, which would benefit Dominicans.
Under the proposal, first put forward in January, the city would issue a new class of medallion that would allowing gypsy cabs to pick up people who hail them on the street outside Manhattan's central business district.

HEADLINE: House Data on U.S. Income Sets Off Debate on Fairness

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
In what has become a rite of spring, Congress today published 1,888 pages of eye-straining social welfare statistics and set off a brawl about the fairness of American society.
The statistics are featured in a bound volume called the Green Book, which has been published annually by the House Ways and Means Committee since 1981. The book has drawn the ire of some conservatives in recent years for data that show widening differences in American incomes. 
 Many liberals, in Congress and in universities, have said the data show that America is becoming increasingly unfair, with the rich reaping windfalls while others tread water or sink.
 
Debate on Income Distribution
 A few Congressional conservatives have said that the data are simply wrong. Last year, Representative Dick Armey, Republican of Texas, denounced it as a "data base for demagogues." Many other analysts have accepted the numbers but put their own twists on them, in what is becoming an ever-larger, and politically charged, debate about income distribution.
This year's episode centers on the question of work effort: Do the poor work enough or do they not?
One table shows that, despite popular images of the idle poor, the poorest fifth of Americans worked 4.6 percent more in 1989 than in the previous decade. But because of sinking wages and Government benefits, their incomes in that same period fell by 4.1 percent.
By contrast, the richest fifth worked an extra 2 percent but saw their incomes soar 19.6 percent.
"It says that the rules of the game are rigged against those with fewer skills: they worked harder and they made less," said Representative Thomas J. Downey, the Long Island Democrat who is chairman of an influential Ways and Means subcommittee.
While work effort may have increased, said Lawrence M. Mead, a political scientist at New York University, it remains quite modest, with the poor working many fewer hours than those further up the income ladder.
In 1989, for instance, members of the poorest fifth of American families worked a total of 850 hours. Those in the middle fifth worked an average of 2,550 hours. And those in the upper fifth worked even more, 3,510 hours.
A typical full-time worker, on the job 40 hours a week for 50 weeks a year, would log 2,000 hours.
"The poor have a whole lot of room to increase their work effort -- a whole lot," said Mr. Mead.
But Mr. Downey said it was often harder for poor families to increase their work effort. Often, he said, they can only find part-time or sporadic work or cannot afford the child care to leave home. And since many poor families are headed by single mothers, they cannot send a second earner into the work force, as many more affluent families do.
The Green Book shows that the poorest single mothers actually worked 6 percent less in 1989 than they did a decade earlier. But their incomes dropped by 17 percent, mostly because of cuts in welfare benefits.
Where both sides agree is that a disproportionate amount of the new prosperity brought by the 1980's went to the most privileged.
At the heart of the widening gap are changes in wage patterns, which have punished the unskilled while gilding the Guccis of the best-educated.
The book shows wages for the richest fifth of Americans rising by 14.7 percent over the last decade; but wages for those in the poorest fifth have dropped by 3.6 percent. On average, the table shows, wages rose 7.3 percent.

HEADLINE: Tongues New to English, Eyes Fresh to the Capital

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER

 BODY:
America has not been all that she had hoped, but as she got off the bus on Pennsylvania Avenue in Washington, Ewa Lis, a Polish immigrant, was not disappointed. The building before her was big and white, "exactly as I imagined it," she said.
Smiling, Ms. Lis handed her camera to her friend Joseph Veninger, who is from Czechoslovakia. "Take a picture of me and my White House." 
 Mr. Veninger wanted to go inside, and maybe get a glimpse of "the person who runs this big system," but it was Sunday, and the White House was closed. Still, Mr. Veninger said he was glad just to be in this mythic town that he knew only from books and television.
"This is for me the main office for America," he said.
 
More Than English Lessons
 Monday through Friday, Mr. Veninger and the other 22 immigrants in Donna Harkavy's class in English as a second language meet in a basement in Brooklyn, offered free by the New York City Board of Education. The subject is not just English, but America, and so on Sunday, after earlier trips to New York landmarks like the Statue of Liberty, the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Brooklyn Public Library, the class convened in the nation's capital.
It was the culmination of the year and, for all but one or two of them, their first trip to Washington. After the trials of real life in their new home, New York, Washington was a place they had to see, a chance to visit the dream America. "Washington is a mecca for immigrants," Ms. Harkavy said.
The Washington they saw -- in six whirlwind hours, for the bargain price of $21, round trip -- amazed them. It was, they said, so clean, so peaceful, so full of flowers.
 
Another Side of Town
 Maria Charles, from Puerto Rico, tried to tell her classmates that beyond the White House and the Lincoln Memorial was another side of the nation's capital that she had read was as poor and dangerous as the city where they lived.
Sunday in Washington reminded Mr. Veninger of being a newcomer in New York six years ago. "At first you're like a tourist, and you see all the museums and big buildings," he said. "But after a while you see what life really looks like -- the killing, the depression, all the sad things that happen in the big city.
"When I came here, my friend said, 'Joe, in New York you have to have special locks, two, three locks, and gates on your window.' I said, 'What for?' Then they robbed my apartment. They take everything, my cheap TV, my mattress, my clothes, even my shoes. Now I have three locks, two Medeco and one regular. I have big gate on my window."
In New York, Mr. Veninger, who was a mechanic in Czechoslovakia, is unemployed. Ms. Lis, who taught psychology in a Polish university, has a job taking care of an elderly woman.
 
A Rare Day Off
 Hawa Jibral, who seven years ago was tending sheep in Somalia and now stocks shoes in a discount store, got a rare day off. "I'm sick of shoes," Ms. Jibral said, boarding the brown and yellow bus at 6:30 A.M. outside the Brooklyn Public Library. "Every day I'm looking at shoes."
But on this day, Ms. Jibral, in a beautiful gold and green African dress and black patent leather shoes, looked at monuments, memorials, gardens and space shuttles at the National Air and Space Museum. A life-size reproduction of the lunar landing of the Apollo II reminded her, she said, of moonlit nights with her sheep in the Somalian desert.
She and her classmates, who were the subject of several articles in The New York Times during the school year, made the trip with another English class, taught by Ms. Harkavy's friend, as well as with friends and relatives. Sam Barq, from Pakistan, brought his wife, his mother-in-law, his two sisters-in-law, his baby, and homemade, hot Pakistani food for half the bus.
They were 49 in all, from Haiti, Thailand, Mali, Senegal, Russia, Peru, El Salvador, Nicaragua, the Dominican Republic and seven other countries. The motto of these travelers was "Speak English," but when the bus hit Maryland, Ms. Harkavy put out a call for international singing. Ms. Charles stepped to the front of the bus, took the driver's microphone and, in a clear soprano, sang in Spanish about an old man who longs to return to San Juan.
Her father and his classmates were concentrating on their new vocabulary words: memorial, monument, Congress, Senate, House of Representatives, Supreme Court, enshrined (at the Lincoln Memorial "the memory of Abraham Lincoln is enshrined forever"). And goose bumps.
"I have goose bumps," Mr. Veninger said, standing before the black marble wall of names at the Vietnam Veterans Memorial ("I thought goose bumps were just from cold, not emotions," Meyer Sadigurskiy, from Russia, said as the class reviewed the words Tuesday).
On the trip home, these tourists watched a video on the bus that Ms. Nolan had selected just for them -- "Green Card," a movie about a French immigrant who marries a New York woman to get that coveted document. At 10 P.M., as the bus approached Brooklyn under a full moon, Ms. Jibral was wistful.
"I want to get a transfer to Washington," she said.

HEADLINE: Naha Journal;
Where the Rising Sun Just Casts a Long Shadow

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAHA, Okinawa, May 18

 BODY:
The Japanese Government spared no effort last week in celebrating the 20th anniversary of America's return of Okinawa, which many regard as the high point in Washington's postwar relations with Tokyo.
The Emperor and the Prime Minister greeted Vice President Dan Quayle warmly as both sides tried to rekindle the good will engendered between the onetime enemies by that act 20 years ago. 
 Only one thing was missing: the Okinawans.
With the main ceremony held in Tokyo, 900 miles to the northeast, and their own rocky, windswept islands reduced almost to an afterthought, the Okinawans decided to hold a separate celebration, pungent with very different meanings.
An orchestra of traditional instruments played the prefecture's distinctive music, strains of China evident in the singsong melodies. But it did not once play the Kimigayo, Japan's unofficial anthem. The song is a paean to the Emperor, making it a symbol here of Japan's wartime oppression of Okinawa, when the islanders could be shot for speaking their own dialect.
 
'Used to Being Insulted'
 And while the national flag, the hinomaru, fluttered in its red and white glory all over Tokyo last Friday, it was conspicuously absent here, except for a single rising sun image above the stage. The three flagpoles in front of the convention center sat empty, bathed in the hard light of a breezy subtropical morning full of hope and frustration for the 1.2 million people of Japan's poorest prefecture.
"Maybe it was insulting for them to have the ceremony in Tokyo, but as an Okinawan I'm used to being insulted," said Tatsuhiro Oshiro, one of the island's most respected novelists. "It will make us stronger. We've accumulated a kind of wisdom from our hardships."
Masahide Ota, the prefecture's American-educated Governor, put the issue in more political, but no less plain-spoken terms. "There would have been one ceremony if the national interests were the same as the local interests," he remarked. "Unfortunately, that was not the case."
The history of the more than 60 islands that make up Okinawa is a story of a culture long caught between more powerful, competing powers. It was a kingdom trading actively with Asia for centuries, then stood in the awkward position from 1611 on of being vassal to both China and Japan. The ambiguity was clarified when the islands were forcibly annexed by Japan in 1879, beginning a period of economic exploitation and cultural intolerance.
The Japanese, preaching homogeneity, looked down on the Okinawans and their dialect, while pressing them to assimilate. The religion of the island, a mix of animism and ancestor worship, was influenced by China, as was its music. Okinawa developed a highly esteemed textile industry, using plantain fiber rather than cotton or silk.
 
A Different Viewpoint
 But Okinawa's economy lagged behind the mainland's, largely as a result of policies formulated in Tokyo. In short, the world looked much different from this easygoing, seaside city than it did from Japan's main islands.
That was never more true than in 1972. In Tokyo, the reversion symbolized Japan's rehabilitation from the defeat of World War II and the beginning of a forward-looking era. But it came at a price, which Okinawa paid on Japan's behalf. Japan allowed the United States to keep its military bases here, a keystone in America's cold war strategy in Asia.
Today, three-fourths of the American forces in Japan are on Okinawa, or more than 30,000 soldiers. The bases take up one-fifth of all the land on the main island here.
Okinawan officials acknowledge that the bases have brought economic benefits, since rent is paid on the land and the bases employ about 8,000 local people. At one time they dominated the economy, but now tourism is the leading industry and much of the base land could be developed far more profitably for resorts or other projects.
More important, the military sites are a nettlesome reminder that, as many here put it, the islands are occupied by a foreign power, sanctioned by Tokyo.
 
150,000 Civilians Killed
 American troops took Okinawa in the last campaign of the Pacific war. Nearly a third of the residents, or almost 150,000 people, were killed as the Japanese forces chose to retreat directly through populated areas. Hundreds more were forced to commit suicide by the defeated Japanese. More than 12,000 American troops and 107,000 Japanese were killed.
Many here remember the American occupation as a period of benign neglect. The Okinawans answered ultimately to unelected American occupiers, but faced none of the cultural suppression the Japanese had inflicted on them.
"I'm not going to forgive you for those 27 years of occupation, Mr. Oshiro said. "But it did make it possible for us to develop independently. We had the space to develop our culture and look at Japan in a new way."
Governor Ota said the Okinawans were waging a battle on two related fronts. On the one hand, he said, the bases must be removed. In addition, the Okinawans insist they will fight to retain their special identity amid a culture that demands conformity.
"It's not quite confidence you see here now, but something on the way to being confident," said Hiroko Sho, the prefecture's Vice Governor. "It's just beginning in a more solid way. That's what has started with the 20th anniversary."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Voters;
Indifference and Disgust Are Leading in California

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MILPITAS, Calif., May 19

 BODY:
When The Milpitas Post sent its inquiring photographer into the streets this week, asking "Are you going to vote?" people hemmed and hawed, more reluctant to commit themselves than they had been the week before, when the question was "What's so special about your mom?"
Fifty percent of them finally owned up that they doubted they would go to the polls on June 2, primary day in the nation's most populous state -- a highly unscientific tabulation, but one that the editor of the weekly newspaper, Tom Gilsenan, found noteworthy compared to years past. 
 "There's a feeling of great disgruntlement," he said. "People are annoyed by the whole political process."
 
Mirror of the State
 Dozens of other interviews in this Santa Clara County community this week, at a shopping mall, a Little League game, a senior citizen center and the town's bustling library, revealed that disgruntlement, and then some.
And what voters are thinking in Milpitas is not an idle inquiry, since this ethnically diverse city of 50,686 has traditionally mirrored the voting patterns of the state.
Many of those interviewed said they were regular voters but were not sure they would cast ballots this time, or would do so only reluctantly, because they doubted that either President Bush or Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the likely Democratic nominee, had the gumption to do anything that would alter their lives or the way business was conducted in Washington.
And as for the two Senate races that are simultaneously under way in California, the vast majority of those interviewed did not know who was running, despite the millions of dollars spent on television advertising.
Over and over, the voters in Milpitas (pronounced Mill-PEA-tis) said they were interested in only three things this election season: the possible candidacy of Ross Perot, a local ballot initiative in nearby San Jose about building a stadium for the Giants baseball team, and term limitations that would force incumbents from office.
None of the three is on the June ballot here.
 
'Other Things to Worry About'
 Linda Runswick, a Bush supporter in 1988 who was watching her son in a Little League championship, said the unappealing choices convinced her it was a waste of time to vote. "I have too many other things to worry about," she said.
Mrs. Runswick's husband was laid off from an aerospace job and is struggling to make a living as a freelance consultant. Eight months ago she was "forced" back to work, she said, as a receptionist. Now she is tired and very angry.
"I can't even figure out who's the lesser of two evils," she said of the presidential candidates.
Her son's coach, Tony Himan, agreed, although he planned to vote -- for Bush in the primary, for lack of alternatives, but he hoped to vote for Mr. Perot in the fall.
"The choices between the Republicans and Democrats are not that different lately," said Mr. Himan, a design specialist at the Stanford Linear Accelerator. "It winds up the same no matter who you elect. I haven't heard anybody that even hints at being radical enough to make any changes." Except Mr. Perot, who the coach thought might be the man to tackle "an economy going nowhere" and "racial tension that hasn't diminished and seems to be on the rise."
 
For the Sake of Change
 The enthusiasm for Mr. Perot, who is viewed as an agent of change although nobody seems to know what changes he would make, matches recent polls that show the Texas industrialist beating both President Bush and Mr. Clinton in a three-way race.
Though Mr. Perot is not on the ballot next month, 11 major Senatorial candidates are but hardly anybody here has a clue what their names are.
"Is it Delaine Easton?" asked 86-year-old John McNevin, lunching at the senior center, who suggested a state Assembly member with no announced plans for higher office.
"Is it Pete Wilson?" asked Patricia Ireland, who described herself as an opponent of legal abortion and was quick to point out that she was not related to her namesake, the president of the National Organization for Women.
 
Memory Aids Needed
 In the stands at the Little League game, Liz Skelly, came a bit closer: "Is there -- I don't know if she's running for Senate or another office, but I know there's a woman who bounced checks. Docker? A name that sounds like Docker?"
Might she mean Barbara Boxer, a member of the House of Representatives who is, in fact, running in one of the Democratic primary races? "Yeah, that's it," Mrs. Skelly said. "I knew I was thinking of those shorts for a reason. You know how you associate things."
Those who could name a Senate candidate rarely knew the opponent. Ralph Santoro, who drove a pickup truck covered with local political posters to a senior center, was asked his opinion of Dianne Feinstein, the former mayor of San Francisco, who is running against Gray Davis, the state comptroller, in one Democratic primary.
"McCarthy's going to get it, he'll beat her," Mr. Santoro declared, referring to Leo McCarthy, California's Lieutenant Governor and a candidate in the other Democratic primary for Senate.
Similarly, Calvin R. Burks, an accountant catching up on his work at the library, said he preferred Ms. Feinstein to Representative Boxer. Told the two were running in different races, Mr. Burks looked confused.
Milpitas, which means little cornfield, was first designated a bellwether town at an 1862 political rally in nearby San Jose, when a sign was raised aloft that said "As Milpitas goes, so goes the state."
Since then, the voting here has generally matched the state's, through the years when asparagus and strawberry fields gave way to a Ford Motor Company plant and more recently as high-technology companies moved in and computer professionals replaced auto workers.
As Milpitas evolved from farming to manufacturing and eventually to high technology, the demographics here have changed dramatically, just as they have statewide. The community now has no ethic majority, as the state will not within a few years, according to census projections.
White people represented 63 percent of the population in 1980, they are now 42 percent, while the Asian population has grown from 12 percent to 33 percent. The Hispanic and black populations have remained relatively stable, at 19 percent and 5.5 percent, respectively. The city government continues to be dominated by white office-holders.
Here and statewide, Asian-Americans are slow to vote, some because they are not yet eligible. One of them, Sam Lin, a Taiwanese engineer who is not yet a United States citizen, interrupted his newspaper reading in the library the other day to muse on the mood of his neighbors.
"Everyone is so interested in Magic Johnson or people in Hollywood and not so much in politicians, who would influence their future," he said. "This is very sad to me."

HEADLINE: Dow Falls 15.13, to 3,378.71, As Hopes for Rate Cut Dim

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The stock market staged a broad retreat yesterday, yielding to new doubts about the outlook for further interest-rate cuts.
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 15.13 points, to 3,378.71, slipping for a second day after hitting a record high on Tuesday. 
 Declining issues outnumbered advances by almost 2 to 1 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Big Board volume came to 184.9 million shares, against 198.9 million on Wednesday.
The broader New York Stock Exchange index fell 1.47 points, to 227.47; the Standard & Poor's 500 lost 2.79, to 412.60; the Nasdaq composite dropped 1.19, to 579.10, and the American Exchange composite lost 0.52, to 391.63.
 
Looking to the Fed
 The market made its run to new highs Tuesday amid rising expectations of fresh moves soon by the Federal Reserve to relax its credit policy. But the excitement began to die down Wednesday when the Fed seemed to signal that it was not yet ready to make such a move.
The chances of Fed action were apparently reduced further yesterday when the Labor Department reported that initial claims for state unemployment insurance dropped by 20,000 in the week ended May 9, indicating an improving economy.
Interest rates rose in the credit markets on the news of that larger-than-expected decline. Prices of long-term Government bonds fell more than $5 for each $1,000 in face value, increasing their yields to about 7.86 percent.
Among active stocks yesterday, Federated Department Stores, dropped 1/8, to 11 7/8, on turnover of nearly 9 million shares. Underwriters late Wednesday priced an offering of 40 million Federated shares at $11.50 apiece.
General Motors held steady at 39, matching the price of this week's huge offering. Volume in G.M. was down sharply from the nearly 17 million shares that traded on Wednesday, but with 2.8 million traded yesterday, it was still No. 4 on the Big Board active list.
U.S. Shoe tumbled 2 1/8, to 12 5/8. The company reported lower profits for the fiscal quarter ended May 2 and said it expected another earnings decline in the current quarter because of what it described as a "soft retail environment."
Navistar was heavily traded, down 1/4, to 2 7/8. The truck maker posted a loss for its fiscal second quarter and projected a loss for the current quarter as well.
Charming Shoppes, traded in the over-the-counter market, rose 1 5/8, to 29 3/8, on the company's report of higher quarterly earnings.
Amgen, another Nasdaq issue, gained 1 3/4, to 59. Gordon Bordon, the biotechnology company's chief executive, described himself as "comfortable" with analysts' estimates that sales would reach $1 billion this year.
Ben & Jerry's Homemade, the ice cream company, also traded over the counter, added 2 1/2, to 43 3/4, on news of a pending 2-for-1 stock split.
Humana fell 1 3/4, to 21 1/4, on top of a 2 1/4-point loss Wednesday, when the hospital company estimated lower quarterly profits.
The upswing in interest rates hurt mortgage-finance issues. Fannie Mae dropped 1 5/8, to 64, and Federal Home Loan Mortgage fell 1 1/4, to 41 1/4.
Numerous industrial stocks linked to the business cycle also lost ground. Phelps Dodge fell 1 1/2, to 88 1/8; Georgia-Pacific 1 1/4, to 64; International Paper 5/8, to 70 5/8; Dow Chemical 5/8, to 61 7/8, and Alcoa 1/8, to 76 3/4.

HEADLINE: COMMENCEMENTS;
Canada's Leader Says Battle For Democracy Is Not Over

 BODY:
Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada told graduates at Johns Hopkins University yesterday that "it is rare in history that there has been such a victory for an idea -- the idea of democracy."
"The defeat of Communism opened the door to democracy," Mr. Mulroney said. "But it also brought economic hardship to 425 million people throughout Central and Eastern Europe." 
 Mr. Mulroney added, "The task the world's democrats face now is to secure that victory and to insure that it is neither hollow nor short-lived."
He addressed the 3,758 graduates outdoors on the Keyser Quadrangle on the campus in Baltimore. It was the university's 116th commencement exercises.
At a separate ceremony held in the afternoon for the graduating seniors only, Lee A. Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, spoke to students and received an honorary degree.
Other recipients of honorary degrees were: C. Everett Koop, former Surgeon General of the United States; Michel Rocard, former Prime Minister of France; Abraham Horwitz, an alumnus and director of the Pan American Health Organization; Zanvyl Krieger, a Baltimore lawyer and businessman and alumnus of the university, and Robert M. Heyssel, the retiring president of The Johns Hopkins Hospital and university's health system.
Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, spoke in the afternoon to the graduate students in the Paul H. Nitze School of Advanced International Studies.
 
Rutgers University
 Francis L. Lawrence, the president of Rutgers University, told 9,675 graduates that "teaching without research is empty" and that "research without teaching is sterile" at the university's 226th commencement, which was held yesterday in New Brunswick, N.J.
Calling research "today's favorite campus bogey" and noting that it is too often seen as an excuse for poor teaching, Dr. Lawrence said that research enriches the teaching process. "Research is the very meat of higher education," he said. "Without it, our table would be bare."
Honorary degrees were awarded to Sir Michael Francis Atiyah, the director of the Isaac Newton Institute for Mathematical Sciences at Trinity College in England; the chef Julia Child; Dr. Ernest Mario, chief executive of Glaxo Holdings p.l.c., a pharmaceutical company, and Dr. Roger Newland Shepard, a professor of social science at Stanford University.
Although the degrees were formally conferred at yesterday's ceremony, most graduates will receive their diplomas at separate convocations, which are being held until May 31st. Speakers at the convocations will include Thomas Pickering, the United States Ambassador to the United Nations, and Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey.
 
Stevens Institute
 "Don't wish for change -- change things," Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey told 729 graduates yesterday at the Stevens Institute of Technology's 120th commencement ceremony, held on the college's campus in Hoboken.
Honorary doctor of engineering degrees were conferred on Governor Florio; Robert E. Allen, the chairman of A.T.&T., and Dr. Kathryn D. Sullivan, an astronaut who has been on three space shuttle missions.
 
Bank Street College
 Bank Street College of Education awarded 190 master's degrees yesterday at its 41st commencement ceremony, in the Synod House at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. It was the school's largest class of graduates.
