HEADLINE: White House Is Ready for a Rosier Outlook

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
President Bush's chief economist said today that because of recent signs of an economic pickup, the White House would soon raise its forecast for economic growth for this year.
Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said that lower interest rates and increases in business and consumer confidence were among the reasons that the Administration would revise upward the growth forecast of 2.2 percent it made in January. 
 The Council of Economic Advisers is required to issue a new, midyear growth forecast each July, and some economists suggested that in tipping its hand now, the Administration was seeking to build momentum for President Bush in the California primary on June 2.
But others said that Mr. Boskin, who prides himself on his professionalism, was merely revising the Administration's forecast upward the way many private sector economists have.
After noting that the nation's economy had endured a long slowdown, Mr. Boskin said, "It's now resumed a pattern of more robust growth."
In a speech today in Washington, Mr. Boskin declined to specify by how much the Administration would increase its forecast, saying the new forecast would be announced in June or July.
Mr. Boskin said there were still several reasons that have kept the recovery from being stronger, noting that cuts in military spending were causing layoffs. He added, "We still seem to have problems in the growth of money" supply and in the availability of credit in certain regions and industries.
Speaking at the same Washington conference, which was sponsored by the United States Export-Import Bank, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady urged the Federal Reserve to do more to ease credit. "We believe there is room for a further easing of monetary policies" to "promote growth," he said.
The Federal Reserve Open Market Committee, the principal group setting monetary policy, met behind closed doors on Tuesday, with many analysts predicting that it would decide against lowering rates soon because the economy was gathering steam. The Wall Street Journal reported today that the central bank had decided on Tuesday against any immediate cut in short-term rates.
Federal Reserve officials declined to comment on that report.
 
Equally Balanced
 Last week, Lawrence Lindsay, a Federal Reserve governor, pointed to no change in rates when he said the risks the American economy faced were equally balanced on the upside and downside. He said on the one hand there was the risk that excessive growth would spur inflation, while on the other side there were dangers of economic weakness.
Businesses and economists have frequently taken a skeptical approach to the Administration forecasts because, particularly in the first term of the Reagan Administration, the predictions were overly optimistic for political reasons. Mr. Boskin's forecasts have been more realistic than those of many of his predecessors.
The Blue Chip Economic Indicators, a survey of leading economists, forecasts that the nation's economy will grow at a 2.8 percent rate from December 1991 to December 1992. That is up from the 2.4 percent forecast the group made in January.
Responding to Mr. Boskin's remarks, Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland and chairman of the Joint Economic Committee, said, "Even if they have some revision upward, it is still pretty poor growth trying to move out of recession. The average growth rate in the first year of other post-war recoveries was about 6 percent."
Mr. Sarbanes said that growth was so slow that most economists were predicting that unemployment would remain above 7 percent at the end of this year.
 
'Substantially' Upward
 Mr. Boskin predicted today that when the Commerce Department revises its preliminary 2 percent growth estimate for first quarter, it would revise the figure "substantially" upward.
"The economy continues to grow in the second quarter," Mr. Boskin said, "and there are a number of favorable signs." He added that inflation was on a downward course and that "the export sector has been a tremendous source of strength." He noted that banks, which he said were not yet an engine of commercial lending to sustain the recovery, had increased their capital ratios and were seeing their stock prices rise.
David Wyss, director of research for DRI-McGraw Hill, an economics consulting firm in Lexington, Mass., said his firm had revised its forecasts upward for 1992 principally because of strong-than-anticipated growth in the first quarter and a surprising burst in consumer spending. In the first quarter, consumer spending rose by 5.3 percent, propelled in part by higher consumer confidence.
In January, DRI-McGraw Hill was forecasting 2.6 percent growth for all of 1992, but its latest forecast calls for 3.1 percent growth.
"It's on the good side or normal. It's not a boom," he said. Then, speaking about the timing of Mr. Boskin's remarks, more than a month before the official midyear report, he added, "This is fairly typical if they're going to have pleasant revision. You expect them to telegraph it a bit."
Lyle Gramley, a former governor of the Federal Reserve who is chief economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, predicts the nation's economy will grow by 2.5 percent this year, while early this year he was predicting annual growth of 2 percent. He noted that early this year many economists were predicting a flat or down first quarter, but he said strong housing starts and consumer spending produced a surprisingly strong quarter.
"Sometimes Administration forecasts have what I call an element of political optimism," he said. "You stretch as much as you can without straining the bounds of credibility."
But he said that, if anything, the council's forecasts under Mr. Boskin have been conservative. "I would not be inclined to put any political interpretation" on Mr. Boskin's remarks, he said, suggesting that the Administration had revised its estimates upward the way so many other economists had.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Japan Sees Chip Pact as Success; U.S. Disagrees

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
Japanese semiconductor makers said yesterday that as part of a semicondutor trade agreement with the United States, Japan had significantly improved foreign companies' access to the home market of the world's largest chip makers.
But American chip producers and industry analysts responded that the Japanese were simply trying to put the best face on troubled high-tech trade relations between the United States and Japan. 
 The market assessment by the Japanese came in a study produced in response to a document by the United States Semiconductor Industry Association. The American report, issued in March, had said bluntly that the 1991 U.S.-Japan Semiconductor Arrangement was not working.
 
Prelude to Japan Tour
 Both sides are jockeying for position as American chip makers prepare to visit Japan next month for consultations with Japanese Government and industry officials. Some American semiconductor executives have been arguing that the trade agreement has failed and that the United States Government should issue sanctions against Japanese chipmakers because Japan has not opened its markets sufficiently.
But yesterday the Japanese report said that steady progress had been made since 1986, when a precursor to the 1991 semiconductor agreement was signed, and that more progress would have been made if the recession had not blunted sales.
"The steady rise in joint ventures and other cooperative arrangements between United States and Japanese chip manufacturers is strong and tangible evidence of success in improving market access," Iwao Ojima, president of the Electronic Industry Association of Japan, said in a prepared statement.
The American view is radically different.In its March report the S.I.A. said that increased access to Japanese markets had essentially stagnated since the first quarter of 1990.
"They have been putting out this misinformation for two years," said Andrew Procassini, president of the S.I.A. "It is appalling that the first or second economy in the world is acting like a bunch of penny pinchers."
Both sides agree that the American share of the Japanese market increased from 8.5 percent in 1985 to 12.5 percent in 1991.
At issue is whether a provision -- contained in both the 1986 and the 1991 agreeements -- to raise the Americans' share to 20 percent was a commitment or merely a goal.
The crucial language of the 1991 agreement reads, "The Government of Japan recognizes that the U.S. semiconductor industry expects that the foreign market share will grow to more than 20 percent of the Japanese market by the end of 1992 and considers that this can be realized."
The report released yesterday by the Japanese says, "The 1991 arrangement was not a guarantee of market share, but a commitment to market access."
 
Interpretation Is Disputed
 United States semiconductor industry executives and Government officials dispute this interpretation. "The bottom line is that we came to an agreement," said William J. Spencer, head of the Sematech, the United States industry-government chip-making consortium.
The Japanese report based its conclusion that the situation had improved significantly on what it called the increase in joint ventures between Japanese and United States chip makers and a growing number of "design-ins" -- American-Japanese corporate relationships that involve United States chip makers in the earliest stages of developing new Japanese electronic systems.

HEADLINE: April Budget Surplus Off

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
Tax collections weakened by the recession helped shrink the Government's budget surplus for April to less than half of last year's level, the Treasury Department said today.
The surplus was $14.6 billion last month, reducing the deficit for the first seven months of the fiscal year to $184.7 billion. But the April budget balance a year ago was $30 billion, swelled by a $5 billion contribution from America's allies in the gulf war. 
 The deficit-to-date this year is 51 percent greater than last year's comparable $122.2 billion. That puts the deficit on track to break last year's record $269.5 billion.
April tax receipts from individuals totaled $68 billion after deducting refunds, down from $77.8 billion last year.
The Bush Administration projected a $399.7 billion deficit, but many economists expect a shortfall of around $330 billion, with much of the improvement attributed to a delay in the savings and loan bailout.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
More Sunday Papers Deliver Shampoo as Well as News

BYLINE: By Eben Shapiro

 BODY:
AN intriguing new idea in newspaper advertising began with a friendly backyard chat between neighbors in Cincinnati.
Cincinnati is home to the nation's largest advertiser, the Procter & Gamble Company, and one neighbor was Kevin Hall, the brand manager for P.&G.'s Vidal Sassoon shampoo. Mr. Hall was musing about the company's growing interest in door-to-door sampling and the difficulty of finding an effective distribution system.
The other participant at the patio meeting was the production chief for The Cincinnati Enquirer, providing Mr. Hall with an idea. "Wait a second," he recalls saying. "The paper goes door to door."
A few weeks later, when The Enquirer's 250,000 Sunday subscribers padded out to retrieve their papers, each one contained a one-ounce sample of Vidal Sassoon shampoo.
In their endless quest to get samples of their products into the hands, hair and mouths of consumers, packaged-goods giants are showing growing interest in using the distribution strength of newspapers.
Since the Sassoon test in Cincinnati last May, many Sunday newspapers subscribers have essentially received a free breakfast, courtesy of similar promotions. Kellogg has used newspapers to send out six million samples of a new cereal, and Maxwell House has delivered small packets of coffee.
Last weekend, using a network of newspapers across the country, P.&G. delivered 18 million small bottles of its Pantene SP shampoo.
Still, the programs are viewed largely as tests, and several marketing executives said that once the novelty wore off, the idea might seem less compelling.
But for now advertisers are looking closely at the approach. "They are wonderful distribution alternatives," said Rick Hosfield, director of media, broadcast and shows for General Mills, which is reportedly studying the use of newspapers for sending out samples.
Mr. Hosfield said the combination of a sample, coupon and full-page advertisements was a potent method to sell packaged goods. "Newspapers have become a multifaceted marketing tool," he said.
Mr. Hosfield and other marketing executives said newspapers were overdue in developing new ways to attract advertisers. "They've been very difficult to do business with," said Mr. Hosfield, who overseas all advertising spending for General Mills. As a result, he said, "They are a terrific resource that has been under-utilized."
The innovation was born of one of the worst recessions in decades for the newspaper industry. Publishers are desperately trying to find new ways to accommodate advertisers and make money.
"Adversity breeds changes," said Marcella Rosen, a managing director of the N. W. Ayer ad agency. Ms. Rosen said the sampling programs were a good idea. "The distribution system is an untapped resource."
Newspapers have good reason to become attuned to the needs of the food and soap companies. They are huge advertisers. P.&G. spent $2.28 billion on advertising in 1990, according to Advertising Age, with network television accounting for by far the largest share. While the food companies use Sunday newspapers heavily to distribute coupons, they do little other newspaper advertising.
Newspapers are using the interest in sampling to sell more ads. As part of a sampling promotion, a packaged-goods company buys a page and a half of advertising. Also included is an advertisement for the product, which would be in the plastic bag covering the Sunday paper. Such promotions cost about 20 cents a sample, including the advertising and plastic bag. That price is similar to the cost of mailing a sample, the conventional way of distributing samples.
Last year, The Chicago Tribune developed a product sampling program called Newspac that allows samples to be inserted automatically into Sunday papers along with coupons.
Mr. Hall of Procter & Gamble said the chief benefit of using newspapers instead of mail for sampling was that all the samples would arrive on the same day. That allows marketers to run advertisements in conjunction with the samples, and it lets retailers stock up on the product.
Mr. Hall said the most successful products for such sampling promotions were those used in a morning routine, like shampoo or soap.
A network, the National Four-Color Newspaper Network, exists that allows consumer-goods companies to distribute samples in 28 million newspapers at once. The sampling programs are still in their infancy. The network has been involved in seven programs so far and is planning several more.

HEADLINE: Claims for Jobless Benefits Drop

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
New applications for state unemployment benefits fell 20,000 in the week ended May 9, the Labor Department said today in a report showing a stronger job market than economists had expected.
It said first-time jobless claims numbered 406,000 in the period, down from a revised 426,000 a week earlier. The department had previously reported 424,000 new claims for the week ended May 2. 
 The four-week moving average number of new applications, viewed by economists as a more accurate barometer of the job market than the weekly figure, was 412,500, up slightly from 412,000.
Analysts said the report showed the economic recovery was gaining strength and provided another reason for the Federal Reserve not to ease interest rates further.
"I am somewhat more optimistic," said David Jones, chief economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Company. "I think the recovery is here to stay. The odds are way down for a further Fed easing."
California reported the largest weekly gain, with 12,013 people filing for first-time unemployment benefits. During the previous week, 13 state unemployment offices had been closed for two days because of the Los Angeles riots.
California attributed the increase to the start of a new quarter of wage credits for benefit purposes; the riots, which resulted in about 3,900 claims, and layoffs in the construction and trade industries.
Ohio reported the second-largest gain, with 3,562 new claims, followed by Georgia, with 1,196.
North Carolina, which reported 4,814 fewer claims, said there were fewer layoffs in the construction and furniture industries.
New York reported a drop of 2,870 claims. It said there were fewer service-industry layoffs.
The total number of new claims was the lowest since the week of April 18, when there were 404,000 claims filed.

HEADLINE: Economic Watch;
Then There Were 3? Don't Bet on It

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
It's war up there.
The bloodiest battle for mastery of the skies may be at hand. Many industry experts say the steep cut in fares that American Airlines initiated last month could bury three competitors operating under the protection of the bankruptcy courts: Trans World Airlines, Continental and America West. And the cuts could mortally wound two others, USAir and Northwest, that are struggling to stay ahead of their creditors. 
 For his part, Robert Crandall, American Airlines' chairman, says that the industry's only real problem is that too many carriers are chasing too few passengers.
Is Mr. Crandall correct? Could the Darwinian struggle for the air traveler's dollar ultimately leave just three behemoths -- American, United and Delta -- to serve the national market?
Market-minded economists, who would have scoffed just a few years ago, are scoffing no more. They now concede that further consolidation is in the cards. But this does not mean that the economics of air travel dictates some small, magic number of survivors. Indeed, many contend that a blind faith in the advantages of large size has been the undoing of some of the giants of yesteryear.
But most important, they are cautiously optimistic that the spectacular progess in reducing the average fare and providing far more frequent service -- improvements that airline deregulation has brought consumers -- will not be lost in the consolidation. And while these experts are not looking forward to testing the proposition, many now believe that three to five national carriers, plus a few low-cost regional airlines, could provide all the competition needed to preserve the fruits of deregulation.
Thus while experts want the overextended airlines to get the best possible shot at survival, few are calling for heroic measures. "Market engineering," said Severin Borenstein of the University of California at Davis, "is not the way to go."
Hardly anyone expected that free markets would favor the established giants, with their featherbedding unions and regulation-as-usual mentality, over lean and hungry upstarts. Certainly not the establishment itself: among the big carriers, only United threw its weight behind deregulation in 1978.
But then, hardly anyone at that time understood the economic advantages of large route systems linking cities through hub airports. It takes 10 planes to provide nonstop service simultaneously on 10 routes, notes Alfred Kahn, who, as the airlines' chief Federal regulator in the 1970's, led the fight for deregulation. But the same 10 planes in the air, he points out, can serve 70 routes by shuffling all passengers through a central hub.
Most travelers, as well as big airlines, have been winners from the rush to hub-and-spoke systems. Before deregulation, for example, there was only enough traffic between Oklahoma City and Dallas to support a few flights a day. Now it pays the industry to run 18 flights each way, because both American and Delta use the link to provide one-stop service from Oklahoma City, through Dallas, to dozens of cities.
If economists were surprised by these "economies of scope," they were truly flummoxed by the success of marketing strategies, pioneered by American Airlines, to take maximum advantage of size. First on the list is frequent-flier benefits aimed at business travelers -- what Mr. Borenstein coolly terms "kickbacks to the purchasing agents." They reward loyalty to an airline that serves thousands of routes because it pays to accumulate mileage in a single program.
Then there are the industrywide computerized reservation systems, installed in travel agencies by the big carriers. Washington cracked down on the practice of listing the flights of the system's owner-airline ahead of the competition. But American and United, with the leading reservation networks, can still get a leg up legally by charging competitors an arm and a leg for booking services.
 
Size Isn't Everything
 Advantages achieved through size explain why the airline industry is far more concentrated than, say, the business of growing soybeans. But in the view of Clifford Winston, an economist at the Brookings Institution, they do not fully explain why so many carriers have bitten the dust in the last few years.
Size alone, Mr. Winston notes, did not save Eastern and Pan Am; nor did size spare Continental from bankruptcy court. The decisive factor in virtually every failure, Mr. Winston argues, has been the inability to aim at a lucrative market or to control costs in a business that operates on razor-thin margins.
Mr. Borenstein agrees. Size, he says, cannot explain how small fry like America West and Midway managed to operate at far lower costs per passenger mile than giants like Delta and USAir. Perhaps most disconcerting to those who like simple tales with simple morals, size does not explain why little Southwest, which Kevin Murphy of Morgan Stanley admiringly calls the "snapping turtle" of the industry, has the lowest costs and highest rate of profitability in the industry.
 
Each Failure Is Different
 Explanations for failure seem unique to individual carriers. Pan Am, for example, never found a way to feed domestic passengers into its lucrative foreign routes. Continental never lived down a reputation for wretched service after its ill-considered mergers with Frontier and People Express. And America West made the lethal error of taking on Southwest.
"There are species in which struggles to the death occur in the litter," commented Michael Levine, the dean of Yale's School of Organization and Management.
What all the battered carriers shared, Mr. Winston notes, was a penchant for growing too big, too fast. Headlong growth made sense to airline executives convinced that economies of scale would prove decisive. But the lemming-like rush virtually guaranteed that the industry as a whole would be unable to fill its planes at fares that generated profts.
"When the country lost 9 percent of capacity last year" in bankruptcy liquidations, Kevin Murphy points out, "nobody gave a hoot" because there were still plenty of seats to go around.
To Mr. Levine, who earned his spurs as president of New York Air, which is now defunct, overcapacity guarantees further consolidation. But he says it is far from inevitable that a market-driven consolidation would leave just three major carriers. Much, he suggests, depends on whether the the three big carriers can "force endgame before the end of the recession."
The case of Southwest particularly intrigues Mr. Levine because it is evidence that a well-managed airlines can still succeed by casting itself in a fresh mold. Southwest, he notes, is too small to benefit from a full-court marketing press. It does not restrict flights to an efficient hub-and-spoke system. And it does not even exploit its outsider status and Sun Belt location by paying nonunion wages.
What it manages to do very well, though, is to provide frequent, no-frills service on busy routes at rock-bottom prices. And while Southwest has benefited from the special advantage of a virtual monopoly at Dallas's close-in Love Field, Mr. Levine is optimistic that other low-cost carriers could find other niches outside the path of a predator.
 
Adequate Competition Is Seen
 A few years ago Mr. Levine and other economists who were upset with the mergers that swept away Western, Republic, People Express, Piedmont, PSA, AirCal and Ozark in the late 1980's had long wish lists of policy fixes to buttress competition. Many still favor changes, ranging from divestiture of computer reservation services to an easing of restrictions on foreign ownership of domestic carriers. But they largely agree with Daniel Kasper, a consultant at Harbridge House in Boston, that the benefits conferred on the Big Three are "water over the dam."
If most experts are more sanguine about the industry's drift toward concentration than one might expect, it is because they believe competition among relatively few airlines may be adequate to keep prices in line with costs.
Instead of looking at traditional measures of industry concentration, Clifford Winston and Steven Morrison of Northeastern University asked how many practical alternatives there were for flying from point A to point B. In their forthcoming book, "The Evolution of the Airline Industry" (Brookings), the two economists distill this route-by-route comparison into an index of "effective competition."
The index rose steadily from 1978, the year airlines were deregulated, through 1986. It has since retreated a bit, but remains as high as it was in 1984.
 
Travelers Have Choices
 Why is less more -- or at least not much less? The hub-and-spoke systems that have played a role in dooming less agile carriers have also given most travelers who live outside hub cities the option of making a one-stop trips through a choice of several hubs.
Take the route between two nonhubs, Kansas City, Mo., and San Francisco. Only USAir flies nonstop. But travelers can also make the trip through Denver on United or Continental, through Phoenix on America West, through Dallas on American, through Minneapolis on Northwest, or through Salt Lake City on Delta.
There are some routes -- especially short routes from hubs to nonhub cities -- where prices do seem out of line. A 1990 report by the United States General Accounting Office found that the average fare per passenger mile on flights originating in hub airports was 27 percent higher than fares on flights from other major airports.
And a new study by Mr. Kahn and Gary Dorman, his colleague at Cornell, suggests this "hub premium" is likely to rise as single carriers muscle their way to monopoly positions at the remaining airports that now serve as hubs for two carriers -- notably, Chicago, Denver and Dallas.
But when Mr. Winston and Mr. Morrison adjusted fares for factors ranging from average trip length to the proportion of business travelers using the routes, the hub premium attributable to monopoly power fell to just 5 percent.
It is worth noting, too, that the fare tribulations of travelers from hub cities are apparently small change compared with gains to other travelers. Adjusting for inflation, Mr. Winston and Mr. Morrison calculate that average fares were 20 percent lower in 1991 than the airlines would have been allowed to charge before deregulation.
 
A Lurking Fear
 If there is a horror scenario lurking, it is one in which the big three airlines dominate all important routes and manage to grow their way out of overcapacity. Then they might allow their costs to rise and service to deteriorate, much the way Detroit auto makers got fat and sloppy for lack of competition in the 1950's and 1960's.
But that scenario depends on the willingness of each of the giants to settle for a stable share of the market -- a tendency none of the three has exhibited in the last decade. It also depends on the reluctance of newcomers to leap at the prospect of skimming the cream from established carriers' less competitive routes.
Mr. Murphy, for one, finds such reluctance very unlikely, provided new airlines have access to airport gates and rights to use congested airports. "You will always have new entry," he said. "Airlines are a glamour business, like the movie business."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Higher; Gold Prices Decline to $337

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended mostly higher in technically driven, light trading yesterday.
Gold prices fell. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery was $337 an ounce, down from $338 on Wednesday. Later, the Republic National Bank also quoted gold at $337, off 50 cents an ounce. 
 A dollar rally amid moderate morning trading ran out of steam in the afternoon ahead of the long Memorial Day weekend, said Ken Boyer, a market analyst with MMS International.
Traders said that indicated the rise had been more a technical correction than a shift in the market sentiment toward the dollar. On Wednesday, the dollar reversed its downward spiral of the last few sessions.
Mr. Boyer said the morning rise was prompted in part by an article in The Wall Street Journal that said the Federal Reserve's policy makers had decided against an immediate cut in short-term interest rates.
Such a move would help the dollar, since lower interest rates make dollar-denominated securities less valuable to investors.
The article prompted short-covering in a market that had heavily oversold the dollar expecting the Fed might tinker with rates to shore up the faltering economy.
Mr. Boyer said that other than speculation about whether or not the Fed would change its monetary policy, there was not much news moving the market.
In New York, the dollar closed at 130.35 Japanese yen, up from 129.50 Wednesday. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to 129.61 yen, from 129.22 at Wednesday's close. In London, it rose to 130.25 yen.
The British pound in New York was quoted at $1.8165, down from $1.8310 late Wednesday. In London, sterling fell to $1.8170, from $1.8300 Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday, were: 1.6155 German marks, up from 1.6010; 1.4850 Swiss Francs, up from 1.4700; 5.4360 French francs, up from 5.3865; 1,218.00 Italian lire, up from 1,205.00, and 1.19745 Canadian dollars, up from 1.19445.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Is There Really A Business Cycle?

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
WHERE are we in the business cycle? Stock prices have soared to a high on expectations that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates again. Bond prices have surged, reportedly on flight-to-safety buying and, contradictorily, on the belief that inflationary fears are unwarranted.
But housing starts plunged 17 percent in April, the biggest decline in eight years, after three months of sharp gains. The dollar slid to a three-month low against the German mark. Japanese stock prices and land prices plummeted. Olympia & York, the world's biggest real estate corporation, filed for bankruptcy. Alexander's, the retail chain, went bust. R. H. Macy & Company, operating under the bankruptcy law, said it would close eight department stores, including four in the New York region. Economists, on average, grew more optimistic, but economists are a lagging indicator. Business sentiment improved. Consumer sentiment zigged and zagged. 
 Is there really such a thing as a business cycle, in the sense of regular waves of expansion and contraction -- or are there just random walks around long-term trends?
In a 593-page tome, "Business Cycles: Theory, History, Indicators, and Forecasting," Victor Zarnowitz of the National Bureau of Economic Research comes closer to belief in the existence of the business cycle than to agnosticism. The evidence, he says, shows "a persistence of sequential relationships and interactions among time series representing a wide range of economic, financial or other variables."
The National Bureau view is that business upswings and downswings are endogenous, that is, built into the capitalist system, rather than exogenous, the result of random shocks coming from outside the system. But shocks like wars or oil embargoes can break or prolong a business cycle.
The National Bureau's conclusion stops short of suggesting that all business fluctuations will have similar durations or amplitudes. The average United States business cycle has lasted about four years, plus or minus one year, but there have been big deviations from that average. While the average duration of four mild recessions between 1920 and 1982 was only 10 months, the Great Depression of 1929-33 lasted 43 months.
So, too, for expansions: While the average duration of seven American cyclical expansions from 1949 to 1982 was 46 months, the shortest expansion during that period lasted only 12 months and the longest lasted 106 months. The life of a boom or a bust can't be predicted by its age.
Economists have propounded a wide variety of theories to explain the business cycle, including underconsumption and overinvestment, imbalances between intended saving and intended investment, unstable flows of money and credit, bursts of innovation and contests by imitators, and false expectations of profit, generating careless investment and then slumps. Every theory fingers its own villains: politicians who overspend or undertax, or underspend and overtax; central bankers who increase the money supply too much or not enough; commercial bankers who lend wildly in the boom and crunch credit in the bust; corporations that overborrow and default on their loans, and consumers who do the same.
Every theory also generates forecasts. But how good are they? Theories that rely on a single interaction (as between rising consumption and investment) or a single type of shock (such as a burst in the supply of money or new technology) are, Mr. Zarnowitz says, "attractively simple and can be instructive," but, on the whole, fare poorly when they are confronted with data, because such models are seriously incomplete.
Similarly, a computer scientist, Prof. Lofti A. Zadeh of the University of California at Berkeley, maintains that conventional quantitative methods of analysis are of limited use with societal systems, such as the national or world economy, because such systems are "much too complex and too ill defined."
Another approach to economic forecasting is the one used by the National Bureau of Economic Research, in which cyclical regularities are sought out by detailed, empirical analysis of past data. Mr. Zarnowitz contends that such forecasting is improving, though he concedes that it is still weak at turning points in the business cycle.
Still another approach to economic forecasting is to pay less attention to historical data and more to the human actors and institutions whose deeds will determine future data and outcomes.
As for economic policy making, since it has been so undependable in curing the short-term business cycle of its instability, it might be better to focus on doing sensible things for the long run, such as raising the rate of saving and investment to increase long-term growth, putting more money into research and development, prime sources of innovation, and improving education and skills.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Prices for Cocoa Plummet To Lowest Level in 19 Years

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: CHICAGO, May 21

 BODY:
Continued selling of cocoa by producers in the Ivory Coast drove the price of cocoa to its lowest point since 1973.
Cocoa for delivery in July settled at $881 a ton, down $30, after setting a new life-of-contract low at $879 on the New York Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange.
The Ivory Coast, the world's largest cocoa producer, is selling roughly 30,000 tons of cocoa a week, analysts said. As of last Friday, producers in the Ivory Coast had sold 310,000 to 350,000 tons of its crop for 1992-93; they will need to sell at least 250,000 more tons by Oct. 1 to fulfill their agreement with the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, analysts said. There was little buying interest by commercial investors. 
 "Cocoa inventories in the U.S. and Europe are bloated," said Jean Sundrla, an analyst with Evans Economics in Washington. Until the supply situation changes, cocoa prices are likely to fall further, she added.
 
Gains for Energy
 At the New York Mercantile Exchange, prices of energy futures settled higher amid perceptions that Saudi Arabia would not press for an increase in the production ceiling of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, as many had expected.
Light sweet crude oil for delivery in July closed 50 cents higher at $20.90 a barrel. June heating oil settled at 56.10 cents a gallon, up 0.9 cent, and June unleaded gasoline settled at 63.20 cents a gallon, up 0.93 cent.
At the Chicago Board of Trade, the price of soybeans and grain for delivery in July plunged because of forecasts of rain and cooler temperatures over much of the Midwest, analysts said.
Soybeans for delivery in July led the decline, shedding 15 1/4 cents, to $5.93 3/4 a bushel. Soybeans, which are just being planted, badly need rain to get the crop under way.
Grain futures also sank in reaction to the forecasts. Wheat for delivery in July fell 1 1/2 cents, to $3.40 a bushel, the lowest price since early January. Corn for delivery in July dropped 2 3/4 cents, to $2.52 1/4 a bushel. Oats for delivery in July fell 4 1/4 cents, to $1.30 a bushel.
Washington's grain and soymeal allocation for Russia, which was announced by the Agriculture Department late on Wednesday, was somewhat disappointing, said Pat O'Connell, a grain analyst with Refco in Chicago. The amount of soy products the Russians will buy with American credit guarantees was less than expected, which weighed further on the soybean market. But Mr. O'Connell said the amount of corn and wheat was close to industry expectations.

HEADLINE: Pop/Jazz;
Cowboy Revue in the Sky At Rainbow and Stars

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN

 BODY:
Rainbow and Stars, the elegant cabaret adjacent to the Rainbow Room atop Rockefeller Center, is not the sort of place where one might expect to find three cowboys swapping songs and stories as though they were sharing a campfire in the Arizona wilderness.
But in a striking change of pace from its typical fare, the club is playing host to "Cowboy Logic," an informal revue of songs and poems dealing with western lore. In a show that changes nightly, the veteran country-pop singer Michael Martin Murphey; Don Edwards, a Texan troubadour and archivist of western music, and Waddie Mitchell, a cowboy poet from Elko, Nev., perform round-robin style, trading songs, verses and yarns, accompanied by a trio playing fiddle, bass and keyboard. 
 "What we do is very improvisational," said Mr. Murphey recently. "We just try to feel it. It may seem rambling, but every night it tends to take some kind of form. One night the theme might be death, another night family problems, and another night the lonesome individual confronting himself."
 
The Cowboys' Roots
 Mr. Murphey, who is the show's unofficial leader, is the best known of the three. A pioneer of the progressive-country movement of the early 1970's, he grew up in a rural suburb of Dallas and has released 19 albums over two decades. In 1975, he had a top-five hit with his song "Wildfire."
Mr. Edwards, who lives in Weatherford, Tex., has been a professional cowboy balladeer since 1960. Among his influences, he cites Marty Robbins, Tex Ritter and Rex Allen. His earliest hero is Nathan Howard, a cowboy who under the name Jack Thorp collected and printed one of the first books of cowboy songs in 1908. Mr. Edwards's repertory includes such classics as "Cattle Call," "The Strawberry Roan" and "The Cowboy's Lament" (which is better known as "The Streets of Laredo").
Of the three, Mr. Mitchell is the most dyed-in-the-wool cowboy.
"I grew up on a ranch that was 60 miles from the nearest town and 40 miles from the nearest neighbor, and 33 of those miles were dirt road," he recalled. "We had no electricity. It was one of those situations where we had to entertain each other."
Mr. Mitchell said that he has written more than a thousand poems and has had two books published. He made his public performing debut eight years ago at the first Elko Cowboy Poetry Gathering, an event he helped to organize. He has since appeared a number of times on the "Tonight" show.
 
Finding Kindred Spirits
 It was at the 1986 gathering -- the first such event he had attended -- that Mr. Murphey met his partners in "Cowboy Logic" and had what he described as "a religious experience."
"I'd been collecting cowboy music and performing it among my friends," he recalled. "But when I saw a lot of other guys like me and also women performing this music and enjoying each other's company, it was the most important thing that had happened to me in years in my musical life."
The singer, who was signed in 1985 to the country-music division of Warner Brothers Records, subsequently approached Jim Ed Norman, who runs the label's Nashville operation, with the idea of putting out an album of cowboy songs.
"Because it had been 25 years since Marty Robbins had put out a western album, they didn't think western could be re-introduced," he recalled. "I said I'd like to take you out West so you can see there's a revival going on."
 
And There's the Proof
 Mr. Murphey invited Warner Brothers executives to visit Westfest, an annual outdoor festival of western music and poetry in Copper Mountain, Colo., that he helped organize. They were impressed enough by the enthusiasm of the 40,000 attendees to allow Mr. Murphey to make his album "Cowboy Songs," which was released in 1989. The record surprised everyone except Mr. Murphey by selling 350,000 copies, the most of any of Mr. Murphey's 7 Warner albums, without the benefit of a hit single. Although the record includes original material, its core is devoted to western standards like "Red River Valley," "Home on the Range" and the Roy Rogers-Dale Evans theme song, "Happy Trails to You."
"Cowboy Songs" was so successful that it has inspired the formation of Warner Western, a new label devoted to western and American Indian music and to cowboy poetry. Warner Western had its official debut last week with albums by Mr. Edwards, by Mr. Mitchell and by a western trio, the Sons of the San Joaquin. All three records were produced by Mr. Murphey.
If the label prospers, he hopes to put out talking books of Elmer Kelton, a revered writer from San Angelo, Tex., whose novel, "The Time It Never Rained," is regarded as a regional classic.
 
Protecting the Tradition
 Since teaming up five years, Mr. Murphey, Mr. Edwards and Mr. Mitchell have performed "Cowboy Logic" everywhere from folk clubs and honky-tonk bars to Las Vegas casinos.
"Bringing it to New York has a little bit of an ambassadorial and political agenda," Mr. Murphey said. "Right now, I think a lot of ranchers and farmers are suffering because people don't understand their function in society. I want to make people take a second look at the agrarian tradition of this country and the culture it has produced. The basis of all economy is growing things and producing food. Without an agricultural tradition that is respected, a country dies."
"Cowboy Logic" plays at Rainbow and Stars, 30 Rockefeller Plaza, through June 6. Shows this weekend are at 9 and 11:15 tonight and tomorrow with an a la carte dinner served from 7 P.M. and supper served from 10:15. There is a $35 cover charge with no minimum. Reservations: (212) 632-5000.

HEADLINE: Rescued -- Before They Drop Out

 BODY:
Finally, there's some consistent good news about New York City school dropouts. For the second year in a row, the rate has declined; it's now down to 17 percent -- a dramatic drop from the early 1980's, when the rate reached 42 percent.
The change may be partly due to New York's faltering economy as students stay in school because there are no jobs. A surer reason is Schools Chancellor Joseph Fernandez and his initiatives to rescue students before they disappear. These efforts deserve more state and city financial help than Mr. Fernandez is now getting. 
 It has never been easy to pinpoint precisely how many students dropped out of New York schools. But since 1986 the Board of Education has tracked through graduation the entire cohort of students who enter ninth grade each year, insuring a more accurate calculation. Numbers aside, the board's efforts to keep students in school have not been uniformly successful. The board was criticized for spreading too thin money it got from a state-financed dropout prevention program.
Two years ago Mr. Fernandez redesigned the program, concentrating on at-risk students in 32 selected schools. Under Project Achieve! participating schools created a more supportive environment by providing students with individualized programs and better instructional and support services. The program also sought deeper involvement by community organizations and parents.
The approach appears to be paying off. For the class of 1991 -- students who entered ninth grade in September 1987 -- the dropout rate was 17.2 percent. That's the lowest rate since the new calculations began in 1986.
The dropout progress vindicates Mr. Fernandez's philosophy of early intervention: Identify problem students in lower grades and give them intensive help. Fewer of these students have had to be referred to special education classes, where they would likely remain for years at roughly twice the cost of regular classes.
In addition, Mr. Fernandez has begun to stiffen curriculum requirements in math and science to improve students' prospects for jobs and college. The tougher standards haven't frightened kids away. School attendance is at the highest level in two decades. Many of Mr. Fernandez's changes have been accomplished just as the school system has been hit with over $700 million in budget cuts. Further large cuts risk turning these considerable, painstakingly won gains into losses.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Lessons For Americans

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

DATELINE: MADRID

 BODY:
Every day now, the new Europe shows it can be strong, united and independent of the United States -- but only until a real crisis comes along that it has to handle itself.
Then Europe becomes a vivid lesson for Americans in the value and strengths of their own country and its special system of government. 
 Thousands of Europeans are being slaughtered by other Europeans. European cities are being smashed. European separatists and terrorists all over the Continent watch to see what may be in it for them one day.
The disaster of Yugoslavia, once a nation, now a scream of agony, should have been crisis enough to persuade the leaders of the new Europe to put up or shut up. They do neither.
They do not have the courage to face the risks of forcing a decent settlement -- or even just stopping the bloodletting. But they remain magnificent when it comes to making statements of huff and puff. They look around for United States help without enough political guts to admit it.
Even a little time spent in Europe listening to the evasions of European leaders should be a great lesson for Americans. It should make them see more clearly the virtues of their own system, so often and so contemptuously dismissed by Europeans and even by themselves.
Western Europe has plenty of troops, planes and ships for the blockades and interdictions that could have smothered the war and forced real peace talks on the combatants. Why were they not used by the new Europe in this year of 1992 that was supposed to be the beginning of the new era of united European power?
Why do we hear, even from Spain's Prime Minister, Filipe Gonzalez, one of Europe's more straightforward and imaginative leaders, the story that the mechanisms, the structures, do not exist for collective action about Yugoslavia? If Europe has one thing in good supply it is structures and mechanisms.
The reason is that this time Europe does not have the United States to count on. It has soldiers and guns but it does not have the political and organizing power that the American Presidency, balanced and strengthened by Congressional backing and public support, can bring to meeting a crisis like Yugoslavia.
Yes, the Bush Administration was part of the West's disastrous buildup of Saddam Hussein and wound up leaving him in power. But when the U.S. decided to stop Saddam Hussein after Kuwait, President Bush had both the courage to act and the system that he needed behind him.
That was the combination -- the determination of a leader and a balanced, unified constitutional system -- that could create the coalition and open the rusty umbrella of the United Nations.
Neither is present now in Europe. Politically a united Europe is one more fictional creature that walks without clothes. Among other recent creations were Perestroika to save the Soviet Union, the Bush "new world order" and the idea that the United Nations has become some kind of separate entity that can take action without the initiative and permission of the major powers.
Yugoslavia showed that Europe is still a collection of states that have separate political needs and fears and will not march politically to the same drum for decades -- probably never.
Economically, where the price of unified action is just money, not blood, a united Europe may work. Maybe -- but before we place any bets let's wait until the first great European economic crisis, like heavy unemployment caused by heavy migration.
The Bush Administration has correctly decided that the civil war in Yugoslavia is one crisis that Europe ought to be able to handle on its own.
One day Americans may not be able to stomach any longer what European leaders keep swallowing -- the death of thousands of Europeans and the destruction of a part of European civilization. Then, with American help at hand, Europeans will suddenly discover those "mechanisms" for action that they have misplaced. But in the meantime Americans can learn a lesson:
The European concept of unity will never be an equal or a substitute for the strength and flexibility of the American constitutional system -- not for the U.S., not for the world and not for those abandoned Europeans living in the pool of blood that was once Yugoslavia.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Kerner Report Said It All About Urban Unrest

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I had forgotten most of the details in the 1968 Kerner Commission report on civil disorders, but the Los Angeles rebellion sent me scurrying to find my old, dog-eared paperback copy. It had been last used in 1972 when I was serving as Special Assistant for Minority Affairs to the Commandant of the Marine Corps and trying to develop recommendations and solutions to the racial strife plaguing the Marine Corps then.
What an extraordinary document! If you were to read the Kerner Commission report today, you would probably think it was written, in many respects, in the aftermath of the Rodney King disturbances. I have just finished reading some portions of it again, and it is startling how little attention has been paid to the conclusions and recommendations from this report during the intervening years. 
 Allow me to quote several passages:
"The capability of a police department to control a civil disorder depends essentially on two factors: proper planning and competent performance.
"The way policemen approach an incident often determines whether it is contained or develops into a serious disorder.
"Unemployment and underemployment are among the persistent and serious grievances of disadvantaged minorities."
Basic program areas were identified for special strategies: Consolidating and concentrating employment efforts; opening the existing job structure; creating a million new jobs in the public sector in three years; creating a million new jobs in the private sector in three years; developing urban and rural poverty areas; encouraging business ownership in the ghetto; consolidating and concentrating employment efforts.
Thanks to the Kerner Commission report, it is clear that we don't need another study of the causes of urban unrest. Thanks, too, to Lyndon Johnson, we have the solution:
"The only genuine, long-range solution for what has happened lies in an attack -- mounted at every level -- upon the conditions that breed despair and violence. All of us know what those conditions are: ignorance, discrimination, slums, poverty, disease, not enough jobs. We should attack these conditions -- not because we are frightened by conflict, but because we are fired by conscience. We should attack them because there is simply no other way to achieve a decent and orderly society in America."
I hope the Kerner report becomes a "must read" item for all in positions of leadership who will be addressing solutions to the recent disturbances. I also hope we have the will to follow through with the recommendations this time. The next time may be too late.
 
EDWARD L. GREEN
Arlington, Va., May 7, 1992

HEADLINE: Help Russia Create a Stable Legal System

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Two Novelties in Russian Courts: Defense Lawyers and Jury Trials" (front page, May 11): Our experience in Russia and other former Soviet states confirms the conclusion that "for all the talk of constitutional and legal reform, there has not been very much of it."
Using as a model the way we and other human rights organizations function in the United States, the American Jewish Congress has tried to introduce Jewish members of the bar, both in the Soviet Union and later in its successor states, to the notion of aggressively using law and legislation to protect and promote individual rights. These efforts were substantially impeded by structural obstacles in the various judicial and administrative systems in these countries, and even more by the lack of understanding and experience by both legal practitioner and the public with initiatives of this kind. 
 In testimony before a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee early this month, we urged our Government to help promote in the successor states the creation of a body of substantive and procedural law that would encourage citizens to press claims and seek redress of rights violations.
Toward this end we urged the enlistment of law schools, bar associations, human rights associations and others in arranging workshops and symposiums, faculty exchange programs and apprenticeships in U.S. law firms and legal advocacy groups.
The emergence of a coherent and stable legal system will not only assure justice among the new republics' citizens but will provide the context necessary to encourage foreign investments. Parties to a transaction must be able to anticipate the results of their decisions. Investors demand assurance that agreements will be enforced, transactions honored, and that legal order will replace bureaucratic arbitrariness.
The creation of a reliable and fair legal system is an indispensable element not only in the evolution toward democracy but in the promotion of economic growth.
 
PHIL BAUM
Associate Executive Director
American Jewish Congress
New York, May 13, 1992

HEADLINE: Swords Into High-Tech Plowshares

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., May 21

 BODY:
Three of Long Island's major research institutions joined forces today to form an institute to find commercial uses for highly technical research. The goal is to help the Island's military industry, its largest private employer, convert to peacetime products.
The new institute, the Long Island Research Institute, was founded by the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, the State University of New York at Stony Brook, and Associated Universities, the managing corporation of the Brookhaven National Laboratory. 
 "There's a lot of talent in these institutions and we want to get some of their ideas out into the marketplace," said Dr. Nicholas Samios, director of the Brookhaven National Laboratory. "We believe there is an untapped potential in the research community that can have an impact not only on the economy of Long Island, but the entire country."
While the end of the cold war has led many research institutions to study ways to convert military industries to peacetime uses, Dr. Samios said he knew of no other project in which three such diverse institutions had joined forces.
The effort comes at a time when the Government is seeking ways to help communities and companies to convert to peacetime pursuits. Congress is considering setting aside part of next year's military budget toward that end.
Officials said the institute would try to develop products in medical equipment and instrumentation, biotechnology, energy technologies, environmental analysis, advanced materials and information technology.
 
Seed Money From State
 The state is providing the institute with $400,000 in seed money. An additional $100,000 has been provided by the three sponsoring institutions, which hope to acquire more start-up funds from the Federal Government.
"We'd like to fill the vacuum being left by the receding defense industry and create the next major high-tech industry right here on Long Island," said Dr. Philip F. Palmedo, a nuclear engineer who was elected president and chief executive officer of the institute at its first meeting today at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory.
Beth Delson, a spokeswoman for the Center for Economic Conversion in Mountain View, Calif., a clearinghouse for ideas to convert military production to peacetime products and jobs, said, "The regional approach of the Long Island Research Institute is unique and one that is welcome and should be encouraged."
Dr. Palmedo, who worked for 13 years at Brookhaven before setting up his own international consulting firm, said the institute hoped to "form a bridge between the research community and the business community to create new products and new jobs."
"Long Island has the real potential to become a significant high-tech region," he said. "The defense industry will obviously eventually disappear, and since we can't bring smokestacks in to replace it, we should look to the research base that is already here. That, combined with a highly educated work force and a favorable living environment, makes for a promising future."
 
A National Concern
 He said the issue of making effective economic and social use of a highly developed research industry was "not only a regional problem, but a national concern."
"We know the Japanese have long had a traditional connection between their research institutions and industry," he said. "They work very closely together with great success."
"In the United States, Federal support for research is entirely distinct from private industry," Dr. Palmedo said. "We would like to bridge that gap. If we're successful, we hope our results have national significance."
The institute hopes to attract corporate support.
"As we start the development of commercial ideas, we will seek funds from those who might like to buy a patent or manufacture products," Dr. Palmedo said.
For example, he said, Brookhaven was been working on energy and environmental technologies and has published the results in professional journals, but has put them to no commercial use.
At Stony Brook, he said, researchers were working on three-dimensional computer imaging that has had some military applications. "But we see a clear application in medicine for a three-dimensional imaging for the brain for use by brain surgeons," Dr. Palmedo said.
The new institute was officially constituted at this afternoon's first meeting of its board. Walter B. Kissinger, the brother of former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger and president of the Kissinger Family Foundation, was elected chairman.
Initially, the institute will have its headquarters at 100 North Country Road, Setauket, at the offices of Dr. Palmedo's consulting company, the International Resource Group.
Other members of the board include John C. Bierwirth, former chairman of Grumman Corporation; G. Morgan Browne, administrative director of Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory; Robert Hughes, president of Associated Universities; John H. Marburger, director of Brookhaven National Laboratory; Jerry R. Schubel, dean and director of the Marine Sciences Research Center at the State University at Stony Brook; James H. Simons, president of Renaissance Technologies Corporation; James Watson, director of Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, and Frank G. Zarb, chairman of Smith Barney Harris Upham & Company.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 23, 1992, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about the new Long Island Research Institute misidentified a director, John H. Marburger, and omitted another. Mr. Marburger is the president of the State University of New York at Stony Brook. The omitted director is Leo A. Guthart, chief executive of Ademco, an alarm manufacturer in Syosset, L.I.

HEADLINE: Bank Curbs Seen Having Little Effect Right Away

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
The new Federal rules setting limits on the interest rates that weak banks can pay depositors will have little immediate effect on the bulk of the industry or on customers, analysts said today. This is primarily because loan demand has been so weak that it has discouraged banks from offering higher rates.
What is more, although the new rules restrict interest rates and deposit-gathering by weaker banks, Federal regulators said today that they expected to grant most requests for waivers. The rules follow Congressional intent by trying to prevent another episode like that in the 1980's in which high-interest-rate deposits caused huge losses -- and an expensive Government bailout. But they do so in form, not substance, some experts said.
 
Some Banks on List
 The banks that will have to apply for permission to accept deposits from money brokers and to offer higher rates include the Chase Manhattan Bank, First National Bank of Chicago, First USA Bank, Bankers Trust, Imperial Bank and First Union, all of which did not qualify for the top tier of institutions based on their financial health at the end of last year, according to an analysis today by Sheshunoff Information Services. 
 The new rules, which were handed down Wednesday by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and will go into effect on June 16, will flatly prohibit the weakest banks and savings and loans from paying higher-than-average interest rates to attract deposits. No waiver will be allowed under the rules for these institutions.
The analysis by Sheshunoff, a banking research and consulting firm in Austin, Tex., also showed that these institutions, which will have to either lower their rates or shed millions of dollars in higher-interest-bearing deposits, include the Maryland National Bank, American Security Bank, the Massachusetts Company, the First American Bank of New York and Midlantic.
Paying higher-than-average interest rates had devastating consequences for the savings and loan industry in the 1980's, as many institution chased deposits gathered by brokers who sought high rates. Huge amounts of this money poured into federally insured institutions, allowing them to make large and risky loans, many of which turned sour. As losses mounted and banks needed still more deposits to stay liquid, the institutions bid up interest rates. Eventually, these high-cost deposits compounded the cost of the Government's savings and loan bailout.
"Regulation failed in preventing the savings and loan crisis so now regulation is attempting to manage the banks in the wake of the recession," said James J. McDermott, director of research at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, a bank research firm in New York. The rules represent the first attempt at regulating interest rates since 1986.
The new classifications are important beyond just brokered deposits because they may also become the standards for determining which financial institutions will pay higher premiums for Federal deposit insurance and which institutions will be able to expand.
 
The Three Groups
 Under the new rules, banks are classified into one of three groups. Those considered well capitalized are able to continue to offer brokered deposits and those considered adequately capitalized must get permission from the F.D.I.C. Banks ruled undercapitalized by the F.D.I.C. may not offer brokered deposits.
Federal regulators said they expected approval of requests from adequately-capitalized banks if they found that they were being supervised properly.
"There's a presumption that they will be approved unless they hear from us," said Robert F. Miailovich, an assistant director of supervision at the F.D.I.C. "We will do our darndest to make sure it's not a long drawn out regulatory process."
The agency Wednesday defined well-capitalized banks as those with a leverage ratio -- the total of equity capital and retained earnings as a share of total assets -- of 5 percent or more and a broader risk-based capital ratio of 10 percent. Adequately capitalized are those institutions lower than the top standard but with a leverage ratio of 4 percent and a risk-based ratio of 8 percent.
 
Chase Manhattan Cited
 Analysts said that Chase Manhattan, with more than $3 billion in brokered deposits, had the largest amount of such higher-yielding deposits in the class of institutions that are considered to be adequately capitalized and would need to apply for a waiver to continue holding such funds. First National Bank of Chicago, First Union and Bankers Trust are also in this category and each holds more than $1 billion in brokered deposits.
Among those institutions considered "uncapitalized," the Maryland National Bank of Baltimore had nearly $2 billion in brokered deposits in December, followed by the First National Bank of Boston, which had $1.7 billion, and American Security Bank, which had $1.4 billion.
 The article also referred incompletely to the role of Sheshunoff Information Services in providing data for the article and the table. The company drew no conclusions about the weakness or strength of any bank mentioned in the article.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 25, 1992, Monday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Friday about new Federal rules setting limits on bank interest rates and brokered deposits misstated the amount of brokered deposits held at the end of the year by the First Union National Bank, of Charlotte, N.C. It was $319.3 million.
A table with the article, listing the two groups of banks that face regulation of their brokered deposits and interest rates under the new rules, included two banks incorrectly in the group that would be prohibited from accepting brokered deposits or paying unusually high rates. The York Bank and Trust Company and the Massachusetts Company should not have been listed.

PACT TO PROTECT SPECIES
After nearly two weeks of negotiations, 98 countries adopted a treaty on preserving the world's plant, animal and microbial species at a meeting in Nairobi. But it was not immediately clear if the United States, Japan and other industrialized countries would sign it. 1

Assailing Serbian aggression in Bosnia, the Bush Administration ordered two of Yugoslavia's consulates closed and expelled some military attaches. The decision follows weeks of inaction against Yugoslavia's Serbian-led leadership. 1

A NASCENT EUROPEAN ARMY
Ignoring concern in Washington and London, the leaders of France and Germany approved the formation of a 35,000-member joint army corps with the aim of turning it into the nucleus of a European army. 1
 
NEAR-CHAOS IN NIGERIA
Bitter clashes between Christians and Muslims are pushing Nigeria toward chaos. At least 500 have been killed in the fighting, which may threaten the military's plan to hand over power to a civilian government next year. 1
 
NO END TO HAITIAN EXODUS
Haitian refugees at an American naval base said their compatriots would probably keep fleeing Haiti in boats, despite the Coast Guard's decision to stop picking all of them up. Meanwhile, demand outstrips space at the Guantanamo Bay base. 1
 
Washington gropes for solutions in dealing with fleeing Haitians. 2
 
THAI PREMIER SEEMS ISOLATED
Thailand's Prime Minister was abandoned by the political coalition that appointed him and presented with what amounted to a demand that he resign for his part in the violent unrest this week. 3
 
2 KOREAS CLASH AT BORDER
In their first serious military clash in years, three North Korean soldiers were killed and two South Koreans were wounded after the North Koreans crossed into the southern part of the Demilitarized Zone. 3

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 4; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1081 words

HEADLINE: After Weeks of Seeming Inaction, U.S. Decides to Punish Belgrade

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, May 22

 BODY:
The Bush Administration, trying to take the initiative after weeks of apparent inaction in the face of Serbian aggression in Bosnia, today announced new sanctions against Belgrade. The measures, while limited, put the United States ahead of Europe in efforts to deter the Serbian leadership of Yugoslavia.
The Administration ordered Yugoslav consulates in New York and San Francisco closed and their diplomats expelled. The Government also expelled Belgrade's military attaches in Washington, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d announced here tonight. The third consulate, in Chicago, will remain open. 
 Calling the situation in Bosnia and Herzegovina a "humanitarian nightmare," Mr. Baker also said the Administration would urge the European Community to consider similar measures. He said he expected to take up the subject Saturday in Lisbon where all the European nations will be represented at a meeting on aid to the former Soviet republics.
 
Recognition Is Withheld
 The actions came as Belgrade's Serbian-dominated Army and Serbian irregulars in Bosnia and Herzegovina continued to attack non-Serbs and block relief supplies.
Mr. Baker, who has been criticized along with President Bush for not taking stronger measures against the Government of President Slobodan Milosevic of the now-truncated Yugoslavia, said that if diplomatic, political and economic measures failed, "then and only then" would the United States consider discussing whether a European force should be sent to Bosnia. Such action has been proposed by the Western European Union, a defense group of European nations.
The Administration has also decided to withhold recognition of the Serbian-dominated Government in Belgrade until Serbian forces are withdrawn from Bosnia and Herzegovina and peace is restored to the former republic, Mr. Baker told reporters after a meeting with Prime Minister John Major of Britain.
Mr. Baker, speaking at 10 Downing Street, said the United States had two immediate objectives: to see Sarajevo Airport reopened and humanitarian aid get through to Bosnia. "We feel that what is happening in Bosnia-Herzegovina is unconscionable," he said, urging cooperation from "others in the civilized world, who, like us, are unwilling to sit and watch what is really a humanitarian nightmare."
He also said he found the British Government to be "totally and completely understanding" of the American position.
The United States Ambassador to Belgrade, Warren Zimmermann, who was recalled last weekend for consultations, will not be returning to Yugoslavia, Mr. Baker said, and the Embassy staff in Belgrade will be reduced.
The Bush Administration, which lagged behind the European Community over the last year -- first in recognizing the breakaway Yugoslav republics of Slovenia, Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, and then in withdrawing ambassadors from Belgrade -- is now expected to urge the Europeans to take stronger measures.
The European Community's executive commission has recommended a trade embargo on Serbia and Montenegro. In a report, the commission said that an embargo on exports from Serbia and Montenegro could have "an important impact" on the two republics since more than 50 percent of their foreign sales are to the community.
The commission recommended freezing the federation's assets at the International Monetary Fund, but noted that most other assets have already been withdrawn from Western banks.
Community foreign ministers are expected to discuss the report -- and announce new sanctions -- after they meet with Mr. Baker on Saturday.
Among some Administration policy makers, there is considerable impatience with the European Community, which tries to work by consensus, getting the agreement of all 12 members before taking action.
On Wednesday the Bush Administration denied the Yugoslav national airline landing rights at American airports. And European nations are considering similar measures, officials said here today.
 
Nuclear Pact on Agenda
 In addition to the weekend conference on how to better deliver international aid to and encourage reforms in the former Soviet Union, Mr. Baker will attempt to put the finishing touches on an agreement with the members of the Commonwealth of Independent States -- Russia, Ukraine, Belarus and Kazakhstan -- that have nuclear weapons on their soil. The Administration was hoping that the agreement to sign and ratify the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty would be signed on Sunday.
Today, Mr. Baker said that there were still some issues to be decided.
"We've been at this for the better part of almost six months and as far as I'm concerned, I'll believe it's put to bed when it's put to bed, because things continually come up," he told reporters on his plane en route from Washington.
After the Lisbon meetings, Mr. Baker will go on to the former Soviet republic of Georgia where he will meet with Eduard A. Shevardnadze, a former Soviet Foreign Minister who is now head of the Georgian State Council, an interim administration that has tried to end a civil war that broke out there shortly after the new nation declared independence.

Aid Convoys Are Suspended
 BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 22 (Special to The New York Times) -- The United Nations' main refugee-relief organization announced today that it was suspending aid convoys to Bosnia and Herzegovina, a day after Serbian gunmen hijacked a dozen United Nations trucks loaded with food and medicine.
The announcement was a blow to humanitarian aid efforts in Bosnia and Herzegovina, where food and medical supplies have shrunk to critically low levels.
"We have been facing increasing difficulty in terms of security and access to the displaced in Bosnia and Herzegovina," said Jose Maria Mendiluce, special envoy to Yugoslavia of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. "There are many armed groups that do not answer to any authority or political party."
"I will not put at risk my staff, drivers or the staff of other non-governmental organizations or the security of the food itself," he said. "In this context, we will not undertake any new operations."
"I hope it will only be a matter of days before we get the security assurances we need to operate," Mr. Mendiluce said, and other officials of the High Commissioner's office insisted that the organization is not completely ending its operations in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
