HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: House Race;
After 115 Years, a Black Will Represent Alabama

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MONTGOMERY, Ala.

 BODY:
The one thing that is certain about the crowded field seeking to represent Alabama's newly apportioned Seventh Congressional District is that from its ranks will come the state's first black member of Congress in 115 years.
The race in the district, which has a voting-age population that is two-thirds black, has attracted six black Democrats and three black Republicans to run in the June 2 primaries. 
 The size and composition of the field is not only a result of population statistics culled from the 1990 census, but also the culmination of a growing tide of black political activity in Alabama since the Voting Rights Act of 1965.
That activity has produced 705 current black elected officials in the state, giving Alabama the largest number of black legislators, school board members, mayors, council members, sheriffs and county commissioners of any state. It has made the black vote the crucial swing factor in several statewide elections. And it has spawned a spirited competition among rival black political organizations.
The state's voting-age population is 25 percent black, but a presence in the seven-member House delegation has so far eluded black politicians. And it is only because of court-drawn redistricting and the requirements of 1982 amendments to the Voting Rights Act that Alabama now seems assured of electing a black representative.
David Bositis, a senior researcher with the Joint Center for Political and Economics Studies in Washington, said that because of this recent political history the race in the new Seventh Congressional District reflects particular vibrance.
 
'A Pretty Impressive Field'
 "What is interesting is the amount of political experience you find in this field of candidates, and in that sense it is a pretty impressive field of people with their own political bases and track records," he said. "It's more competitive than most Congressional races, and therefore people have to pay closer attention."
The last black Congressman from Alabama was Jeremiah Harralson, a former slave who was elected from Selma, in the state's fertile cotton-growing Black Belt. He, like two earlier Reconstruction-era black Republicans, James T. Rapier, and Benjamin Turner, were ultimately ousted amid the resurgence of the Democratic Party, the growth of Jim Crowism and quite a bit of voter fraud, said William D. Barnard, a history professor at the University of Alabama.
The new Seventh District was drawn by a Federal District Court after a challenge by Gov. Guy Hunt, a Republican, to the plan drawn by the Democratic-controlled State Legislature.
In a number of states where Republican governors have found themselves at odds with their legislatures, a strategy has emerged of taking the disputes to Federal courts in the belief that Republican appointees in the judiciary would view the disputes in ways more favorable to Republicans.
 
Black Areas and White Areas
 As a result, in Alabama as in many other states, the new voting districts have concentrated urban and rural black voters, leaving many other areas whiter, more suburban and potentially more Republican.
In accomplishing this, Mr. Barnard said, the new Seventh District "yokes together by violence" areas as geographically different but racially similar as a large portion of industrial Birmingham and vast stretches of the rural Black Belt, where the small populations of some counties are as much as 60 to 70 percent black. It also dips into the state's other major urban area, here in Montgomery.
The Republicans in the race are Kervin Jones of Tuscaloosa, Jonathan McPherson of Hueytown and Alfred Middleton Sr. of Birmingham. But the district is overwhelmingly Democratic, and it is the Democratic candidates who are the better known and more established.
The candidate who is viewed as the favorite in the Democratic race is Earl Hilliard, a 50-year-old State Senator from Birmingham, which includes more than 45 percent of the district's population. Mr. Hilliard has the strong support of Richard Arrington, the Mayor of Birmingham.
One of Mr. Hilliard's principal opponents also is a State Senator. He is Hank Sanders, 49, a Harvard-educated lawyer from Selma who represents 8 of the 14 counties in the district.
 
Extensive Political Experience

 Other Democrats who have extensive political experience are State Representative E. B. McClain, 52, a three-term lawmaker from Bessemmer and Fairfield, just outside Birmingham, and County Commissioner John Knight, 46, an administrator at predominantly black Alabama State University in Montgomery. Mr. Knight is a longtime leader in the Alabama Democratic Conference, the state's oldest and perhaps most influential black political group.
Rounding out the Democratic field is Sam Taylor, 34, a former Washington aide to Representative Claude Harris, the white incumbent who has decided against running in the newly apportioned district, and State Representative James Thomas, 48, a four-term lawmaker, school principal and businessman from the Black Belt.
If no candidate receives more than 50 percent of the vote in the primary there will be a runoff, something most of the candidates concede is likely because of the crowded field.
Three of the state's important black political organizations have made endorsements in the race, with Mr. Sanders getting the support of the Alabama New South Coalition, Mr. Hilliard the support of the Jefferson County Citizens Committee and Mr. Knight, the Alabama Democratic Conference.

HEADLINE: French and Germans Plan an Army Corps Despite NATO Fears

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, May 22

 BODY:
Ignoring concern being voiced in Washington and London that they may be undermining NATO, the leaders of France and Germany today approved formation of a 35,000-member joint army corps with the aim of turning it into the nucleus of a future European army.
Meeting in the western French port of La Rochelle, President Francois Mitterrand and Chancellor Helmut Kohl said the so-called European Corps would become operational on Oct. 1, 1995, and would have European defense, peacekeeping outside Europe and humanitarian actions as its main missions. They argued that it would help give the European Community its "own military capability." 
 They invited other members of a nine-nation military pact known as the Western European Union to join the corps. So far, Belgium, Luxembourg and Spain have shown interest in doing so.
The idea of turning an existing 4,200-man joint French-German military brigade into a fully fledged army corps comprising one French armored division and two German mechanized brigades was first raised by Paris and Bonn in October in the context of the community's debate on closer political unity.
But the speed with which the two Governments have formalized the initiative has stirred fears in some Western capitals that the European Corps could challenge the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's traditional domination of European security questions and damage its credibility.
Aware of these worries, Mr. Mitterrand and Mr. Kohl insisted in a joint statement today that the corps "will contribute to strengthening the Atlantic alliance." They also recalled that Washington had often demanded greater "burden sharing" by its allies in the cost of protecting Europe.
"We're doing what the Americans have asked us to do for years -- be able to assure our own defense," Mr. Kohl said at a news conference. Sitting beside him, Mr. Mitterrand added: "We want the presence of Americans in Europe. We know what we owe to NATO."
But concerns remain above all because France, which withdrew its troops from NATO's military command in 1966, has long regarded the 16-nation alliance as an instrument of American foreign and military policy and would like to see its political influence reduced in the post-cold-war era.
 
Warning From U.S. Envoy
 Speaking on Thursday, apparently in response to prior information of today's announcement, the American Ambassador to NATO, William H. Taft 4th, warned that "undermining the alliance's integrated military structure in the uncertain process of developing a European security identity would be the height of folly."
The American Defense Secretary, Dick Cheney, sounded more conciliatory on Wednesday when he said formation of the force "is probably basically a sound proposal." In private, though, American officials make no secret of their distrust of French motives.
Britain's Defense Secretary, Malcolm Rifkind, said today that "the criteria we will apply is whether it will strengthen or weaken NATO." But a senior official in Prime Minister John Major's office said the corps could create "confusion and uncertainty" and he asked, "What precisely is it there for?"
As seen from NATO's Brussels headquarters, where officials are struggling to design a new post-cold-war strategy for the alliance, the corps is a signal that, sooner or later, the 12-nation European Community will want the freedom to act militarily without depending on the United States.
 
Yugoslav War Cited
 French officials point to the civil war in Yugoslavia as an example of a situation where NATO is constrained by its charter from acting "out of area" but where a future European army could help make or keep the peace. Now, though, the community lacks both authority and instruments to do so.
In promoting the European Corps, France has also seen an opportunity to strengthen its ties with Germany and to demonstrate that at a time when a united Germany is rapidly emerging as Europe's dominant power, Paris and Bonn are still jointly setting the pace of European integration.
Aware of French apprehension about new German might, Mr. Kohl has often stressed the continuing importance of what is known as the Paris-Bonn "axis." Mr. Mitterrand has in turn repeatedly sought ways of requiring Germany to acknowledge publicly that France remains its political equal.
In the case of the European Corps, Paris placed Bonn in a particularly difficult position, not only because the German Constitution still forbids it from sending troops outside NATO's European sphere of operation, but also because Mr. Kohl is anxious not to be seen by Washington as undercutting NATO.
In the end, Germany went along with today's announcement, with military planning to begin in detail when the corps' headquarters is established in the French border city of Strasbourg on July 1. But many complicated political problems remain unresolved.
 
Opposition in Germany
 The German Defense Minister, Volker Ruhe, acknowledged today that a constitutional change would be required if German troops were to carry out all the corps' proposed missions. But the opposition Social Democratic Party has pledged to block any amendment allowing German troops to be sent outside the NATO area.
If no such amendment is approved before October 1995, one of the justifications for the corps -- its ability to defend European interests outside the NATO area -- will disappear, leaving it to duplicate NATO's military responsibilities in Europe and to carry out humanitarian actions abroad.
France and Germany also have different interpretations of the corps' peacetime role, with Paris arguing that its division and Germany's two brigades should be assigned exclusively to the corps and Bonn insisting that its forces will be "double hatted" and will answer first to NATO.
This week, the Secretary General of the Western European Union, Willem van Eekelen, said the new corps' relationship with NATO had still to be clarified, while NATO's retiring military chief, Gen. John Galvin, said NATO should retain the first option to mobilize the force.
 
Other Ties Unclear
 No clearer is the corps' relationship with the Western European Union. Community leaders agreed in December that the organization should become the new European defense pillar, subservient to NATO on European military matters but free to act outside the NATO area. For the moment, though, the corps will be answerable only to Paris and Bonn.
This month, the competition between military groups has become even more intense. Last week, the British Defense Secretary said London was ready to make troops and a command center available to the Western European Union. He also said the union should be able to call on European forces assigned to a new rapid reaction force being set up by NATO.
This week, NATO's Secretary General, Manfred Worner, said the alliance had agreed to offer its peacekeeping and humanitarian services to the 52-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, a move that -- if accepted -- could result in NATO forces being given missions outside Western Europe.

HEADLINE: U.S. Says It Misjudged Numbers on Student Aid

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22

 BODY:
The Bush Administration said today that it had underestimated the number of college students eligible for a major Federal scholarship aid program, but that all students who qualified for the grant this year would receive it.
In testimony before a Senate appropriations committee earlier this week, Education Secretary Lamar Alexander said his department had predicted that 3.7 million students would receive Pell grants, the main Federal higher education aid program to college students. But he said more than four million students actually qualified for the next school year, producing a $1.1 billion shortfall in the budget. 
 "We were wrong on our estimate," Mr. Alexander told the Senate committee Wednesday. "We missed it." Mr. Alexander offered no explanation for the error, but Etta Fielek, a spokesman for the department, today described the method the department uses to calculate the number of students receiving the grants as being less a matter of science "than instincts and guesswork."
"In this case our crystal ball broke and about 300,000 more students received Pell grants than we anticipated," said Ms. Fielek.
 
No Grants Being Cut
 But Ms. Fielek said that no student who has received notification of the amount of his or her Pell grant would get a reduced grant as a consequence of the underestimation.
"You've got that many more people of all ages taking advantage of the best system of higher education in the world," said Ms. Fielek. "The Government wants to support students in school. The commitment is there. And no student is going to suffer. We would not under any circumstances go back and adjust those amounts. But it a serious bookkeeping problem."
The department has not yet decided how to cover the shortage, but the money will have to be taken from some other programs' appropriations.
Education experts say that the increase in the number of students applying for the grants is a result of a stagnant economy. Students are staying in school longer because of a lack of job opportunities; adults are going back to school to sharpen skills or to retrain for better-paying jobs.
 
Political Factors Seen
 "This is just mostly due to the recession," said David Merkowitz, director of public affairs for the American Council on Education. "It's not a big surprise, but the department's underestimates have been chronic, which has been somewhat a political thing on their part."
The miscalculation comes at a time when Republicans and Democrats in Congress had hoped to increase the grant level and expand the program's support by including more middle-class students.
"Everybody was hopeful about getting an expansion into the middle class, but more importantly an increase in the size of the maximum award," said Mr. Merkowitz. "This miscalculation forecloses that possibility."
The Pell grant program is the chief Federal program for aid to undergraduates. In the school year just ending, it provided $5.3 billion in direct grants to 3.4 million college students, most of them from families earning less than $35,000 a year. The maximum grant of $2,400 is based on need and college cost, not academic merit.
 
Centerpiece of Policy
 Administration officials have promoted Mr. Bush's education-legislation package and the $1.6 billion increase in the education budget as the centerpiece of White House domestic policy.
Now some Congressional critics maintain that the miscalculation is a politically motivated attempt to blame Congress for cutting back other social programs, like Head Start, to make up the shortfall in the college program.
"The $1.6 billion increase in discretionary spending the Department so proudly announced in January is now completely gone," said Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, during the appropriation's committee hearings. "This spending boost will be soaked up by the Pell grant shortfall and other new requirements unless the Administration can come up with a solution."

HEADLINE: Violence Flares Again in Delivery Drivers Dispute

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL

 BODY:
In a surge of violence in the 16-day-old newspaper delivery dispute, a replacement driver was critically injured late Thursday by a brick-size rock thrown through the window of a bus carrying nonunion workers into a New Rochelle, N.Y., newspaper distribution center, the New Rochelle police said.
The worker, Gary Lee Mauney, 50 years old, from Fayetteville, N.C., was hit in the head. He underwent 12 hours of surgery in New Rochelle Hospital and was in critical condition in the intensive-care unit, police and hospital officials said last night. 
 Charged in the incident was one of nine union drivers for whom the union had been demanding amnesty for earlier complaints. Disagreement over the amnesty issue unexpectedly derailed a union ratification vote scheduled for this week on proposed contracts with The New York Times and Arthur E. Imperatore, the newspaper distributor who owns the center in New Rochelle where the attack occurred. Union officials were trying to reschedule a vote for next week.
The latest violence, which included other reported overnight incidents, hardened Mr. Imperatore's stance against amnesty, his lawyer, Jerold E. Glassman, said in a statement yesterday. Mr. Glassman said the amnesty demand was to blame for "giving a lawless element the impression that any misconduct or violent act will be forgiven at the conclusion of a labor dispute."
Douglas LaChance, the president of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers' Union of New York and Vicinity, called the incident in New Rochelle "very unfortunate" and acknowledged that "it makes things more complicated."
Mr. LaChance went to the New Rochelle center last night to talk to the drivers on the picket line, telling them that he deplored violence on both sides. He also said that he was not convinced the arrested driver was guilty in the rock-throwing incident. "When some guy from North Carolina unfortunately got hurt, I'm sorry he got hurt," Mr. LaChance added, "but what is he doing here from North Carolina? Except to perpetrate economic despair on these poor people here, who are all legitimate working guys."
But labor advisers for both sides who spoke on the condition of anonymity said that concern over the violence and worries that it might increase could prompt a speedier resolution in the dispute. Moreover, they said, focusing attention on the amnesty issue might make it, and not the contract itself, the primary obstacle a settlement. If that could be resolved, they said, the rest of the dispute might well follow.
The arrested driver was identified as Robert Boyle, 27, of the Bronx. He was charged with second-degree assault, criminal possession of a weapon and criminal mischief, and held without bail pending further investigation, said Detective Lieut. Anthony Murphy, a spokesman for the New Rochelle police.
Lieutenant Murphy said a tour bus was carrying the replacement drivers from a local motel into Westfair Newspaper Distributors Company in a downtown industrial park about 11:15 P.M. Thursday when the rock was thrown through a side window. A second passenger, Tom Haynesworth, 41, also of Fayetteville, was treated for facial cuts and released, the police said.
Saying he deplored violence "on both sides," Mr. LaChance said in his Queens union hall last night that he still hoped to reach an agreement on the fate of at least the eight other workers, clearing the way for a rescheduled vote next week.
Before the members are four contracts -- one with The Times, two with delivery companies whose assets The Times has contracted to acquire, and one with Mr. Imperatore's Imperial Delivery Service -- that would secure the jobs of some 1,000 current permanent drivers in exchange for attrition, sharp cuts in guaranteed overtime and other economies.
From the companies' perspective, the contracts seek to secure labor peace through the year 2000 and clear the way for the opening of a new Times printing plant in Edison, N.J. The contracts would give management considerable new leeway in redrawing routes and curbing overtime. They would also permit the first introduction of part-time workers, while easing driver advancement and providing some wage and benefit increases.
 
Earlier Contract Rejected
 An earlier version of the contracts, also approved by the union leadership, was decisively rejected by the membership on May 6. Mr. Imperatore then hired replacement drivers for the Westfair center and a second distribution center in East Farmingdale, L.I., setting off the dispute.
Mr. LaChance, who is besieged by vocal dissidents and other opponents in the ranks, sought this week to win amnesty for some of the union pickets charged with disruptions at Mr. Imperatore's two suburban centers as a way of bringing in a victory that could help pass the contracts. But Mr. LaChance said yesterday that Mr. Glassman backed out of an understanding on amnesty that left the union leader embarrassed and exposed.
Mr. Glassman acknowledged yesterday that "we had the germ of a settlement" but he said it had not yet been agreed on when Thursday night's violence "took amnesty off the table."
The Times's publisher, Arthur Sulzberger Jr., said yesterday that the latest violence nearly cost a life and said "these terrible actions must cease."
"I'm saddened by the events of last night and also by the slow response to them by the New Rochelle Police Department," he said in a statement.
Lieutenant Murphy said the police did respond quickly and added: "Both sides complained about us -- we just walk the line."
 
Times Cites Other Incidents
 A Times spokeswoman, Nancy Nielsen, said there were several other "serious acts of violence" that in some cases delayed delivery of papers to parts of Manhattan and Long Island.
At 3:30 A.M. yesterday, she said, a truck owned by Metropolitan News, a New York City distributor that is one of the two wholesalers The Times plans to acquire, was "hijacked" in lower Manhattan by three men wearing bandannas over their faces. After forcing the driver to abandon the truck, they fled with it, she said.
The New York City police said that in a second incident an hour later, three men made off with another Metropolitan News truck while the driver was making a delivery inside 157 West 124th Street in Manhattan. Three men were later arrested. The police identified them as Gerald McGraw, 24, of Babylon, L.I.; Peter Rauchut, 33, of Lake Ronkonkoma, L.I., and William Groh, 26, of Bellport, L.I.
In the legal arena, Judge Pierre N. Leval of Federal District Court in Manhattan, enforcing an earlier finding, entered a judgment against the union yesterday for $100,000 for violating a contempt order not to interfere with Times deliveries.

HEADLINE: Washington Memo;
A Year for Repackaging Volatile Census Reports

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22

 BODY:
Concern is growing among Census Bureau employees that the Bush Administration, with its eye on the election, may be impeding access to economic statistics that tell the country about itself. While the bureau has dispensed demographic data from the 1990 census with uncommon speed, the openness has been less evident in the handling of economic news that could be politically volatile in this election year. Economic reports have been delayed, retitled and repackaged in recent months. Discouraging statistics have been presented to the public through rose-colored news releases, and some numbers have been made public without notice.
In the last three months, two reports that at best gave a mixed picture of jobs and poverty were delayed during long negotiations between the authors and the public information office over the wording of the accompanying news releases. The practice of putting experts' names and telephone numbers on news releases was abandoned, and restrictions were placed on public relations employees in the bureau. 
 "There's been somewhat of a change," said Daniel Weinberg, chief of the bureau's division on housing and household economic statistics. "Any Administration would be sensitive to economic figures."
 
'Major Behavioral Change'
 Another bureau researcher, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said: "It's a major behavioral change going on. This place has always been wide open. A lot of people see a drive to alter that."
The change is evident in bureau policy concerning contacts with news organizations. An old Commerce Department policy, which makes it more difficult for the reporters of major news organizations to gain access to Government experts, was recirculated at the Census Bureau after two researchers spoke openly with reporters about delicate subjects.
In one case a researcher, Beth DaPonte, gave a public interest group estimates of Iraqi deaths in the Persian Gulf war that exceeded the Pentagon's. Bureau employees said Ms. DaPonte's superior tried to dismiss her and then relented. Ms. DaPonte told colleagues that the action was simply political retaliation.
In another case a bureau analyst, Jack McNeil, gave several interviews on his latest findings on the widening gap between the incomes of the richest and poorest Americans. When news reports appeared, an associate undersecretary at the Commerce Department, the bureau's parent agency, complained to the bureau's public information director.
Later, both people, Susan Howard of the Commerce Department and Karen Wheeless of the Census Bureau, said the complaint had involved the bureau's failure to notify the Commerce Department of the interviews.
 
Data Unchanged
 A Commerce Department official, also speaking on the condition that he not be identified, said it was appropriate for researchers to comment on the factual content of reports. But he added: "The question is, if you decide to work for the Government, do you still have the academic freedom to say anything you damn well please? I think it's pretty clear that if you work for the Government and the Census Bureau, that you don't state opinions where it isn't appropriate for you to reach opinions. These people aren't on a level to be speaking for the Government."
In no case did anyone say that the Administration had tried to change data. The concerns involved the way statistics were presented and whether reporters were denied access to experts, important issues at an institution that employees call the "fact factory."
The new policy on news contacts is being reconsidered in the wake of the uproar that ensued when Mr. Weinberg announced the policy in an April 27 memorandum. It said, in part, that bureau employees could not "give out simple numbers, such as the number of housing units in the U.S.," unless such a contact had been cleared by the public information office.
 
Disagreement at Top
 Barbara Everitt Bryant, the bureau's director, said in a recent interview: "The Dan Weinberg memo is not bureau policy. I'm working to correct this misunderstanding."
In the last year, the bureau's Assistant Director for Communications, John J. Connolly, who is a political appointee, has been on the pre-publication distribution list for all bureau reports. "I don't edit reports," Mr. Connolly said. "I do ask a lot of questions about press releases."
One recent report, highlighting the growth in the number of low-paying jobs, was eventually released months behind schedule with no accompanying news release. "That was my news judgment," Ms. Wheeless said, adding that she did not believe that the report had added to information in earlier reports.
A second report, on the creation of new jobs, was accompanied by a news release that highlighted the number of people entering jobs in "high-paying" industries but that did not note that about half of the workers were paid less than $200 a week.

HEADLINE: PATENTS;
Cold War Secrecy Still Shrouds Inventions

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22

 BODY:
Despite the collapse of the Soviet Union, the Federal Government is still placing gag orders on nearly 6,000 inventions that it believes could threaten national security, according to recent data obtained by a public interest group.
Imposed by the Patent and Trademark Office under a 1951 law called the Invention Secrecy Act, these secrecy orders block patents from being issued and in many cases prohibit the inventors from selling or licensing their technology to anybody except the Government -- regardless of whether the technology was developed with private or Government money. 
 The biggest growth in secrecy orders has not been those imposed on military secrets, like the blueprints for making nuclear weapons, but rather from "dual use" technologies that can be used for both commercial and military purposes. These can range from certain kinds of computer hardware to advanced ceramic materials, laser systems, semiconductor manufacturing technologies and automated process control systems.
Newly available data, obtained from the Patent Office under the Freedom of Information Act by the Federation of American Scientists, show that the number of new secrecy orders increased steadily from 290 in 1979 to 774 in 1991 and that some of the biggest increases took place in the last three years. The total number of secrecy orders in effect has grown steadily in the last decade, from 3,600 in 1979 to 5,893 in 1991.
No complaints have been heard from companies that have received secrecy orders, which still amount to less than 1 percent of the patents issued each year. But the new numbers surprised and disturbed some patent experts.
"The number is higher than I would have expected," said Herbert Wamsley, executive director of Intellectual Property Owners Inc., a lobbying group for inventors here. "The concern about a large number of these orders is that they could impair plans to commercialize valuable new technology."
Steven Aftergood, head of the Project on Government Secrecy at the Federation of American Scientists, said the rise in secrecy orders was at odds with national interests in the 1990's. "It makes no sense," he said. "At a time when the military threat is receding and the economic threat is on the rise, it is anomalous at best that restrictions on new inventions should be skyrocketing."
In secrecy orders imposed for purposes of export control, a company may sell or license its product within the United States to those who have legitimate business interests, but it cannot even reveal details of the technology or sell the product to foreign companies. These export control orders accounted for less than 10 percent of secrecy orders imposed in 1980, but almost half of those issued last year.
Perhaps the most surprising shift is that a growing proportion of the inventions placed under wraps are ones in which the Government does not hold title to the patent. Some of these inventions have been developed in part with Government funds, but the companies that obtain the patent hold all or part of the ownership interests.
In 1991, fully three-quarters of all new secrecy orders -- 506 out of 774 -- were imposed on inventions patented by private companies. By contrast, a study by the House Government Operations Committee in 1982 reported that in 1979 about 43 of 290 secrecy orders, or about one-seventh of the total, were imposed on non-Government inventions.
Robert Garrett, director of the office that oversees secrecy orders at the Patent and Trademark Office, said the secrecy orders were not as ominous as they might seem because the export control orders were more lenient than imposed on "classified" technology. But he refrained from commenting on whether the orders represent appropriate policy. "It's the law, and it's what I'm charged with the responsibility for administering," he said.
Robert E. Garrett, director of the office that oversees secrecy orders at the Patent and Trademark Office, acknowledged that the restrictions were unusual in that they could block the publication of information developed entirely by private individuals. The only comparable law is the one that prohibits people from publishing information about building atomic weapons.
But Mr. Garrett argued that patents represented a unique source of how-to information, in part because inventors are required by law fully to disclose the details necessary for others to reproduce the invention. He also noted that the collapse of Communism in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe had not put an end to security threats from countries like Iraq and Libya or from terrorists.
In addition, Mr. Garrett said the Pentagon was now in the process of revising its list of "militarily critical" technologies that are likely to be kept secret. In the last several months, he said, Pentagon officials have recommended fewer secrecy orders than they did last year, but he said it remained unclear whether this was a blip or the start of a trend.
John Preston, head of licensing for the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said that his university had received several secrecy orders over the years but that almost all had stemmed from inventions at the Lincoln Laboratory, which M.I.T. operates under contract for the Federal Government.
In one exception, he said, the Federal Government has tried to impose a secrecy order on a patent application for producing energy through "cold fusion" technology, an area of research that generated great excitement several years ago but now appears to be ineffective.
But Mr. Preston echoed the view that some restrictions were still necessary in the post-cold-war world. "There are definitely reasons to keep some of our research secret," he said. "Making it easier for a small Middle Eastern country to make nuclear weapons is not a prospect that makes me feel comfortable."

HEADLINE: Saratoga's Sparkling Spring Is Stilled No More

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.

 BODY:
Since a spring of sparkling water was found hundreds of feet below sand and rock on a farm here in 1872, the Saratoga Mineral Water Company has been a good-luck charm and a goodwill ambassador for this genteel city.
So for a place that takes its waters as seriously as its horses, it was a dismal day last August when the company's most recent owner, the French company Evian, succumbed to the dual pressures of the recession and the crowded bottled-water market and closed the company, apparently for good. 
 Throughout the state, companies have been folding and workers laid off. But sometimes, enough is enough. In Saratoga Springs a group of investors, motivated as much by civic pride as by business, decided that whatever happened, they could not let the company die without a fight.
 
Workers Return
 After months of negotiations with Evian, they bought Saratoga Mineral Water. Almost all the laid-off workers returned, even the ones who had found new jobs. Later this month, the water in the slender, icy-clear bottles will be tumbling off the production line once again.
The return of Saratoga Mineral Water is, in part, a small victory in the midst of a lingering recession. It is also the story of local people offended by the big-company attitudes of a foreign conglomerate that seemed to have little time to focus on a tiny American company, even one that meant so much to the community.
"Saratoga water was always in the refrigerator when I was growing up and when I heard it was shut down I thought it was someone's idea of a bad joke," said Anthony Malatino, a local stockbroker who, with several partners and the support of the Center for Economic Growth in Albany, a private agency, raised the millions of dollars needed to buy the company. They won't say exactly how much they raised, but it was between $4 million and $5 million, a local businessman said.
"The president of Evian's only trip up here was a seven-minute meeting to shut the plant down," Mr. Malatino said. "I believe that he had to ask for directions."
To understand what makes Saratoga Mineral Water so special is to understand the history of a city whose original Indian name is a reference to the bubbly water that comes from under the ground.
As long as people have been traveling to Saratoga to soak in the luxurious spas (in which a guest sits naked as carbonated water shoots at the body from every direction), and to bet on the horses, they have been drinking the water from the springs.
In the late 19th century, when Saratoga Mineral Water was founded under the name Saratoga Vichy, residents became accustomed to drinking "Scotch and Vichy," swearing that, because of its fine natural carbonation, it never led to a hangover. In 1892, the water won a gold medal in the World Columbian Exposition in Chicago, and a drawing of the bottle appeared on the front cover of Harper's Magazine. Last year, the company shipped thousands of cases to the U.S.S. Saratoga, during the Persian Gulf war.
 
A Friendly Company
 If ever a company could be called friendly, this one could. The workers happily wear company T-shirts, pride themselves on "cross training" -- meaning they know how to work on many pieces of equipment, so they don't get too bored -- and appreciate the way the company's chief operating officer, Mark Wiggins, challenges them to games of horseshoes on lazy Friday afternoons (he usually wins).
Plus, they say, they get to drink the water. (Connoisseurs swear that what makes it special is that it has smaller-than-usual bubbles, giving it a Champagne sort of feel, but such subtleties are lost on the lay person.)
"It's great water," said Ernie Wren, a 51-year-old forklift operator, whose father worked at the plant for 20 years and who has put in 30 years himself. "It's part of Saratoga originally, you know. And practically all of my friends and relatives seem to work here."
Until the late 1970's, the company was owned by a local family. The plant is on the same spot as the original plant, on Geyser Road across from the Saratoga Spa State Park. The building is crisply clean and painted periwinkle blue.
Water comes in through a series of pipes directly from the springs in the woods. The carbonation is removed and then replaced to make the bubbles uniform. After it is purified, the water is spurted into bottles of various sizes, which are capped, labeled and then dropped into cartons for shipping, mostly locally (its new owners want to market it as far away as Florida and California). The machines can bottle as many as 550 7.7-ounce bottles a minute.
 
Thanks for the Samples
 Since the company announced plans to reopen, many people here have expressed their delight. Mary Lou Whitney, the grande dame of Saratoga horse racing, who owns a summer home here, wrote a nice letter to Mr. Malatino thanking him for some free samples he had sent and offering to provide marketing advice. Aggie's, a clothing store on Broadway, decorated its front windows in Saratoga Mineral Water motif and got its employees to wear commemorative T-shirts.
"I cannot tell you how many people have come in here and said we're so glad to see them back, where is the water," said Mary Lou Mullaney, the store's owner. "People had been hoarding cases of it and siphoning it out one bottle a month, because they were afraid they'd never be able to get it again."
A. C. Dake, the Mayor, has been feeling downright celebratory. "This is a great confidence builder and it just makes people feel very glad," she said. At the event announcing the purchase of the company, she said, she joined other officials in guzzling Saratoga Mineral Water. "We were sitting around drinking it like it was Champagne," she said.

HEADLINE: Storage Technology Drops

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LOUISVILLE, Colo., May 22

 BODY:
The Storage Technology Corporation stock fell today after the maker of computer data-storage products warned that its second-quarter results should be below the company's previous expectations.
While the company declined to estimate the exact amount, it said earnings were expected to be below the first-quarter result of 30 cents a share. 
 The company's shares fell $3.75 to close at $33.50 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Company officials said the company's performance was expected to improve through the end of the year, with overall earnings for the year in the same range as 1991.
The principal reason for the change in second-quarter earnings estimates, the company said, is continuing softness in orders for its 4400 Automated Cartridge System, a device that stores computer data on magnetic tapes.
The company also cited the recession, other competitive pressures and high overhead costs resulting from lower-than-expected manufacturing volumes.

HEADLINE: OPEC Sets Slight Rise In Its Output

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: VIENNA, May 22

 BODY:
OPEC struck a deal today to raise oil production only slightly during the peak-demand summer season, hoping to keep crude prices firm.
The oil minister of Libya, Abdallah Salim al-Badri, said the group reached the accord during a three-hour meeting. 
 Iraq's oil minister, Osama A. R. al-Hiti, said he had refused to sign the agreement because "the Saudis were dictating the positions" of other producers. Iraq, however, is not exporting oil because of a United Nations embargo imposed after its invasion of Kuwait nearly two years ago.
 
Exception for Kuwait
 The accord calls for all OPEC members but Kuwait to hold production at current levels in the July-September quarter. Kuwait was allowed an unlimited increase as its oil industry rapidly bounces back from the damages of the Persian Gulf war.
The deal would effectively set OPEC's production ceiling at about 23.4 million barrels a day -- around the level of current output.
Prices have been higher than expected this spring, but are still about $2.50 a barrel below OPEC's $21 target. A barrel is 42 gallons.
Analysts said the agreement probably would keep prices steady.
Paul Mlotok, head of energy research at Morgan Stanley in New York, said the deal would "probably lead to a balanced market," keeping supply and demand in line. Prices will probably stay "more or less around current levels," he said.
Prices had risen about 50 cents a barrel Thursday after the outline of the agreement filtered out. Prices had been down some because many industry people had expected a bigger increase in output.
 
Small Price Declines
 Prices today ended higher, with light crude oil for July delivery up 4 cents to $20.94 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Demand normally grows in the summer, the peak driving season. Moreover, the economic recovery in the United States is expected to lift sales of crude oil.
The current supply ceiling, set in February, restrained pumping to avoid a price collapse in the spring, when demand normally falls.
At that time, Iran complained that the production ceiling was too high; it expressed similar objections to the new accord.
The ministers met in the hotel suite of Youssef Omeir bin Youssef, the oil minister of the United Arab Emirates and the current president of OPEC.
Earlier, ministers gave sketchy details of the emerging accord.
 
Little Change Seen
 The oil minister of Iran, Gholam Reza Aghazadeh, said the proposed accord was "basically a rollover" of the current oil production ceiling. It appeared the plan would allow Saudi Arabia, the group's most powerful member, to continue pumping at a high level, which is estimated at about 8.1 million barrels a day at present.
United Nations and Iraqi officials have discussed a proposal that would allow Baghdad to sell oil to buy food and other humanitarian supplies. No progress has been reported recently.
OPEC's members are Algeria, Ecuador, Gabon, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Libya, Nigeria, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Venezuela.

HEADLINE: Treasury Issues Higher in Light Trading

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose in light trading yesterday, as some investors and traders stepped up and bought notes and bonds after two days of fairly sharp price declines.
Most of the gains were recorded during overnight trading in Asia and later in European financial markets. Analysts said participants in the United States seemed to be more interested in the start of a long holiday weekend than in taking on new positions. In preparation for the Memorial Day holiday, trading was suspended at 1 P.M. 
 Despite the price turnaround, analysts noted that the market remained defensive. Since the Federal Reserve Board apparently decided to keep short-term rates steady at least for now, traders have become mindful of the next round of economic reports, the analysts said. If the data due next week are stronger than expected, investors may begin to watch for the possibility of a Fed move might be to tighten policy, they said. "The market still seems a bit suspect," said William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. "It would take some really weak data to get rates to move back toward their lows."
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 29 1/2-year bonds of 2021 were offered at the close of trading at a price of 1022/32 , up half a point, to yield 7.82 percent, compared with 7.86 percent late Thursday and 7.81 percent on May 15.
Among outstanding Treasury note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 101 1/8, up 9/32 , to yield 7.33 percent.
Prices of new Treasury notes auctioned earlier this week also recovered.
The 5 1/8 percent two-year notes sold Wednesday were offered in when-issued trading yesterday at a price to yield 5.24 percent, compared with 5.30 percent late Thursday. And the 6 3/4 percent five-year notes auctioned on Thursday were offered on a when-issued basis yesterday at a price to yield 6.69 percent. They were auctioned on Thursday to yield 6.75 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were unchanged to down slightly.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 3.67 percent late yesterday, unchanged from Thursday. Six-month bill rates fell by 1 basis point, or one-hundredth of a percentage point, to a late rate of 3.77 percent. And one-year bill rates fell by 6 basis points, to a late rate of 3.98 percent.
No new corporate or tax-exempt municipal bonds were priced yesterday, and trading in the secondary markets for investment-grade corporate and municipal bond markets was extremely slow.
Traders said that prices of most outstanding corporate issues were essentially unchanged.
And participants in the tax-exempt municipal bond market said that prices of most widely quoted securities were unchanged to up an eighth of a point.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Turns Mixed in U.S. In Light Day as Gold Rises

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar turned mixed in domestic dealings yesterday after gaining ground overseas. Trading was light.
Gold prices advanced after falling in Asia. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $337.90 a troy ounce, up 90 cents from Thursday. The Republic National Bank said gold rose 75 cents an ounce to a late bid price of $337.75. 
 Analysts said the dollar posted some gains on the belief that the Federal Reserve was holding monetary policy steady, which would rule out a much anticipated cut in interest rates. Lower interest rates make dollar-denominated securities less valuable.
"There has been a lot of dollar weakness predicated on a Fed ease and widening interest-rate differentials in Europe," said Michael Malpede, an analyst with Refco Inc. in Chicago.
He said most traders were preoccupied with adjusting their holdings ahead of the long Memorial Day weekend.
 
New Data Next Week
 Other currencies -- particularly the Japanese yen and the German mark -- appeared to dominate trading. United States dealers are looking to the release next week of fresh economic data, including April durable goods orders and weekly jobless claims, to offer some direction to trading.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 129.65 Japanese yen, from 129.61 yen on Thursday. Later in London, it fell to 129.40 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 129.20 yen, down from 130.35 yen on Thursday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.8155, from $1.8170 late Thursday. In New York it cost $1.8160 to buy one pound, less expensive than Thursday's $1.8165.

HEADLINE: The End of Sovereignty

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis; Flora Lewis is Senior Columnist of The New York Times.

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
Europe is experiencing severe growing pains. All 12 members of the European Community must ratify the Treaty of Maastricht, agreed upon by government heads in the Netherlands in December, if European unity is to be achieved. The debates are stormier than expected.
Critics in each country have their own sticking points, plus domestic political feuds that complicate the issue. But the storms should have been expected because matters of nation and sovereignty are being broached directly as never before. 
 Fundamentally, all members have to face the question of whether democracy and the free market economy are compatible. Both are being urged on ex-Communist and developing countries as the essential double helix of successful societies, necessarily intertwined. The paradox is that advanced states are finding it hard to keep them together as they accept the facts of interdependence.
This is true everywhere, including in the U.S., but Europe must be first to tackle it.
Sovereignty is a matter of frontiers, and democracy is anchored in politically defined territory. But, as Britain's former Foreign Secretary, Sir Geoffrey Howe, has said, "Sovereignty isn't like virginity." There are degrees of sovereignty, and the modern world is eroding the notion of absolute and exclusive nation-states.
The market disrespects sovereign borders as much and wherever it can. The global economy has swollen to a fluid mass that no government can regulate on its own, yet it affects the everyday life of ordinary citizens more and more directly. Jobs, interest rates, the value of money are matters each government talks about to its electorate, but the people are touched by decisions beyond their leaders' control.
Instant, 24-hour access to stock markets around the world, vast international banking entanglements that can confound national monitors as the Bank of Credit and Commerce International did, make a mockery of sovereignty. Likewise the real estate giant Olympia and York, whose properties can't be foreclosed to pay debt like those of lesser operators would be because that would drive down real estate values in too many countries and threaten too many banks.
Some Europeans, like Margaret Thatcher, oppose letting European union nibble away at sovereign command within national borders because they consider Brussels likely to reintroduce socialistic tendencies. Some agree with France's former Defense Minister, Jean-Pierre Chevenement, a socialist, who says it would expose his countrymen to the "power of international money" regardless of their votes.
Jacques Attali, the puckish Frenchman who heads the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, says that the market needs to overcome borders while traditional democracy needs to keep them. So the aim for the future, he argues, must be a "democracy without frontiers," a superior democracy of overlapping units, where everyone can be a member of a variety of democratic entities of various shapes and sizes.
These are difficult, challenging ideas, and the future citizens of the European Union are stumbling into them as they debate the new treaty. The choice is stark: Europe, yes or no. France, a key founder of the Common Market, is raging with doubt, though most people see there is no going back. The democracy dilemma will have to be addressed with new, transnational countervailing forces, growing out of the growing pains.
This is the way the world is going. Yugoslavia shows what the opposite direction means. The European Community has to lead in defining the issues of sovereignty, economy and democracy. Others won't escape it.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Classical Music in Review

BYLINE: By Bernard Holland

 BODY:

Janice Weber
Pianist
Steinway Hall 
 Midway through her piano recital at Steinway Hall on Thursday night, Janice Weber spoke of opera transcriptions as educational tools for the media-bereft audiences of the 19th century: a kernel of truth in that but much to argue about. Four-hand duets, simple arrangements for the modest pianist, yes, but what Ms. Weber proceeded to play -- a late Liszt setting from "Die Meistersinger," Busoni's "chamber" transcription of themes from "Carmen" and an Abram Chasins inflation of hit tunes from Weinberger's "Schwanda, the Bagpiper" -- seemed less an educational service for others than significant self-serving by the pianist-composers who wrote them.
Familiar operatic material exists in all three, but it is swamped with notes, thousands of them. Around Wagner's aria "Am stillen Herd" rippled waves of scales and arpeggios. Busoni, a serious thinker who nevertheless seemed helpless before the lure of virtuoso extravaganza, set Ms. Weber severe problems here, at the same time making interesting observations on Bizet's already interesting harmony. The "Schwanda" transcription was the weakest of the three musically: a pretty tune wrapped in bombast.
Pieces like this, of course, tempt pianists like Ms. Weber. She can handle their complications with firmness and confidence; and where there is music worth exposing and organizing, she finds and projects it very clearly. Ms. Weber continued her underlying theme of driven virtuosity with Leo Ornstein's Fourth Piano Sonata. Its relentless difficulties begin with the French and Russian colorists of the early 20th century and then congeal them into thick blocks of busy, powerful movement. Mr. Ornstein, as Ms. Weber reminded us, is alive and well at age 100 and living near Green Bay, Wis.
The program began with the two Beethoven Sonatas of Opus 27: the E-flat major and the familiar "Moonlight."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

And Bear in Mind
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
I'M DYSFUNCTIONAL, YOU'RE DYSFUNCTIONAL: The Recovery Movement and Other Self-Help Fashions, by Wendy Kaminer. (Addison-Wesley, $18.95.) The author, a lawyer and journalist, offers a witty, occasionally harsh account of people who call their troubles diseases and blame other people for them.
AFTER HENRY, by Joan Didion. (Simon & Schuster, $22.) Reports and meditations, affording the pleasures of literature, on phenomena like Patricia Hearst, brush fires, Ronald Reagan.
ALL THE PRETTY HORSES, by Cormac McCarthy. (Knopf, $21.) The first volume of a planned trilogy, this dark, uncomfortable, magnetically attractive novel projects its 16-year-old hero's activity on a world too vast and alien to be much affected.
TIME AND TIDE, by Edna O'Brien. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $21.) A brilliant product of its author's imagination for disaster, this harrowing novel concerns a woman, called Nell, whose loss of a child is only the worst of the tactics with which life defeats her.
DREAMING IN CUBAN, by Cristina Garcia. (Knopf, $20.) A fine first novel about the mysteries of place and the passions carried into exile, grounded in the life of a family of the Cuban diaspora.
BLACK WATER, by Joyce Carol Oates. (William Abrahams/ Dutton, $17.) A 26-year-old woman drowns when a senator's car goes off a bridge; but the point of view in this powerfully imagined novel belongs to the victim, whom we are made to know and whose tragedy we are made to comprehend.
VERY OLD BONES, by William Kennedy. (Viking, $22.) The sixth novel in the author's Albany cycle is a sort of excavation into the past of his own career as a writer, where the undoing of gloom and the reconciliation of family members are central themes.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 16; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1580 words

HEADLINE: FILM;
'American Dream' Charts Labor's Loss

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS; Sam Roberts covers politics and labor for The New York Times.

 BODY:
When Florence Reece wrote the labor anthem "Which Side Are You On" back in the 1930's, her question was rhetorical. Four decades later, when she sang it in Barbara Kopple's paean to labor, "Harlan County, U.S.A.," the song title was still listed in the credits without a question mark.
But by the mid-1980's, when Ms. Kopple filmed "American Dream," about a protracted meatpackers strike against Hormel, the nation had grown more ambivalent about organized labor. Few union leaders would risk asking such a sweeping question of the public -- or even of their own members. 
 A very different song punctuates "American Dream," the 1990 film for which the director won an Academy Award. Twice during the movie, which opened in March and is playing at the Quad Cinema in Greenwich Village, a union leader named Jim Guyette loosely invokes the lyrics of "No Surrender," Bruce Springsteen's rock ballad of rebellion. In the end, Mr. Guyette lives the lyrics: he neither retreats nor surrenders. But he and the militant meatpackers' union local he headed are defeated nonetheless.
In most film versions of labor strife, from "On the Waterfront" in 1954 to "Newsies" earlier this year, heroes and villains are easy to identify. Fiction has that advantage: people and controversies can be defined starkly, without ambiguity. Few filmgoers left Martin Ritt's "Norma Rae" (1979) or John Sayles's "Matewan" (1987) cheering for management. Even Ms. Kopple's "Harlan County, U.S.A." (1977), which also won an Academy Award, generally championed the Kentucky coal miners.
But "American Dream" is a labor nightmare from real life. A reflection of the times, it offers more questions than answers through a largely nonjudgmental account of Mr. Guyette's inspiring crusade against both the management of George A. Hormel & Company and the curiously pragmatic leadership of his own international union.
The film tells the story of the yearlong strike precipitated in 1985 after the company unilaterally cut hourly wages from $10.69 to $8.25 at its Austin, Minn., plant. The walkout finally ended when the company reopened the plant with permanent replacement workers. The international union seized control of the local and negotiated a new contract that guaranteed the strikers only a place on a waiting list -- at lower pay.
As "American Dream" makes clear, the dispute at Hormel went beyond wages and working conditions. It also involved a breach between a defiant local and a remote leadership in Washington that was more than willing to urge concessions on the part of higher-paid employees to spare workers at the lower end of the pay scale.
Ms. Kopple's account could not have captured raw emotion any better if the dialogue had been scripted and the characters professionally cast. But, at times, her eyewitness camera blinks: specific details about internal union politics take second place to the human drama that pits brother against brother -- in one case literally -- in a debate over principle versus survival. Workers at Hormel were also worried about on-the-job injury rates, an issue ignored by the film. Hormel was profitable but, some analysts suggested, it stood in a precarious position in a changing industry -- another topic the movie doesn't explore.
Ms. Kopple insists that "American Dream" is not agitprop but rather a tale of people fighting to preserve a value system that began to erode when worker loyalty was rewarded not with a raise but with a pay cut.
In a recent interview Ms. Kopple said she was inspired by "Salt of the Earth," the 1954 fact-based portrayal of striking miners in New Mexico. One measure of organized labor's progress since then is that while distribution of "Salt of the Earth" was initially blocked by the motion picture industry, both of Ms. Kopple's films won Oscars.
From the very beginning, "American Dream" suggests that times have changed. The film opens with reminders of the Reagan Administration's attacks on organized labor and gritty images of hogs being led to slaughter -- a metaphorical foreshadowing of the fate of hundreds of members of Local P-9 of the United Food and Commercial Workers Union, the striking union at Hormel.
Hormel had been an industry pioneer in guaranteeing annual wages and offering a profit-sharing plan and had operated its Austin plant for 52 years without a strike. For these reasons, workers there seemed particularly hurt by the company's demand for wage concessions -- concessions that jeopardized their ability to fulfill their modest version of the American Dream.
In the film, grown men weep because they can no longer be breadwinners. The union hall is transformed into a social institution where members, united in desperation and self-rightousness, pool their financial and professional resources. It is a spirit born of a small town and of a proud heritage, a vitality that evokes the collective agony of "The Grapes of Wrath" and the leadership of labor icons like John L. Lewis. It is rare to find such energy displayed by unions today.
Miscalculations on the part of organized labor contributed to a climate in which President Reagan could crush the air traffic controllers' union after an illegal strike in 1981. This climate, combined with the consolidation of American industry and an increasingly troubled economy, has led many unions to scale down their agendas: job guarantees and better health benefits have become higher priorities; wage increases have been linked to improved productivity. Last month, the mere threat of hiring replacement workers brought an end to a strike at Caterpillar Inc. in Peoria, Ill.
Predictably, union activism is on the decline. Although a strike threat is often a more potent weapon than an actual walkout, strikes nevertheless represent one test of union resolve. Federal labor officials recorded 40 last year, fewer than one-tenth of the peak four decades ago. Today, about one in six members of America's workforce belongs to a union, compared to more than a third of the workforce back then.
Given the troubled state of labor and the economy, it may be no surprise that the situation at Hormel turned so messy. The rift between the Hormel local and the international union deepened when Mr. Guyette recruited Ray Rogers, a labor consultant whose New York-based Corporate Campaign Inc. had helped pressure the J. P. Stevens Company to sign its first union contract in 1980. Mr. Rogers's strategy is to transform negotiations into political campaigns that risk leaving reticent labor leaders far behind their rank-and-file. Mr. Rogers was arrested twice for advising the strikers.
With the strike by 1,500 workers in its 20th week, Hormel reopened the Austin plant. After 10 days, 75 striking workers returned, and hundreds of replacement workers were hired. Months later, the international seized control of the local and signed a contract under which the base wage rose to $10.70 by the third year -- one cent more than the company had been paying before the strike.
Not long after the settlement, Hormel leased the Austin plant's slaughterhouse operations to a company that offered a $6.50 hourly wage. Of nearly 500 strikers on a waiting list, Hormel says that all 292 who chose to return have been rehired at Austin, where the base wage is now $11.15.
Would P-9 have won with the international's support? Maybe not. But without it the local was doomed. "What the leadership did to undermine P-9 affected every major fight from Eastern to The Daily News to Caterpillar," Mr. Rogers said in a recent interview.
In "Salt of the Earth," a miner's wife declares: "I don't want to go down fighting. I want to win." By contrast, "American Dream" is pervaded by a sense of futility, albeit one that Ms. Kopple maintains was unintentional. She agrees that the strike galvanized the community and brought workers together as nothing had before. Still, its legacy is decidedly mixed.
The law under which Mr. Rogers was arrested has since been voided. Minnesota passed a ban on hiring permanent replacement workers. Mr. Guyette moved to New York, where he is chief organizer for a municipal employees' union. A woman who left town with her family while her father remained on the picket line -- "We're not abandoning him," she says in the film. "We're just taking our fight someplace else." -- has returned to Austin. Two brothers, R. J. and Ron Bergstrom, were pitted against each other by the strike -- "He won't be my brother if he crosses the line," R. J. says of Ron. But they began speaking to each other again when R. J. asked Ron to teach his daughter softball.
But bitterness lingers. So does a sense of betrayal, ambivalence about whom to blame and frustration over having the American Dream redefined by forces from afar.
"You can't win every fight, and that doesn't mean you've lost," Ms. Kopple maintains. Indeed, as a showing of her film ended the other day at the Quad Cinema, an angry young man yelled, "Boycott Hormel!" -- an empty gesture, perhaps, since the fight against Hormel is long over.
In the book "No Retreat, No Surrender," a study of the Austin strike, Dave Hage and Paul Klauda quote a former official of the international union as saying this about a failed negotiating session: "We were sleeping with the same whore, but we were having different dreams." For organized labor, Ms. Kopple's film suggests a rude awakening from the American Dream rather than its realization.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 3; Column 1; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 1319 words

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Motels Turn Their Attention to Security

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE

 BODY:
SPURRED partly by well-publicized negligence settlements against Motel 6 in the last year, safety gets increased attention in motels these days. When I stayed in a Holiday Inn last month in Columbia, Mo., I got a plastic card with a magnetic strip -- like the ones in high-priced downtown hotels -- to open an electronic lock on my room door, instead of the metal key for a tumbler lock. Increasingly these electronic locks, which may cost $250 to install, are found in budget places. The reason is that a metal key often has a room number on it and is easy for a criminal to copy or keep for theft later. A Holiday Inn spokeswoman said that the organization "highly recommended" that hotels convert to the key card when they modernized, and that key card systems were required for all its new buildings. Because franchise holders are not required to report on this recommendation, the organization does not know how many have converted.
 
Lock Systems Crucial
 A motel's system for locks is crucial to guest security. Ray Ellis, head of risk management for the American Hotel and Motel Association, estimates that break-ins are reduced 75 to 80 percent when electronic locks are used. 
 Mr. Ellis of the association cited the actions of some big chains on the concerns. One, the Budgetel chain, is shifting to a key card system over three years for its 89 motels in 23 states in the Eastern half of the country and is halfway through this $3 million project, according to Dale Nichols, vice president of marketing.
The Motel 6 chain has undertaken an $8 million overhaul of its security in 668 motels, retraining all the employees in the process, although it is not shifting from metal keys. The Super 8 chain, with 890 motels, also keeping its metal keys, is instituting tighter key inventory, requiring that a motel replace the lock if a key is missing and redo the entire motel if a master key disappears.
Part of the increase in security consciousness involves the increasing number of women traveling by themselves: industry research shows that 39 percent of business travelers last year were women; in 1970, the figure was 1 percent.
Another factor is the economic pinch, which causes travelers to pick less expensive places. And, in the words of Robert C. Hazard Jr., chairman of Choice Hotels, a group that encompasses several budget chains, including Sleep Inns in the $35 or $36 bracket. "As the price of the room goes down, the guest's concern for safety and security goes up."
 
Negligence Suits
 A more abrupt spur to nationwide assessment of motel security was a pair of negligence lawsuits against Motel 6 that brought big damage payments. One suit, by a woman who was raped and robbed of her photographic equipment at a motel operated by the chain in Fort Worth brought a settlement worth $10 million last June. The other suit, also involving rape, was settled in March, but this agreement specified that the details of the case would not be made public.
Last summer, after the first settlement, The Wall Street Journal carried an article on the issue of security at budget motels, with copious quotes from witnesses at the trial. The negative publicity led to a closed meeting of many motel-chain officers at the American Hotel and Motel Association, setting off the current cycle of reassessment and change. "We've always been very security conscious," said Mr. Nichols of Budgetel, "but when something like that happens, everybody runs back quick to look at what they're doing."
Anthony Marshall, dean of the School of Hospitality Management at Florida International University in Miami, said heightened concerns should affect hotels and motels at all price levels since, in his experience, neither high price nor brand name was a foolproof guarantee security.
Motel 6, which operates all its 568 motels rather than franchising, has spent six months assessing its security rules. Five years ago, it embarked on installation of deadbolts and peepholes. After the reassessment, according to Hugh Thrasher, executive vice president, the chain went to work to meet the "new expectations" of the public on security.
The Motel 6 identification and numbers have been taken off room keys, in favor of a code and it is now required that a new cylinder be installed if a key is lost. Lighting in parking lots has been surveyed and the chain now requires a certain level of brightness in the dimmest part of the lot. The chain has codified the duties of security guards, where they are employed, and has provided two-way radios to every motel to connect with security guards.
Under a new policy, guests under 18 years of age are no longer allowed to register, and some identification, like a credit card, is required for everyone even though 60 percent of Motel 6 guests pay cash. Mr. Thrasher said he expected that since everyone would be "carded," no one would feel discriminated against, and would welcome the added measure of security. The chain has also put up for sale, and does not advertise, six old downtown motels that are on bypassed highways because they no longer serve a traveling public. The two negligence cases did not involve any of these six, according to the company. Maintaining these security changes and paying higher insurance premiums and wages for additional personnel are expected to cost Motel 6 $3 million a year. Motel 6 charges $24.95 for a single in most places.
 
Credit Card as Key
 The 19 Sleep Inns, all new, have a sophisticated key system: the customer's credit card opens the door to the motel and to the room, creating a record for the office of all the times the door is opened.
Like Motel 6, many motels continue to use metal keys because of the high cost of card systems. But all of them are also tightening up on key control because, as Mr. Ellis points out, if there is a security negligence suit at a motel with a key and knob lock, the motel is going to lose. "For a while," he said, "when I looked at the database, I thought that security problems were stabilizing, but then we realized it was an artificial indication because motels that still used keys were settling privately, before court, in assault cases." He said that in 1962 only one suit based on a break-in cost a company more than $1 million. In 1986, for example, 500 suits cost more than $1 million.
Microtel, a chain with seven motels in New York, Ohio and Kentucky, has made security one of its big selling points although it uses metal keys. All doors into the hallway are locked 24 hours a day, except for the one that passes the desk. The outside doors open with the room key. If a key disappears, the lock is replaced. This is carried out by on-site managers, and no locksmith need be called, according to a spokesman.
 
 
New Candor
 Both Motel 6 and Budgetel have prepared "security tip" sheets to be placed in each room, and they have also sought publicity for projects to enhance security.
This candor about a sensitive topic represents a turnaround that will help travelers in the long run because they will be aware of what they should get. For example, motels without door peepholes are unsafe because locks are to no avail if a guest opens the door in ignorance. A room phone is a good defense from intruders and disturbances in the hall, but it should be tested to be sure it works. A deadbolt is essential, and a metal flip loop on a solid door is better than a chain on a hollow door.
But Mr. Ellis of the motel association reported that most smaller motels were reluctant to give guests printed information about fire safety or checking out room security lest the guests fear they were in an unsafe place. To meet this problem, the association itself will take the onus and is preparing a safety sheet, closely modeled on the Motel 6 version, to be used by all member companies. The sheet should be distributed by June or July.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 21; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk
