HEADLINE: TV VIEW;
Here's One Loser People Really Look Up To

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir

 BODY:
Meet George Costanza, Lord of the Losers and Jerry Seinfeld's best friend on NBC's "Seinfeld."
Behold his self-esteem: "No one's a bigger idiot than me." 
 . . . his philosophy of power: "Once in my life, I'd like the upper hand. I have no hand. No hand at all. How do I get the hand?"
. . . his sexual naivete: "Lesbian wedding. How do they work out the bride and groom on that? What do they do, flip a coin?"
. . . his paternal instincts: "I'd like to have a kid. Of course, you've got to have a date first."
George Costanza is situation comedy's Job, for whom life is one continuous push into a steaming bowl of soup. He is so incompetent he can't move cars from one side of the street to the other without a crash. His social acumen is such that he wears a wedding band to entice single women. His paranormal abilities foretold only that he would be bald.
George may be a loser, but "Seinfeld" is not. Last week, NBC announced that the quirky sitcom will keep its Wednesday slot (at 9 P.M.) on the fall schedule. The show has a distinctly urban appeal, striking a chord with those who empathize with four New Yorkers muddling their way through inanities of urban life. "Seinfeld" has proved popular with a hip audience of 18- to-34-year-olds (it ranked 20th with this age group in the ratings). NBC has run two episodes back-to-back on several occasions. And, to give "Seinfeld" a head start this fall, the program's new season will begin in August after Olympics coverage is over. (In the meantime summer reruns will resume June 24.)
The show's popularity has elevated Jerry Seinfeld to the top echelon of comedians. He recently took his act to Carnegie Hall and to the Kennedy Center in Washington, and he was host of NBC's "Saturday Night Live" and appeared on the cover of GQ magazine.
But his sitcom friend George, who is played by Jason Alexander, is on no such path. What is there to say about a short, chunky, jobless misfit in his 30's with dinosaur sheets on his bed who gets arrested for urinating in a shopping mall garage and who wonders why baseball teams don't get wiped out in plane crashes?
George is not merely a sitcom loser or simply a quantum leap beyond other TV unfortunates like Barney Fife of "The Andy Griffith Show," Mel Cooley of "The Dick Van Dyke Show" or Cliff Clavin of "Cheers." He is the shlimazl who stirs the "Seinfeld" drink, the downtrodden super neurotic who suffers the worst misfortunes of the show's four single, fretful characters.
"George is the catalyst for the shenanigans," said Mr. Alexander, who won a Tony Award in 1989 for his performance in "Jerome Robbins's Broadway." "He puts himself out there more than the other characters. George's fatal flaw is that he tries to be everything for everyone and always winds up spreading himself too thin, and that's when he gets his head cut off. It's not a terrible trait, just a tragic flaw. But I don't see him as a loser."
Because George is the show's hod carrier of angst, he is the easiest character to identify with. Seinfeld, as himself, is a too-neat, too-successful comic in pressed jeans who is lucky enough to have his car stolen and returned Simonized with the wheels aligned. Kramer, Seinfeld's next-door neighbor with the Erasherhead hairdo, is too bizarre and mysterious to be a central character. Elaine, Seinfeld's ex-girlfriend, is a one-of-the-guys woman who has her neuroses but too often is too normal.
Informal conversations with "Seinfeld" watchers confirm that they feel a kinship with George -- even if they don't want to publicly admit it. Said Bart D., a young advertising copywriter: "When George was set up on a blind date by Jerry and Elaine and said in his first phone conversation with her things went so well that he threw away his notes, I said, 'Whoa! Somebody else does this?' "
Ralph O., a housewares salesman, also closely identifies with Costanza, the only palpable difference between the two being Ralph's successful career. Costanza has no career. One job as a reader in a publishing house ended when he had sex with a cleaning woman on his desk. Seinfeld calls him Biff Loman, after Willy Loman's unsuccessful son in "Death of a Salesman."
"A lot of people tell me I look like George," said Ralph. "What's close to me is being bald, short and never getting the girl. But I like that he's always scrapping and battling. He always loses. Please, God, make my results different."
What saves George from becoming a one-note shlep are little signs of opportunism and clever thought, as well as a core of basic goodness. He is a loyal friend who tries (not as hard as he could) to get a girlfriend and job and might succeed if only he didn't sleep 18 hours a day. And while he is a magnet for others' cruelties, he can't return fire. Mr. Alexander said that when the show's writers tried to make George too tough, audience reaction forced them to retreat.
"I make him someone who can laugh at his own foibles when he's in the thick of his troubles," said Mr. Alexander. "What makes him appealing is that he has a strong female side. Lots of his anxieties are feminine: How do I look? What impression do I make? Am I prepared?"
Mr. Alexander envies George, who was fashioned out of the life of Larry David, co-creator of "Seinfeld." "I envy that he states his opinions so firmly," the actor said. "George is not an equivocator. I can be. He may do an about-face, but it's as thorough as his first attempt."
For example, he tries to qualify for unemployment benefits by saying he was interviewed for a job by a fictitious latex maker. When that ploy fails, he offers to date his unemployment clerk's unattractive daughter. When she dumps him, he vows to bring Keith Hernandez, the former New York Met who befriended Seinfeld, to meet the clerk. Of course, that ploy fails, too.
While George's shlimazlhood may be secretly admired, it has not led to an outward display of affection for Mr. Alexander's portrayal. He said he gets perhaps 20 letters a month.
"The people who watch us tend to be very cool," he said. "They'll come over and say a line from a show. One time George was mistaken for another character on the show, a neo-Nazi. Someone yelled, 'Hey, O'Brien, you Nazi S.O.B.!' It's nice to be noticed, but I wondered what other people there who hadn't seen the show thought."

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
Some Welcome Fiddling With Landmarks

BYLINE: By Paul Goldberger

 BODY:
Two proposals to change the face of New York saw the light of day in the last couple of weeks, and they may or may not have something to do with each other. No, strike that. Actually, they have quite a bit to do with each other. Each plan is about giving the public what it wants, and about the realization by people in authority that what the public wants in architecture is not always what it has been given. And each in its own way holds out no small degree of hope for this beleaguered city.
The more striking of the two proposals -- and the one that seems almost too good to be true -- is the suggestion floated by Amtrak officials that the railroad abandon the present Penn Station, that wretched thing undeserving of the noble name it bears, and build a new train station within the shell of the old Post Office across Eighth Avenue, due to be largely vacated in 1993. Amtrak's spokesman even talked of the "marketability of architecture" as an aid to train travel. 
 Could this really happen? Did we ever think that the day would come when a railroad would admit that the quality of a train station might have some connection with the public's willingness to travel on trains? And that Amtrak might take it upon itself to liberate us from that ghastly place that combines the elegance of a subway station with the charm of an airport?
Pinch me, please; I'm obviously having an architectural dream. Such things don't happen, certainly not in New York. The demolition of Penn Station in the early 1960's was the greatest single act of architectural vandalism New York has ever seen -- the unconscionable destruction of one of the noblest buildings in American history. Designed by McKim, Mead & White, the old Pennsylvania Station was at once a stirring gateway to the city and an utterly brilliant work of engineering and urban planning. The same architects designed the post office across the street as a companion piece to the classical station, so there is poetic justice to this plan to place a new station behind the great colonnade of the post office: history's cruel slight to McKim, Mead & White reversed.
A lot could go wrong, of course. Amtrak could be unable to come up with the $100 million needed to turn the post office into a workable station (the tracks are already under it, making access easy; the problem is reworking the interior spaces). The design could turn out to be awful. But in a period of such miracles as Donald Trump's abandonment of his Trump City scheme and the United States Supreme Court's decision to let stand the prohibition against erecting a skyscraper beside St. Bartholomew's Church on Park Avenue, I would prefer to think in terms of the glory of the possible.
If the Penn Station proposal would fiddle with one landmark to evoke another, the Sony Corporation's plan for the A.T.& T. building on Madison Avenue fiddles with a landmark to bring it closer to its ideal self. At least that's the goal of this scheme, which would dramatically change the way the public perceives this tower, which fills the block front between 55th and 56th Streets.
A quick bit of history. The pediment-topped A.T.& T. Building -- celebrated or notorious, depending on your point of view, as the "Chippendale skycraper" -- was designed by Philip Johnson and John Burgee in 1978. Surely New York's most widely known ex-
ample of post-modern architecture, it has been far more effective as a piece of architectural proselytizing than as headquarters for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which was broken up by Government decree before the building was finished in 1984.
Company executives made no secret of the fact that they found the structure's haughty classicism at odds with the new, high-tech image they sought for the post-breakup A.T.& T. But they held on to the building until last year, when they leased it to Sony USA, a corporation not without a high-tech image of its own -- but with an even more determined eagerness to house itself in a structure with a high architectural profile.
For all its significance as the first important post-modern corporate skyscraper, the A.T.& T. Building has always been more successful as a symbol than as an actual building. The problem is less the building's bizarre top, which is dowdy at worst, than its heavy-handed bottom, which aspires to monumental civic grandeur but doesn't really work. When the design was announced, the public space around the base -- set within open, 60-foot-high, vaulted arcades with columns of pink granite -- seemed just the thing for a city crying out for a nobler public realm. But once built, these spaces turned out to be noisy, windy and dark. Their elegance was too self-conscious to offset the cold formality that pervades the building; the grandiose architecture rolls over the space and quashes it.
No wonder usage of this public space has been sparse, and most people in this neighborhood with a few moments to spare have ended up in the glass-enclosed atrium of the I.B.M. Building next door instead. Sony, determined both to put its own mark on the building and to fix what was broken, hired the architects Charles Gwathmey and Robert Siegel to renovate the structure. They in turn enlisted Philip Johnson as a consultant, to give the project the proper pedigree. The three architects produced a scheme whereby the open arcades would be enclosed in glass and turned into elegant Madison Avenue shops. To make up for some of the loss of public space, the secondary public space in the building, the block-long glass-roofed arcade behind the tower, would be upgraded and expanded.
From a purely esthetic point of view, the design -- which will require the approval of the City Planning Commission -- is unquestionably an improvement. The tall openings in the Madison Avenue facade would not be changed but would be filled in with windows of a design consistent with those used elsewhere in the building. Functionally, the plan makes sense, too: a solid facade with storefronts is better on Madison Avenue than the present open facade broken up by columns. And public space belongs off the avenue, in the glass-roofed arcade, which even now is a far more successful space than the one in front.
But although the proposal would serve the public better in actuality, as a symbol it is more than a bit disquieting. If we measure by square footage, the public is forfeiting open space to private retail uses. But are we really losing overall? Somewhere there are people who like the A.T.& T. space as it is, but I doubt there are many. I would trade 18,947 feet of fair-to-middling space, which is what the building now has, for 10,220 feet of inviting and usable space any day. And if this important work of architecture ends up with an improved look in the bargain, so much the better.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 2271 words

HEADLINE: For Troubled Co-ops, the Workout Rx

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
THREE years after sponsor defaults began undermining the financial health of hundreds of New York City's converted co-ops and condominiums, the pace of new defaults has slowed considerably and many troubled buildings are working their way back to stability.
Last June, the New York State Attorney General's office said that sponsors had defaulted on maintenance payments and carrying charges in about 400 co-ops and condominiums, or about 10 percent of the 4,000 buildings converted since 1980. A year later, the number of troubled buildings remains at 400. 
 "We are still seeing sponsors default," said Frederick K. Mehlman, the deputy attorney general who as of May 15 resigned as head of the Real Estate Financing Bureau, which enforces the conversion laws. "But at the same time the number of troubled buildings is being balanced out by buildings where successful workouts have taken them off our list. There will still be some co-ops that will fail, but the worst may be behind us."
Nevertheless, the turn in the tide on sponsor defaults has left a legacy of difficulties that is likely to persist for several years. Most mortgage lenders continue to refuse to renew underlying mortgages or to make loans to apartment buyers in buildings where sponsors have defaulted or where they still own a majority of the apartments.
Board members describe desperate last-minute searches for refinancing when their buildings' loans are due and budget cuts that force them to reduce staffs and delay necessary repairs. Banks' reluctance to make new loans means that apartment owners who bought into conversions and now want to sell cannot move and retrieve their investments even when they find willing buyers.
YET the worst nightmare that haunted owners in troubled buildings, a possible replay of the widespread co-op failures of the 1930's, has not occured and seems increasingly unlikely. Only two small buildings have been seized by lenders and converted back into rentals, with apartment buyers losing their investments.
One reason the picture is improving, Mr. Mehlman said, is that financial-disclosure statements required of most sponsors by his office allow the agency to identify potential problems earlier. Another is the willingness of lenders, sponsors and boards to come to the table for workouts.
"It is a relief to have moved beyond the cloud we were under," said Peggy Segal, president of a group that represented most of the shareholders in a co-op at 114 East 84th Street that negotiated a deal with the defaulting sponsor of its conversion plan. "We are now in better shape than ever before."
The corporation took back 17 sponsor-owned units in exchange for forgiving more than $250,000 in maintenance arrears. Last month, the nine apartments not sold to their occupants or other shareholders were auctioned at prices that ranged from an average of $27,000 for the occupied units to $321,000 for a seven-room apartment that will be delivered vacant.
Paulette Bonanno, vice president of the National Cooperative Bank, said the policies of her institution, like those of other mortgage lenders that do not keep loans on their own books but sell them on the secondary market, are largely dictated by the requirements of the second-market buyers.
"The risk issue for lenders is tied directly to sponsor involvement," said Ms. Bonanno. "Reducing risks of the lender, by reducing investor participation, is critical for these buildings."
The National Cooperative Bank, which offers only underlying co-op mortgages in New York City, will not write mortgages for buildings in which more than 30 to 35 of percent of shares are held by the sponsors or investors.
Mark T. Simpson, director of mortgage underwriting standards for the Federal National Mortgage Association, a major second market buyer, said its lending policy on individual co-op loans requires that 80 percent of the shares in a co-op be owned by resident shareholders.
"We will grant variances in some cases," he said. "The key is that projects with rent-regulated tenants cannot depend on subsidies from sponsors, but must be buildings where the maintenance is covered by the rents."
Maryann Rothman, executive director of the Council of New York Cooperatives, who has met with some lenders to discuss the situation, is hopeful that they will become more flexible in their judgment of which buildings qualify for loans.
"Eventually, there will have to be some give," said Ms. Rothman. "I think we will see lenders that will be willing to distinguish between buildings that are sound but have a high percentage of sponsor-owned apartments, and the few that are not so healthy. It is in their best interest to find ways to make the distinction."
Meanwhile, the conversion of rental buildings into co-ops or condominiums has slowed dramatically. According to the Attorney General's office, the peak year for conversions was 1987, when the office accepted 556 co-op and condominium plans for filing. Last year the number dropped to 127 and so far this year 23 plans have been submitted, but none has been declared effective.
The vast majority of converted co-ops and condominiums, Mr. Mehlman said, remain sound investments. And he characterized as "questionable" the plans filed for the two failed conversions that have reverted to rentals. Those plans never should have taken effect, he said.
The Depression years saw scores of co-ops, including some on Park and Fifth Avenues and Sutton Place, converted to rental buildings after shareholders, unable to support operating losses, walked away from their investments.
Until 1989, the possibility of sponsor defaults caused little concern for lenders or buyers in the market for converted apartments. The notion of defaults was almost unheard of, even in buildings where sponsors kept a high percentage of the shares. As long as sales were strong, most sponsors could count on profits from those transactions to cover the gap between what rent-regulated tenants paid in rent and the maintenance payments due on their unsold apartments.
But seams in the system -- which permit the conversion of a building with as few as 15 percent of the units sold -- began to show when the demand for converted apartments dropped sharply in 1987 and 1988. With the stream of income from sales dried up, some sponsors fell into arrears. A broad crisis emerged as more and more buildings had to struggle to cover their bills with reduced income from maintenance fees.
In response to the situation, Attorney General Robert Abrams imposed new financial-disclosure rules on co-ops and condominiums early in 1990. All builders and sponsors holding more than 10 percent of the shares in their co-ops or condominiums were required to file annual reports providing details of their ownership positions and financial status.
Scrutiny of the disclosure documents showed most sponsors were overly optimistic in their projections of sales and were victims of the recession and the downturn in the real estate market. In some cases, evidence of fraud emerged.
Last month, the Attorney General's office brought its first criminal case against a defaulted sponsor, Vlas Stevens of Mount Vernon, who was charged with grand larceny and real estate fraud. The complaint asserts he willfully jeopardized the investments of the residents of Hudson View Estates in Yonkers, "looted" the building's reserve fund and collected enough in rents to cover his maintenance payments but did not make them.
Mr. Stevens's attorney, Stanley N. Kutcher, said his client pleaded not guilty. "This is not a criminal matter," said Mr. Kutcher, "but a real estate deal that went bad."
MR. MEHLMAN, who left for private law practice after heading the Real Estate Financing Bureau since 1985, said there will be more criminal cases against defaulted sponsors. His successor is Gary R. Connor, bureau chief for enforcement and litigation since 1984.
The Attorney General's office has a civil case pending against the Resolution Trust Corporation -- the Federal savings-and-loan bailout agency -- about the rights of rent-regulated tenants in buildings now in its hands. Seeking to sell unsold units in buildings it had taken as a result of bank failures, the R.T.C. tried to evict their occupants. The Attorney General has challenged those evictions as violations of the state's rent-regulation law.
The initial case concerned eight apartments in a building on East 57th Street in Manhattan. But the potential impact of the decision is broader now that more bank and thrift failures have put nearly 1,000 occupied units under R.T.C. control.
The consensus among bankers, lawyers and others involved with co-ops and condominiums in distress is that, for now, workouts are the best hope for financial recovery.
These deals can take many forms. In many instances, the lender restructures the mortgage by lowering the interest rate, stretching out the payment period or letting the co-op make interest-only payments for a period. In other cases the co-op is given control of the unsold units by either the lender, if there has been a foreclosure, or the sponsor. When this arrangement is part of a workout plan, the units often are reoffered for sale to their occupants at rock-bottom prices.
An ongoing effort to unravel the tangled finances of a 10-unit co-op on West 103d Street in Manhattan shows how delicate these negotiations can be. With assistance from the Attorney General's office, the four resident owners are trying to work out a solution.
IF the plan the agency has proposed holds up, it will put six unsold units, a $69,492 cash payment and back maintenance from defaulted sponsors' investors in the hands of the corporation. The co-op would take control of the apartments -- two of which are now empty and could be sold or rented -- and gain control of the corporation's business.
But the resident owners are wary.
"We want to work out this situation," said Susan Mancuso, one of the resident shareholders, "but we see potential problems in the settlement. If the deal goes through we inherit the complete liability of the sponsor, including a shortfall of almost $4,000 a month that is not covered by the rents. Given the state of the market, sales are unlikely. Who would buy an apartment with maintenances as high as ours?"
Ms. Mancuso said that the shareholders could not afford an increase in the maintenance charge, now more than $950 a month on their one-bedroom units. The other worry is the potential burden of assuming total responsibility for the $465,000 mortgage, privately financed, which comes due on Aug. 1.
"We think there were serious problems with the conversion plan," Ms. Mancuso said, "so we want some assurance that we won't be left holding the bag when the sponsors get off the hook."
A spokesman for the Attorney General said the agency could act only as a facilitator in the negotiations and not impose a settlement.
In many financially pressured buildings, the lenders holding loans taken by sponsors on their unsold shares foreclose, taking control of the collateralized units. Such foreclosures turned out to be boons for many buildings; they obliged the lenders to pick up the sponsors' portion of the maintenance.
Even when a bank steps in to cover a shortfall, problems often remain.
A CASE in point was the situation at the Kimberly, a 400 unit co-op conversion in Yonkers. According to a member of the board, in August 1990 Coronet Properties, the sponsor of the conversion plan there, stopped paying its share of the maintenance on the apartments it owned. Coronet put a second mortage on the building using unsold shares as collateral. Union Savings Bank of Patchogue, L.I., held the second mortgage and paid Coronet's share of the bills until it foreclosed earlier this month.
While Union Savings' contributions relieved the corporation of a short-term financial crisis, for the long term it left the building in limbo.
"Coronet's problems became our problems," said Amie Reinhertz, a member of the board of directors. "The taint of the sponsor's troubles and the bank's delay was very hard on owners because no one was able to sell because banks would not give mortgages for our building."
Ms. Reinhertz said that an additional worry for some owners is that their own mortgages are held by Coronet, which offered to finance inside purchases as a sales incentive. The board hopes the recent foreclosure by Union Savings will lead to fresh start.
"When Coronet moves out of the picture," she said, "we can start solving some of the problems here. Until then, things are sort of frozen."
Some feel a lasting solution to the risk of sponsor default can come only when the laws are changed to make it harder to convert a rental building into a co-op or condominium.
For more than five years, Attorney General Abrams has been urging legislators to amend the conversion laws to increase from the present 15 to 25 percent the percentage of apartments that must be sold for a noneviction conversion to take place. Measures passed by the State Assembly have stalled in the Senate.
Claire Shulman, Borough President of Queens, which has many troubled buildings, has been among those in New York City who have called for stiffer conversion requirements.
"We are still taking distress calls," said Andrew Kelman, an aide to Mrs. Shulman who has set up a task force to help troubled co-ops. "It may be that overall the picture is getting better, but we have not seen a significant diminution of the problem. There have to be changes in the laws."

HEADLINE: MUSIC;
Survey Finds Support for the Arts

BYLINE: By ROBERT SHERMAN

 BODY:
THE recession has taken its toll on the arts. Public and private donations are way down, and one organization after another has been forced to cut back operations. Many have been forced to shut down.
But there is a brighter side to the artistic picture, delivered in a nationwide survey conducted for the American Council for the Arts by Louis Harris and Associates and underwritten by Philip Morris Companies Inc. 
 The American people, the report found, do care about the arts, and in far greater numbers than one might have supposed. They attend concerts, support artistic training in the public schools and are even willing, up to a point, to pay higher taxes for government financing of arts programs. The telephone poll, conducted in February, surveyed 1,500 adults nationally. The sampling margin of error is plus or minus 3 percent.
"This survey has been conducted in the middle of what the vast majority of Americans feel is one of the deepest recessions that has gripped the country in some time" Mr. Harris said. "It is striking that all regions of the country, all strata of education, all races and all income levels support Federal funding of the arts. The results are clear-cut and decisive, the majorities are significantly high."
Despite the controversy swirling about the National Endowment for the Arts's support of specific artists and arts programs, the public vote on separating government financing from government control was also decisive, with nearly 80 percent of the sample opposed to artistic restrictions.
More than 90 percent of those who responded to the poll confirmed that the arts should be required as part of the public school curriculum; 6 of every 10 adults interviewed said that the arts are just as important to a youngster as math and science. And 8 of every 10 respondents maintained that in studying the arts, children could learn skills that would be useful in a job.
The Harris survey looked at music specifically and found that 28 percent of the respondents play a musical instrument; 17 percent sing in a choir or other vocal group, and 35 percent are involved with the dance (although that figure may be misleading since it includes aerobics). It also reported that 20 percent listen "frequently" to classical music, 21 percent attended four or more classical concerts last year, 9 percent are "frequent" purchasers of classical tapes or records, 24 percent have attended live opera or musical theater performances and 21 percent have attended live dance programs.
"We took the name 'Friends of Music' from the 'Gesellschaft der Musikfreunde,' started in Vienna by Beethoven and his pupil and patron Archduke Rudolf," said Ruth Steinkraus Cohen, the pianist who founded the Friends organization with two colleagues, the violist-conductor Frank Brieff and the composer-critic Artur Holde. "The idea in 1813 was to mingle composers, performers, patrons, presenters and audience together: before the performance to study, afterwards to enjoy conversation and refreshments. That is still our idea, which makes us unique among chamber music series."
As the Friends' 35th anniversary season comes to a close, it has continued to follow a distinguished path. On Wednesday evening at 8:15, the violist and arts consultant William Selden will give a lecture and ademonstration, "Listening to Fugues," at his home in Westport; the final concert of the season will be Saturday at 8:30 P.M. in the Unitarian Church, followed by refreshments. The performers, all from Connecticut, are Viviane Bertolami, a violinist and the director of the "Adventures in Music" series at the Burndy Library in Norwalk; Sadao Harada, a cellist in the Tokyo String Quartet, and David Korevaar, a pianist and founding member of the Hexagon Ensemble. They will present Trios of Dvorak and Tchaikovsky (227-3345 or 227-2253).

HEADLINE: Talking: Eviction;
Facing Up To Arrears In the Rent

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
AFTER being laid off and having problems getting unemployment compensation, a medical technician at St. Raphael's Hospital in New Haven found herself threatened with eviction from her $550-a-month apartment a few months ago.
Such tales are becoming common as the recession touches the lives of a growing number of people, many of whom never dreamed of facing such a predicament. And landlords, worried about cash flow, are taking action as fast as possible. 
 Housing Court in New York City is so backed up with eviction cases resulting from nonpayment of rent that lawyers say a legal eviction can now take six months.
"Only the permanent underclass used to have trouble meeting rent payments," said Glenn Falk, managing attorney of the housing unit at New Haven Legal Assistance, a federally funded legal-aid office that helped the technician. "Now we're hearing from all sorts of people."
Though it may seem at first that there is little tenants can do when their money runs out, they usually have more options than they realize. These include: working out a delayed payment plan to slowly make up the arrears, negotiating for a lower rent, temporarily tapping the funds being held as a security deposit, filing for bankruptcy to wipe out or lower the arrears, taking in a roommate, subletting to someone who can afford to pay or negotiating with the landlord for a transfer to a less costly unit.
Mr. Falk's office discovered a defect in the way the eviction papers had been served on the medical technician. This helped delay the case until her unemployment checks started coming in.
A landlord might be willing to strike a deal because it can cost more to replace than to work with a delinquent tenant, especially if the tenant is normally reliable and likely to find another job soon.
"The landlord has to consider the loss of rental income while he finds someone else," said Robert A. Jacobs, a Manhattan lawyer. "He has to paint and fix up and pay a broker's commission." The only exception would be a rent-regulated apartment where a vacancy would permit a rent increase.
Moreover, even if the landlord decides to get rid of the delinquent tenant he might be stuck with that person -- and no rent coming in -- for six months until the case could be heard. If the tenant chose to contest the eviction, the case could drag on even longer.
A reason for the tenant to negotiate is that just ignoring dunning notices could make it hard to be accepted elsewhere. "Once you get a bad reputation you could find it hard to get another landlord to take you," said Mr. Falk.
Also, a callous disregard for a landlord tends to anger a judge. Ignoring the court papers also keeps tenants from offering evidence in their own defense.
The other common mistake, said Mr. Falk, is to panic and run away after getting the first notice from the court. Instead, the troubled tenant should seek advice from the clerk of the court (named in the papers), a legal aid office or a private lawyer.
It's normally best to begin negotiations before arrears pile up to a point where the landlord is enraged and eviction seems inevitable. The strategy selected should be based on whether the financial crisis is likely to be temporary or long-lasting.
If the cash crisis is temporary -- say there was a layoff and the tenant now has another job -- it is worth trying to reach a settlement.
Walter Jennings, a Manhattan lawyer who has been representing tenants for 21 years, favors starting with an informal offer to set up a plan that permits the arrears to be paid off gradually. If the tenant would have great difficulty paying off the arrears, Mr. Jennings recommends seeking relief from the city's One Shot Deal program.
Available since 1989 from the New York City Department of Social Services, it will -- under certain circumstances -- provide tenants facing eviction for nonpayment of the rent with a grant to cover arrears. Over 3,000 families have received such grants.
OTHER municipalities and states have similar grant programs. In New Haven, for example, it is called the Rent Bank (details can be obtained from any local social service or legal-aid agency). Each case is judged individually, with grants most often approved when the tenant would otherwise lose the apartment, has no other assets but now has a job and an income to meet current and future rent obligations.
Mr. Jennings recently represented a divorced woman who had been diverting rent money to cover medical expenses for her teen-age daughter. A year later, with eviction inevitable, Mr. Jennings said he was able to get $7,500 towards the arrears paid by the One Shot Deal program because the woman had a steady job as a receptionist and her ex-husband agreed to pay the daughter's expenses.
If a grant or compromise cannot be obtained and the landlord refuses to consider a payment plan, a third option would be to file for personal bankruptcy. Doing so should temporarily halt a pending eviction, said Mr. Jennings, and force the landlord to accept a compromise settlement -- say, 30 percent of of the arrears.
But it will not eliminate the tenant's obligation to pay ongoing rent. Lowering that figure can be done, said Mr. Jennings, only when it is clear that comparable rents have declined.
John Griffin, president of Griffin Realty, a Manhattan company that manages and rents market-rate apartments, said he has worked out deals in which the security deposit is temporarily used to cover missing rent. But a landlord will allow that, he said, when the tenant is without income only temporarily and willeventually be able restore the deposit to its original level.
Another way out is to take in a roommate. In New York State a single tenant has an automatic right to bring in another individual under the state's 1983 Roommate Law. In other states it will depend on local law and the terms of the current lease. Rights to temporarily sublease an apartment also are based on local law and lease terms.
Yet a further way out would be to find a cheaper apartment. But before rushing to look elsewhere the tenant should ask the landlord if he has a less expensive apartment in the same or a nearby building, said Mr. Jacobs. This could prevent the loss of the deposit money that often accompanies a broken lease.
If the apartment is rent regulated and the rent is low, the tenant might even get the landlord to cover the moving costs, said Mr. Jacobs, because a vacancy in such an apartment can entitle an owner to a substantial rent increase."

HEADLINE: Streetscapes: The Fred R. French Building;
Refurbishing 'Mesopatamia'

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY

 BODY:
THE highly colored terra cotta of the 1927 Fred F. French Building at 551 Fifth Avenue, at 45th Street, has been wrapped in scaffolding for two years. This fall, as a $9 million facade restoration is completed, it will reappear. A fresh look at the building's ancient styling and skyscraper modernity should give anyone a start.
Fred Fillmore French, developer of the building, began his real estate career in 1908. In 1921 he hit on the "French plan" to finance his development activity -- each project was sold as common stock to small investors. By avoiding traditional bank financing he was able to maximize both control and profits, a goal he furthered by organizing his own departments for architecture and property management. 
 By the mid-1920's French had built a dozen good-sized apartment houses this way. In 1925, he began the project bearing his name.
The 38-story building was unusual in many respects. According to "New York 1930," by Robert A.M. Stern, Gregory Gilmartin and Thomas Mellins, it was an early example of the new rectangular skyscraper at a time when towers were usually square. This allowed more flexible layouts and opened up more sites for development.
Its style, according to French's house architect, H. Douglas Ives, is "Mesopotamian," Working with John Sloan as consulting architect, Ives produced a tall slab, rather ungainly, but with dazzling decoration. At the lobby, a coffered bronze portal with rams' heads and other Near Eastern elements leads to brilliant ceiling murals in archaic styles and what is probably the only Assyrian Revival mailbox in New York City.
On the exterior, the middle of the tower is trimmed in bands of bright terra cotta, red, black and other colors. At the top is surely one of New York's signature architectural elements: Facing north and south are giant, brilliantly colored faience panels with sunburst designs. According to Ives, they are sunrises indicating progress and the flanking, Assyrian-style griffins represent integrity and watchfulness.
Panels on the east and west facades carry heads of Mercury "spreading the message of the French plan," according to Ives. They are high above street level but, once spotted, they make the building hard to forget.
George S. Chappell, architectural critic of The New Yorker, ignored the color and styling and criticized the "rows of dreary factory windows," adding: "Can't the Fifth Avenue Association do something about this?" The 1939 "W.P.A. Guide to New York City" called the faience work "of questionable taste."
As he moved his real estate firm into 551 Fifth Avenue, French was also moving ahead with his giant Tudor City complex and would assemble his employees every morning for inspirational sales talks. Much of his Tudor-style office still survives on the 12th and 13th floors.
In 1986, the Landmarks Preservation Commission designated the building a landmark a year after it was bought by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. The facade restoration began in 1990 and is being supervised by Wiss, Janney, Elstner Associates.
If the large tile panels look like small bursts of color from afar, they are cascades close up. Glazes of plum, orange, yellow, gold, tropical green and other colors cover "some of the biggest pieces of terra cotta I've ever seen in my life, some four feet long," says Diane Kaese, senior architect on the job.
SHE believes French paid close attention to the economics of building. He used limestone sills throughout the facade, except where setbacks rendered them invisible from the street, where he used less expensive precast concrete.
The large faience panels are in excellent shape; it is the terra cotta banding in other locations that has required massive replacement, because it is next to steel shelf angles. These were designed without flashing to protect them from water and they have rusted and expanded, cracking the terra cotta. Kimball Beasley, an engineer with the firm, says the lack of such a detail is common in the period. "Architects just didn't realize that some water would inevitably get inside a building," he said, and they supposed interior steel work required little protection.
The work is to be completed and the scaffolding removed in September, when the rich sunbursts will shine out again. Until then, there is an additional reward for the few fortunate enough to prowl the temporary boards around the top. The limestone coping at this level was not as highly controlled for uniformity. There are a dozen or more pieces that would never be used at street level. They are "spoiled" by a riot of fossilized plant life, shells and marine animals, elements of an ancient sea floor brought to the top of this skyscraper inspired by antiquity.

HEADLINE: Contest Introduces Students to Wall Street Risks

BYLINE: By TOM TOOLEN

 BODY:
THE red brick elementary school in East Orange may seem an unlikely place to run across the trappings of Wall Street, but for 10 weeks more than 200 students at the school, the Jackson Academy, were engaged in managing stock portfolios worth hundreds of thousands of dollars.
Each of the participating classes received a theoretical $100,000 to invest in any stock listed on the New York, American or NASDAQ stock exchanges. And at the end of April, their results were compared with those chalked up by some 20,000 students across the state -- all players in a competition called the Stock Market Game. 
 A total of 1,900 New Jersey teams, from fourth grade through college, participated in the game, including 7,000 high school students and several hundred college students. Nationwide, 400,000 students took part. The game has been sponsored in the state for seven years by the New Jersey Council on Economic Education, which is associated with the New York-based Securities Industries Association.
"The game really helps the students gain insights into math and logic," said Gladys Calhoun, principal of the Jackson Academy, "as well as giving them an insight into how the American economic system works. Many of the students did not know what a stock was before they started playing the game."
 
First Place, for a While
 Though the entire student body of the Jackson Academy participated in the Stock Market Game for the 10 weeks that ended in the last week of April, the clear stars at the school were in Adele Braswell's fourth-grade class.
For two golden weeks in March, the 22 fourth graders in Ms. Braswell's class were in first place among all fourth graders in the state. A banner quickly went up in their classroom, and it read: "This is the home of the Wall Street whiz kids."
"The students couldn't wait to get to school to see how their stock was doing," Ms. Braswell said.
At the start of the competition, the students chose only one stock, CBS Inc. "They liked watching the Olympics and some of the children's shows on CBS, so they went with their hearts," Ms. Braswell said.
It worked for a while. The CBS stock they bought at $141 a share jumped to $161. Then the students decided to get out of CBS, figuring that it had gone as high as it was going to, and bought I.B.M. shares.
"If we had held it a bit longer, it would have been better because eventually CBS climbed into the 180's," said Ms. Braswell, a former fashion editor who has been teaching for three years. The class ended up in 23d place in the state.
 
Effect on Self-Esteem
 Ms. Braswell said the game had worked wonders with the students' self-esteem. "The children became winners," she said, "and they came to school excited about what they were doing as they looked at the financial pages of the paper to see where their stock was. It also opened up the possibility of a new world, Wall Street."
Mrs. Calhoun, the principal, said the contest fitted perfectly with the goals of the school. "We tell the students that they can do anything and accomplish anything if they keep trying," said Mrs. Calhoun, who has taught for 24 years in the East Orange school system.
"We know that there is often trouble outside our doors, but when the students walk into this building in the morning, we shut all that out," she said. "The only aim here is to learn and achieve."
The Wall Street game has changed some plans among Ms. Braswell's students. "I want to be a stockbroker when I grow up," said Tatteera Sampson, 10, as she bounded to her feet to answer a question.
Did she know about stockbrokers before the game? "Well, no, not really, but it was fun," she said, a smile breaking across her face. "Besides, you can make money playing this game."
 
Doing 'Something Better'
 But Renai Field, 11, has resisted Wall Street's lure. "I want to be a teacher like Ms. Braswell," Renai said. "I like the game, but Ms. Braswell does something better. She helps us."
Contestants were divided into four categories based on age. In the category for grades four to six, the winner was the Memorial School of Union Beach, which made $128,551 on its paper portfolio. The Jackson Academy's 23d-place finish was accomplished with a figure of $103,062.
The competition for grades seven to nine was won by students from the Yayneh Academy of Paramus with a portfolio of $155,011.
The largest portfolio and the grand prize winner was in the high school category, where a two-student team from Northern Valley Regional High School in Old Tappan ended up with $168,928.
The winners, Scott Soussa and Brian Havbas, both of Old Tappan and both juniors, divided their $100,000 between two stocks, Walt Disney Company and Digital Equipment Corporation. After some buying and selling, they took on a major stake, 10,000 in shares, in College Bound, an educational testing company.
 
'Definitely a Big Break'
 Then they heard on a television program that College Bound was in trouble. They sold their shares at $18, and the stock plummeted to $8.
"It was definitely a big break," Brian Havbas said. Both youths said they were considering a career on Wall Street.
The college category was won by students from Gloucester County Community College with a portfolio of $107,565.
In the Stock Market Game, said Dr. Robert L. Stout, president of the New Jersey Commission on Economic Education, "the students also learn communication skills and most importantly learn the value and limitations of money."

HEADLINE: A New Strategy For Luring Vacationers

BYLINE: By HELEN PIKE

 BODY:
EUGENE DILBECK, the state's travel and tourism director, stood before an easel in the interpretive center at Liberty State Park in Jersey City, describing for the benefit of the State Senate Budget and Appropriations Committee the national advertising campaign his office started this spring. Its slogan is "New Jersey: You Should See Us Now!"
The ads carry images of history, seafood, amusements, casinos and the outdoors, and they are part of a major new strategy to convince out-of-state travelers that New Jersey's image as a polluted, crime-ridden stepchild of a state is out of date. 
 A tall, ebullient 49-year-old with a pronounced Midwestern drawl, Mr. Dilbeck took his post two years ago as the first professional -- as opposed to political -- appointee to head the New Jersey Division of Travel and Tourism. He has presided over the division's first study of the travel and spending habits of vacationers to the state and over a strong move to unify a traditionally fragmented tourism industry.
But the Office of Legislative Services recommends trimming $2.6 million from Mr. Dilbeck's proposed fiscal 1993 advertising and promotion budget of $5.1 million. On May 13, Mr. Dilbeck was calling upon all his considerable selling skills to convince the appropriations committee that his $5.1 million ad budget proposal should remain intact.
It was not Mr. Dilbeck's first experience with the budget ax. The division's budget over all, which reached a high of $9 million in 1988, has been steadily cut back. Last year it dropped to $6.3 million, and his total proposed budget for 1993 is $6.2 million.
Mr. Dilbeck was showing an ad that featured a colorful blur of an amusement park ride and a headline, "New Jersey at 75 M.P.H.," when Senator John H. Ewing, Republican of Bedminster, interrupted. "Don't you think that ad gives the impression young people can go 75 miles an hour on our highways?" the Senator asked. Mr. Dilbeck hesitated, slightly thrown off balance, then responded, "I'm sure the Department of Public Safety would tell us if there is a correlation between our ads and speeding on the roadways." Senator Ewing shrugged, and Mr. Dilbeck continued.
Later, Senator Dick LaRossa, Republican of Ewing Township, spoke up. "Has anyone ever heard of Trenton, home to eight million people?" he asked, noting that the State House, subject of a multimillion-dollar restoration completed earlier this year, appeared nowhere in the ads.
"I assure you, Senator, next year we'll do that," Mr. Dilbeck said.
In his campaign to hold on to his budget, Mr. Dilbeck has the benefit of a new study commissioned by his office indicating that tourism plays a much larger role in the state's economy than previously believed. Estimates of annual tourism revenue had ranged from $10 billion to $13 billion, while the new figure for 1991 is $17.8 billion -- making tourism second in revenue to the pharmaceutical-chemical industry.
That was a 2.4 percent drop from 1990's revenue, but Mr. Dilbeck says this result was a tribute to the division's 1991 multimedia advertising campaign in light of the adverse effects that the Persian Gulf war and the severe recession had on travel.
Last year's $4.5 million campaign sought to raise the awareness level of the state's varied tourism offerings, with particular attention to weeklong travelers, who typically spend more money than day-trippers or vacationers visiting relatives.
 
Commissioned a Study
 Mr. Dilbeck also commissioned Longwoods International, a travel market research company in Toronto, to conduct a comprehensive study of the state's tourism potential and tourism industry. Interviews were conducted with focus groups in Toronto, Boston, Atlanta, Dallas and Chicago. The groups, said William Siegel, president of Longwoods, were made up of people "who had had some kind of experience in New Jersey and those who wouldn't reject it outright."
"The real surprise," Mr. Siegel said, "was that people do respond positively when they find out what New Jersey has to offer."
An even more dramatic surprise was the 264 percent rise in requests for travel literature in 1991 over 1990 in response to the new advertising. "I've never seen this kind of response before," said Mr. Siegel, who has been studying travel and tourism trends since 1985.
"New Jersey was being passed by because it never marketed itself as a touring destination," Mr. Siegel said. He added that few states seriously market their tourism or even have professionals in the job.
Mr. Dilbeck, who hails from Cassville, Mo., was hired by Gov. Jim Florio after 15 years in the industry, including stints in Texas and Oklahoma. A three-day car trip from the Delaware River area through Princeton to Cape May and the Wildwoods convinced him there was more to New Jersey than negative headlines.
 
'A Lot Is Going On'
 "A lot is going on in New Jersey," said Mr. Dilbeck, who talks enthusiastically of the state's mountain ranges and recreational opportunities, its historic sites and culture. "I never had the opportunity to sell beaches and skiing at the same time," he said about the chance to do year-round promotions.
Tourism in New Jersey has historically been viewed as a summer-only shore-area industry. Mr. Dilbeck has sought to change that view. "Marketing a destination is very scientific," he said. "Research gives us perspectives."
The Longwoods study found that certain areas promoted themselves as single destinations, divorced from any identity with the rest of the state. The result, Mr. Dilbeck said, is that travelers have little awareness of what exists beyond any of the major highways they use to get to those destinations.
Atlantic City, for example, had been promoting only its casinos and entertainment, primarily to bus tours that never detoured from the Garden State Parkway. This kind of narrow focus had left the public with the perception that the city was "small, kind of seedy and not very safe" when compared with other gaming spots in the country.
"Even Atlantic City had a lot to offer in the way of charm and history when it was presented differently," Mr. Siegel said.
 
Change Seen in Promotion
 Paula Williams, operator of the Whistling Swan Inn, a bed-and-breakfast in Stanhope, said, "Tourism used to be every person for himself." Now, she said, all the regions are more equally promoted. Mr. Dilbeck, she said, has brought planning, documentation, objectives and specific business applications to the state's tourism industry.
"The political appointees were sincere, wanting to do the right thing, but they had no specific plans," she added. "We never came together before."
Mr. Dilbeck has established committees representing a cross section of the tourism industry: airlines, convention centers, hotels and motels, restaurant associations and bed-and-breakfast inns.
The travel and tourism director has also created groups whose members are drawn from the ranks of both tourism and state government. Representatives from the Department of Transportation monitor the state's traffic infrastructure, while representatives of the Department of Environmental Protection and Energy monitor beach pollution.
 
Handling News on Beaches
 News of any instance of beach pollution, for example, has the net effect of keeping people away from the 127-mile shoreline, Mr. Dilbeck said, while only a quarter of a mile might be affected. "We have to get the word out that all the rest of the beaches are still open," he said.
Senator Joseph M. Kryillos Jr., Republican of Middletown Township and chairman of the State Senate Committee on Coastal Resources and Tourism, said of Mr. Dilbeck, "He can see our strengths and weaknesses from an outside perspective" and praised his "real understanding" of the state industry.
 
'He's a Tourist'
 Steve Richer, president of the Atlantic City Convention and Visitors Bureau, added that Mr. Dilbeck had another advantage:
"He's a tourist. He's an 'aw shucks' person from America's heartland. Golly, if he likes it, then others are bound to like it, too."
The Longwoods data showed that in 1991 travelers spent $5.5 billion on food, $4.4 billion on retail purchases, $2.5 billion on gambling and $1.8 billion on lodging.
Overnight visitors generated $10.2 billion in revenue, and day-trippers, $5.1 billion. Tourists spent more than $5.9 billion in Atlantic County last year, and $5.2 billion in the Gateway region, which includes the counties of Bergen, Essex, Hudson, Middlesex, Passaic and Union. The Delaware River region, including the counties of Burlington, Camden, Gloucester, Mercer and Salem, brought in $2 billion. And in the Skylands region, including Hunterdon, Morris, Somerset, Sussex and Warren Counties, the total was $1.6 billion.
The state collected $2.2 billion in taxes from the tourism industry last year and sustained a total of 353,000 jobs.

HEADLINE: Ye Olde Inferiority Complex

BYLINE: By ELISABETH GINSBURG

 BODY:
THERE are times when thoughts of New Jersey bring a tear to the eye -- times when trash fires spew forth enough airborne contaminants to cause widespread weeping on both sides of the Hudson. Or when mayors of various communities are under investigation for various forms of corruption. Or when headlines tell of the latest roundup of New Jersey-based mobsters or the State Health Department declares war on eggs "over easy."
A rich compost of negative images applied over three centuries has given rise to one of the state's hardiest crops, the collective inferiority complex. 
 Radio, television and movies have contributed to the problem by coming up with thousands of throwaway lines, but New Jerseyans themselves seem strangely compelled to assist in the process. The New Jersey joke thrives in part, said a Rutgers sociologist, Dr. Karen Cerulo, because "people who are insecure about themselves develop a self-deprecating humor."
Dr. Margaret Snyder, a clinical psychologist in Upper Montclair, agrees. Because the state is associated with so many negative images, she said, an insecure individual is not likely to live in New Jersey voluntarily. "People who are insecure are more concerned about addresses," she said.
Children whose parents praise their accomplishments are less likely to grow up to be the kind of adults who suffer from the New Jersey inferiority complex, Dr. Snyder said. But she added that the problem did not rank high on her patients' neurosis scale.
"The New Jersey inferiority complex is a pervasive attitude," she said, "but not a treatment issue."
The sense of collective inferiority may stem from the fact that New Jersey received insufficient nurturing as an infant. England, the mother country, paid much more attention to New Jersey's more boisterous siblings, New York and Pennsylvania. From 1703 until Lewis Morris became governor in 1738, New Jersey was even forced to share a governor with New York.
William Penn was the first public figure to rise to New Jersey's defense: "It is not right in any to despise or dispraise it." Unfortunately, the "despising and dispraising" continued.
Though many travelers found the state beautiful and inspiring, complaints about predatory mosquitoes and bad roads were numerous. Bad or not, the roads were well used.
 
Benjamin Franklin's Line
 Benjamin Franklin's frequently quoted aphorism -- that New Jersey is "a keg tapped at both ends" -- neatly sums up another major cause of the state's identity problem. Long before the New Jersey Turnpike smoothed the bumps out of travel, New Jersey was known primarily as a conduit between New York City and Philadelphia.
"In order for human beings to develop an identity, they must become separated from things outside themselves," Dr. Cerulo said. From pre-Revolutionary times, New Jerseyans have been hard pressed to establish the degree of separation needed to form that distinct identity.
Dr. Angus Gillespie, co-author of "Looking for America on the New Jersey Turnpike" (Rutgers University Press, 1989) and professor of American studies at Rutgers, says New Jersey's image has a lot to do with the behemoth across the Hudson.
"In the 19th century, Manhattanites looked down on Brooklyn," said Dr. Gillespie, who noted that Manhattan's censorious gaze began focusing on New Jersey at the turn of the century, around the time Brooklyn was incorporated into the City of New York.
 
Changes After World War II
 Dr. Cerulo thinks that commuters who live in New Jersey and work in New York are particularly susceptible to a feeling of inferiority because "they have to take so many jokes from co-workers."
The volume of New Jersey jokes increased exponentially after World War II when the suburbanization of northern New Jersey took place. The spurt in road building, including the completion of the turnpike, brought millions of additional nonresidents barreling through the state, seeing the ugliest, most blighted parts of the landscape rather than more bucolic vistas.
The poet Robert Burns wrote that it is a gift "to see ourselves as others see us." For New Jerseyans, such a gift may have dubious value.
Dr. Gillespie contrasts New Jersey with Connecticut, a state he says is similar in size, level of industrialization and infrastructure. In Connecticut, he said, many of the highways run through rolling countryside, whereas in New Jersey they go by tank farms. That explains why Connecticut has a pastoral New England image, he said, while New Jersey is viewed as a soulless expanse of rusting industry.
New Jersey joke fodder continued to pile up at an impressive rate in the 1960's when the Federal Government began investigating municipal corruption. In the 70's and early 80's, more unsavory images presented themselves as state and Federal officials began unearthing toxic dump sites.
 
Embracing the Negative
 If, as Dr. Cerulo suggests, the New Jersey joke is a result of insecurity, then New Jerseyans have some of the highest amounts of insecurity anywhere. "In a perverse way, New Jerseyans embrace the negative image," Dr. Gillespie said.
Residents of Buffalo may equate blizzard survival with machismo, but New Jerseyans have grafted an almost heroic collection of beliefs and attitudes onto their gritty industrial roots. In his book, the Rutgers educator writes of seeing T-shirts at Newark International Airport emblazoned with the slogan: "New Jersey -- Only the Tough Survive."
By the mid-1980's, New Jersey's image seemed to be emerging from decades of gloom. Bruce Springsteen, whose songs celebrated New Jersey's grittiness, was riding a mammoth wave of popularity, and the Meadowlands and the Garden State Arts Center gave the state its own focal points for entertainment and culture.
In late 1984, the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University conducted an extensive opinion poll, concluding that New Jerseyans "are beginning to identify more strongly with their home state and to take pride in New Jersey."
 
Fewer New Jersey Jokes
 And what of the 90's? This year, the Nets were in the playoffs for the first time since 1986. The Devils slapped the puck from New Jersey into the Stanley Cup playoffs. The New Jersey Symphony enjoyed a national prominence. And Eric Magnusson, manager of Rascal's Comedy Club in West Orange, said the comedians he saw were not spending much time on New Jersey jokes anymore.
Yet a smaller-scale Eagleton Institute poll released in July 1990 suggests that the state's residents have become somewhat less satisfied with the quality of New Jersey life. Poll takers found that 59 percent of respondents rated New Jersey an "excellent" or "good" place to live, as opposed to 78 percent in February 1988 and 80 percent in December 1984.
Dr. Gillespie said the sour economy had made a difference. "We're not as ebullient as in the mid-80's, but we're still making a comeback," he said.
Is there a more permanent cure for the inferiority complex that can withstand the vagaries of economic fluctuations? Dr. Cerulo held out hope.
She suggested an increase in the amount of attention given to New Jersey history and culture in elementary and secondary school curriculums: "Just as more inclusive history curriculums have boosted ethnic pride, an increase in New Jersey-centered education could boost pride in the state."
 
A Lack of Totems
 New Jersey's quest for a positive image is also hampered by its lack of totems, she said. After three centuries there is still no state song, and the Meadowlands is probably too new to be identified as a cultural icon. "New Jersey has no Liberty Bell, no Empire State Building," she said, "and people bond to symbols."
What symbols could New Jerseyans bond to? Celebrating the traffic cloverleaf, a notable New Jersey first, conjures up thoughts of those notorious toll roads. Saltwater taffy is primarily associated with the Shore. Hymns of praise to the New Jersey tomato might be open to all kinds of interpretations. And the blueberry is tasty and nutritionally correct, but it lacks charisma.
"Take images which have no previous meaning," Dr. Cerulo advised, "and elevate them to public consciousness." The European Community has done very well with its new flag and anthem, she said.
What is required above all, Dr. Cerulo said, is a widespread resolution to change the negative image behind the inferiority complex -- an all-out, statewide effort. Even then, she warned, "it doesn't happen overnight."

HEADLINE: The View From: Mount Vernon;
Celebrating 100 Years of Struggling Toward a Better Life

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON

DATELINE: MOUNT VERNON

 BODY:
WHEN Ronald A. Blackwood arrived in Mount Vernon from Jamaica in 1955 "to bunk in with a friend" while he looked for work, the 28-year-old Caribbean immigrant was following a path that others had traveled -- and would continue to travel -- for a century.
"There was an apartment waiting for me in Brooklyn, but I liked what I saw in Mount Vernon," he said. "So I stayed." Thirty years later he became the city's first black Mayor, and this year he will preside over Mount Vernon's centennial. 
 "I still like Mount Vernon," he said, after reviewing its strengths and weaknesses in a lengthy interview. "We have people from 92 nations, and they continue to arrive." Next Saturday, in what is likely to be the highlight of its 100th-year ceremonies, Mayor Blackwood will preside over Mount Vernon's Centennial Ball.
The ball is listed as a black-tie affair, but attendees are also welcome to come in native or period clothing as part of the city's effort to promote its ethnic diversity. They will pay $60 a plate for the five-course dinner and dance, which is to be held in a decorated cafeteria at Mount Vernon High School.
 
Metal Detectors Approved
 It is perhaps a sign of the times that the school has been the focus of less celebratory news in recent months. Responding to the fatal shooting of three Mount Vernon teen-agers, the Board of Education voted on April 3 to install walk-through metal detectors at the high school.
The Superintendent of Schools, Dr. William C. Prattella, said, "We're still considering whether to install them." He noted that none of the shootings took place inside the high school and that metal detectors, the first outside of New York City, would be a precautionary move.
The century that followed Mount Vernon's incorporation as a city on April 1, 1892, has produced an uneven profile and an uncertain future. Some of the most dramatic changes have come in the last half-century, when Mount Vernon became the first step for lower-middle-income families leaving New York City as well as a refuge for families displaced by urban renewal projects elsewhere in Westchester.
Mayor Blackwood said that when he arrived in Mount Vernon a decade after the end of World War II, minority groups represented 15 to 20 percent of the population. Since then "it has changed significantly," he said, "to about a 50-50 mix, with the school population about 75 percent minorities."
The black population, which rose from 7 percent in 1945 to 30 percent by the mid-1960's, stands today at 55 percent; the city's population is 40 percent white and 8 percent Hispanic. Minority members make up 84 per cent of the school population: 76 percent black and 8 percent Hispanic.
It was in the 1960's that Mount Vernon began to cope with a problem that was to affect other Westchester cities, changing from a middle-class residential suburb with strong buying power to a city that began to resemble New York City in its economic and social aspects.
While blacks who flocked to Mount Vernon in the postwar years included many professionals and semi-professionals who integrated easily, the city was becoming segregated -- with whites taking up residence north of the Metro-North railroad tracks and blacks clustering south of the tracks. It became difficult, and finally impossible, to achieve racial balance in the schools as blacks became the majority.
 
School System Improvement
 But the public school system -- 2 middle schools and 11 elementary schools in addition to the high school -- has improved over the past two decades. "In the 1970's, we had 75 percent of our students scoring below the state reference point in pupil reading and math evaluation tests," Dr. Prattella said. "Now we have fewer than 2 percent scoring below that state level." Both middle schools are magnet schools: one offers performing arts, mathematics and science; the other global studies, business and law.
The 1990 census, meanwhile, tends to support Mayor Blackwood's optimism over the future of Mount Vernon. The number of professionals increased from 21 percent in 1980 to 27 percent in 1990, the percent of high school graduates increased from 64 to 71 percent and the percentage of residents holding bachelor degrees increased from 14 to 20 percent.
Median household income more than doubled, from $16,000 to $35,000, as did median family income, from $20,000 to $41,000. The percentage living below the poverty line dropped from 14.6 percent to 11.8 percent and 31 percent of Mount Vernon's residents reported incomes of $50,000 or more in the 1990 census.
The number of housing units owned and occupied by residents increased over the decade, from 4,600 to 5,100 for whites and from 3,180 to 3,900 for blacks. Rentals by whites dropped sharply from 8,700 to 6,500 while rentals by black families rose marginally, from 8,200 to 8,700.
The median value of owner-occupied housing soared from $63,000 to $227,000 over the decade, in part a result of the housing boom in the 1980's. This startling increase in the value of Mount Vernon real estate lends some credence to an assertion made by Mayor Blackwood that "you can buy an excellent house for sometimes 75 percent of the asking price."
"Some places you pay for the name," he said, "like when you buy certain name brand goods they are sometimes no better than the house brand. You don't get a better buy, but you pay for the name. You pay for Scarsdale, you pay for Bronxville, because people want to live in those communities -- they're on top of the world."
"But you can live the same way in Mount Vernon," Mayor Blackwood added, "at much less cost with equivalent services. Would you believe we have people who move from Broxnville to Mount Vernon?"
There are other statistics, however, that paint a less positive picture. Crime is increasing, as indicated by a 6 percent increase from 1990 to 1991 in the number of calls for police assistance. The Fire Department responded to 4,159 alarms in 1991, 16.7 percent more than in 1990, and 42.6 percent of them were false alarms.
But parents, students and elected officials see the city's crime problems in more graphic terms. So far this year three Mount Vernon 16-year- olds -- Andre Frank, Kasiem Merchant and Cleavon Johnson -- were gunned down in street shootings. Police believe the shootings were committed by other teen-agers.
Mayor Blackwood initiated a gun amnesty program, but only four weapons were turned in. A crisis intervention center was established in the high school, where students had said gun possession was widespread.
Youngsters attending a rally at the high school on March 31, in the aftermath of the shootings, criticized the city for spending millions of dollars for a new police and court building while refusing to invest in recreational programs.
Mayor Blackwood acknowledged the existence of disruptive students "who don't settle arguments verbally anymore." He said: "People used to settle arguments by fighting -- you'd punch out a guy and that would be the end of it. Now you don't punch him, you shoot him."
Mount Vernon's economic status provides a somewhat rosier picture. Although unemployment, at 8 percent, is at the highest rate since the mid-1970's and nearly twice the 3.7 percent level of 1990, Mayor Blackwood attributes the figure to the recession rather than to local conditions. "A lot of our people work in New York City and therefore suffer the city's problems," he said.
 
Spending Reduced by $770,000
 Meanwhile, the city has pulled in its financial reins in the wake of the recession, approving a 1992 budget that will reduce spending by $770,000. Twenty-five unfilled jobs have been eliminated and appointments of some city officials delayed. Services have not been cut, however, and spending on library books and magazines continues at previous levels.
City employees have been working without contracts since Jan. 1, and the outlook for 1993 is bleak. Residents who stormed City Hall last year demanding a reduction in the proposed 18.9 percent property tax increase, and got city officials to reduce spending, can be expected back this year if property taxes go up again.
There have also been some economic losses: Consumers Union, the publisher of Consumer Reports, moved from Mount Vernon to Yonkers recently, and Lillian Vernon Corporation, a national mail order company, announced last month that after 41 years here it plans to move its headquarters to New Rochelle.
But Mayor Blackwood sees economic conditions improving, pointing to a $10 million supermarket that is planned for a five-acre site in a commercial district of south Mount Vernon as well as development of a transportation center in the eastern end of the city.

HEADLINE: MUSIC;
Despite Continued Cuts, Arts Remain a Priority

BYLINE: By ROBERT SHERMAN

 BODY:
THE recession has taken its toll on the arts. Donations -- personal, corporate and governmental -- are way down, and one organization after another has been forced to cut back operations. Many have gone out of business. On this Memorial Day weekend, however, let us look at the brighter side of the picture, which comes from a nationwide survey prepared for the American Council for the Arts and underwritten by Philip Morris.
The American people, the report said, care about the arts in far greater numbers than one might have supposed. They attend concerts, support artistic training in public schools and are willing, up to a point, to trade higher taxes for government financing of arts programs. 
 The telephone poll, conducted in February by Louis Harris, the public-opinion analyst, questioned 1,500 people over the age of 18 nationwide. The margin of sampling error was plus or minus 3 percent.
"This survey has been conducted in the middle of what the vast majority of Americans feel is one of the deepest recessions that has gripped the country in some time," Mr. Harris said. "It is striking that all regions of the country, all strata of education, all races and all income levels support Federal financing of the arts. The results are clear-cut and decisive, the majorities are significantly high."
Despite all the controversy swirling around the National Endowment for the Arts' support of specific artists and arts programs, the public vote on separating government financing from government control was equally decisive, with nearly 80 percent of the respondents opposed to artistic restrictions.
"These heavy majorities," Mr. Harris said, "spell out a clear-cut mandate for the government that Federal control of the substance of what the artists create should not be a condition of Federal funding."
An even greater number -- more than 90 percent -- felt that the arts should be a required and regular part of the public school curriculum. By a 3-to-1 ratio, the respondents said arts training should be part of the regular school budget; 6 in 10 said the arts were just as important to a youngster as math and science.
Mr. Harris said that it was significant that 8 in 10 adults were convinced that in studying the arts, children can learn skills that can be useful in a job. Thus the arts, viewed as esoteric and even an indulgence by some, "are seen by the vast majority of Americans as a crucial and central experience in education," Mr. Harris said.
In an article last month in the Lincoln Center magazine Stagebill, James Wolfensohn, chairman of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, echoed that sentiment and added a note of urgency. "This is a national responsibility," he wrote. "If we do not infuse the arts into the entire educational experience at all levels, it will be our children -- and ultimately our society -- who will suffer."
The Harris report yields other interesting statistics. Twenty-eight percent of the respondents, for instance, said they play a musical instrument; 17 percent sing in a choir or other vocal group; 35 percent are involved with dance, although that figure may be misleading because the category includes aerobics. Twenty percent listen frequently to classical music on radio or recordings, and another 20 percent said they listen to it every once in a while.
Obviously, these figures are modest compared with those for sporting events or pop music attractions, but they do indicate a deep awareness that children should not be deprived of the higher quality of life that music, painting and literature can bring them. In Westchester, there are many public and private organizations working toward that purpose; but individual support, too, is needed for local orchestras, choirs and chamber ensembles to thrive, as well as for a return to significant music education in school curriculums and making sure children are exposed to music, dance and theater events.
"Taken together," Mr. Harris concluded, "the levels of participation in the arts and commitment to the arts reinforce previous findings."
"To link those who participate and those who attend is a significant issue for the future," he added. "There is an enormous potential here -- in terms of involvement, but even more important in terms of building a constituency. How to bring the two together is a fundamental challenge to the arts community."
A booklet containing highlights of the poll is available for $3 (the complete survey is $20) from the American Council for the Arts, Publications Department, 1285 Avenue of the Americas, New York, N.Y. 10019, or by calling (212) 245-4510.
The Rosenthal Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. of Northern Westchester in Pleasantville and the Hoff-Barthelson Music School of Scarsdale have announced summer programs for school-age youngsters.
In the Y's classrooms, theater, gymnasium and playgrounds, the Summer Center for the Arts plans a variety of experiences for boys and girls in kindergarten through sixth grade, including workshops in songwriting, sculpture, dance, music and more, leading to a Festival Production and Art Show in the final week of the program. The number to call for more details is 741-0333.
For Hoff-Barthelson, the Summer Arts Program enters its 20th year with a new option for afternoon sports at Concordia College in Bronxville. The mornings, however, will be filled with music at the school, with classes in singing, eurythmics and sight reading, individual lessons on any instrument and group performance opportunities in orchestral, choral, wind and jazz ensembles. The telephone number at Hoff-Barthelson is 723-1169.
