HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

 
 
BIKING FOR DIABETES
 About 500 bicyclists are expected to take part in the Tour de Cure next Sunday, sponsored by the Lower Hudson Valley Chapter of the American Diabetes Association. Riders may choose from three scenic courses of 25, 50 or 100 kilometers, all beginning and ending at the Stouffer Hotel in Harrison.
Registration at $25 will begin at 6:30 A.M., and cycling will start at 8 A.M. Each rider will be required to have a minimum of $50 in pledges, and winners will receive merchandise from Sharper Image or, as a grand prize, a four-day cruise for two to the Bahamas. 
 All the routes will be monitored by marshals and served by volunteers at rest stops and water stops. At the finish line all riders will be treated to food, drink and entertainment.
Proceeds will be used for research projects, programs and services of the American Diabetes Association. The number to call for more information or a registration packet is 345-9300.
 
ART QUILTS ON DISPLAY
 Ann Trusty began making quilts as an art form 20 years ago. Since then she has developed skills that involve more than the piecing together of store-bought fabric. She dyes her own materials, silk-screens her own prints, paints fabric by hand and has perfected a series of complex stitches.
Her work has been exhibited in Europe, Japan and throughout the United States, and a collection of her quilts will be on display in the Art Workshop Gallery at the Westchester County Center in White Plains from Thursday through June 25.
She will present a lecture and seminar on the art quilt on Friday in the Art Workshop. The talk will begin at 9:30 A.M. and end at 11:30 A.M. Those who participate in the seminar and hands-on workshop may remain until 3:30 P.M. Admission to the lecture will be $10; the lecture and seminar will cost $36.
Visiting hours at the gallery are 10 A.M. to 8:30 P.M. Monday through Thursday, 10 A.M. to 3:45 P.M. Friday and 10 A.M. to noon Saturday. The number to call for more information or to register for the seminar-workshop is 684-0094.
 
FROM THE RAIN FOREST
 A replica of a herbal healer's house, typical of those in the world's rain forests, replete with tools and equipment for making medicines from plants, is part of an exhibit opening Saturday at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.
The display, "Green Treasures: Useful Plants of the Tropical Rain Forest," will acquaint visitors with the research done by the botanical garden's scientists in Belize, Central America, since the late 1980's.
Examples of more than 100 medicinally useful plants will be bedded in the lush vegetation surrounding the healer's house. Among them are cowfoot, used as an anti-swelling agent; avocado, whose leaves are effective in treating coughs, and annatto, a food coloring and a treatment for fever.
Herbal healers of Belize assisted Dr. Michael J. Balick, director of the garden's Institute of Economic Botany, and Prof. Robert Mendelsohn of Yale University in their research on harvesting medicinal plants in rain forests. The findings showed that such harvests yield rich rewards economically as well as scientifically, exceeding revenues from clear-cutting forests or from cultivation. Both practices have led to widespread loss of species, deforestation and environmental damage.
The exhibition will run through Oct. 25 on Tuesdays, Wednesdays, Thursdays and Fridays from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. and weekends and Monday holidays from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission is $3, $2 for children age 6 to 16, students and people 65 and older. Children under 6 are admitted free, and admission is free to everyone on Saturdays from 10 A.M. to noon. The number to call for directions or more information is (212) 220-8777.
 
ANTIQUES APPRAISALS
 For a $15 donation to the Pound Ridge Arts and Antiques Appraisal Committee, visitors to the first Pound Ridge Arts and Antiques Appraisal Day and Festival on Saturday may have two items appraised by an expert from Sotheby's. They will also become contributors to the Pound Ridge Historical Society and Museum.
The festival will be held in the Scott's Corners business district in Pound Ridge from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.
Appointments must be made with a Sotheby expert in advance by calling 764-4949 or 764-1247, specifying the type of object to be appraised -- furniture, decorative pieces, accessories, paintings, prints, jewelry, silver, crystal or china. Anything too large to carry may be appraised from a recent photograph.
Sotheby's appraisers and a number of skilled artisans will be stationed in various antique and arts shops. Among demonstrations will be restoration of antique furniture, brass and bronze, lacquering, restoration of oil paintings, trompe l'oeil and faux finish painting techniques, gilding and restoration of antique lamps and chandeliers.
A shopping guide, walking map and listing of the day's events will be available at the information booth in front of the Arts Center Building on Westchester Avenue (Route 124). More information may be obtained by calling 764-4477.
 
EGG TEMPERA SHOW
 Egg tempera is a medium seldom used by modern artists, with the notable exception of Paul Cadmus, because the process is extremely time consuming and considered somewhat old-fashioned.
Adrienne Riso apparently is undaunted by the required meticulousness and patience employed by Renaissance painters in their widespread use of egg tempera. She has completed a series of paintings called "Human Nature," on view at the Mamaroneck Artists Guild, which echo the detailed genre paintings of centuries ago, telling stories and recording important family events.
A companion exhibition of natural vine basketry and sculpture by Diane Heiman carries out the theme of the human form in semi-abstract and naturalistic techniques.
The guild, at 2120 Post Road in Larchmont, is open Monday through Saturday from noon to 4 P.M. A reception for the two artists will be held on Saturday from 2 to 4 P.M., and the exhibition will remain through June 14.
 
FOLK MUSIC IN PAWLING
 Walt Michael & Company will be on stage at the Towne Crier Cafe in Pawling tonight at 8:30, featuring Evan Stover and Frank Orsini on fiddles and Tom Wetmore playing string bass.
Mr. Michael, a folk and bluegrass virtuoso, is an extraordinary technician on the hammered dulcimer and a formidable singer and guitarist. Performing as a quartet, the ensemble will present a program of southern Appalachian, Celtic, Gospel and original compositions.
The admission fee is $12.50. The cafe is at 62 Route 22. The number to call for reservations is 855-1300.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
The Very Careful British Market

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
Is the British stock market too efficient? That might seem an odd notion, since the market took off after the Conservative Party victory in national elections on April 9. The Financial Times index of 100 leading stocks is up 13.5 percent and has set new highs, closing at 2,715.0 on Friday.
Moreover, many analysts contend that the market will rise even more, making it a good bet even after the 322 point rally so far. Paul Walton, the British strategist at James Capel Inc. in London, is so bullish he thinks the F.T. 100 can reach 3,000 by the end of the year and even 3,500 by mid-1993. Goldman Sachs in London also sees it at 3,000 by the end of the year. 
 But some investors are not sharing in the enthusiasm, and this is where the efficient market question enters. Teton Partners in Boston, a hedge fund manager that takes both long and short positions in stocks, thinks the British market is too efficient because too many stocks are followed by too many analysts and investors. This makes it very difficult to find bargains. So Teton prefers mostly looking elsewhere.
"Britain is never really on the top of our list," said Susan Boland, the Teton partner who covers Britain. "It is harder for us to find stuff that everyone else has not picked over. I prefer the Continent. The markets are much less efficiently researched."
In one sense, nothing has changed since the British elections -- the Conservatives, led by Prime Minister John Major, remain in power. But that was a surprise. As election day approached, the City had moved toward the conclusion that there would be a hung Parliament, with no clear victory for either Labor or the Conservatives.
In the detailed outlooks that many investment firms produced then, the Conservative victory scenario, although downgraded as a possibility, predicted an immediate rally and forecast that the F.T. 100 would rise to 3,000 by the end of the year.
Developments in the rest of Europe have added to the bullish fervor since then. In France, for example, the Socialists have dumped one prime minister and suffered setbacks in regional elections. The Italian Parliament cannot agree on choosing the new president needed to begin the process of forming a new government because the ruling coalition was rebuffed in recent elections.
Germany has been troubled by public workers' strikes and concerns about the stability of the coalition led by the chancellor, Helmut Kohl. Some of these fears receded after surprise union agreements in the metalworking and construction industries early last week and two more agreements for shopworkers and printers on Friday. This sent the Dax index in Frankfurt up more than 4.5 percent last week, though the political problems still remain.
All this seems to mean that Britain, the island, is one spot with political stability. There can be five years of a Conservative Government before another election. Moreover, the pound has demonstrated a reassuring stability to foreign investors since its entry into the European Monetary System. So Britain is increasingly seen as a magnet for large institutional investors and portfolio managers looking for Europe's best bets.
But at Teton Partners in Boston, led by George Noble and Tom Niedermeyer, the British market's magnetism does not have the same attraction.
Ms. Boland has only a few stocks in Britain. Two of her picks are small companies that are not in the center of the blue chip bull's-eye. One is Kwik-Fit, a small company that should benefit from new regulations requiring thicker treads on tires in Britain. The company sells tires and has fast repair muffler outlets.
In the Institutional Brokers Estimate System, which follows earnings projections on companies around the world, the forecasts for Kwik-Fit's earnings are for a rise of 13.3 percent in the fiscal year ending next February. And there is close agreement among the individual analysts on this outlook. Since the election, Kwik-Fit is up 27.6 percent.
Ms. Boland's second company -- of those she would name -- is a small homebuilder in southeast England, Berkeley Group, which will get a lift from the turnaround in the British economy that appears to be under way. She said Berkeley's owner has a lot of cash on hand because he stopped building near the top of the housing market.
The estimate system's median forecast for Berkeley Group earnings in the fiscal year ending next April is for a 69 percent increase. While there is a wide variation in the individual projections of analysts, they are all up substantially on Berkeley, except one, which shows no increase. Since the election Berkeley has risen 55.7 percent.
"We are willing to put the time in to do the homework," Ms. Boland said of what might seem obscure picks. "If you are willing to stretch your horizons a bit, you can make money."
But Ms. Boland also is not loath to chase after some of the biggies -- sometimes. In this case, the stock is Powergen, a utility listed in the F.T. 100. "We will still buy the big ones when they look like they are being undervalued in the market," she said. But she sold Powergen in the past week. "We owned it for a while because utilities were cheap before the election. But it has done its thing."
That's the efficient market for you.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Hewlett Tries Some Mainframe Magic

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
The list of minicomputer manufacturers that have entered the mainframe market is a short one, and with good reason: most that have tried have failed. Undaunted, the Hewlett-Packard Company announced its first mainframe-class machines last week.
Lewis E. Platt, Hewlett-Packard's executive vice president and general manager of the computer systems organization, said the new machines offered performance comparable to an I.B.M. 3090, but for one-tenth the cost and at one-tenth the size. The machines achieve this performance breakthrough with the use of reduced-instruction-set computing, or RISC, which speeds things up by relegating many common tasks to software. 
 "RISC technology has allowed us to do some very compelling things," said Mr. Platt, who is 51 and considered a leading candidate to succeed John A. Young as chief executive at the company, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif.
Mr. Platt said the new machines were aimed primarily at traditional mainframe customers who are considering "downsizing," industry jargon for moving applications to smaller, more cost-effective computers.
According to Dataquest Inc., a market research firm in San Jose, Calif., more than 46 percent of mainframe users are considering downsizing. Because the new machines can run all the software written for Hewlett-Packard minicomputers and work stations, current customers are also a major market opportunity, Mr. Platt said.
That software base is a significant reason that Hewlett-Packard can succeed where others failed, Mr. Platt said. The Digital Equipment Corporation "made a big mistake because it rolled out a piece of hot hardware, but there was no networking capability, no software," he said.
Priced from about $335,000 to $925,000, the new computers will begin to be shipped in August. Contrasted with a room-filling, liquid-cooled mainframe, the Hewlett-Packard machines are about the size of a refrigerator and are air-cooled. Companies that have already begun moving applications from mainframes to Hewlett-Packard's machines include 3M, GTE Telephone Operations and ITT Sheraton.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Congress Stops, the Dow Goes Up

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
In today's quiz, the answer is: "A place full of greedy, selfish people who are oblivious to the damage they inflict on the real world." The correct question is: a.) How would an investment banker define Congress?, b.) How would a legislator describe Wall Street?, or c.) Both of the above.
Unfortunately, you should choose "c." Now that the cold war is over, the world offers few ideological divisions as wide or as deep as the one that yawns between the nation's capital and the nation's marketplace. 
 At Washington dinner tables, legislators sneer at overpaid investment bankers rushing off in limousines to do deals that will put people out of work. In Wall Street bars, any query about Congress produces angry war stories about profits lost and deals killed by legislative bungling.
One such story is told by Eric Singer, an investment banker with Gerard Klauer Mattison & Company, a New York financial boutique known for its in-house research. On Oct. 19, 1987, as Mr. Singer was trying to negotiate a lucrative corporate acquisition, the target company's owner sensibly walked out rather than sell in the middle of a panic -- a panic Mr. Singer blames on Congressional proposals to change the tax treatment of interest costs in corporate takeovers.
But Mr. Singer has done more than gripe about how Congress hurts Wall Street. He has researched it, comparing stock market performance and legislative activity from V-J Day 1945 to the end of 1991. His conclusion: The stock market performs better when Congress is not in session.
Historians generally credit Gideon J. Tucker, a New York surrogate in the 1860's, with the observation that "no man's life, liberty or property are safe while the legislature is in session." But Mr. Singer's study suggests that one's portfolio is in peril as well. He found that, between mid-1945 and the end of 1991, the gain in the Dow Jones industrial average in the periods when both houses of Congress were closed was 17 times as great as when both houses were open.
For the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, the results were less dramatic but still notable. Mr. Singer found that the increase in the S.&P.-500 index while Congress was closed was almost four times as great as when Congress was open.
Last year was a case in point. The Dow gained 558.16 points between Dec. 31, 1990 and Dec. 31, 1992. But Mr. Singer calculates that 492.17 of those points were added while at least one house of Congress was closed, and 421.27 points were gained while both houses were closed. Only 65.9 points were gained while both houses were in session.
Over time, the Senate has been somewhat kinder to the market than the House, said Mr. Singer. "But when both the House and the Senate are closed is the best time for the market," he added. Indeed, he suggested -- not entirely in jest -- that a profitable investment strategy would be to buy S.& P. futures when Congress shuts down and sell them when it opens again.
Of course, rather than Congressional activity causing weak markets, it may be the other way around. After all, when the national economy is troubled, lawmakers might feel obliged to stick close to their desks. Similarly, when the market is strong, legislators are probably more likely to leave well enough alone, using the time to do a little campaigning among their constituents.
But with those caveats, several Wall Street veterans who have served inside the Beltway found it quite understandable that Wall Street might cringe whenever Congress springs into action. "Washington basically doesn't understand economics," said Mark Melcher, director of Washington research for Prudential Securities. "So the typical lawmaker views the markets not as one of the country's greatest assets, a place where capital is honestly priced, but as a gambling institution, where a lot of fat cats are playing sophisticated games. Their ignorance on the importance of the markets is pretty profound."
On the other hand, he noted, "Wall Street is often very naive about how this town works, too." As a result, when it comes to distinguishing a genuine threat from a legislator's random musings, Wall Street may panic first and ask questions later.
Mr. Singer acknowledged that Wall Street might be too quick to react when Congress indulges in its habit of "negotiating in the newspapers." But he argued that the market's skittishness is the only logical response to decades of disastrous legislative initiatives, dating back at least to the Smoot-Hawley tariffs that helped usher in the Depression. "The only smart thing to do is be very cautious when Congress is in session, because you never know what they'll come up with next," he said.
Mr. Singer's argument drew a bemused nod of recognition from J. Chester Johnson, a Treasury Department official in the Carter Admininstration and now the head of Government Finance Associates, a public finance advisory firm in New York. The enmity between market-maker and lawmaker has grown so deep, he said, "that I'm not very optimistic that there will ever be a rapprochement." He added, "And frankly, I'm not sure there should be."
However upsetting this public-private tension is to the markets, he continued, it may be just what the country needs to stay on an even keel. "Wall Street's hostility toward Congress puts pressure on Washington to be less facile about reaching into its citizens' pockets," Mr. Johnson said. "And Washington's hostility puts pressure on Wall Street to be a little more sensitive to the social needs and the public agenda. So each side helps restrain the worst tendencies in the other."
Mr. Melcher of Prudential agreed that a truce between Wall Street and Washington was unlikely, even if peace might be reassuring to the market. "These are antagonistic animals," he said. "And as Woody Allen would say, the lion may lie down with the lamb, but the lamb won't get much sleep."

HEADLINE: The Executive Computer;
More Home Workers and More Machines in Their Offices

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

 BODY:
Talked on the phone recently with the chief executive of a small prosperous company? You may never have suspected that the calm, assured voice at the other end belonged to a man in his underwear, interrupted while searching under the desk for an escaped hamster.
Ah, the joys of the home office. 
 While most home office do not have hamsters, the latest figures from the Link Resources Corporation, a market research company in New York, show that most do have personal computers. For the first time, the percentage of home offices that use a computer has topped 50 percent.
"I see it as a significant milestone," said Thomas E. Miller, a vice president at Link Resources. Mr. Miller said that final numbers from his company's 1991 work-at-home survey were being tabulated but that more than 39 million people appeared to have done all or part of their paid work at home last year.
Put those two calculations together and 20 million people are using personal computers at home to do some or all of their paid work -- running a primary or secondary business, working at home a day or two each month, or simply catching up on correspondence at night or on weekends.
One subset of home office workers is called "corporate home workers," people on the payroll of a company outside their home, and nearly 60 percent of them use a computer, said Mr. Miller, who is also an example of this. He works from his home in upstate New York and "commutes" to the city electronically.
Because of the recession, the heady growth in the number of home offices appears to have slowed, Mr. Miller said, but the adoption of computers and other information technologies in those offices is increasing. People are relying more on telephones, modems, facsimile machines and scanners as well as computers to help them with their jobs.
Beyond the mere statistics, the broader message is that the personal computer has become a standard tool in even the smallest businesses in America. The Small Business Administration says these smallest businesses -- all the way down to one-person pet-sitting services, window washers, gardening consultants and moonlight word processors -- collectively generate as much of the country's gross national product as the 500 largest multinational corporations.
And businesses that do not use computers are officially in the minority for the first time.
"It is a milestone, and it was a long time in coming," said Paul Edwards, who with his wife, Sarah Edwards, has written several books and lectured widely on the work-at-home phenomenon. "In the big- and small-business sector it was passed quickly, but it was more slow to develop in the home. It is a recognition that the computer, as an extension of the brain, has become as indispensible to operating a business as the telephone is as an extension of our voices."
"People who are not computerizing are not able to compete as well," said Sarah Edwards. "They're struggling, or just hanging on."
The Edwardses are authors of "The Best Home Businesses for the 90's" and "Making It On Your Own" (each $10.95, from Tarcher Books, a division of Putnam Publishing Group of New York) cited the recent example of a woman who ran a bookkeeping service from her home.
The message for any business, Paul Edwards said, "is that personal computers are now integral as opposed to supplemental," adding: "Now it's no longer a matter of gaining a competitive edge. It's a matter of keeping up."
In the electronic forums that on-line information services provide, home office and small business workers are asking a lot of questions. Many home office workers rely on these forums for their technical information, because they do not have the technical support staffs that are common in larger businesses.
"I need to know how much RAM my system has," writes Fran, of Margate, Fla., in the home business forum on Prodigy Information Services. "Also, where do I find how much MG I have?" She gets replies from a self-described "old lady" named Jane; Mark in Norman, Okla., and others who guess that Fran means megabytes of disk storage space rather than monosodium glutamate or machine guns. They tell Fran to use the DOS CHKDSK and MEM commands.
"About 35 percent of our members work at home," said Brian Ek, a spokesman for Prodigy Information Services Inc. of White Plains, which is a joint venture of the International Business Machines Corporation and Sears, Roebuck & Company.
David, in contrast, asks other musicians for more technical advice. "I have a Roland CM-32L synthesizer with the MPU IMC card. When I try to initialize the Win 3.1 driver for MPU-401 . . ."
Frank uses the computer to ask where he can get more information about a balloon-decorating business. Michael asks about the availability of facsimile machines for use in his car and gets replies from across the country. Another Michael uses his computer to inquire about starting a mobile oil-change business for people who don't have time to wait at the 10-minute lube shops. A baseball-card collector in Fort Worth asks about the profitability of opening a sports card shop and receives some rather bleak replies along with a report on the return-on-investment of 1989 Ken Griffey Jr. rookie cards ($2 to $3 then, now $45 each).
The recession and subsequent layoffs of thousands of mid-level business managers nationwide has changed the dynamics of new home office ventures, Mr. Miller of Link and the Edwardses agreed. Many executives who lost their jobs are starting home-based businesses, using computers and other information technologies to re-create their former office environment.
Rapidly falling prices, as well as career decisions, are driving computers deeper into the home office.
"When I started in this field in 1983, I paid nearly $5,000 for a fully loaded Apple II," Mr. Miller said, chuckling at the thought. Today, $5,000 will equip a home office with a computer many times more powerful than the Apple II, along with software, a couple of telephones, an answering machine, a fax machine, a modem and other equipment -- with enough left over for a nice desk and lamp.

HEADLINE: At Work;
Is the American City Obsolete?

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
There seems to be very little good news coming out of America's cities these days. First, a flood in Chicago, then fire in Los Angeles, events that seemed to bring the prophecy from an old slave song -- "God gave Noah the rainbow sign, no more water, the fire next time" -- perilously close to reality. Cities, some social critics contend, are obsolete -- vestigial remnants of an era earlier in this century when proximity was critical to commerce. New York, for example, was a hub through which money and people, immigrants, for example, were sped into the flourishing national economy.
At the very least, goes the argument, cities are now a reminder that the country has lost its edge in manufacturing and has been unable to solve the problems of structural poverty. Urban jobs have flowed offshore and to places with more enticing, dependable infrastructure. The future is in a white-collar service economy that can be conducted in so-called "edge cities" far from an urban core.
 
 Whenever he hears another knell sounded on behalf of the late-20th-century American city, Elliott Sclar, professor of urban planning at Columbia University, tends to want to reach up and grab the clapper. "If you look at societies through history, when they are growing and dynamic, their cities are vital and dynamic," he said in an interview last week. "In the Dark Ages, cities were walled and people were fearful." Professor Sclar sees ominous signs in what he regards as the abandonment of the cities, both literally and in the American imagination. "In the future, people may look back at us and see a fearful society that is closing down," he said.
If Professor Sclar were philosopher-king, he would put cities in the center, not of a social agenda, but of an economic and industrial agenda. Late last year, he and two colleagues, Joseph Persky, an economist at the University of Illinois, and Wim Wiewel, the director of the Center for Urban Economic Development at Illinois, posed the question "Does America Need Cities?" in a report for the Economic Policy Institute. In that report and in an update written by Professors Persky and Wiewel two weeks ago as Los Angeles and the rest of the nation cooled off, they answered the question with an impassioned affirmative.
"The cities of the nation, for all of their social problems, play host to the country's most productive activities," the authors wrote, flinging a pot of paint in the face of conventional wisdom that "productive activity" is most profitable far from the demimonde of, say, Manhattan, Chicago or San Francisco.
"Right now we are writing off 20 to 25 percent of our population and 50 percent of our most valuable real estate," said Professor Persky of the trend toward situating industry a long freeway or turnpike ride away from city centers. "That's just a wastefulness we can't afford as a society."
The utility of the traditional city lies in what the authors call "agglomeration," the concentration of a high-density population of workers with diverse, leading-edge specializations. Corporations can move their routine "back office" chores out into the countryside where employees do a good job at less pay than in the city. "But the work force in the command and planning part of a corporation doesn't have routine work to do," Professor Sclar said. "They have to evaluate and analyze information and make decisions."
Telecommunications and technology like modems and fax machines are never likely to replace the face-to-face encounter. Fortunes can rise and fall on the simple business lunch. "It's no accident that financial firms don't leave the city," Professor Sclar said. "They lend billions of dollars, and they do it almost intuitively. Some things involve being together and making judgments."
The authors believe the nation is at a crossroads in allocating its resources. As the edge cities mature into settled population centers, they have the same infrastructural needs as the older cities, which will require outlays for roads, sewers, school systems, public transportation and other necessities of life. The growth of edge cities is already beginning to slow as they reach the limits of their usefulness as isolated centers of industry. "They are looking for a more urban, high-density base over the next 10 to 15 years," Professor Persky said. "Those areas will continue to grow, and we will have to increase connections between them. That will be expensive."
The vast expenditures necessary to diversify the edge could go to helping the center cities hold. The authors don't expect much help from the current troika of Presidential candidates. America's deep ambivalence about its urban areas could too easily render any truly pro-city politician obsolete.
 
 
 
COLLEGE EDUCATION NOT REQUIRED
 The argument raised most frequently against trying to revive cities is the complexity of remedies needed. Concern is endemic among executives that young people in general and big-city young people in particular are poorly prepared for the demands of work in the 21st century.
One of the authors of a report arguing in favor of salvaging the cities questions the accepted wisdom that college degrees will become prerequisites for even modest entry-level employment. "It's as if people have accepted the notion that high school can be written off," said Joseph Persky, an economist, "that people either go to college or drop out of high school." Professor Persky says the key question is not how long people go to school but what they learn. "There's no reason someone coming out of high school could not have the skills to become a skilled technician," he said. "We are getting an overcredentialed work force."
An educational revolution is not necessary, Professor Persky argues: "Basic literacy skills, basic math and a little awareness of the world. That's not too much to ask."

HEADLINE: An Alternative to Seawolf

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Washington helpless? Hardly. The problem in Washington is not a lack of funds but a lack of imagination throughout the system, which includes both political parties. 
 Why is it that we can find $300 billion for defense but nothing for substantial manufacturing training in civilian production? Surely Government subsidies now given out as military contracts to build such products as Seawolf submarines could be devised to go to the same companies in the same communities to build other more useful products. High-speed rail transportation systems, commuter transportation, airport improvement, civilian aircraft and the like all have real value and can serve multiple purposes in regenerating our inner cities as well as our national economy.
Why is it that McDonnell Douglas must go to Taiwan for capital when the United States needs its production capabilities and may someday need its military production capabilities? Why not a direct Government program to produce civilian transport that will keep it here and prosperous?
Washington has the money, the country has the need and it is absurd to suggest that Washington is helpless in the face of this type of challenge. No one in either party appears to have spent any time thinking about how to make the transition from a war economy (albeit mostly cold war) to a peace economy. Why not encourage the military industry to become the peace industry?
 
SETH M. BODNER
Summit, N.J., May 3

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
The Frozen President

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

 BODY:
Something has happened to President Bush. In recent weeks and months he has ducked and vacillated on issues, seemingly unwilling to take decisive positions, unable to lead. It is as if he were immobilized.
His supporters have noticed. They are more and more openly expressing concern, discontent, bewilderment at his performance. They are starting to look elsewhere for leadership. 
 The most striking example of his indecisiveness, and very likely the most damaging to Mr. Bush, has been his response to the jury verdict and riots in Los Angeles. After the verdict he urged people to await a nonexistent "appeals process." Since then he has alternated between calls for law and order and sympathetic talk about urban needs.
The country urgently wanted leadership after Los Angeles: a sense of direction, a sense of hope. President Bush temporized, heard conflicting ideas from his advisers, came up with a tired little package of old proposals. There has been no sense of the White House as a beacon in hard times.
But the phenomenon is not limited to domestic issues. A President who made his mark in foreign affairs and used to revel in taking strong stands abroad has become weak and indecisive there, too.
Look at Yugoslavia. The Persian Gulf war is only a little more than a year old. Could any of us have imagined then that George Bush would be whimperingly unable to respond to brutal aggression by a Serbian Communist? That he and his foreign-policy aides would stand mute while the Serbs mimicked Nazi tactics by pulling non-Serbians out of their homes in Bosnia and Herzegovina in the cause of "ethnic purification"?
The question of help to post-Communist Russia is another puzzling example. Mr. Bush came forward with no proposals to help save the budding Russian democracy from economic disaster until he was shamed into doing something by former President Nixon.
Then there was his trip to Japan. He first canceled it so he could look more like a domestic President. Then in January he went, and the proclaimed supporter of free trade used the trip to act as a Willy Loman for U.S. auto manufacturers.
The pattern reached a comic height last week in the incident of Dan Quayle and Murphy Brown. The Vice President attacked the TV character for "mocking the importance of fathers by bearing a child and calling it 'just another life style choice.' " This threw Mr. Bush and the White House into a tizzy.
"I don't know what it's about," Mr. Bush said. "Where's Marlin on this?"
Marlin Fitzwater, his spokesman, first condemned "the glorification of the life of an unwed mother." A few minutes later he corrected himself, praising Murphy Brown's "pro-life values." The President himself came out strongly for "families with a mother and father."
What is going on? The one thing that George Bush has not been during most of his life is reluctant to act or decide.
He was the youngest Navy pilot in World War II, a gung-ho character. As President he ordered the invasion of Panama: an adventure that did not help Panama's problems of drugs and poverty, as it turned out, but that was surely bold. And then there was the war on Iraq.
In personal style, too, Mr. Bush is the opposite of idle. He is Mr. Kinetic, constantly in motion, a man whose idea of a restful seaside holiday is to zoom around in a noisy speedboat.
How, then, can we explain the immobilism that has crept over George Bush the President? I think the reason is politics: politics of a particular kind.
In this election year Mr. Bush is trying to avoid doing things that may upset people. He is trying to finesse hard issues.
Thus he tries to mollify the doctors and scientists who want to use fetal tissue as it is used in every other country, to cure human diseases, without roiling the anti-abortionists. He proposes a fetal-tissue bank that will be forbidden to benefit from voluntary abortions -- and hence will be useless.
The whole strategy, if that is what it is, is useless. The country will not wait for action until November. The world will not wait. And the voters will not wait.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: U.S. Acts the Spoiler in Global Climate Talks

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Last week delegates from 143 countries reached tentative accord on a Framework Convention on Climate Change after marathon debates during their final negotiating session at the United Nations in New York.
As it stands, the convention requires that industrialized countries look to "return by the end of the present decade to earlier levels of anthropogenic emissions of carbon dioxide and greenhouse gases" but includes no specific reductions or timetable. While the convention has been criticized as being too weak, a second criticism must be directed not to the result but to the process. 
 The group began the negotiating process more than 15 months ago, pursuant to a United Nations resolution. During the third session, held in September 1991, the European Community surprised many delegates by endorsing the specific commitment of stabilizing greenhouse gas emissions at 1990 levels by the year 2000. Japan, Australia, Canada and the Scandinavian countries soon followed suit. Virtually all developed countries also supported the proposal. Only the United States stood its ground, and the stalemate lasted through the next two sessions.
Shortly before the start of the final session, the chairman of the group, Jean Ripert of France, consulted with a handful of member countries of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, including the United States and Britain, to develop language substantially the same as that adopted last week. During the session Mr. Ripert in essence admitted he had bowed to the U.S. position so that the U.S. would be a party to the proposed convention.
While practical, Mr. Ripert's action lacked courage. Many arguments exist for structuring a treaty palatable to the United States. As both the world's largest greenhouse-gas emitter and the world's deepest pocket, the U.S. must be a party to make the treaty meaningful, so the argument goes. Even without the United States, however, the treaty's effectiveness might not have suffered greatly. Furthermore, as industrialized countries party to the convention develop new energy-saving technology, U.S. companies would be obliged to keep pace with their foreign competitors. In bowing to the U.S., Mr. Ripert sacrificed the willingness of many for the obstinacy of one.
It is unfortunate for the other delegates, the negotiating process and the global environment that the treaty to be signed at the Earth Summit next month in Rio de Janeiro is the anti
climactic (and anti-climatic) result of the long, arduous negotiations that preceded it.
 
JASON M. PATLIS
Lansing, N.Y., May 13, 1992
 
The writer, a law student, attended two sessions of the Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee for a Framework Convention on Climate Change.

HEADLINE: L.A. Police Were Tried by a Jury of Their Peers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I am writing to correct a small but critical error that continues to appear in discussions concerning recent events in Los Angeles. 
 "The Jury Said, 'I'm White, and You're Wrong' " (letter, May 10) asks the rhetorical question, "White suburban juries as peers of black urban citizens? By what measure are they peers?" By the same measure, apparently, the writer himself employs: race and economy.
What he and others fail to note is that the jury in question was hearing the case against four white Los Angeles police officers; they were not hearing a case against Rodney King, who never appeared in court. If we judge parity by race and economy (class), then the Los Angeles police officers most certainly were tried by a jury of their peers.
On the one hand, this "error" should be understood as the legitimate call for justice for Rodney King that it is. The tendency to describe the jury as "non-peers" reveals a strong desire that his beating be seen for what it was, a racist attack. It reveals the concern that it be seen from the perspective of the African-American community, which experiences the justice system quite differently from whites.
However, the deeper question -- What is a peer? -- continues to be answered in terms of race by both blacks and whites. We must understand, though, that while the answer may be similar, the rationale is much different for whites than it is for blacks. And that a "better" answer waits on a more fundamental change in how we as a society understand and regard racial differences.
 
ROBERT MC CLUSKEY
New York, May 11, 1992

HEADLINE: An Election-Year Amendment;
Would the Budget Deficit Be Constitution-Proof?

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE proposed constitutional amendment to balance the budget is in many ways a gamble, and the debate about it boils down to whether the gamble is worth taking.
Senator Paul Simon, the Illinois Democrat who is the chief sponsor of the leading proposal, says that only something as weighty as a constitutional amendment can force the White House and Congress to get serious about eliminating the deficit. Since the President and Congress must swear to uphold the Constitution, he asserts that they would not dare shirk their duty to implement a new amendment. 
 But opponents say the proposed amendment is a gamble that will not pay off. They argue that there is no way the amendment, well-intentioned as it may be, will force the White House and Congress to take the painful, possibly traumatic, steps needed to erase the deficit. Convinced that such an amendment will prove as worthless as an overdrawn check on the House Bank, opponents say it would be an insult to the hallowed Constitution to add an amendment on the mere hope that it might prove effective.
Mr. Simon's amendment would require the President to propose a balanced budget to Congress, which could waive the requirement with a 60 percent vote in each house or in the event of war. The Bush Administration has repeatedly backed a balanced budget amendment, although conservatives generally prefer a version offered by Senator Robert W. Kasten Jr., Republican of Wisconsin. His version, which is given less chance of passing, would require a 60 percent vote in each house to increase taxes.
Mr. Simon said an amendment would stop Congress and the President from burdening future generations with debt. "Right now we don't have to do anything except build up an enormous tab that we won't be around to have to pay," he said. The deficit is expected to soar to over $350 billion this year.
Mr. Simon likes to point out that several prominent economists who opposed such an amendment in the mid-1980's now support it. Admitting that the amendment is heavy-handed, these economists have still seized upon it in the desperate hope that it might work where nothing else has.
 
A Convert Explains
 "I used to think it was unnecessary," said Barry Bosworth, a Carter Administration economics official who is a fellow at the Brookings Institution. "But deficits have now gone on for a decade and a half. We may need some institutional change because we have this continual practice of a government split between Republicans and Democrats, and no one is taking any responsibility for the deficits."
He fears that lawmakers and the public fail to recognize how harsh the steps would be.
Robert Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, laid that out very clearly in recent testimony. One formula to balance the budget by 1997, he said, would be to raise overall taxes by 4 percent, cut projected spending on entitlement programs like Medicare and Social Security by 3 percent, and cut discretionary programs like Head Start, highways and medical research by 20 percent. If discretionary programs were left alone, he said, taxes could be raised by 7 percent and entitlements cut by 10 percent.
Another package, he suggested, could erase the deficit over 10 years without tax increases: cut the military budget by 40 percent, other discretionary spending by 16 percent, farm payments by 70 percent, veterans benefits by 13 percent, federal retirement programs by 7 percent, programs for the poor by 1 percent and discretionary spending by 16 percent. It would also hold growth in Medicare and Medicaid spending to 10 percent a year, not the projected 12 percent, and index Social Security benefits to rise each year by 1 percent less than inflation.
Knowing how painful these spending cuts would be, he sketched an alternative: raise personal tax rates from 15, 28 and 31 percent, to 16, 30 and 33 percent, respectively; lift the corporate income tax by one point to 35 percent; limit itemized deductions to those in the lowest tax bracket; and place a 5 percent value-added tax on all goods and services except food, housing and medical care.
Mr. Reischauer said a balanced budget is desirable because deficits hold down investment, productivity and growth -- although he said a balanced budget requirement could prolong recessions by preventing countercyclical spending. The problem, he said, has not been getting a consensus for a balanced budget. "Rather, the problem has been agreeing to the specific spending cuts and tax increases that could bring this about. A balanced budget amendment, in and of itself, does little to force such an agreement."
Critics worry that if Congress and the President cannot agree on a balanced budget, the unelected Federal judiciary might be called to intervene and might end up managing the budget.
The morning betting line is that Congress will pass the amendment this year. Opponents say it is a cheap vote. In an election year when incumbents face charges of fiscal irresponsibility, lawmakers will be able to boast that they wholeheartedly support a balanced bud get. But they will not have to take any of the nasty steps to balance it. That will wait until 38 states ratify the amendment.
Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, a Maryland Democrat opposed to the amendment, hasn't given up hope. "As people begin to see things more clearly, they will begin to understand more of the amendment's implications."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Across Southeast Asia, Awakenings to Democracy

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AN announcer on an army-run television channel in Bangkok tried to explain last week why several hundred thousand Thais were in the streets demanding that an unelected Prime Minister resign. Evildoers, the announcer said, had "planted time bombs in the minds of the people."
Time bombs have indeed been going off with some regularity over the last decade in minds in much of Southeast Asia, but there are more credible causes than "evildoers." In areas of rapid economic growth, political liberalization has not in general kept pace; in other countries, autocratic regimes have thwarted economic growth. 
 So it is not just in Thailand that large groups of people are asking if economic progress will be accompanied by democratic reforms, as supporters of democracy throughout the area grow disdainful of the argument that Asians are somehow different, that they prefer the stability of even corrupt authority over the uncertainties that come with free expression and elections.
In 1986, the Philippines felt the effect of this when its "people power" revolution sent the late President Ferdinand Marcos into exile. In the same year, violence racked Sabah, a Malaysian state where an elected administration was under siege from Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad and his dominant political party. Then a short-lived challenge to General Suharto's choice for vice president was mounted in Indonesia, where even military officers were beginning to chafe under the general's virtual presidency-for-life. And in 1988, gentle Burma erupted in rage when the military crushed a pro-democracy movement.
Each time such things happen, Southeast Asians, part of a coalescing community of nations despite their cultural differences, plunge into introspection about what Asians really want. And each time, the answers become clearer. Although the circumstances and settings are different, the aims of popular movements are pretty much the same as in other parts of the world. These people want the right to conduct business in an environment reasonably free of stifling corruption, and they want real power in choosing their leaders.
When middle class Thais joined the ad hoc revolution on Bangkok's streets last weekend, they challenged the assertions made by Southeast Asia's many intolerant governments that order and consensus are more important there than freedom.
 
A Widely Held Notion
 "The popular outrage against Suchinda and demand for democracy indicate that the notion, widely held in Administration circles, that Asians are somehow more comfortable with authoritarianism is utterly false," said Sidney Jones, executive director of the human rights group Asia Watch. "The Thai pro-democracy movement should also send a warning signal to Indonesia and Malaysia, who say that the developed countries focus too much on civil and political rights when the real priority of Asians is economic development."
Not all Southeast Asians argue that the philosophical underpinnings of the region dictate that societies will be essentially passive. When tensions were rising in Singapore a few years ago, the Confucian scholar Wu Teh Yao said in an interview that individualism may not rank high in his philosophical system, but that this did not mean an acceptance of authoritarianism, especially amid prosperity. "In all human societies, once the tummy is full, the mind begins to think," he said. "So whoever is going to rule, even in Japan or China, will have to pay attention to the people's needs and wishes."
The argument that there is a Southeast Asian way of interpreting democracy is another matter, and it has some validity -- as shown last week by the longing of the Thai people for King Bhumibol Adulyadej to intervene in the crisis to calm it. He did so a manner rich in symbolism, making the antagonists kneel at his feet. The concept of a ruler acting in the best interests of the people has been part of political life from Vietnam to Java. There is also a genuine desire for consensus and a talent for smoothing away potential clashes. But big problems arise when these natural or traditional instincts are appropriated by politicians or military strongmen and twisted to justify their unwillingness to allow pluralism to develop.
Evelyn Colbert, a former Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Asia and the Pacific, said in an interview last week that she was struck by trends in the Philippine election. "The influence of the church on people's voting patterns has been much less than one might have expected," she said. Also, she noted, "in both the Philippines and Thailand, the issue of corruption has been very potent politically."
Ms. Colbert added that success by the Thais in forcing the military-dominated government to make concessions "in some constructive way" would encourage democrats in Burma to continue their campaign.
 
A Jolt to Neighbors
 James Clad, a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, said: "What happened in Thailand has jolted Indonesia and the region far more than the Philippine revolt in 1986, far more than Burma's savagely repressed riots." The Philippines and Burma "were seen as places that were failing in many ways," he said in a telephone interview from Singapore. "Thailand is different. It was a place that had everything going for it."
In Indonesia, where the military has wielded great political influence since independence in 1949, Mr. Suharto has been in power with army backing since 1965; now word has slipped out in Jakarta that he will more than likely seek another five-year term next year, after parliamentary elections choose his indirect electors in June. Many Indonesians are tired of this closed system, though, and several parties have begun to explore ways of pushing the limits of the carefully controlled process.
In Indochina, the prospects for democracy seem more distant; it is hard to know what odds to give the United Nations' efforts to build representative democracy in Cambodia, and Vietnam is fighting to keep Communism alive. In Vietnam, in fact, what one hears from the leadership has a familiar ring: that Asians are simply not enamored of messy multiparty political systems.

HEADLINE: Federal Environmental Oversight Is Limited;
The Oil Industry Likes to Keep Regulation Close to Home

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO

DATELINE: HOUSTON

 BODY:
WHEN drilling rigs were plentiful across America's oil patch, state governments fought to keep revenues and regulatory control close to home, minimizing Washington's role. Even as domestic oil and gas production are at the lowest levels in decades, Congress will soon decide whether this fading industry should be compelled to pay more for environmental cleanup or continue its longstanding exemption from Federal environmental laws.
At issue is a delicate calculation applicable to many environmental dilemmas at a time of scarce government resources and a stalled national economy. If an industry is not pushed hard enough, environmental damage piles up, but if it is pushed too hard, businesses simply shut down, abandoning polluted sites. 
 Until now, state agencies, many of which were created to promote the oil industry, have tended to make this calculation for oil and gas fields, the largest generators of wastes still exempt from the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act.
The principal complaint against the states is that even when their rules are adequate, enforcement is uneven. After oil-field waste polluted water-supply lakes, Oklahoma set up a prevention unit. Lowell Brown, its sole agent, said, "I have no directives and no work plans. I have been sitting here essentially doing nothing because I don't have any authority."
Under legislation proposed by Representative Dennis E. Eckart, Democrat of Ohio, the Federal Government would set minimum standards, stricter than many now imposed by any state. The states would retain considerable say over enforcement.
The proposals have met resistance. "To legislate such unnecessary changes at a time when we have the lowest rig count in history," said Denise A. Bode, president of the Independent Petroleum Association of America, "the lowest level of oil production in 30 years, the lowest natural gas prices at the wellhead in more than 15 years and when we have lost over 350,000 jobs in the production end of the business is irresponsible."
With Congress more likely to limit than expand the scope of the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, Mr. Eckart acknowledges the difficulty he is having in trying to push through his legislation. "When an industry has a blanket exemption and someone suggests the most modest regulation, they see it changing the universe in which they do business," he said.
Pumping oil, especially in America's substantially depleted fields, produces briny water, the most significant oil-field waste. It's as much as four times saltier than the oceans and contains a variety of heavy metals, organic toxins and low levels of radioactivity. Nearly 80 percent of the wells in Texas draw less than nine barrels of a oil a day and as much as 50 barrels of brine.
Often this brine is forcibly pumped back into the ground to maintain pressure in oil-bearing formations, a process subject to some Federal rules. A few states have tightened regulations on disposal methods like pouring it into open pits or dumping it in waterways. Nationwide, however, the laws are inconsistent.
"How do we make them realize that if these same substances were found anywhere else they would be regulated?" says Mr. Eckhart. "They feel they are entitled to this free ride, when in fact the days of entitlements for the oil industry are over."
The oil industry counters that it is already adequately regulated by the states and can't afford to do more.
Last year, the American Petroleum Institute calculated that under a hypothetical Federal regulatory program tougher than any proposed thus far, some 80 percent of all domestic oil and gas wells would be rendered unprofitable and would halt production, eliminating more than 40,000 industry jobs.
Melinda Taylor, an attorney for the National Audubon Society, which supports the Eckart bill, dismisses such numbers as the kind of lobbyists' doom-saying that confronts many new regulations. Insisting there's no intent to shut down marginal operators, Ms. Taylor complains, "They don't want to even talk about things like market incentives that have worked with other industries."
Governments of 29 oil-producing states have already closed ranks with the industry by stating their unanimous opposition to eliminating the oil field exemption.
Lena Guerrero, chairwoman of the Texas Railroad Commission, which regulates the oil industry, said, "I resent the idea that somebody in Washington will protect our environment better than we can. The geology, the industry and the environment is different in every state."
Proponents of the Eckart bill insist states would have the flexibility to deal with these differences, but also, as Ms. Taylor put it, "Federal standards give states backbone."
Texas adopted the most aggressive oil field cleanup program of any state, she noted, and yet could still take up to 50 years. Under the Eckhart bill, those same objectives would have to be met in just 10 years.
Martin V. Melosi, a history professor at the University of Houston, argues that state governments in the oil patch are now resisting Federal intrusion out of fear for their economic future. In 1981 Texas drew 28 percent of its state revenues from severance taxes on oil production; a decade later it was less than 9 percent. Every Texas budget now sparks dreaded talk of imposing income taxes for the first time.
"Texas has not readjusted its tax structure or altered its relationship with the oil industry ," said Professor Melosi. "Oil is still an important part of the fiscal mix, so it is easier to keep believing that prices will go up again someday, solving all the problems."
As Governor of Louisiana, Buddy Roemer imposed tough regulations on oil field wastes. Last year he was defeated for reelection, with much of the industry backing his successor, Gov. Edwin W. Edwards. Now there's a move to undo some of his efforts.
"Just turning an environmental problem over to the Feds won't solve it," Mr. Roemer said. "That's no substitute for an informed public looking after its own backyard. But the danger of leaving it to the states is that the track record is so uneven. Their history is often driven by personalities, not policies."

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
A Political Movement Blends Its Ideas From Left and Right

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS

 BODY:
HERE'S a barely noticed fact that could augur a serious change in the political landscape: not everyone who agrees with Dan Quayle about Murphy Brown is a conservative.
On the same day the Vice President complained in California that the popular television series was contributing to the woes of the poor by rendering single motherhood glamorous and derogating the importance of fathers, two speakers at a largely liberal gathering in New York City made exactly the same point. 
One was William A. Galston, a political philosopher at the University of Maryland, who occasionally advises Bill Clinton. The other, David Blankenhorn, heads the Institute for American Values, a Manhattan-based research center dealing with family issues. Both referred to a critique of Murphy Brown's motherhood by Barbara Dafoe Whitehead, a scholar who is a colleague of Mr. Blankenhorn's, that appeared in The Washington Post two weeks ago. The meeting was a "Communitarian Teach-In," and Mr. Galston, Mr. Blankenhorn and Ms. Whitehead all signed a "Communitarian Platform" that was issued last November.
Communitarianism is the new kid on the political block, staking out territory somewhere between the liberal advocates of the welfare state and civil liberties entrenched on one corner, and conservative devotees of laissez-faire and traditional values on the other. Communitarians generally line up with liberals as defenders of individual rights, equality and democratic change. But none of these things, they argue, can be preserved unless the nation's basic communities and institutions -- families, schools, neighborhoods, unions, local governments and religious and ethnic groups -- succeed in building character and instilling the virtues of citizenship.
"Strong rights presume strong responsibilities," said Amitai Etzioni, a George Washington University sociologist and one of the founding fathers of a movement he compares to the environmental movement.
Just as Americans could once take the quality of their air and water for granted, he explained, they could once concentrate on spelling out rights while assuming that citizens were endowed with a well-developed sense of obligation and responsibility. Where environmentalism focuses on the degradation of nature, communitarianism concentrates on the social environment.
Communitarians fault liberals for reflexively blaming economic and political forces for poverty, drug abuse, crime and urban and environmental blight while neglecting the importance of personal responsibility and the forces that have traditionally nurtured it. They also fault conservatives for exalting the free market and the pursuit of self-interest as remedies for social problems while ignoring the corrosive effect of economic pressure and a competitive ethos on family life and community spirit.
Communitarianism's leading concern is the family, "where each new generation acquires its moral anchoring," according to its platform. Most communitarians unabashedly endorse the two-parent family as the norm for society, although they acknowledge that some single parents succeed.
They also want to put the issue of widespread divorce back on the public policy agenda. Divorce laws, they argue, should be changed to ensure the economic support of children.
If that sounds conservative, communitarians sound liberal when proposing European-style child benefits, extended paid and unpaid parental leaves and flexible working hours.
From kindergarten to college, the communitarians argue, schools should make moral education and character formation leading priorities, rejecting the idea that Americans are so divided over basic values that moral education is impossible. Classroom instruction, they add, is less effective than the personal example set by educators and the atmosphere of the institutions.
An increased sense of public safety and order, stronger local government and renewed public spiritedness are other communitarian interests.
 
No 10-Point Program
 To achieve these ends, the group considers ideas from both liberal and conservative toolkits: informal social pressure on personal behavior, government funding of political campaigns and access to television, national service for young people and strict limits on gun ownership. But there is no 10-point program to which all communitarians agree. Some people view it more as a mood than a movement. "I see it simply as "a fresh way of talking and listening," said Mary Ann Glendon, a professor at the Harvard Law School, "an effort to break out of well-worn mental grooves and get a conversation going about things that aren't being addressed."
Professor Glendon helped formulate the group's platform, published in The Responsive Community, a quarterly journal founded -- "with some reluctance," Dr. Etzioni said -- to explore communitarian notions.
The signers of the platform include educators, feminists, former presidential advisers -- Republican and Democratic -- economists, theologians and a least one pollster. Democratic Senators Daniel P. Moynihan of New York and Al Gore of Tennessee and Republican Senator David Durenberger of Minnesota joined in a teach-in on Capitol Hill last year. Secretary of Housing Jack Kemp has also signaled his interest.
Like Ross Perot, the communitarian impulse appears to have surfaced out of a dissatisfaction with the alternatives. And like Mr. Perot, this neophyte movement has yet to define itself on many tough issues.
Its amorphousness has led critics on the right to dismiss communitarianism as merely warmed-over Great Society, while critics on the left fear it as the thin edge of the Moral Majority or a retreat to the 1950's.
"A lot of communitarian rhetoric appears to emphasize voluntary measures," said Nadine Strossen, president of the American Civil Liberties Union. "But that rhetoric is very slippery," she added, when it involves government in creating legal obstacles to divorce, indoctrinating through the public schools or giving police more leeway to search suspects.
Joan W. Konner, dean of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism, puzzled over communitarianism at a dinner preceding last week's teach-in. It appeared to be one part church sermon, one part reassertion of old values, one part political campaign message and one part social movement, Dean Konner said.
The implicit criticism left Dr. Etzioni unfazed. "I couldn't have said it better myself," he replied.

HEADLINE: Conversations/Sergio Munoz;
An Invisible Presence Grows In the Barrios of Los Angeles

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
THE only decoration on the wall of Sergio Munoz's new office as executive news director of KMEX television is a color-coded map showing the density of the Hispanic population of Los Angeles by zip codes.
"This is the real story, as shown on this map," he said the other day, starting to speak before a visitor had time to take a seat. "You can see it very clearly. The growth of the Latino population is a fact of life. But if you look at the power structure, look at the social structure, look at the government, it's not there. From the outside, it's some sort of ghost, and it frightens people." 
Los Angeles has just passed through a social convulsion, a riot that shouted the message of economic inequalities in its inner city, but even now the huge Hispanic population remains something of a ghost as public attention is focused on the anger and the needs of the black community. Yet the focus of the recent rioting, Los Angeles's South Central section, is home to an almost even mix of black and Hispanic residents.
"Yes, the spark was black. It was the failure of the justice system to serve minorities, which is something Latinos can identify with," Mr. Munoz said, taking his seat at last. "The trigger was black. But the underlying reality was the interracial, inter-ethnic tensions of life in the inner city."
As an administrator and executive editor of La Opinion, the city's largest Spanish-language daily, for 12 years until last January, and as executive news director of its largest Spanish-language television station for the last four months, Mr. Munoz has observed the fast and silent expansion of the city's Hispanic population. Over the decade beginning in 1980, it swelled by 70 percent, from 816,000 to 1.4 million, and now comprises approximately 40 percent of the city's population of 3.7 million.
"There was a transformation we went through from an invisible community to a problem community, because we were either causing the problems or we were the victims of the problems, or both," Mr. Munoz said. "This fight for recognition has been very tough; very, very tough. Many people would say we haven't been as discriminated against as blacks, though if you go through the barrios you hear a lot of horror stories. The problem is how to gain access to institutions, how to become known as anything else but problem people."
 
Rapid Growth
 The first step is for the Hispanic community to know itself, but its rapid growth, intertwining a number of national histories, has outpaced the capacity of even its own leaders and public figures, like Mr. Munoz, to take its measure. In addition to the massive influx from neighboring Mexico, which has mushroomed in the last decade and a half, the growth since the 1970's has included a continuing wave of refugees from war and economic dislocation throughout Central America.
"I was once asked how it was to be the editor of a newspaper that is trying to cater to so many groups, to Nicaraguans, Salvadorans, Mexicans," Mr. Munoz said. "My answer was, that's not the worst part. The worst part is trying to please a community that is fragmented even within these groups. On the newspaper itself there were Sandinistas and Contras, and all the Argentinians that were for the Sandinistas and all the Chileans on the other side."
Drawn first to the traditional Mexican-American neighborhoods of East Los Angeles, the various national groups have radiated outward through the center of the city, their progress traced in the red, purple and green that show their density on Mr. Munoz's map. Many of them displaced and mingled with the black population of the South Central area.
When the rioting exploded, Mr. Munoz said, he was among the leading Hispanic figures who gathered to call for calm, only to discover that they did not know the names of any Hispanic community leaders in the South Central area. "What we learned was that there are all these people who are not represented anywhere," he said. "So now we are going to have to go down to the streets and talk to the people and see who they are, what they want, where they come from, who represents them and how they are planning to make their lives there."
A conversation in Mr. Munoz's small, spare office is interrupted constantly as he turns to speak on the telephone, gets up to make coffee or takes "just three minutes, please," to explain an assignment to one of his reporters. Born and raised in Mexico, educated in Mexico, Great Britain and the United States, Mr. Munoz, who is 50 years old, was a student of philosophy, then of film, then of literature before joining La Opinion as a journalist. At KMEX, he is the West Coast bureau chief of the nation's largest Spanish-language network, Univision, which is based in Miami. In the aftermath of the riot, he has been called upon to join the Ad Hoc Unity Coalition, political and community leaders gathered together to represent the needs of the Hispanic community in the city's economic recovery.
Today he took three minutes to discuss with a reporter a series of interviews with political candidates in which they would be asked, on behalf of the station's Hispanic audience, what difference the race for state Senate would make in their lives. For much of his audience, which can be as large as 300,000 viewers, political enfranchisement is a question that seems to lie well beyond their daily concerns. But in fact, Mr. Munoz said, it is at the heart of the pressures that exploded in the violence of the riots.
 
Explaining the Fires
 For the most part, the more established residents -- the homeowners, the extended families, the tight-knit neighborhoods -- of East Los Angeles stayed out of the rioting that swept through the South Central area.
"How do you explain the fires?" Mr. Munoz said, leafing through figures from the 1990 census. "Let's see how many of these people in South Central own their own homes: 62 percent of the houses in South Central are rented. Of this same population, 28.5 percent have less than a ninth grade education. You have 32 percent of the population under the poverty line, and what is really terrifying, 44 percent of the very poor people are children under the age of 18."
Many of these are the poor immigrants and their children who make up the bulk of the city's Hispanic population -- people Mr. Munoz described as sleeping in crowded rented garages, speaking little English and working for the mimumum wage or below.
People like this, he said, had little incentive to protect their communities from destruction and little to motivate them to preserve a social order in which they play little role. "You see all these people coming into stores and getting mattresses and getting Pampers. Are you going to hold onto your ethics and say, 'I'm not going to participate in this?' I really doubt it."
But as the red areas at the center of Mr. Munoz's map spread outward from East Los Angeles through the purple and into the green, and as the varied Hispanic communities put down roots and find their leaders, the little-noticed ghost will take more tangible form. "It seems that people on the East Coast, and many here in the West, still do not understand that things are no longer black and white here," Mr. Munoz said. "This is now a very complex interracial economic war."
