HEADLINE: Official Summer Outlook Calls for Clean Shores and Big Crowds

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON

 BODY:
From Mystic to Cape May, from Fire Island to the Thousand Islands, the New York region is approaching the summer of 1992 with an optimism unseen in recent years, anticipating clean beaches and big crowds.
Just as a blast of hot weather this week quickly burned off the chill of a cold spring, officials are hopeful that their expanding fight against ocean pollution will result in a second straight trouble-free beach season, further dimming memories of the beach closing in 1987 and 1988 prompted by the washup of medical waste and other pollution problems. 
 The tourism industry, meanwhile, sees signs that people are shaking off the recession and taking more vacations. Many campgrounds are full this Memorial Day weekend, state park officials say. A survey of New Jersey resort rentals and hotel reservations show bookings are ahead of last year's pace, and New York City, buoyed by the upcoming Democratic National Convention and other events, is expecting a strong rebound from a bad 1991.
"There's a pent-up demand for travel," said Eugene Dilbeck, director of the New Jersey Division of Travel and Tourism. "I don't think there's any doubt we'll have excellent numbers. But the key will be how much they contribute to the economy on their trips. People are still budget-minded."
 
Heading for the Beach
 As the three-day holiday weekend began yesterday, temperatures climbed into the 90's, and hundreds of thousands of people jammed the highways and flocked to beaches, parks and shady retreats.
The temperature reached 92 in New York yesterday afternoon, short of the 94 degree record for the date set in 1964, but still hot enough for Gene Salerno, a National Weather Service meteorologist, to call it the best beach day of the weekend. Today was expected to be mostly cloudy, with a high in the 70's, and tomorrow's forecast called for a high in the low 60's.
After a drizzly spring, yesterday was like a light-speed jump to the middle of summer, and thousands of people seemed eager to get off to a fast start to the do-nothing season.
"It's Fourth of July weather," Milton Berger said as he looked out over vast crowds sprawled on the beach and strolling on the boardwalk and in the amusement areas at Coney Island, where he promotes the heart-stopping roller coaster known as the Cyclone and other attractions. "It's hot, but it's comfortable," he added. "It's air-conditioned by the Atlantic Ocean."
At Jones Beach, on the South Shore of Long Island, the Long Island State Park Commission estimated that more than 100,000 people were on the sand and in the surf. Scores of other Long Island beaches were open and crowded yesterday, though numbers were not available.
New Jersey's 127 miles of ocean beaches were also jammed yesterday, and the Greater Atlantic County Convention and Visitors Bureau estimated that two million people would be on the shore beaches during the three-day weekend.
In New York City, Parks Commissioner Betsy Gotbaum pronounced the city's 15 miles of freshly cleaned beaches "fabulous." And Dr. Margaret Hamburg, the city's Health Commissioner, said water quality had improved enough to permit swimming at Midland and South Beaches on Staten Island for the first time in 20 years.
Along the Jersey Shore, there is a resurgent confidence about ocean waters that only a few years ago evoked suspicion and fear in many people as sewage spills closed some beaches and dolphins died of a mysterious infection.
"I've been surfing here for 12 years, and this year it looks better than ever," Glenn Hamill said as he and his 7-year-old daughter, Amy, braved the cold surf in Seabright, N.J., on Friday. "It's the cleanest I've ever seen it."
Officials warn, however, that much of their hope for a successful summer depends the weather. The season got off to a slow start because the cold spring kept ocean temperatures under 50 degrees, and a summer of rain could ruin hopes for both clean beaches and crowded resorts.
Environmental officials are proud of their efforts to prevent or quickly clean up pollution from sewage-treatment plants and floating debris, whether spilled garbage, carelessly discarded syringes or rotting pier timbers.
Helicopters patrol New York Harbor and the shoreline south, watching for slicks of debris, and cleanup crews are sent out after moon tides and rain, which wash trash from the shore into the water.
 
Reducing Garbage Spills
 New York City has greatly reduced garbage spills by covering barges on their way to the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island, laying booms around docking areas and sending out skimmer boats to pick up what does spill.
The Army Corps of Engineers is continuing to remove rotting piers from the Arthur Kill and New Jersey has continued a shoreline cleanup in which prison inmates, in their first two months this year, picked up 1,600 tons of timbers and other trash along 18 miles of waterfront.
In March 1991, New Jersey stopped dumping sewage sludge at sea, meeting its own deadline, and New York City is taking steps to end its sludge dumping by a June 30 Federal deadline.
As a result of these efforts, only one beach in New York and New Jersey was closed last summer because of washed-up debris.
 
More Difficult Tasks
 But officials say the easiest, most obvious steps to prevent pollution have been taken. Continued progress, they say, depends on two difficult long-term tasks: spending billions of dollars to separate sewer lines and storm drains so that rainwater can no longer overwhelm sewage-treatment plants; and educating the public that even flicking away a cigarette butt on a city street can result in a dirty beach.
Margaret Randol, a spokeswoman for the regional office of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, said a study done for New York City estimated that as many as 1.2 million "floatables" -- anything from a cigarette butt to a log -- may enter New York Harbor each month.
More than 80 percent of that debris, she said, comes from sewer overflows or is flushed out of storm drains by rain runoff. The runoff can also carry animal feces, oil, chemicals and other pollutants.
Environmental agencies have begun a campaign to tell the public how litter and other waste can be flushed out to sea and end up on beaches.
"Back in 1987 and 1988, a lot of people thought much of the beach wash-ups were materials dumped illegally," Ms. Randol said. "But our research showed that was not the case. Much of it was just stuff from the streets."
 
Shorter Trips
 A relatively dry summer will help beaches by limiting the rain that can overwhelm sewage-treatment plants and flush out storm drains.
Despite the recession, officials say, people are determined to take vacations, and if they continue a trend toward more day trips and shorter, though more frequent, vacations, that should mean good business for resorts surrounding the New York area, with its 20 million people.
"The indications are that people will travel more by car, take shorter trips, and are going to be thrifty," said Joseph Cohen, a spokesman for the Connecticut Department of Economic Development. "That works extremely well for Connecticut tourist attractions, but it does mean that some parts of the industry will have to work harder."
A New Jersey survey of shore resorts found summer rentals and hotel reservations as much as 10 percent to 15 percent ahead of last year. Rental agents on Long Island also report an improvement over 1991.
This optimism comes even as New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have cut back on their promotion of tourism because of budget problems.

HEADLINE: Inflation Outpaced Doctors' Income in '90

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CHICAGO, May 23

 BODY:
Doctors' average income rose $8,500 in 1990, to $164,300, according to a study by the American Medical Association.
The 5.5 percent increase over the 1989 average of $155,800 was less than the 6.1 percent rate of inflation that year. 
 Surgeons had the highest salaries, averaging $236,400, and radiologists were next, at $219,400. Lowest-paid were general practitioners and family practitioners, who averaged $102,700 and $106,500, respectively.
As in previous years, rural doctors earned less than their urban colleagues, averaging $130,500, compared with $163,300 for doctors in areas with more than a million residents. Doctors in metropolitan areas with less than a million people earned an average of $172,700.
The study also found that doctors in the depressed New England region averaged $142,500, $21,800 less than the national average. Doctors fared best in the region comprising Texas, Louisiana, Arkansas and Oklahoma, where pay averaged $178,800.
The figures were issued Wednesday in the A.M.A.'s Socioeconomic Monitoring System Report. The A.M.A. monitors, based in Chicago, surveyed more than 4,000 doctors practicing at least 20 hours a week, but excluded those employed by the Federal Government.

HEADLINE: Nautical Question Decides Geography Bee

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23

 BODY:
With a perfect record in two days of competition, 13-year-old Lawson Fite of Vancouver, Wash., won the National Geography Bee on Thursday.
Lawson, an eighth grader at Shumway Middle School, won after a tight battle with Geoffrey Hatchard, 13, of Cresco, Pa. 
 The deciding match came when the boys were asked to identify the initials E.E.Z., described as the areas that extend 200 nautical miles from the shore of many coastal countries that claim sovereign rights over those areas for resource exploration.
Lawson said "Exclusive Economic Zone." Geoffrey, who had already missed an earlier question, said "Environmental Economic Zones."
Nearly six million students in the sixth through the eighth grades competed in the various levels of the 1992 National Geography Bee. The 57 finalists, who began the last round of competition here on Wednesday, represented the 50 states, the District of Columbia, Defense Department schools and five American territories.
The Geography Bee's sponsors are National Geographic World, the National Geographic Society's magazine for children, and Amtrak, the nation's intercity passenger railroad.
As the winner, Lawson gets a $25,000 college scholarship and round-trip, first-class tickets for four to any Amtrak destination.

HEADLINE: European Nations Preparing for Penalties Against Serbia;
Belgrade Is Silent

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 23

 BODY:
The Bush Administration's move to increase pressure on the Yugoslav Government was met with official silence here today. But continued fighting by Serbian forces in Bosnia pointed to a determination not to yield to the threat of tightening sanctions.
Mr. Milosevic's Government appeared to be watching closely to see how far the European Community's members would go in pressing new economic sanctions. 
 A senior adviser to Mr. Milosevic, Zeljko Simic, described the latest American moves as "undemocratic," because the United States, ge argued, had singled out Serbia for punishment and taken no action against Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia or Slovenia.
Although the American steps have a deep resonance here, their effect seems to be largely political, as they focused on increasing Serbia's diplomatic isolation.
If sanctions are to have a major practical effect, diplomats here in Belgrade say, they will have to come from the European Community, since it is with Europe that Serbia and Montenegro have the bulk of their trade.
The only new American measure that had a direct effect on the Serbian economy was the decision to suspend flights by the Yugoslav national airline, JAT, to New York and Chicago, And the effect of that was likely to be small, as long as Canada permitted the airline to continue twice-weekly flights to Montreal and Toronto.
If the European nations adopt any of the measures that have been discussed by senior European Community officials in recent days, including a trade embargo, a freeze on assets, or an oil embargo, the effect would be more severe. But few diplomats here believe that economic sanctions are likely to decisively change the Serbian Government's course on Bosnia.
They say that the Serbian economy was severely damaged by the fighting last year in Croatia and Slovenia, and more so by the more recent Bosnian warfare. Despite this damage, they say, Mr. Milosevic has shown no sign yet of subordinating his Serbian nationalist goals to economic considerations.

HEADLINE: MAY 17-23: Dropouts;
Truant Officers or Jobs Are Keeping Them in School

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
So much fretting goes on over the state of the nation's schools and the ignorance of American students that it's easy to miss the good news that sometimes comes along.
Last week, New York City, the nation's largest school system, reported a sharp drop in its dropout rate. And the Council of Great City Schools, comprising the 47 largest systems, said New York was leading a nationwide revival; two-thirds of its members also kept more students in school. New York did particularly well in comparisons of how many students quit last year: 6.8 percent versus 16 percent in Los Angeles and 13.2 percent in Chicago. 
 Many educators, including New York's Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez, believe high schools are learning how to hang on to youngsters for up to seven years until they graduate. Expensive programs that chase and counsel truant and failing students are finally paying off -- some schools even have machines that dial students' homes with taped messages saying they are absent. Diane Ravitch, an Assistant United States Secretary of Education, also thinks more rigorous academic requirements have shown students that they are being taken seriously.
But even Mr. Fernandez credited part of his success to the scarcity of jobs luring students away. The painful paradox is that if a revived economy were to give Mr. Fernandez the money to improve schools it might also beguile more students to drop out.

HEADLINE: A Blueprint of the Future Along the Hudson River

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
In the three decades since the West Side piers bristled with waterborne commerce, New York City has been trying to revive the decaying Hudson River shoreline. For the most part, the efforts have produced one failed plan after another, seemingly as numerous as the stark pilings that mark the voids where piers once stood.
But in the last few weeks, a series of proposals and decisions have come forth that have the potential for remaking much of the West Side waterfront, from Battery Park City to West 72d Street. 
 As a result, it is possible to sketch a conceptual tour of Manhattan's future Hudson River shoreline, where parks and recreational piers may someday alternate with massive low-rise structures and tall towers.
None of these visions may come to pass, since complicated political and financial obstacles must be crossed. And any of the projects that get built will almost certainly have been altered by the time the ribbons are cut.
But there has been movement.
 
A Series of Announcements
 On Monday, city planners certified that Donald J. Trump's proposal for a new riverfront neighborhood from 59th to 72d Street, called Riverside South, was ready for public review.
Then Gov. Mario M. Cuomo signed an agreement with Mayor David N. Dinkins on a plan to redevelop the shoreline from Battery Park City to 59th Street. The prime agent would be the Hudson River Park Conservancy, a subsidiary of the state Urban Development Corporation and successor to the West Side Waterfront Panel, which drew up the redevelopment plans. The director-designate is Tom Fox, executive director of the Neighborhood Open Space Coalition.
And on Friday, three bids were accepted by the state Transportation Department for the redevelopment of the Chelsea Piers, with proposals that included ice-skating rinks, studios, a marina and a yachting school.
Earlier this month, the State Court of Appeals cleared a major legal obstacle from the path of a proposed development by Larry A. Silverstein on the waterfront at 42d Street. And early next month, the North Park at Battery Park City is to open to the public, creating a pedestrian route along the water's edge from the financial district to TriBeCa.
 
Many Questions Raised
 Imagining the future of the West Side waterfront, Barbara J. Fife, the deputy mayor for planning and development, said: "You would have a ribbon of green going all the way up. It will probably be the most spectacular waterfront in the world. It will certainly be the most significant."
Critics and skeptics abound, however. There are also fears that the commercial and residential development could have significant unwanted impacts on the environment and on existing neighborhoods.
"We're very, very much for the ribbon of green," said Marcy Benstock, executive director of the Clean Air Campaign. "Instead, what's being proposed is to defer the park into the 21st century while holding the waterfront for real-estate speculation."
And Ruth W. Messinger, Borough President of Manhattan, said, "To be talking too terribly seriously about which elements do or do not belong on the waterfront, meet current housing needs or fit with the ambience of the West Side begs the big-ticket question: What the hell are they going to do with the sewage?"
The debate has only begun. But if the projects are to happen as now envisioned, a trip up the West Side might unfold like this:
 
BATTERY-FINANCIAL DISTRICT
 Battery Park, at the tip of Manhattan, would be given new life under a $22-million reconstruction that would, among other things, extend the greenery closer to the water's edge and expand it to and across adjacent streets. But there is no money budgeted for this project.
Another plan calls for the conversion of the historic Pier A into restaurants and a visitor's center.
At the tip of Battery Park City, a design team has been hired to plan South Park. The proposed Living Memorial to the Holocaust-Museum of Jewish Heritage would be nearby.
The eight-acre North Park, with lawns, basketball courts and handball courts, a continuation of the esplanade, a lookout pavilion, a playground and a lily pool, is to open June 4. Stuyvesant High School nearby is to open in September.
 
TRIBECA
 Between Stuyvesant High School and Pier 25, the waterfront panel has proposed an area for court games such as basketball and tennis. Piers 25 and 26 would be open to the public.
An "ecological" park would stretch from Pier 26 to Canal Street. This park would be bordered at the north by a new pier running to the ventilating shaft for the Holland Tunnel.
 
GREENWICH VILLAGE
 The waterfront panel has designated Pier 40, at Houston Street, a 16-acre structure with a awarehouse and garage, as one of three major building sides. The panel specified a maximum development of 1.775 million square feet -- 1.535 million square feet residential and 240,000 square feet commercial -- and a maximum building height of 85 feet (eight or nine stories). But it left open the question of whether Pier 40 would be best used commercially or residentially. Under the densest residential scenario, there would be about 1,700 apartments.
A park, punctuated by four public recreation piers, would stretch from Leroy to Gansevoort Street.
CHELSEA
The second major development site proposed by the waterfront panel involves three of the four Chelsea Piers. On June 15, the state is to announce the winner of Friday's auction, which involves a 10-year lease. The longer-term future could hold a rehabilitation of the existing structure or large-scale construction involving 720,000 square feet of new residential space (about 800 units) and 110,000 square feet of renovated commercial space.
To the north the panel has proposed an eight-acre Chelsea Waterside Park, which it called the "largest and most active recreation area" between Battery Park City and Riverside South. The park would be bounded roughly by 11th Avenue and the river, 21st and 24th Streets, and bisected by Route 9A. Piers at the north and south ends of the park would be open to the public.
 
CONVENTION CENTER-CLINTON
 Pier 66, at the foot of 26th Street, would be used as a heliport, under the panel's plan. A waterfront park would follow, to 35th Street. East of this park is the Caemmerer West Side Yard, used by the Long Island Rail Road, above which the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has envisioned office and apartment towers and a hotel, in a project now dormant.
On Pier 76, now a tow pound, a development team headed by Julien J. Studley has proposed the Hudson River Center, a hotel of approximately 40 stories, linked by bridge to the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. Those plans, too, seem moribund.
The third of the development sites proposed by the waterfront panel would be Piers 81, 83 and 84, where a commercial complex might be built, offering berths for cruise and charter boats, as well as dining and entertainment. There would be an amphitheater between Piers 83 and 84.
To the east of this site is a full block owned by Silverstein Properties, which has been devising a 1.6-million-square-foot commercial, residential and institutional project. The required rezoning was upheld by the state's highest court May 5 against an environmental challenge by neighborhood residents.
Mr. Fox said that no more than two of the three piers of the New York City Passenger Ship Terminal complex are needed today.
The Clinton waterfront park would run between Piers 94 and 97, with the two intervening piers demolished.
 
UPPER WEST SIDE
 With that, Mr. Trump's Riverside South project would begin. At the southern end of the site would be an enormous commercial structure, two blocks wide, with 1.8 million square feet of studio space and two 30-story office towers at the eastern end.
Sixteen apartment buildings, up to 49 stories tall, would stretch from 59th to 72d Street. All told, there would be 5,700 housing units and a population of about 10,550.
A 22-acre park is the centerpiece of this proposal, which Mr. Trump undertook with six civic organizations. But the park depends on the relocation of the West Side Highway from its elevated riverfront viaduct to a curving inland route. That, like so many assumptions behind the visions of the waterfront, is eagerly awaited but far from a sure thing.

 CORRECTION:
A map legend last Sunday about proposals for rebuilding the West Side waterfront referred incompletely to the areas shown. The shading marked areas proposed for recreation and park development as well as for real estate development.

HEADLINE: VOWS;
Kathy Phillips and Jake Daehler

BYLINE: By Lois Smith Brady

 BODY:
WHEN Jake Daehler, a 33-year-old actor, met Kathy Phillips, a 31-year-old actress and bike messenger, it was not love but fear at first sight.
"We met four years ago in an acting class," Mr. Daehler said. "Kathy was this totally wild person. She hitchhiked. She went hang gliding. She ran with the bulls in Spain. I remember I saw her on the street once: She was on her bike, smoking a cigarette and wearing this nutty Mary Poppins hat and a cat suit. I thought, 'She's cute but probably criminally insane.' " 
 Mr. Daehler is the opposite: a self-described Felix Unger type who always uses a place mat at dinner and drove a station wagon when he was a teen-ager. "I love his manners and his control," Mrs. Daehler said. "He loves my out-of-control."
Last Saturday they were married at the Biodome, a loft-and-rooftop space in a brownstone on East 34th Street in Manhattan. The Rev. Claire North performed the rooftop ceremony, which was written partly by Mr. Daehler and included lines like: "Your journey together has often been bumpy, especially in the last couple of weeks" and "This marriage is truly a testament to the effectiveness of the psychoanalytic process." (Both Mr. and Mrs. Daehler are in couples therapy, group therapy and psychoanalysis.)
After they were pronounced "wife and husband," most of the guests headed down to the loft, but Patricia Scanlon, a playwright, lingered. Wearing a black-velvet dress and lavender boots, she said: "That was such a funny, unpretentious ceremony. It was so Jake and Kathy. They didn't hide the fact that having a relationship is tough stuff."
The bride, who was also on the roof, suddenly lifted her Victorian dress to reveal brown lace-up boots, neon-green socks, a garter belt and a snake tattoo on her right thigh.
In the loft, many of the guests were under 40 and simpatico -- man or woman -- with the Julia Roberts or Darryl Hannah philosophy of dressing: mismatched skirts and tops, cowboy boots, thrift-shop jackets and retro eyeglasses.
Guy Veryzer, a ceramics artist, wore six medallions picturing Greek gods around his neck. "They're my past lives," he explained. Several people introduced themselves using slashes, as in "I'm a stand-up comic slash photographer slash aerobics instructor."
At one point, Mr. Daehler gave a speech in honor of his new wife. He quoted a J. D. Salinger story in which the narrator advises the reader, "Never marry no ordinary dame. . . ."
During dinner -- vegetarian lasagna and Caesar salad -- most of the guests gathered in the kitchen, where there was the kind of camaraderie you might find in the smoky back room of a small-town cafe. Everyone drank wine out of plastic cups and used paper plates.
"This is a very Bush, very recession, no-frills wedding," said Ben Dimmitt, a photographer. "It's just a bunch of people sitting around seeing each other."
Before the carrot cake was cut, the bride and groom's psychotherapists each delivered toasts. The groom's therapist began: "When I first met Jake, he used to dream he was bald. This obviously did not correspond with any reality."
She added: "But Kathy is perfect for Jake. He is now a guy who no longer feels bald."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kathy Phillips and Jake Daehler at the Biodome, May 16 (Edward Keating/The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Personal Finances;
Perot Reneged on Pledge to Reagan

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KELLY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23

 BODY:
A little more than a year after pledging $2.5 million to support President Ronald Reagan's official library, in thanks for the President's "years of outstanding leadership and service," Ross Perot reneged on most of the pledge in 1987 because he apparently was angry over what he saw as a lack of interest in American servicemen missing in Southeast Asia.
The episode suggests the importance of Mr. Perot's experiences with the prisoner-of-war and missing-in-action issue in changing his feelings toward the Reagan Administration and then Vice President George Bush, whom Mr. Perot now seeks to replace in the White House. 
 Mr. Perot's financial involvement with the $60 million Ronald Reagan Presidential Library began March 6, 1986, when he wrote a letter to President and Mrs. Reagan at the White House, saying that his family had decided to support the privately financed library because Mr. Reagan had been "such a great President."
 
A Letter of Superlatives
 His family, Mr. Perot wrote to Mr. Reagan, had asked him to:
"Thank you for making us proud to be Americans again.
"Thank you for your leadership in lifting our nation's sense of destiny above the day-to-day problems that surround us.
"Thank you for reminding us that we are our brothers' keeper, and that we must help one another.
"As the leader of the free world, thank you for keeping us at peace.
"Thank you for stabilizing the economy, dramatically reducing inflation, and interest rates and creating an environment where most Americans have secure, stable jobs."
Mr. Perot went on to thank Nancy Reagan for her "great work in caring for the families of the men who were prisoners of war in Vietnam and for mobilizing the nation to protect children from drugs."
He then wrote that "the Perot family pledges $2.5 million to the Reagan Library to thank and honor both of you for your years of outstanding leadership and service to our nation and the world,"
 
Pressing Interest in P.O.W.'s
 Mr. Perot donated $500,000 as an initial payment toward his pledge, James Squires, the spokesman for Mr. Perot Presidential drive, said today and left $2 million outstanding.
At the time, Mr. Perot was passionately concerned with the P.O.W.-M.I.A. issue. For years he had held a strong view that American servicemen, perhaps hundreds of them, were secretly held prisoner in Southeast Asia and that American officials knew this but were unwilling, for various reasons, to act on it.
Mr. Perot discussed the matter with Vice President Bush, and he has said, in interviews, that Mr. Bush asked him to conduct a study of Government P.O.W.-M.I.A files, to determine if American officials were doing a good job. His search led him into confrontations with Federal officials over the best strategy for negotiating with Vietnam to win the release of any Americans still held captive and the remains of those American prisoners who had died in North and South Vietnam.
 
Crucial Visit to Hanoi
 In March 1987, Mr. Perot went to Hanoi, Vietnam, to continue his work on the issue, a trip he has said in previous interviews that he undertook with the blessing of the White House.
That trip, and his disappointment in the Government's reaction to it, was the turning point in Mr. Perot's relationship with the Reagan Administration and led directly to the cancellation of his pledge to the Reagan library.
"Perot came back convinced that we could deal effectively with the Vietnamese," Mr. Squires said, "but he found when he returned that the Reagan Administration would not take the trip seriously. He gave a report to the Reagan Administration criticizing its policies and soon after that he canceled his pledges."
Mr. Perot could not be reached today to discuss the issue. According to an account in The Washington Post last month, he has said he reneged on the pledge because of his disgust over the Iran-contra affair, which began to come to light in November 1986, and not because of the P.O.W-M.I.A. issue
Mr. Squires said Mr. Perot "became unhappy with Reagan and Bush" for several reasons, including the matter of arms sales to Iran and undercover aid to the Nicaraguan rebels. But he added that Mr. Perot's anger over the Administration's handling of the P.O.W.-M.I.A. issue and its response to his trip to Hanoi were central to his turning against the President he had so highly praised the year before.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ross Perot reneged on most of the $2.5 million he pledged to support President Reagan's official library in 1987 because he was angry over the lack of interest in American servicemen missing in Southeast Asia. The former President was congratulated after he spoke during the dedication of the library in 1991 by, from left, Barbara Bush, President Bush and Nancy Reagan. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Biography

COMPANY: REAGAN, RONALD, PRESIDENTIAL LIBRARY REAGAN ADMINISTRATION (74%); GOVERNMENT P O W-M I A (63%); RONALD REAGAN PRESIDENTIAL LIBRARY (62%); 

ORGANIZATION: REAGAN, RONALD, PRESIDENTIAL LIBRARY

GEOGRAPHIC: UNITED STATES (97%); SOUTH-EASTERN ASIA (94%); ASIA (94%); VIET NAM (92%);

SECTION: Section 8; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1255 words

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
A Downtown Started for Rural Retirees

BYLINE: By LYN RIDDLE

DATELINE: SANTEE, S.C.

 BODY:
Like many rural areas around the nation, this town of 650 people has seen hundreds of retirees move in in recent years, not only to specially designed retirement communities, but also to scattered houses beside Lake Marion or one of three championship golf courses.
Now the town, halfway between Charleston and Columbia, wants to give something special to its new residents: a downtown. Because Santee was built up first as a resort and only later as a retirement community, it has never had what is commonly considered a downtown. 
 So last month, in a cornfield not far from the existing town hall, Santee began grading roads around what will become a village green. The first building in a project that is expected to cost $3 million will be a 3,500-square-foot town hall, which will rise later this year financed by a loan and an expected grant from a South Carolina utility company.
A police station, library, literacy center and a dozen commercial buildings will be built as public and private money becomes available. They will be similar in design to those in Colonial Williamsburg, Va.
While a downtown built from scratch is a rarity, multimillion-dollar projects, from shopping malls to nursing homes to hospitals, have been rising in the nation's small towns to serve the increasing number of retirees now making their homes there.
From Kingstree, S.C., to Guntersville, Ala., to Crossville, Tenn., the Southeast has become especially popular. Its low cost of living, especially for housing, has lured retirees, not only from the North and Middle West, but also from the traditional retirement areas of Florida and Arizona and Hawaii.
"Nobody expected this," said Peg Thompson, whose Huntsville, Ala., consulting firm helps market retirement areas. "Many towns would have drifted away, but these retirees bring the needed energy and intelligence to a dying town."
Analysts say 32 million people in the United States are 65 or older and about 7 percent of retirees move after quitting work. Mrs. Thompson said a large percentage of them are moving to the "sticks," either to a retirement community centered on some sort of leisure activity, like Santee, or to a small town, like Kingstree, S.C..
Bill Irish, who retired in 1984 after a career selling railway supplies, came here from Franklinville, N.J., looking for good fishing and occasional golf, but has since become the principal fund-raiser for Santee's downtown project.
"I recall getting up one morning and seeing snow and I thought it was time to get away from all that," he said. He and his wife, Catherine, paid about $90,000 for a 1,200-square-foot house in Bradford Village, a retirement community with a pool, clubhouse and tennis courts. The 110 houses there, all sold, were priced from $85,000 to $110,000.
There are two other housing developments. Santee Resort with 244 one-family houses and a golf-course was built and sold over the last two decades; Chapel Creek Plantation, with a mix of 350 one-family houses and patio homes, is now under construction. Eleven houses and 40 lots have been sold. Its golf course has been completed, but houses are being built only after the lots are sold.
Nevertheless, the town remains little more than an interchange on Interstate 95, about halfway between New York and Miami. Long home to cotton and wheat farmers, its development began in the 1940's with a handful of small motels and some restaurants designed to cater to the New York-to-Miami travelers. Fishermen trying to snare the landlocked striped bass, a freshwater game fish, from Lake Marion brought more development, then, later, the retirees brought still more.
Because growth was unplanned, it became a "hodgepodge commercial area," including an outlet shopping mall, some stand-alone small stores and restaurants, said Bill Clark, a local architect who donated the plans and part of the land for the downtown and is chairman of the Main Street Project. He broached the idea of fixing up the old town hall several years ago after seeing how seedy it looked on a local television report.
"Now the plans have turned into something that is right big and grand," said Mr. Clark, who built Chapel Creek Plantation as well as Santee National Golf Course.
Added Mr. Irish: "The growth possibilities are enormous once we get the downtown built." A state study showed that once the downtown is completed it will draw even more tourists and retirees and create 5,000 jobs and $110 million in new revenue. Already, a million tourists come here each year.
All the developments here have been built by local companies, but some national firms, among them Cooper Communities of Bella Vista, Ark., have grown into lucrative businesses by building retirement villages in rural areas with scenic attractions.
Cooper Communities built three resorts in the Ozarks in Arkansas and one in Tennessee and its newest development is now rising in McCormick, a small town in southwestern South Carolina. There, nearly 50 homes have been built over the last two years on the Lake Thurmond shore. When finished, the development will have 6,000 lots, ranging in price from $7,000 to $136,000.
Mrs. Thompson said this type of development has probably reached its peak as a result of lenders' misgivings about real estate projects in general. Large companies with the ability to finance their own projects will be the only ones developing in the 90's, she said.
"There will be no large-scale resort development until the baby boomers hit 50," she said.
Small towns, meanwhile, have been equally successful in luring retirees, even without specially designed retirement communities.
Pat Mason, the executive director of the South Carolina Retirement Association, said one of the main necessities cited by retirees is not golf, tennis or high-living, but walking paths.
"And what do small towns offer?" he said. "Sidewalks. Small towns are not going to get much industry, that's just a fact, but retirement can be one of the things that can add magnetism to a town's growth."
With 4,000 residents, Kingstree remains a quaint Southern town with antebellum homes and a bustling Main Street. It's newest citizens are retirees, many of whom discovered the town through an advertisement in Modern Maturity, the magazine of the American Association of Retired Persons.
About 550 inquiries were received, and perhaps 10 people moved to the town, which was settled in 1732 by makers of ship's masts who found in the Black River basin stands of tall, straight pine trees. Kingstree is about 45 miles due west of Myrtle Beach.
Mr. Mason's group says 10 retirees have the same effect on the economy as a company employing five people. Surveys show that the average retiree spends $135,000 on a house and deposits $22,000 into the local bank.
Other towns have had similar success. In Guntersville, population 7,000, about 25 retirees have moved in to take advantage of low housing costs. A typical house on Lake Guntersville, about 35 miles south of Huntsville, costs $65,000, although much larger lakefront homes sell for as much as $300,000.
And in Crossville, four retirement communities have been built over the last two decades on a mountain plateau in the center of the state. The town of 7,000 people offers mountain scenery, mild weather and low taxes, according to the Chamber of Commerce.
"There's not a state in the nation without a resort area that has attracted a fair amount of retirees," said Mrs. Thompson. "The big asset is the real estate."

SECTION: Section 13LI; Page 1; Column 3; Long Island Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1580 words

HEADLINE: Returnees' 'Stuff' Overflows Houses

BYLINE: By JUDY GLASS

 BODY:
WHEN Janet Kranik's son, a college student from Northport, arrived home for the summer with a van loaded with a roomful of furniture, a stereo, books, supplies and boxes of clothes, his mother would not let him into the house.
"Don't even stop," Ms. Kranik told her son, instructing him to deposit everything at a nearby storage warehouse. Ms. Kranik recalled how she had spent the prior summer tripping over his things and vying for room. 
 "When they leave home, you get used to having everything in its place and having it stay there," she said. "We had a much more enjoyable visit this time."
Andy Cadel's graduation from the University of Virginia Law School this month was the first in a series of moves that he expects to make in the next few months. Rather than clutter his parents' house in Oceanside with the contents of his apartment at school, he had the mover go directly to GLG Mini-Storage in Island Park, where he rented a 5-foot-by-15-foot space for $76 a month, and "everything fit perfectly," he said.
Mr. Cadel is moving into a studio in Greenwich Village for the summer while he studies for the bar and will then take off on a cross-country motorcycle trip before starting a job at the law firm of Weil, Gotshal & Manges in Manhattan.
"I can peel things out of the bin as I need them," he said, "without dumping onto my parents." On his own for four years, Mr. Cadel said he expected to make one more move, to a larger apartment, in New York City, and "this arrangement gives me a lot of flexibility."
Temporary self-storage warehouses, springing up in many parts of Long Island, are intended to meet the needs of an increasing number of residents who are squeezed for space in their houses or who have become part of the mobile society that relocates frequently. Their use also reflects changing styles of life and real-estate patterns.
Every summer college students coming home to Long Island when they are out of school or leaving local colleges to fly home, use storage centers for temporary safekeeping, said Thomas Hinck, manager of GLG and County Seat Storage in Mineola.
The arrangement is particularly popular with families on the Nassau-Queens border, where cooperatives and condominiums often cannot accommodate additional furniture, said Mark Trifon, owner and manager of Store More in New Hyde Park, who charges $81 a month for a 5-foot by 10-foot space.
Storage warehouses are "a mini-real estate situation," said Janet Kranik, project manager for Public Storage in Northport, part of a nationwide chain with 10 centers in Suffolk County. The renters represent a cross-section of people and adapting to changing circumstances.
Years ago people's lives and living arrangements were more stable and predictable, said Barbara Roberts, a broker at Flynn Realty in Kings Park and a director of the Long Island Board of Realtors.
But traditional ownership cycles have changed in the last 10 years. "In the past," Mrs. Roberts said of housing in her area, "a young couple bought their first three-bedroom home in a development when their children were young. As their income rose and they needed more room for the growing family, they'd move to a four-bedroom colonial north of 25A and sell the small home to another young family. If they really prospered, they'd move up to Fort Salonga, until their teen-agers left the nest."
People nearing retirement who wanted to "downsize" without leaving Long Island often bought smaller houses on the North Fork, Mrs. Roberts said, rather than move to places like Florida, so that they could stay near their adult children and their families. Today, she said, young people cannot afford to buy houses on the Island or, because of high taxes, have to find smaller housing, consolidate their assets or move away.
Faced with the loss of thousands of jobs on the Island, Mrs. Roberts said, younger families are putting job opportunities first and leaving without knowing whether the move is temporary or permanent.
 
Those Overflowing Closets
 For families who move to smaller houses when the children go to college, a major problem may be what to do with closets full of trophies, toys, records and other memorabilia amassed over the years. The children may say, "Dump it," but their parents often refuse. The entire collection is likely to wind up in a warehouse, which will usually accept almost any items that are not hazardous or risky to other renters, said Ms. Kranik, who is a project manager for Public Storage, a year-old warehouse in Northport with 800 units. But storage is not a place for treasures. Insurance is limited.
Some people, although contemplating an ideal retirement home or savoring a future without responsibilities, find that they cannot leave the homestead, after all.
For a variety of reasons, grown children are returning to the family houses with their own children, and many families on Long Island, Mrs. Roberts said, are combining households because they cannot afford to maintain separate houses.
A college graduate would rather spend a low salary on recreation than rent, she said, and married children transferring to out-of-state jobs or dividing assets in divorces often return for weeks, months or years.
Sometimes the surviving spouses of parents who have just died go to live with the families "temporarily," but cannot bear to part with family treasures. "I can't tell you how many houses we inspect that have another full house in the basement," Mrs. Roberts said.
 
Demand for Space
 "What can you do with furniture for two living rooms, two sets of appliances and duplicates of pots, pans and dishes?" asked Joanne Hendricks, an agent for Storage Masters, a warehouse in Huntington.
Storage Masters is expanding its two-year-old site.
"Statistics on consolidation, downsizing and upsizing in the Long Island real-estate market don't exist," Mrs. Roberts said. "It's strictly anecdotal, but the fuel companies and electrical utilities keep track, and we are observing it."
Years ago people may have rejected consolidating or sharing their large houses. But now having done so with family members or noting the increasing number of rentals on Long Island, such moves become more viable solutions.
Prospective tenants who are divorced or were formerly homeowners may deposit their half of the property in a warehouse and move a house. They are not ready to part with their belongings permanently.
Downsizing, or moving to a smaller house, is increasingly a choice for those who want to stay on Long Island and relish their privacy, but no longer want high maintenance costs, said Mrs. Roberts, who moved to a smaller house between marriages.
"I felt independent," she said, "because I could handle the work and still have a home of my own."
"Warehouse space costs a lot less than buying a new home or renting more office space," said Lisa Crane, a marketing manager for Public Storage. The California company has more than 1,000 sites nationwide.
"There was opposition to the facility on Route 25A and Fort Salonga Road in Northport when it was first proposed because it's in a residential neighborhood," Ms. Crane said. "Now it's being used by doctors, dentists and businesses to store inactive files and equipment, as well as by families. Executors of estates sometimes use it as a central location for family members who want access to the effects at almost any time."
 
Few Comforts of Home
 THE rooms for rent have no heat, no light and no ventilation, but there is so much demand for them on Long Island that two buildings with about 1,000 units have been constructed within 15 miles of each other in the last two years.
The storage warehouses in Northport and Huntington can be a practical economical solution for an increasingly migratory population that is moving around on and relocating to the Island, breaking up large family homes to move to smaller residences and coping with the effects of divorces, deaths and departures of the young.
Professionals and businesses use them to store inactive files, and executors use them to centralize effects for visiting family members.
The classified telephone directory lists about 50 public-storage warehouses on the Island, not counting storage at moving companies.
At Storage Masters in Huntington, video cameras scan the long black corridors of metal doors with locks, and no one gains access without a photo-identification card. At Public Storage in Northport, renters enter the gates with cards that register on a computer. If the card is stolen, there will be a record of entry.
Managers live at the site to "keep a high profile," warehousers say. Renters are responsible for locks and access to their units.
A 5 x 10 x 8 room can be rented at Storage Masters for $67.60 a month. At Public Storage, that approximate space rents for about $50 a month. With little variation in price, renters usually choose locations closest to home.
"You can cram a lot in a small space if you're a good stacker," one manager said.
Renters cannot store chemicals, paints or other potentially dangerous materials, but the warehouses do not inspect the items unless there is a suspicious leak or odor.
Warehouses are not places for items that belong in safe-deposit boxes. The warehouses are insured only for damages caused by their negligence. Some homeowners' policies cover possessions off-site. Renters can also purchase insurance.

PUB-DATE: May 24, 1992,

SECTION: Section 13WC; Page 1; Column 3; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1436 words

HEADLINE: Realtors Say the 90's Mood Is Sober

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON

 BODY:
IT began with a wrong turn off a highway. With that and what they have come to call "the souring of their romance with city life." David Nelson and Jazan Higgins, executives with publishing concerns in Manhattan, were driving in the county one Sunday afternoon last spring when they found themselves on Main Street here. The couple recalled coming upon a sleepy village with the charm of a bygone era -- a quaintness, they said, that no amount of money could buy in New York City.
They also remembered looking at pictures of houses for sale in the windows of Peter J. Riolo Inc., a Hastings real-estate concern, and asking each other, "Why not?" 
 That "Why not?" led, they said, to a river view, a five-minute walk to the train station and a 33-minute commute to Grand Central Terminal. Now, after months of renting, they are ready to buy their first home. The couple's price range is in the neighborhood of $300,000, Mr. Nelson said.
 
A Distinctly Different Mood
 But like many other first-time buyers, Mr. Nelson, who is 44, and Ms. Higgins, 36, are gingerly approaching a real estate market that has fluctuated wildly in the last several years and is showing the first signs of stability since the late 1980's.
As previously reluctant sellers put their homes on the market and buyers obtain the lowest interest rates in 18 years, brokers countywide are reporting brisk sales activity. This, they say, is some of the best news the industry has had since the recession began.
But even with signs that the real estate market is heading for a recovery, the mood is distinctly different from what it was in the 1980's. It is more sober, brokers say, and there is a marked change in attitude on the part of both buyers and sellers.
"Buyers are shopping smarter this time around," said Louis J. Calcerano, a salesman at Janet Nold Realty in Irvington. "They are more cautious now. Everything was so wild in the 80's." As Mr. Nelson described it: "We're not rushing into anything. We want something with charm and character but also a house with a modern kitchen and modern bathrooms -- something with a good sense of design, something that is priced well and something that is going to be right for a long time."
Buying a house "is a big commitment of money," he said. "One never knows with the job market what the future will bring. We're taking a 90's approach -- more conservative."
Mr. Nelson and Ms. Higgins are typical of the customers many realtors are seeing in their offices. At the Westchester County Board of Realtors, a trade association in White Plains, P. Gilbert Mercurio, the executive vice president, reports a high proportion of first-time buyers who are looking for one-family houses in the $250,000 to $325,000 range.
 
Potential Buyers at Exposition
 At a trade association exposition in the Westchester County Center in White Plains in March, Mr. Mercurio said that many of the estimated 6,000 who attended were first-time buyers -- "couples, some with strollers, who had come out from New York City."
Sellers, also cautious and trying to understand the dynamics of the 1990's real-estate market, are at last adopting what realtors call "proper price strategies."
At Weichert Realtors in Croton-on-Hudson, the sales manager, Renee Goldman, said: "This is already 1992. People aren't thinking about the peak anymore. They have come to terms with the changes, and they are just glad things are moving again."
It has taken sellers about four years to adjust, Mr. Mercurio said, "but they have finally made their peace with the lower prices."
That, however, does not appear to be the case in some areas. At Cleveland E. Van Wert Inc., a realty concern in Scarsdale, a saleswoman, Norma Roberts, said homeowners with more expensive properties still cling to their asking prices.
"They really believe values never sink in Scarsdale," Mrs. Roberts said. "And in some sense that's true, especially at the upper end."
 
Three High-Value Areas
 Not only in Scarsdale but also in Bronxville and Irvington, properties have held their values for the most part, said Nancy L. Chen, an independent appraiser working throughout the county.
In the majority of areas in the county, however, sellers just a year ago were pricing their homes 10 to 15 percent above what the market would support, realtors reported. And now they are pricing the houses, on average, only 5 to 7 percent above what they eventually will sell for.
"What we are seeing," Mr. Mercurio said, "is that there is a deeper appreciation that even with the slippage in the market in the last few years, anyone who held on to their properties for eight or nine years is still realizing an enormous gain."
"There comes a point," he said, "when you take the profit that was fairly realized and don't get greedy."
But greed, Janet Nold, the owner of Janet Nold Realty, is not the sole reason some sellers refuse to scale down their expectations.
 
Some Sellers Are in a Bind
 For example, on the surface it may appear that someone who bought a home 30 years ago for $20,000 is making a substantial profit by selling that house now for $350,000. But in reality, Mrs. Nold said, the owners may have taken out additional loans on the house, when it was worth more, to send their children to college or to start a business.
"Both that kind of seller and the one who purchased a home during the boom period of the 1980's are in a bind," she said. "It would be very difficult for them to come down in price."
For the first quarter of this year, the median sale price of a single-family house in Westchester was $270,000, which means that half of the houses sold for more than that amount and half sold for less. The first-quarter figure of $270,000 was $5,000 higher than the median for the first quarter of 1991.
A peak was hit in the second quarter of 1988, when the median price of a single-family home in the county reached the $320,000 mark.
 
Some Gains in the First Quarter
 There were 903 completed residential real estate transactions in the first quarter of this year, with a total dollar volume of $256.9 million, according to figures released by the Westchester Multiple Listing Service. The number of closings was 22 percent higher than in the same period a year ago, and the dollar volume was 28 percent more.
When seasonally adjusted, however, the first quarter of 1992 reflected a yearly rate of about 4,840 sales, which is 3 percent below 1991's sales and 1 percent below the annual average of 4,887 sales for the last four-year period. The first quarter of 1991 was one of the lowest quarters since the mid-1980's. Total sales in 1991 were 4,988.
Selling time in the county, from the date of listing to the date of closing, averaged 199 days during the first quarter of 1992, compared with 180 days two years ago and 160 days in the mid-1980's.
"There's no fast action," Mr. Mercurio said. "And it doesn't mean sellers are taking a beating. It's just taking time."
Westchester, according to figures from the National Association of Realtors, remains one of the most expensive areas in the country, with only Honolulu, where the median price of a single-family home for the first quarter of this year was $342,000, being more costly. San Francisco was less costly, recording a median price of $243,900. The median price for the New York City area was $169,300 for the first quarter of the year.
 
Co-ops Are 'Down to a Trickle'
 If realtors are cautiously optimistic that this time the market is truly on a track toward recovery, without hitting the peaks and valleys that characterized the late 1980's and the first two years of the 1990's, they are less confident about the market for cooperatives, which appears mired in a slump, Mr. Mercurio said.
Sales of co-ops, Mr. Mercurio said, are "down to a trickle," and the median price is $82,000.
But in a county that has had a lack of affordable housing, co-ops may provide lower-income buyers with "a wonderful opportunity," he said.
Sales have been hurt, in part, by policies set by the cooperative boards, which often prohibit owners from renting their units. This is seen as restricting one's ability to move on to something else.
With the exception of the co-op market, realtors are seeing slow, steady growth.
"It is not going to come back in one fell swoop," said Peter J. Riolo Jr., president of the realty company here that bears his name. "We are not seeing a quick fix, which is good. Growth appears to be heading in a healthy and slow and deliberate direction, and frankly, I think that is what we all prefer."

SECTION: Section 9; Page 4; Column 1; Styles of The Times

LENGTH: 2088 words

HEADLINE: Name That Decade

BYLINE: By DAPHNE MERKIN

 BODY:
A DECADE is a decade is a media construction.
Just try getting into the Park Avenue Cafe to discuss the earnest, penitential 90's with a friend and you'll see what I mean. A phone call to the restaurant to book a table produced the same results on three separate occasions in the last two weeks: nothing available until 9:30. So much for everyone sitting at home, munching on terra chips and watching the latest video release. 
 Everywhere you look -- from Charivari's fey new ad campaign knocking the 90's credos of "nesting" and "basics" along with such non-cutting-edge fashion items as ripped jeans and T-shirts, to the booming business in eating out -- there are indisputable signs that some of the superficial, high-spending 80's is creeping back into the reflective, austere 90's. Not quite two years into the new decade, it seems some of us not only have tired of everything it's supposed to be about but are already pining for the styles and influences left behind.
What's in a decade, anyway? And how is it that this arbitrary and slim crosscutting of time, a mere 10 years, has grown and flourished to the point that we all walk around in a self-conscious haze about what a new decade represents even before the previous one has tolled its last?
This imposed sense of short-lived generational identity makes for a curious kind of awareness, and it prompts one to wonder if other periods were similarly burdened by predictive assessment. Did people in the Lost Generation, for instance, walk around thinking of themselves as the Lost Generation? Did people coming of age in the 30's realize they were meant to be Radical? And what if you were saddled with an obstreperous nature but doomed by dint of your birthdate to grow up in the pliant 50's?
The writer Tom Wolfe, himself no mean gauger of shifts in the Zeitgeist, and one of the few culture-watchers whose coinages, including the "Me Decade," have stuck, says there's nothing new about the effort to label epochs. When pressed for examples before this century, he pointed to the "Gay 90's" (1890's, that is), to the term "fin de siecle" and to "the Mauve Decade" (which he's read about in the work of one Thomas Beard but is not sure what span of years this refers to). Mr. Wolfe went on to ponder the impure science of which he is a master: "What does it mean to capture a decade? It means you're hitting on something that resonates with other people's impressions."
Lest one think that coming up with catchy monikers is as easy as this description would make it sound, keep in mind that it helps to take a long hard look before you leap into phraseology: "I waited until 1976," Mr. Wolfe admitted, "before I opened my big mouth about the 70's. Hindsight is easier."
Calling a decade before it happens, however, is another matter. For clues as to how the New Earnestness, or whichever hastily concocted media definition of the 90's you prefer, has lost its sheen so quickly, one has to look to the contemporary practice of forecasting, with its reliance on buzzwords (like "downscaling") and tags ("baby boomers").
Faith Popcorn, chairwoman of Brain Reserve, a trend-research firm in New York, is retained by Fortune 500 companies for her and her staff's ability to spot trends. "We predicted 'cocooning' in 1981," she crowed. "It's already in its second decade of use." When I suggested that I saw evidence that "cocooning" might not be holding quite the sway over the 90's that it was supposed to, she blithely predicted that even more mole-like activity was in the wings. "Cocooning will become burrowing," she said with great assurance. "People will stay at home and hang out in 'virtual reality' rooms for good." (For those who have been too busy making dinner reservations to keep up, "virtual reality" is shorthand for ordering in the world.)
Of course, the complex welter of impulses that go into the making of subtle shifts in the social landscape don't really lend themselves to a marketing executive's demographic approach. There's fame and fortune to be had in naming fads for a living, but one can't help thinking the people who do it are perched at a safe distance from reality, like the golden bird in W. B. Yeats's "Sailing to Byzantium" who sits on a golden bough and sings "of what is past, or passing or to come."
If you believed the trendmeisters' version of it then, this was what was prognosticated for the American psyche and wallet as we moved out of the 80's and into the 90's: Glazed and repelled by the wanton spending of the wild capitalists, with the economy roiling from too much schlag and not enough basic nutrients, we were all supposed to retreat behind our white picket fences, there to bring up our children on Gap clothes and Recycling 101, sipping Clearly Canadian and munching on newly reclaimed home-style values.
The 90's, in other words, were to be the 60's but without the hallucinogens and with more character built in. Goodbye, Bright Lights, Big City. Hello, Fresh Air, Snug Houses.
For a while, at least in the universe that is governed by the laws of consumerism, it seemed true. The merchandising atmosphere that had prompted one advertising company's house publication to state in 1985 that "what has increased so dramatically in recent years is not household income, but the number of households with a taste for lavish living" was banished along with Wall Street's Bad Boys. Glamour and sophistication (Lacroix's poufs and top-of-the-line Mercedeses) were ushered out as the hallmarks of the good life; low-key sincerity (the fresh-faced parents and tot gathered round the tub in this year's Liz Claiborne ads, shot in understated black and white) was ushered in.
The trouble with this smoothly executed about-face is that what worked so well for the mercantile imperative -- for Giorgio Armani, say, who introduced his soft-shouldered "schlep" suit just in time for the humbled posture of the new decade -- worked less well for real humans, whose morals and outer garb don't so easily mix and match. "Trends like casual dressing and nesting," said Richard Kirshenbaum, 31, the creative director of the New York agency that has handled the Charivari account for the last four and a half years, "take the wind out of people who want to have a good time. You're not a terrible person if you want to buy a Yohji Yamamoto blazer."
Kirshenbaum & Bond's much-discussed farewell-to-the-90's ad campaign, with its "wake us when it's over" tag line, was generated by a round-table discussion with Jon and Barbara Weiser, who run Charivari. "There was a shared sense," he said, "that people in general seemed to be depressed and understated, that they wanted the 90's to be over and were waiting for the next thing."
What of the person who yearns to paint the town red in an age of staying home and curling up with a good book?
It is tempting to construe decade-bucking as no more than a failure to fit in with the clothes of the times, as though life itself comes down to a War of the Labels, a matter of siding with expensive foreign designs and against moderate native shapes. And there may be something in the very nature of trying to codify tiny segments of history -- with the instant exhaustion of events and responses that inevitably goes with it -- that runs counter to making serious claims upon our attention.
"What we do when we 'decadize,' " said Marshall Blonsky, who teaches semiotics at the New School, "is to substitute nostalgia for history. And nostalgia means that what is produced is an idealized version of what was. What you've done is to open up a new market -- for Golden Oldies, or 60's tie-dyed clothing or whatever. You've commodified the decade. It's all part of the incessant fashion game in the States. Time itself becomes a matter of fashion."
Still, underneath the carping about clothes and cars lie deeper anxieties. These include the increased perception, with each succeeding decade, of ourselves as the objects of a proliferating and bewildering taxonomy, as cogs in the vast hype machine that has come to dominate the late-20th-century landscape.
"Decadology," said the writer Barbara Probst Solomon, "ought to be outlawed. When I got through college I was told I was a member of the Silent Generation, yet all my friends were very political. It was a press-agent's gimmick then and it's one now."
A small but crucial aspect of the emerging collective resistance to the quick-change personifications that are thrust upon us faster than you can say thirtysomething is, simply, this: Upbeat, expansive versions of our forthcoming lives are inherently more appealing than dour, contracted ones.
The yen for glitz is undoubtedly not one of the more mature human characteristics, and yet it continues to thrive, if only because life is not, bottom line, a glamorous proposition. What seems unlikely is that such an appetite, irresponsible or unprofound as it may be, can be denounced as unfashionable. Or that recasting the daily round of one's life as glamorous, which is what all the 90's-speak of hearth and home has tried to do, will fool anyone for long. The uninhibited spirit of ostentation that prevailed while the bronco bankers were in the horse's seat may well have gone undercover, but at the end of a hard-working day people still want to have fun. Drew Nierporent, proprietor of New York's Montrachet and Tribeca Grill, noted: "As long as there are baby sitters, there'll be eating out."
The question, finally, to be posed about the passing of the climate of excess is whether the cold shower of the economic recession has genuinely spilled over into other areas; that is, whether Americans have rethought their values so much as cut back on them.
Tom Wolfe, while conceding that "there's been a lot of ethical and moral questioning on all sides," has his doubts as to whether there have been any cataclysmic shocks to the underlying acquisitive ideology. "I don't see any great movement," he said, "that's going to change anything. Nobody wants to admit that all that went wrong in the 90's is that the money stopped flowing. It's much easier and more satisfying to think in cosmic terms, that God had something to do with it."
The Marxist critic Frederic Jameson has suggested that consumer society, by transforming American experience into a pretext for glossy images, has left us "bereft of all historicity." In "Postmodernism" he writes, "We seem increasingly incapable of fashioning representations of our own current experience." Where that leaves us is in an uneasy limbo, clutching after the future even as it is being wheeled offstage, and searching among the discarded props of the recent past for something that corresponds to our memories of it. "Who was Hitler anyway?" Jameson asks, with deadly irony. "Who was Kennedy? Who, finally, was Nixon?"
A decade is a decade is a media construction. When I asked William Phillips, founding editor of Partisan Review and a man who has observed many an intellectual fad come and go, to characterize the decades as he remembered, he had no trouble except when it came to the 40's. What happened to the 40's, stuck between the "radical" 30's and the "quietist" 50's? Mr. Phillips shrugged his shoulders. "They were the post-30's."
The 40's, of course, were the War Years, also known as the Duration. It appears that when something big is going on -- when a nation has to pull together to fight a common enemy -- the urge to "decadize" (at least in the sense of characterizing spending habits) falls away. If entire decades get lost in the shuffle, others exist only in truncated form: The 60's, Mr. Wolfe said, existed only from '65 to '69. So if you can't find a decade to label, half a decade will do nicely.
Even the wrong pronunciamiento will pass muster, if the right person utters it. With a twinkle in his voice, Mr. Wolfe recounted how he was asked on a TV program sometime in the late 70's to name the 80's. Too vain, by his own account, to resist, Mr. Wolfe announced that it would be known as the Purple Decade. (Given the royal spending that was about to begin, he wasn't far off.) "You can look back at any decade and hope it was mauve," he concluded, somewhat inscrutably.
Pick a color, any color, and wake me when the contest is over. Or perhaps it's time, as we scramble toward the end of the second millennium, to stay wide awake and start thinking in terms of the long haul. Anyone got any suggestions as to what color the next thousand years will be?

HEADLINE: The Nippon Jungle

BYLINE: By Frank Gibney; Frank Gibney's books on Japan and East Asia include "The Pacific Century," to be published this fall. He is the president of the Pacific Basin Institute.

 BODY:

PACIFIC RIFT
By Michael Lewis.
128 pp. New York:
W. W. Norton & Company.
$14.95. 
 Each spring, like a variety of mutant cherry blossom, books that provide devastating analyses of Japan seem fated to bloom over the New York literary landscape. Following Michael Crichton's "Rising Sun" and a host of economic exposes, Michael Lewis now gives us "Pacific Rift." At 128 pages it is, mercifully, a short book, though it manages to include more sweeping judgments, definitive statements and blanket assurances than many a 500-pager. Fortunately for the reader, it is nicely written and amusing. Indeed, "With Divining Rod and Grin Through Darkest Tokyo" might have been a more accurate title. I am sad to make this judgment because I much enjoyed Mr. Lewis's earlier books, "Liar's Poker," his best-selling account of the bond market, and his collection of essays, "The Money Culture."
Retaining his chatty style here, Mr. Lewis explains that since "most of what has been written" about the tensions between Japan and the United States has had to do with politics, he will now write about businessmen and their problems -- "real people in the midst of the fray." What he has been reading about the "relationship" I don't know, but I do know from personal experience that by far the greatest portion of the tonnage written has dealt not with politics, but with business or the economy.
The conclusion of Mr. Lewis's book, he attempts to tell us, is: "I'll bet the question in America will no longer be 'How do we open Japan?' Instead it will become 'How can our capitalism beat their capitalism?' " This is hardly an earthshaking revelation. Peter Drucker, Lester Thurow, Chalmers Johnson, Robert Reich and others have been saying much the same thing for many years. About the only people who still believe that Japan's version of the free enterprise system is just like ours are the neoclassical economists who have apparently been advising the White House.
Mr. Lewis chooses two "real people" to report on -- Robert J. Collins, an American who worked in Tokyo for some years selling insurance to the Japanese for the American International Group (A.I.G.), and Shuji Tomikawa, a Japanese who lives in New York and sells American real estate to his fellow countrymen for Mitsui Real Estate. Both seem to be nice fellows, and we are vouchsafed amusing glimpses of their business activities. But it is difficult to perceive what Mr. Lewis is trying to prove with their stories -- other than to reaffirm the obvious fact that Japanese and American ways of doing business are often very different.
On the way, however, the author makes a variety of overstatements and conclusions that hardly seem justified. He maintains, for example, that A.I.G.'s success in Japan could never have been achieved if it had not got a toehold there during the American occupation of the country following World War II. Quite possibly so. But it is inaccurate to generalize from this example that the foreign businessman in Tokyo is doomed because of what Mr. Lewis calls the "Japanese Defense," a combination of cartels, distribution practices, government surveillance and the like.
He quotes the president of A.I.G., Buck Freeman: "We have learned to survive in the Japanese jungle, and it is a jungle." This can be said of almost any business society -- Wall Street, for example -- especially when visitors don't know very much about local practices and overconfidently expect them to be like their own. Japan, a country where cartels are not illegal but merely good business and where Government "guidance" has the force of law, is a very difficult country to do business in -- no doubt about it. But many foreign companies set up shop in Tokyo long after the occupation ended and did quite well by paying close attention to local ground rules.
Part of Japan's business success has come from its executives' ability to adapt. To do so they need no prompting. It is highly debatable -- to put it mildly -- whether "every important American-style change in Japan has been made while staring into the barrel of a gun or under the threat of American trade sanctions."
For the rest, Mr. Lewis is appallingly superficial in some of his comments. History he ignores. To describe the Meiji Restoration, Japan's great self-started 19th-century cultural revolution, as "a coup d'etat politely known as the Meiji Restoration" is laughable. He oversimplifies the beginnings of Japanese industry and the impact of the American occupation on Japan. Modern Japan is handled in a similarly casual way. "Here in Japan, no bankruptcies," he quotes an insurance guild official as saying. In fact, not only do large numbers of middle-sized Japanese companies regularly go into bankruptcy, but in recent years some rather big enterprises have been allowed to bite the dust.
On a more mundane level, to call the small neighborhood around the Roppongi crossroads "the Western quarter of Tokyo" is like describing the Japanese restaurant belt in Manhattan's East 40's as the "Eastern quarter of New York." On a trip to a Tokyo nightclub -- now virtually obligatory in such books -- we are introduced to "Kiko, Miko, Yuko, and a couple of others with equally improbable names." How ethnocentric can you get? And Mr. Lewis's voyage through the Japanese economy is not made easier by his single-minded reliance on the semiconspiratorial view of history advanced by such current revisionist patriarchs as Karel van Wolferen, who is fast becoming a kind of fangs-bared Lafcadio Hearn for modern critics of Japan who don't have the time to read on their own.
There are real difficulties in Japan's dealings with the United States. But not the least of these is American ignorance of Japanese economic and social realities -- not to mention our failure to devise better ways of producing and competing on our own. As an admirer of Michael Lewis's journalism, I only wish he had taken a good bit more time to examine and discuss the real issues.
