SECTION: Section 7; Page 2; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1656 words

HEADLINE: From the Stone Age to Tiananmen Square

BYLINE: By Jonathan Spence; Jonathan Spence teaches modern Chinese history at Yale University. His latest book, "Chinese Roundabout," will be published this summer.

 BODY:

CHINA
A New History.
By John King Fairbank.
Illustrated. 519 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
The Belknap Press/
Harvard University Press.
$27.95. 
 SLIGHTLY before the midpoint of John King Fairbank's latest and last book -- the eminent Harvard historian of China died last year at the age of 84 -- appears the only overtly autobiographical passage in the volume. It was in the early 1930's, Fairbank writes in "China: A New History," that he and his wife settled into Beijing life, and three things at once impressed the young newlywed graduate students as unusual. First, there was the extraordinary extent of their privilege as foreign residents; they were treated as members of the ruling-class elite from the first moment in China and were left unbothered by the ubiquitous police. Second, because of the incredible surplus of Chinese manpower the easiest form of transportation around the ancient city was by rickshaw: you lay back against the seats of the two-wheeled vehicle while the "intelligent human horse between the shafts" trotted and sweated his way to your destination. Third, in both city and country, all women of early middle age and over had bound feet, which left them "stumping about awkwardly on their heels as though the front sections of their feet had been amputated."
Why had this last practice in particular, Fairbank muses, been so little studied or discussed by either Chinese or Western scholars? For close to a millennium, hundreds of millions of Chinese women had had the toes of their feet systematically bent under their arches, and the arches themselves strapped, tilted and broken, and then the women had performed the same protracted and agonizing ritual deformation on their own daughters. Why had no one tried to assess the "social and psychic repercussions" of this nightmare practice, reputedly performed for the sensual delectation of men, even though the physiological, esthetic or erotic effects of foot-binding were far from clear?
Perhaps, Fairbank concludes, Chinese scholars had dodged the topic because it would have forced them to confront the whole problem of women's subjugation; and perhaps the Westerners had dodged the topic as well because they were eager to avoid giving offense to Chinese sensitivities. Few scholars "are muckrakers by temperament," notes Fairbank, and since foot-binding was unique to China it was not a convenient topic for comparative sociological study. Furthermore, he observes, there is an "occupational quirk of sinologists, a secondary patriotism or sinophilia that may lead otherwise hard-headed scholars to want to say no evil of the object of their researches."
This last sentence is starred to a footnote on the same page, almost the only time in this entire history that Fairbank uses such a device, and the purpose of the starred note is clearly to deepen the autobiographical reflection further, and to carry it forward in time into another kind of dangerous psychic terrain. "For an outstanding example of sentimental sinophilia," Fairbank adds, "see my statement in Foreign Affairs, October 1972, that in a certain context the Maoist revolution was 'the best thing' that had happened to the Chinese people in many centuries."
In these brief passages we have a distillation of the historical stance that Fairbank adopted in the last years of his long and formidably productive scholarly life -- a stance that sought to present itself as both frank and skeptical, tackling the difficult questions and suggesting directions for new research, while making the author himself disarmingly vulnerable by his admission of past mistakes. Fairbank, this century's foremost promoter of Chinese studies, chose to bow out with a show of modesty.
I say show of modesty not with any intention to belittle this extraordinary man, but rather to underscore the incredible ambitiousness of his final work. "China: A New History" sets out to cover, in 432 pages of text, the entire span of China's history from the paleolithic cultures of 400,000 B.C. to the Tiananmen massacre of 1989, and it does so with a brisk and sprightly air but also with an awesomely thorough overview of the current scholarly work of scores of historians. The book is indeed a kind of reprise not only of Fairbank's life as a reader and teacher, but also of his long years as editor or co-editor of the many volumes of the monumental "Cambridge History of China," Volume 15 of which, on the People's Republic and Taiwan between 1966 and 1982, was published last year. Perhaps most surprisingly, for those who have followed Fairbank's extraordinary range of studies in the fields of Chinese-United States foreign policy, institutional history and missionary history, "China: A New History" is dedicated in large part to social history, to the infrastructures and daily life of the Chinese, and to the elusive world of "civil society" that obviously existed and flourished at many levels under the watchful eyes of the purportedly omnipresent autocratic state.
Despite Fairbank's attention to social movements in this volume, his intellectual energy seems still to be most concentrated on the problems of state power and dissonance that led -- among other things -- to those three aspects of exploitive hierarchy that he highlighted in the book's autobiographical musings. In one passage, arresting to the historian at once for its concision and for the vastness of the ideas tackled, Fairbank reflects on how a kind of unifying theory does seem to emerge from his lifetime's reading and research on China's long history, a theory that makes sense because it incorporates the rhythms of China's periods of fragmentation and conquest by others along with its own enduring institutional forms. In Fairbank's words:
"The hypothesis may be stated as follows: (1) that early China created a politicized state organized for purposes of central control both by bureaucratic methods of philosophic persuasion and by the imperial autocrat's use of violence; (2) that non-Chinese invaders from Inner Asia became integral participants in the Chinese polity by their military prowess and administrative skill; and (3) that the resulting Sino-nomadic imperial power continued to maintain the primacy of central political control over the subordinated processes of economic growth and cultural diversification."
Elsewhere in the volume, Fairbank produces a rather different formulation that he felt contrasted China succinctly with the main lines of Western development. Where the main line of Western national "style" had been "industrial-military-entrepreneurial," that in China had been "agrarian-nomadic-bureaucratic." In many ways, as Fairbank's chapters on modern China show, both Chiang Kai-shek and Mao Zedong were caught in this cycle of values. Fairbank is distinctly unsympathetic to both these central leaders of 20th-century China, consistently with his earlier views in the case of Chiang, and perhaps seeking to bury the ghost of those 1972 "sentimental" deviations in the case of Mao.
Though the economic, educational and industrial reforms of Chiang's Kuomintang years are discussed fairly and thoroughly, Chiang himself emerges as a "vigorous Dr. Jekyll" who "metamorphosed" into a "sordid Mr. Hyde," and lost the civil war of 1946-49 through "stupidity" and "incompetence." Similarly, though Communist attempts at national and rural reconstruction get their due, Fairbank writes that Mao's basic "organizational principle" was that of any traditional Chinese "bandit" who used "force and guile . . . to curry favor with the local people," before he emerged at last as an "updated emperor" whose final acts were to lead his people "up a mountain and into a volcano."
The only man to get an equally bad press is the leader of the massive mid-19th-century Taiping Rebellion, Hong Xiuquan, whose "bizarre and irrational" theocracy prompts Fairbank to search for parallels that range from Napoleon to Hitler. The invoking of such parallels is a device that Fairbank enjoys, and like his invocation of echoes from China's past it can be effective and arresting. Occasionally it illuminates the instant with a zany humor similar to that which did indeed bubble just beneath Fairbank's own often formidable public persona. One of my favorites is Fairbank's aside that the closest equivalent he can think of to Mao's massively publicized swim across the Yangtze River in 1966 would be "the news that Queen Elizabeth II had swum the Channel."
SUCH asides may not be good history, but they are good-humored and make a point. On other occasions, the aside can trivialize the moment. Thus to summarize the archeological finds of Stone Age Chinese skeletons with smashed-in skulls as showing that "Peking Man was a small-time cannibal or at least a head-hunter who savored brains" strikes me as a little tacky; to equate Han dynasty neo-Confucian imperial rituals with White House "foto-ops and sound-bites" is erratic; and to call the terrible famine that followed the Great Leap Forward "first-class" is truly odd.
Such ruminations aside, this book is an admirable achievement. And even if one cannot accept the idea that this history is entirely new, Fairbank has filled the analytic narrative with intelligent ideas and original contributions: on the long-term effect of the absence of early maritime trade in China, on frontier appeasement policies, on the inherent problems of translation of foreign texts into Chinese characters, on Confucian attitudes to the military, on the development of popular religion, on sweated labor, on the failures of democratic experimentation and the other quests of China's new elite of "Sino-liberals," on the politics of repression and the role of sycophancy. Fairbank dominated the field of China studies in the West for 50 years. In this volume, we see that even on the edge of death his hand had not lost its cunning.

Elizabeth Albert, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey D. Albert of Massapequa, L.I., was married last evening to Howard Mark Kleinman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Kleinman of Fair Lawn, N.J. Rabbi Martin Freedman officiated at the Water's Edge restaurant in Long Island City, Queens.
Ms. Albert, who is 30 years old and keeping her name, is a lawyer in the investment firm of Morgan Stanley & Company in New York. She graduated cum laude from Radcliffe College, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and received a law degree from Yale University. Her father is an owner of Albert Brothers Hardware in Bellmore, L.I. 
 Mr. Kleinman, 29, will become an associate in the Tokyo law firm of Nishimura & Sanada in August. A graduate of Columbia University, he received a master's degree in international relations from the London School of Economics and a law degree from New York University. His father owns Gerald Kleinman & Company, a New York textiles importer and distributor. His mother, Sally Kleinman, is an administrative assistant at Fair Lawn High School.

HEADLINE: New York's Carriage Drivers Are Getting an Unfair Rap

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Everyday when I go to work, driving my horse-drawn carriage, I meet people with hate-filled faces who scream at me how cruel I am to my horse. They have probably never brushed a horse in their lifetime, and dare to tell me how to work with it.
I brush my horse every day, assure myself that it has no sore, give it a shower after every hot summer day, massage its legs and shoulders with alcohol, feed it, water it, call the vet if it's sick, give it a day off if it's tired. The horse is my partner not only in my economical subsistence but also emotional: it is a friend. 
 I pick up fliers issued by "animal rights activists" that tell the people of New York City how cruel and irresponsible the carriage drivers are toward their animals.
For instance, one stated that during the winter the stables were not heated, and that during the summer they had no air conditioning. Well, during the cold months, horses grow thick fur coats. If the stable were heated, the horses would lose their coats and then get pneumonia from working outside.
On the other hand, if the stables had air conditioning during the hot season, the horses would grow fur coats and then suffocate under the summer heat. Such blatant ignorance is constantly fed to people of good will who care about animals. It gives these people the illusion that the horse and carriage industry is insensitive and purely exploitative of the animals.
I drove a horse once that had been sent to the country to recover from a sore. I took it out in the streets for the first time after three weeks' convalescence. This horse was so happy! It was trotting in the streets, tail up, neighing to the other horses. Pulling a carriage is good exercise for them. It keeps them healthy and happy.
I agree with certain laws to protect them, such as those mandating only one shift or the temperature under which they can work. But other laws are just completely ridiculous and prevent carriage drivers from making a decent living.
For instance, the hours limiting the day shift are too short. The hours from 4 to 7 P.M. are hours when people are finishing their day of work and are willing to take a ride. Those hours are crucial to our business and should be given back to us.
The city should also give us back the streets at night, as soon as the rush hour is over, and during the weekends when the traffic is not as heavy. This would make the business more prosperous and would diminish the competition among us (we are all crowded in one area, and with the recession, times are very hard).
 
FRANCINE DICKEY
New York, May 6, 1992

HEADLINE: The Road To Rio -- Setting an Agenda for the Earth;
Difficult Algebra for China: Coal = Growth = Pollution

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, May 24

 BODY:
China's economic revolution may be dotting the countryside with new factories and electricity plants, but it may also be having an unintended effect: its contribution to global warming may be rising more quickly than that of any other major country.
Most countries have become increasingly aware that warming of the earth could cause climate changes and rising sea levels. Even the United States, which many scientists say contributes more to the greenhouse effect than any other country, is considering curbs on gases thought to cause global warming.
 
The Centrality of Coal
 But here there is little awareness of the problem. China burns increasing amounts of coal and is expected to surpass the United States and the former Soviet Union to become the single greatest contributor of greenhouse gases in coming decades. 
 "China will probably become the No. 2 emitter within the next 10 years," said Christopher Flavin, a climate specialist at the Worldwatch Institute, an environmental research group in Washington, D.C. "The rate of growth in China's carbon dioxide emissions is far, far greater than any major emitter anywhere in the world."
Burning coal produces carbon dioxide, the most significant greenhouse gas, but coal is China's main source of energy and thus an essential element of its strategy to catch up with the industrial world.
Next month at the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro, world leaders will try to persuade countries, particularly developing nations like China, to use less coal and to spend more on the environment.
But there is no doubt that China will continue to rely on coal well into the next century, so the crucial question environmentalists are asking is, Will China be willing to curb the country's release of threatening gases, even at the possible cost of economic growth?
For now, the answer is no.
"China must develop, and its people must enjoy a better life, but we can't make it without energy," said Bai Xianhong, a senior official at the State Science and Technology Commission, which oversees environmental work. "You can't say that for the sake of lowering carbon dioxide emissions, China shouldn't burn coal anymore. This is impossible. In winter, people wouldn't be able to keep warm. They'd have no electricity or lighting."
In wintertime, plumes of black smoke rise from millions of homes that burn coal for warmth. In major cities, where few use gas heating, a typical family may burn nearly half a ton of coal during winter. Three-quarters of China's energy comes from coal, and power generators and industrial boilers pump hundreds of thousands of tons of carbon dioxide into the air each day.
"Every morning a dense black smoke streams out of the smokestack right behind our house," said a young worker who lives in Beijing. "Who's thinking of global warming, when we can barely even breathe?"
Each year, China mines more than a billion metric tons of coal, more than any other country in the world. By the end of this century, the country plans to produce 1.4 billion tons each year, almost all of which it will burn at home, and by 2020, it could mine 2 billion tons a year, half the world's production.
Chinese leaders say they are well aware of the pollution that unrestrained coal-burning can cause, aside from the risks of global warming. But the Government has made its position clear: It will not sacrifice development for the environment.
 
'Above All, Development'
 "You can't even talk about economic sacrifice," said Jing Wenyong, director of the Environmental Engineering Institute at Qinghua University. "Above all, we must have economic development."
At last count, in 1989, China produced 9.1 percent of the gases that contribute to global warming, ranking third in the world, according to World Resources Institute, a nonprofit research group in Washington, D.C. The United States produced the largest amount, 17.8 percent; the Soviet Union followed, with 13.6 percent.
On a per-capita basis, China does not even rank in the top 50 countries, the institute says; each American released nine times as much greenhouse gas as each Chinese.
But if China's gross domestic product grows 8.5 percent a year for the next three decades -- unlikely but not impossible, since China's economy grew by 9.7 percent a year in the 1980's -- then by 2025, the amount of carbon dioxide released could be three times the amount released by the United States, according to estimates by the Stockholm Environment Institute.
 
Growing More, Burning Less
 Scientists both here and abroad say China must improve the efficiency of its steel mills, its factories and all energy consumption if it wants to continue growing while limiting its contribution to global warming. Energy use by China's industry is among the least efficient in the world, said William U. Chandler, senior scientist at Battelle Pacific Northwest Laboratories, an environmental management and consulting group in Richland, Wash.
"The United States is the greatest concern because it is the largest emitter now," Mr. Chandler said in a telephone interview. "But the lines will cross in the future in terms of their emissions versus ours, and they will become the largest emitter. If they do that without becoming energy efficient, they will suffer the wrath of the rest of the world the way the United States does now."
While United States environmentalists take an active role in proposing measures to curb global warming, many critics say the United States as a nation has left the largest trail of pollution and done little to clean up after itself. Chinese specialists argue that it is unfair to impose constraints on China when Western countries have been polluting the atmosphere for more than a century and China has only recently become a significant offender.
"It's not good enough to calculate total emissions of a year, but for the last 200 years," said Wang Mingxing, an atmospheric physicist at the Chinese Academy of Sciences. "If you calculate the emissions for 200 years, China's concentration is very small."
Critics of this view argue that global warming and its causes have become a concern only in recent years.
To be sure, China is somewhat sensitive to environmental issues and natural resources constraints. Some experts say that China is among the most environmentally enlightened of the developing countries, and Beijing is collaborating with Western advisers to develop strategies to protect its soil, water and air.
In its current five-year plan, to 1995, China sharply raised spending on the environment, but the amount still remains about nine-tenths of 1 percent of gross national product. Environmental spending in the United States runs 1 percent to 2 percent of G.N.P.
China only recently acknowledged that on balance it would be hurt by global warming. It says that if the overall temperature were to rise one to two degrees, some colder agricultural areas would benefit because the extra heat and sunshine would extend the growing season. But warming could dry up crops more easily and cause droughts and hot winds in many other areas, leading scientists to say that China could lose 5 percent of its agricultural production.
A warmer climate would also shrink water supplies. And a rise in sea levels could seriously damage coastal areas, the backbone of the national economy; Shanghai, the nation's biggest city, could be flooded. On parts of the Tibetan plateau in northwestern China, highways, railways and housing could tumble as the permafrost they are built on melted.
Partly because of these concerns, China has set aside about $15 million for research on global warming. The Government also sees the issue as a way to broaden its role in the world, and so it has held international conferences on the environment and a special international council to examine environmental issues.
"China is playing both sides of the sword," said a Western environmental specialist. "The Ministry of Foreign Affairs wants to reassert its role in the developing world. It also knows it can endear itself to the developed countries by showing it is doing a lot on the environment."
China has also called upon Western countries to finance environmental improvements in developing countries, including China.
While China has recently run articles and television specials on the environment in preparation for the Earth Summit, awareness of environmental problems in general is much lower than in the West.
When "green" movements in the West were beginning to blossom in the 1970's and 80's, most of China had not even seen plastic. Now, in offices, conference rooms and meeting halls across China, slogans focus on developing the economy as quickly as possible.
"Most people here simply don't care about the environment, especially in the township and village enterprises," said a Chinese reporter who used to cover the environment. "They don't realize it will affect their future."

HEADLINE: Russian Says Communists Still Resist Reforms

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LISBON, May 24

 BODY:
Russia's Foreign Minister warned today at an international conference on aid to the former Soviet republics that a determined Communist resistance movement was threatening economic reforms.
In remarks that appeared to be aimed in part at the other republics, the Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, said hard-line Communists bent on revenge often allied themselves with nationalist movements to obscure their true goals. 
 "The resistance to reform makes even more important the political solidarity we see here at this conference," Mr. Kozyrev said. Seated around him at the news conference were ministers or high-ranking officials of other new nations, including Ukraine, which is locked in a tense dispute with Russia over the future of the Crimea.
Officials at the meeting, which was organized by the European Community to follow up on a conference convened by the United States in January, heard reports on immediate food, medical, energy and other needs of the nations that emerged from the breakup of the Soviet Union in December.
 
October Session Planned
 Another session of the aid conference, which was attended this time by more than 60 nations and international organizations, is tentatively planned for October in Japan.
At the news conference, Mr. Kozyrev appeared to be responding to charges that Russia's decision to ban the Communist Party of the former Soviet Union was a violation of political rights, a criticism heard occasionally in the West. The ban is to be tested next week in a constitutional court in Moscow, the Foreign Minister said.
He said that while people were free to believe in Communism or join other parties espousing it, the Communist Party of the Soviet Union was an undemocratic and "illegal" organization.
The United States proposed several projects at the weekend aid meeting, including technical assistance to improve safety at 37 nuclear plants in the former Soviet republics and to convert military industries to civilian use.
The initial American contribution will be a $25 million expansion of advisory work already being provided by the Energy Department and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. The centerpiece of the expanded program will be two regional centers, in Russia and Ukraine, for training on the principles and methods of nuclear safety management.
Another Administration grant of $20 million will be used to help convert military industries to civilian production. The money will pay for the assignment of resident American advisers in Russia, Ukraine and Kazakhstan. Trade and investment centers will also be established, backed by promises of low-cost loans to small businesses.
 
Surveys by I.M.F.
 Today Mr. Baker said that the international aid and economic support package pledged to the new nations had already had tangible results. He said that 103,000 tons of food and millions of dollars in medical aid had been delivered and that half a million children had been vaccinated in a joint project by the World Health Organization and Unicef, which also surveyed the medical needs of the region.
Michel Camdessus, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, said that his organization had completed comprehensive surveys of the economies of the new nations and that policy and technical assistance was already in place. The I.M.F. and World Bank accepted most of the former Soviet republics as members in April.

HEADLINE: Baker Puts Pressure on Europeans For U.N. Penalties Against Serbs

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LISBON, May 24

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d called today for United Nations sanctions against the Serbian nationalist Government of Yugoslavia, using his toughest language yet in criticizing European nations for not trying to stop the fighting or punish Belgrade.
"Anyone who is looking for reasons not to act, or arguing somehow that action in the face of this kind of nightmare is not warranted at this time, I think in the view of all of us in the civilized world is on the wrong wavelength," Mr. Baker said. 
 His remarks appeared to be directed at some European countries, especially France and Greece, that seem to be holding up any European consensus decision on sanctions against Serbia in the civil war engulfing Yugoslavia. Mr. Baker's actions also were the latest steps by Washington to try to take the initiative after a period of apparent inaction as the Yugoslav and Bosnian crises became worse.
The Security Council is likely to approve mandatory, step-by-step sanctions against Serbia and Montenegro this week, including a ban on civilian air links and then an oil embargo, according to diplomats and United Nations officials. [Page 6.]
The statements and discussions at the Lisbon meeting, which had been called to discuss aid to the former Soviet republics, revealed the different approaches of the major countries concerned with security of Europe in the post-cold-war world. The approaches appear to be diverging because of a complex mix of domestic and international policy goals, traditional attitudes toward the Serbs or Croats and new fears about the precedents that could be set by intervention.
 
Warning From German
 Joao de Deus Pinheiro, Portugal's Foreign Minister and current president of the European Council of Ministers, said it was a European principle to invoke sanctions "gradually." A meeting on Tuesday in Brussels of European experts to consider sanctions against Serbia would discuss only the "possible identification of sanctions," he said.
But Germany's Foreign Minister, Klaus Kinkel, warned members of the European Community that "people have the impression we are groping in the dark while the killing is going on in Yugoslavia."
Mr. Baker raised the specter of the Persian Gulf war, saying discussions had been opened at the United Nations on the possibility of invoking Chapter 7 of the United Nations Charter, which allows collective action, including economic sanctions and military intervention, against a renegade nation.
Referring at a news conference to action against the Serbian Government, Mr. Baker said: "I can't predict for you when that might or might not be possible. But I can predict for you that we intend to continue those discussions, and push them as forcefully as we know how because of what's taken place in Bosnia and Herzegovina."
Drawing a parallel to the campaign that led to the imposition of sanctions and finally a war against Iraq in 1990-1991, he said he did not rule out support of an international force for Yugoslavia, but repeated that all other methods should be tried first.
 
Allusion to the Nazis
 He also alluded to Nazi Germany in his remarks, which were made as he sat at the same table with Mr. Kinkel. "The ethnic purification of certain portions of Bosnia and Herzegovina is all too reminiscent of something that we sat back and witnessed a number of years ago," Mr. Baker said.
He said he was encouraged to hear that European Community experts would meet to discuss sanctions on Tuesday in Brussels at the European Community headquarters. But he said he would be "even more encouraged if, coming out the meeting on Tuesday, there were a willingness on the part of our European colleagues to act."
After attending the meetings here today, the Russian Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, flew off to Yugoslavia tonight on a personal mission to try to negotiate the reopening of the airport at Sarajevo, the capital of Bosnia and Herzegovina. He also said it would be a grave mistake to withdraw United Nations peacekeepers from the former Yugoslav republics.
The setting for the exchanges was an international meeting on aid to the former Soviet republics. But in the corridors and at the news conferences, the subject being discussed was the assault on Bosnia and Herzegovina and how Europe and its North Atlantic partners were performing in their new task of insuring security in the post-cold-war era.
 
Speculation on Motives
 Mr. Baker's tough new line on Yugoslavia has been variously interpreted by European and American anaylsts. Some see it as a negative reaction to the French and German decision to create a 35,000-man joint military corps that American officials have feared would be the beginning of a wider European force that could undermine the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
Others say Mr. Baker risked a policy embarrassment if the Bush Administration continued to say it is following the European lead on Yugoslavia if the Europeans are in fact not leading the alliance anywhere near a solution to the Yugoslav crisis.
There are also Europeans who regard the sudden switch to a high-profile policy as an attempt by the United States to reassert a pre-eminent position in the Western alliance. Still others note that President Bush is running for re-election.
The remarks of the outspoken Mr. Kinkel also came under scrutiny today. At a news conference, the German Foreign Minister said that while Europe was grateful for the interest of Mr. Baker in the Yugoslav crisis, "it will be the task of Europe to conquer this problem."
But he challenged his fellow Europeans to take a more realistic view of the problems of Bosnia -- or a view more in line with Germany's traditional support of Croats against Serbs.
"What is happening in Yugoslavia is atrocious," he said. "As I see it, it should be stated clearly who is responsible for this. The Serbians are responsible."
The French, who did not send a minister to today's news conference, have fought shy of this view, as have the Greeks. Both are thought to be stumbling blocks to concerted European action on sanctions.
Mr. Kinkel, on the other hand, backed Mr. Baker's calls for more European action by saying a consideration of sanctions was "indispensable."
The negative effects on Russia of an oil embargo may be part of Moscow's reluctance until now to support tougher action against Belgrade in the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, which failed to suspend Yugoslavia two weeks ago because of Russian obstruction. Russia has just signed a contract to sell or barter $3.5 billion in oil and gas to the Serbs.
Today Mr. Kozyrev supported sanctions as a last resort when speaking to reporters at a separate news conference with Mr. Baker after the two had discussed further weapons cuts and the impending visit of President Boris N. Yeltsin to Washington.

Canada Recalls Envoy
 MONTREAL, May 24 (Reuter) -- Canada recalled its Ambassador from Belgrade today and suspended landing rights for the Yugoslav airline, JAT, to protest continuing violence in Bosina and Herzegovina, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney announced. The Canadian Government also called for an urgent meeting of the United Nations Security Council to impose economic, trade and oil sanctions against the Belgrade Government.

HEADLINE: U.N. May Widen Yugoslav Sanctions

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, May 24

 BODY:
The United Nations Security Council is likely to approve mandatory, step-by-step sanctions on Serbia and Montenegro on Wednesday or Thursday, according to diplomats and United Nations officials.
Diplomats said that the new measure was being drafted by the United States, Britain and France, and that while details were still being worked out, the first step would probably be a call to follow the United States example by cutting civilian air links by banning all flights by JAT, the Yugoslav national airline. 
 A second stage probably would involve an oil embargo, diplomats said, but a general trade ban is likely to be held in reserve as an ultimate step because Security Council members are reluctant to add to ordinary people's privations.
 
Who Speaks for Yugoslavia?
 The Security Council has already forbidden all arms deliveries to the former Yugoslav federation, of which Serbia and Montenegro are the remaining members. The other four, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Macedonia, have declared themselves independent.
The United States is also pressing Serbia and Montenegro over membership in the United Nations. Last week, Washington told Serbia and Montenegro, which declared themselves the successor to Yugoslavia, that they must reapply for membership. That would give Washington the chance to veto the application when it comes before the Security Council.
Earlier this month, United Nations Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali irritated European Council members by saying that continued tension and fighting made it impossible for the organization to expand its peacekeeping role in Bosnia and Herzegovina and might even force it to pull out of Croatia as well.
As a result, the Security Council adopted a resolution that reaffirmed its peace plan for Croatia and Slovenia.
The council members are also under growing pressure from Islamic countries, which complain that Serbia has expanded the Christian area of Bosnia and Herzegovina at the expense of its Muslims, which are the largest single group. This weekend Iran, which provides about 15 percent of Serbia's oil, said it would not send supplies until Belgrade stops mistreating the Muslims.
Sanctions would be imposed under the rarely used provisions of Chapter 7 of the United Nations Charter, which were also invoked when the council authorized the war 15 months ago to dislodge Iraq from Kuwait.
Chapter 7 says that if efforts to resolve a dispute peacefully fail, the Security Council may impose mandatory trade and economic sanctions on a country that is threatening international peace and security, and may resort to armed force if that country still refuses to obey the council's orders.
 
Counting Votes
 Russia is reported to be anguishing over the proposed resolution because it does not like moving against a former ally and because Russia swaps oil for farm materials and building supplies from Yugoslavia. But Western diplomats believe Russia will agree in the end because Moscow cannot afford to be seen rescuing President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia.
China, which is Serbia's largest oil supplier, also faces economic losses from an embargo. But diplomats note that China traditionally goes along with any course of action agreed to by the other four permanent Security Council members -- the United States, Britain, France and Russia.
Officials say it is unclear whether the European Community will be willing to impose a complete trade ban. For one thing Greece, a community member, might suffer from any general embargo because much of its trade with the other 11 members goes by road across Serbia and Montenegro.

HEADLINE: Haitians Still Determined to Get Out

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PETIT-GOAVE, Haiti, May 24

 BODY:
Despite new measures aimed at discouraging Haitians from fleeing, this town's beaches, like the bays and coves elsewhere in the south, are teeming with Haitians determined to leave their country and builders readying boats to carry them.
Citing increasingly heavy repression by the military and the suffocating grip of a hemisphere-wide trade embargo imposed on Haiti last October in the hope of reversing a military coup against the elected President, Haitians said that nothing could dissuade them from leaving. 
 Comments like these were offered hours before President Bush authorized the Coast Guard to start picking up all fleeing Haitians at sea and returning them directly to their country.
But those who had heard of measures adopted last week by the United States to limit the exodus, like pulling Coast Guard ships further from the Haitian coast and rescuing only the refugees whose boats were in imminent danger of sinking, expressed some impatience.
"We don't just want to go to Miami, we want to get out of Haiti," said Gerald Labarre, a 28-year-old unemployed painter, who said beatings at the hands of soldiers and policemen had already twice driven him to set sail from this small town in the hope of reaching another country.
 
'People Beaten and Killed'
 "It doesn't matter where we land," Mr. Labarre said. "Things are not right here. Every day people are being beaten and killed.
Mr. Labarre, whose bruises were still visible around one eye, said his companion from two previous attempts to escape Haiti on a small boat had set out again Saturday. "As for me, I fled once, and they returned me," he said. "I fled a second time and they sent me back. I've got to get out, and as soon as we have enough people for a boat, I'll try again."
Others in this one-street town of dilapidated gingerbread houses and tin-roofed shacks 40 miles southwest of the capital cited the crushing weight of the embargo as their principal reason for fleeing.
Unlike people in the drought-stricken northwest, no one starves here along Haiti's verdant southern peninsula. But for weeks now residents say they have not had enough to eat regularly. And many complain that with the economy virtually shut down by the embargo, they no longer have any work.
"All we can do is sit around and wait for change or leave," said Pauline Jean-Baptiste, one of a handful of women who stopped to talk with a visitor on the shores of a small cove where four boats were being readied for the journey toward the United States. Asked how many of them hoped to get aboard the boats, the women shouted in unison, "We all do!"
Like others, Miss Jean-Baptiste said the measures taken by the United States, including the decision on Thursday to stop only the most unseaworthy boats leaving Haiti, would have no effect on her calculations. For these people, the only driving concern is how to get out.
Despite the vigilance of the Coast Guard, which has picked up more than 30,000 Haitians at sea since October and returned most of them to their country, Haitian builders were busily completing dozens of boats, both large and small, for yet more risky voyages in bay after bay along this coast.
People who have made repeated efforts to reach the United States only to be returned said that so many boats were becoming available that the price of the trip had declined. At the start of the Haitian refugee crisis last fall, prospective passengers said they were being asked as much as $500 a seat , a huge amount of money in the hemisphere's poorest country.
 
Fare Now Around $100
 Interviews with travelers today suggested that the common fare is now hovering between $100 and $150.
"There are literally hundreds of boats out there all over the country now just waiting to be launched," a diplomat who has access to reconnaissance information said. "We have spotted one on La Gonave that is being called Noah's Ark. Its hold is as least 40 feet deep. And it appears to be as long as the village where it is being built."
La Gonave is a Haitian island off of the main body of Hispaniola that has long been a staging point for boat trips toward the United States.
In one cove after another, and in parishes and on street corners, Haitians openly shared their motivations -- typically a mixture of crushing hardship and terror -- for wanting desperately to leave.
 
Military Repression Cited
 The Rev. Jean Woudy Louis, a Roman Catholic priest in Petit-Goave, sees brutal military repression of suspected supporters of the overthrown President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, as been the main factor.
"There are roundups all the time, and young men are either forced to go underground or set out to sea to survive," Father Louis said. "Even possessing the picture of Aristide can get you in trouble. Here at our church we have even been threatened by the soldiers."
"We are living in a permanent, unofficial curfew," said Lionel Jocelyn, a 35-year-old unemployed seaman in Petit-Goave who also hoped to find a boat out of the country. "Every night there is a blackout here. The police tell us to stay out of the streets. Meanwhile there are armed bandits who circulate freely committing organized robberies."
Though the signs of repression are multiplying, many other Haitians said it was first and foremost economic misery that had tempted them to leave their homeland.
 
Prices Increase Rapidly
 Coffee and mangos sit stockpiled or spoiling because the embargo has closed off export markets. The price of peasant livestock, another important source of income, has plummeted because of a lack of feed. Meanwhile, prices for transportation, kerosene, cooking oil, milk and many other basic consumer items have increased rapidly, making even a rudimentary living unaffordable for many.
"Prices have gone up so much that people who could normally afford to buy their food are now in trouble," said Virginia Ubick, director of the aid group Care in Haiti, which is feeding more than 300,000 people a day. "They have rice and beans in smaller portions, forget meat, and they just stretch things out as far as they can."
Although admirers of Father Aristide boldly proclaimed their support for the embargo until recently, conditions have deteriorated to the extent that many people are now publicly pleading that it be lifted.
"It's the embargo that has done this to us," said a visibly angry woman in Petit-Goave, pointing to a small child on her lap who she said was hungry. "If you don't lift the embargo soon, we are all going to leave this country. You'll see."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Senate Races;
Women's Issues Draw Attention In Two Contests

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 23

 BODY:
Californians will elect two United States Senators this year, and increasingly it appears that one, possibly both, will be a woman.
There are only two women in the 100-member Senate -- Barbara A. Mikulski, a Maryland Democrat, and Nancy Landon Kassebaum, a Kansas Republican. But if the latest statewide polls here are on the mark as the June 2 Democratic and Republican primaries draw near, Dianne Feinstein, a Democrat and former Mayor of San Francisco, is well on her way to becoming a Senator. 
 At the same time, the polls indicate that Representative Barbara Boxer, a Democrat from Marin County, outside San Francisco, also has a solid shot at becoming a Senator, though her political strength at this point does not equal that of Ms. Feinstein.
The racial violence in Los Angeles has become the most important factor in the two Senate contests. Candidates are arguing bitterly over the causes and cures and pouring in huge amounts of television money in an effort to make their cases and grab the attention of a bored, cynical electorate that knows few of them by name other than Ms. Feinstein.
 
Importance of Women's Issues
 But though racial violence, along with California's faltering economy, are the dominant issues in the two contests, both Ms. Feinstein and Ms. Boxer are being closely watched for indications of where women and women's issues are headed in national politics in the aftermath of several major rape trials, developments in the abortion rights debate and the Senate's widely publicized hearings on sexual harassment.
And because the elections are taking place in California, the nation's most populous state and often its political cutting edge, the importance of women's issues is increased.
Earlier this year, in Democratic senatorial primaries in Illinois and Pennsylvania, little-known female candidates pulled off major upsets. In both of those states, women's issues were major campaign factors, just as they are here.
"Whatever else 1992 is, it's the 'Year of the Woman' when it comes to politics," Ms. Feinstein says repeatedly as she tours the state. "Two percent may be good for fat in milk but it's bad for women in the United States Senate."
 
Hoping to Replace Wilson
 Ms. Feinstein is one of six candidates -- three Democrats and three Republicans -- running in a special election to fill the remaining two years of Pete Wilson's term. Mr. Wilson was elected Governor in 1990 and appointed John Seymour, a fellow Republican, to fill his seat until a special election was held.
Mr. Seymour, a former State Senator, appears likely to win the Republican nomination.
In the other race, for a full term, Ms. Boxer is one of six candidates seeking to replace Alan Cranston, a Democrat who is retiring after four terms. There are also three Democrats and three Republicans in this contest. Like Ms. Feinstein, Ms. Boxer is the only woman in her race.
Though the contest for Mr. Cranston's seat is at first glance the more important, since it involves a full Senate term, it is a political muddle at this point, with the outcome of both primaries in doubt.
 
Clear Leaders in Race
 By contrast, the contest for Mr. Wilson's old seat appears to have sorted itself out for the most part.
True, some of the television advertising provocatively promotes a law-and-order theme by featuring scenes of violence from the Los Angeles riots. True, the latest anti-abortion commercial includes pictures of an abortion in progress.
And this is not inexpensive stuff, not at $10,000 or more for a 30-second advertisement, with some of the candidates planning to spend more than a million dollars on television advertising over the next 10 days.
But despite such costly, hard-edged campaigning, polls published in the last two weeks showed little has changed since surveys of a month or so ago.
According to the new surveys, Ms. Feinstein, a moderate, is headed for an easy victory in the Democratic race, in which her two opponents are State Controller Gray Davis, a liberal, and Joseph M. Alioto, a lawyer and son of a former San Francisco Mayor. She leads Mr. Davis by a 2 to 1 margin and Mr. Alioto by a margin of 8 to 1.
Trying to catch up, Mr. Davis took an uncharacteristic turn to the political right this week by broadcasting one of the law-and-order advertisements about the Los Angeles violence, prompting Ms. Feinstein to accuse him of "pandering."
Mr. Davis countered that Ms. Feinstein was "unelectable" because state authorities were investigating her handling of money in previous campaigns. The recent polls disagreed, indicating she would win handily in a two-person race with Mr. Seymour in the fall.
In the Republican primary, the new polls showed Mr. Seymour, a moderate, holding a comfortable lead over his closest opponent, Rep. William E. Dannemeyer, a conservative from Fullerton, and over his other opponent, William Barclay Allen, a conservative who was a chairman of the Federal Civil Rights Commission and is the only black running for either Senate seat.
Mr. Allen has recently drawn more notice because of his anti-abortion advertisement, which he said he intended to "advance public understanding" for the need to stop abortions.
Mr. Seymour stuck with the racial violence issue, urging legislation that would provide Federal aid to clean up and restore the part of Los Angeles destroyed by rioting. Mr. Allen and Mr. Dannemeyer opposed such help, saying it would "reward" lawlessness.
 
Feinstein on Women
 In emphasizing women's issues, Ms. Feinstein mostly speaks generally, leveling few anti-women charges at her opponents.
Polls indicate her positions attract more votes from women than from men, but she nevertheless has strong support among men.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Finances;
Lobbyists Favor Senator By Financing Son's Race

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23

 BODY:
Tens of thousands of dollars of political donations are pouring in to Bennett Johnston from lobbyists for the energy, pipeline, utilities and nuclear power industries, according to reports at the Federal Election Commission.
That would not be surprising if the donations were to Senator J. Bennett Johnston, the chairman of the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee, who has solicited and received political donations from these groups for years. But Senator Johnston, a Louisiana Democrat, is not up for re-election this year. 
 The donations are going instead to his 32-year-old son, J. Bennett Johnston 3d, who is running for Congress from Marin County, Calif. With the enthusiastic help of his father, the younger Mr. Johnston has so far raised a handsome campaign fund of $324,000, outpacing all his opponents.
 
Senator Pushes Son
 Much of it is from lobbyists in Washington who have business before his father's committee. The senior Mr. Johnston has herded many of these lobbyists into his office or to lunches with his son. In those meetings, Senator Johnston said, he has strongly urged them to support his son's candidacy.
Almost all of them have obliged.
Some of the lobbyists, who refused to be quoted by name, said they were giving to the younger Mr. Johnston's Congressional campaign to keep on the good side of the Senator. And therein lies an irony: the younger Mr. Johnston is an ardent environmental advocate who strongly disagrees with many of his father's views about the industries that are rushing to support his candidacy.
Mr. Johnston is the national director of land conservation for the Trust for Public Land, a not-for-profit organization that tries to acquire and preserve open spaces. He opposes offshore drilling and exploration for oil in the Arctic, positions supported by his father. He also strongly favors abortion rights, while his father takes the opposite view.
 
Addressed Environmental Rally
 Daniel F. Becker, a lawyer who works on energy matters in Washington for the Sierra Club, said that when his organization held a rally last summer in San Francisco to denounce an energy bill sponsored by Senator Johnston, the younger Mr. Johnston appeared and asked to be allowed to address the crowd.
"It was quite amazing," Mr. Becker recalled. "He took the microphone and said, 'Dad, I love you, but it's time we stopped this kind of special-interest legislation.' "
Among the donors to Mr. Johnston's campaign are the Alabama Power Company Employees Political Action Committee; Arkla, a pipeline company, and Southern Nuclear Operating Company Employees PAC.
Also giving to the younger Mr. Johnston are a slew of lobbying organizations representing other industries and professions.
The younger Mr. Johnston, who is one of nine candidates seeking the Democratic nomination in California's Sixth District in the June 2 primary, said in an interview that people give to candidates for many reasons.
"There are people who are contributing to my campaign who have met me through my father," he said. "But the suggestion that they are doing so to gain influence with my father is nonsense."
 
Refuses Oil Money
 He said he has refused to accept certain kinds of contributions, notably those from oil companies and weapon manufacturers. A donation from the Occidental Petroleum Company listed on his campaign records is a mistake, he said, probably a result of a mix-up between his and his father's political committees.
Mr. Johnston cheerfully acknowledges his differences with his father.
"I'm an intense environmentalist," he said. "That's my principal identity." His father's principal identity, on the other hand, is as an advocate of the energy industry, which plays a major role in Louisiana's economy.
Senator Johnston said it was unfair of environmentalists to characterize him as "the Darth Vader of the environment," but he acknowledged profound policy differences with his son.
 
Distasteful but Necessary
 Asked about the fund-raising, Senator Johnston said, "It's certainly true that I'm helping him as much as I can with my friends." He characterized the business of raising campaign money as distasteful but necessary.
Father and son share the same principal fund-raiser, Cheryl Shelby. When Ms. Shelby is not raising money for the Johnstons, she is an aide on Senator Johnston's staff.
Mr. Becker of the Sierra Club said there was little mystery about why many of the lobbyists donated to the younger Johnston's campaign. "Every piece of energy legislation is either written by or has to pass through Bennett Johnston," he said. "If he asks you for a donation to his son, you give it."
Michael Hogan, the director of the PAC for the American Chiropractors Association, which gave the maximum $5,000 donation to Mr. Johnston, said he did so after being invited to lunch by the Senator to meet his son. Also invited to that lunch was a lobbyist for the concrete industry.
Lobbyists for the insurance, health and energy industries said they, too, had been invited to Senator Johnston's office in the Capitol to meet his son. One who spoke only on the condition of anonymity said Senator Johnston asked for support for his son. When the Senator disclosed that his son worked as an environmental advocate, the lobbyist said, one representative of an energy group "looked as if he'd been whacked in the head."

LENGTH: 1200 words

HEADLINE: Las Vegas's Hopes Leave Blacks Bitter

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, May 22

 BODY:
When gambling boomed in the 1980's, this flamboyant city dangled the promise of thousands of jobs for those without college diplomas or special skills, as factory towns once did, but with a lot more glitter.
If any place in America could lend hope to the jobless of its inner city, it seemed to be Las Vegas, which led the nation in job and population growth through the decade. 
 But as casinos and the sun nurtured handsome new subdivisions on every edge of the city, the poor, overwhelmingly black neighborhoods a few miles from The Strip remained mired in decay and hopelessness.
For most Las Vegans, it was a forgotten world -- until the gunshots and fires erupted.
 
Looters and Snipers
 A wave of violence hit the city's black neighborhoods after the April 29 acquittal of four white police officers in the beating in Los Angeles of Rodney G. King, the black motorist. In a handful of troubled nights since the acquittals, looters raided and burned several stores and offices, snipers rained gunfire on intersections, a man suspected of looting a burning building died in the flames and one white motorist was pulled from his car and beaten.
The violence occurred about seven miles from the Strip, and officials emphasize that the city is by and large calm, with no major incidents reported in the last six days. "This in no way, shape or form comes close to what has happened in Los Angeles," Lieut. Charlie Davidaitis said.
But to many residents in a city that thrives on unlimited opportunity, the woes in the midst of plenty underscore a missed chance to heed a desperate call.
"Things could be so different here," said the Rev. Jesse Scott, the leader of the local National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. "The potential for our people should be so great in Las Vegas. But we've only gotten just a little bit of the pie. And our people feel hopeless."
 
Isolation in Growth
 After a decade of growth, Las Vegas now has 300,000 residents, 11 percent of them black. But the growth has done little for the section of the city that has historically been black, except to make its name, the West Side, something of a geographic misnomer. The city's sprawling corporate limits now extend much farther to the west.
If anything, the black neighborhoods have become even more isolated, more than 25 blocks bereft of commerce and marked by rows of identical, low-slung, cement-block housing projects, which give it the uniform look of a military base.
The city has grown around the West Side, and the riots only made it worse. Fires destroyed a job training center, a medical center, a black-owned gas station and the local headquarters of the N.A.A.C.P. City officials say the riots caused $6 million in property damage and eliminated more than 200 jobs.
"This has set us back 20 years," said Yvonne Atkinson Gates, a black former school board member who is running for a post on the Clark County Commission. "I stood in my backyard and watched the flames and heard the gunshots. It makes me so angry."
 
Years of Discrimination
 But the anger that fed the riots was fueled by more than despair at not finding a job. Years ago, black people in Las Vegas called the city the "Mississippi of the West" for its racism.
Lured west in the 1930's by the construction of the Hoover Dam and the emergence of the hotel industry, blacks for generations were kept from living anywhere in Las Vegas except the West Side. But today the number of blacks living in more integrated neighborhoods surpasses the number on the West Side, and after the riots, Mr. Scott said, people from all over the city helped clean up the debris.
Still, the acquittal of the Los Angeles police officers had a familiar ring here. A black casino dealer was choked to death by three Las Vegas police officers two years ago, and a jury acquitted them of murder charges last year.
The astonishing rate of growth in Las Vegas has slowed a bit in the last year, as the recession dampened the casino business. Unemployment, which had dipped below 5 percent in 1990, rose to 6.5 percent in March, though it was still under the 7.3 percent national rate. But the economy has started to rebound, and three new casinos, which are scheduled to open next year, will provide 20,000 jobs.
But people on the West Side say the hotel and casino jobs have not been going to black workers. "You go into the hotels and see who's working," said Gene Collins, a former State Assemblyman. "People from Asia, Mexico, South America."
Hotel officials say the work force on The Strip has indeed become much more international in recent years. "At any given casino, there are workers who speak 40 or more languages," said Van Heffner, the president of the Nevada Hotel and Motel Association.
Mr. Heffner said black workers have not been excluded but rather forced to compete with the changing makeup of the job market. The population in Clark County grew by nearly 40 percent in the 1980's, to about 700,000, 9.5 percent of it black. The foreign-born population doubled in that time, and now almost one in every seven people in the Las Vegas area has a native language other than English.
Rosa Mayorga, a 24-year-old immigrant from Guatemala, came to Las Vegas in 1989 for a job as a maid at The Residence Inn. "I make $8 an hour here," said Ms. Mayorga, who was named Employee of the Year last year. "I have television, VCR, telephone. It's very different than Guatemala."
 
Crime Rate Is Low
 Though the city's crime rate remains far below that of other major cities, the police say Los Angeles gangs have established outposts here, leading to 17 gang-related homicides last year, up from 11 the year before.
West Side residents say violence is an everyday fact of life. "There's always someone getting shot," said Bessie Braggs, who runs a food bank on the West Side. "We have bars on our windows, bars on our doors."
As fires burned other buildings in the recent violence, a black-owned restaurant, Chez's, went untouched. But one recent morning only a few customers had ventured inside for breakfast.
"Usually we'd be packed," said Tarisha Hughes, a 24-year-old waitress, whose tips have dwindled since the riots. "But people are afraid to come outside."
Ms. Gates, the county commission candidate, was born to a bricklayer and hotel maid and has lived all of her life on the West Side. Her brother, Eddie, was stabbed to death while he was walking down the street a few weeks before the riots.
"The police have witnesses, but nobody is willing to talk," she said. "These young punks threaten your life if you talk."
The everyday violence has left her son, Brian, too frightened to play outdoors. "He's 9 years old, and he's too scared to play outside," she said, shaking her head.
Her husband, Lee Gates, is a district judge, and they can afford to live in the safest, most prosperous neighborhood in town. But she said she would stay on the West Side.
"If I left, people would say I'm deserting them," she said. "And they would be right."
She added: "But I take my son to a tutor for Spanish and art classes. I want him to know there is something outside of this world of violence."
